{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"The ECB says it will scale back its bond buying faster than planned, as Russia's war on Ukraine is a 'watershed moment for Europe'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ecb-taper-bond-buying-interest-rate-russia-ukraine-watershed-inflation-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622a0a647eb82f00180e4daf?format=jpeg\" height=\"2667\" width=\"3557\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Christine Lagarde European Central Bank ECB\"/><figcaption>Christine Lagarde is president of the European Central Bank.<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Lohnes/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The ECB said Thursday it will move faster on scaling back the size of its monthly bond buying.</li>\n<li>The central bank plans to end its asset buying in the 3rd quarter, but will revise that depending on inflation.</li>\n<li>It said the Russia-Ukraine conflict is a &#39;watershed&#39; for Europe, as it held interest rates steady.</li>\n</ul><p>The European Central Bank said Thursday it will move faster on scaling back its monthly asset purchases, as it takes into account the uncertainty caused by Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>In a surprise move, the ECB revised its taper schedule and said it may end its bond buying in the third quarter. However, it said it will keep assessing inflation data and will adjust its plans if required.</p><p>&#34;A faster winding-down of the asset purchase program will perhaps come as a surprise to market participants who expected an ECB capitulation in the face of weaker growth forecasts,&#34; Seema Shah, chief strategist at Principal Global Investors, said.</p><p>&#34;Yet, with inflation still drastically above their target, it is important that the ECB retains an air of unwavering commitment to price stability,&#34; she added.</p><p>The ECB&#39;s shift was likely influenced by the increased risk of stagflation in the economic fallout from the Russia-Ukraine conflict, some analysts said.</p><p>&#34;The Russian invasion of Ukraine is a watershed for Europe,&#34; the ECB <a href=\"https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/pr/date/2022/html/ecb.mp220310~2d19f8ba60.en.html\">said in a statement</a>, promising to implement the sanctions decided by the EU and regional government.</p><p>Sanctions imposed by the West on Russia have added to fears of disruption to supply from the country, a major producer of oil, gas, nickel and other commodities</p><p>Commodity prices have soared since Russia attacked Ukraine two weeks ago, with the likelihood the rises will feed through into higher prices for consumers. That has brought warnings from analysts about the risk of stagflation &#8212; where stagnant economic growth is combined with rampant inflation.</p><p>The ECB now plans to buy 40 billion euros&#39; worth of assets in April, and then reduce the total by 10 billion euros in both May and June. It had laid out purchases of 40 billion euros a month during the second quarter, then 30 billion euros in the third quarter, and 20 billion euros in the fourth.</p><p>Its new plan could be revised again, depending on the pace of inflation. It rose to 5.8% in February, from 5.1% the previous month, according to data from Eurostat.</p><p>&#34;If the medium-term inflation outlook changes, and if financing conditions become inconsistent with further progress towards our two per cent target, we stand ready to revise our schedule for net asset purchases in terms of size and/or duration,&#34; the central bank said in a statement after its policy meeting.</p><p>The euro was trading at around $1.100 after the decision, down 0.6% on the day, having fallen back from a session high of $1.1121.</p><p>At the ECB meeting, its policymakers kept key interest rates unchanged, saying they would stay at current levels until it sees inflation reaching its 2% target well ahead of its projection horizon.</p><p>&#34;It looks like rates are going nowhere, up or down, any time soon,&#34; Neil Birrell, CIO and fund manager at Premier Miton Investors, said.</p><p>&#34;The only real certainty is that inflation is on the way up and growth is under threat &#8212; it must even be worried about financial stability, so caution and flexibility are the watchwords.&#34;</p><p><em><strong>Read more: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/oil-price-surge-inflation-commodity-rally-sanctions-strategy-demand-destruction-2022-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" aria-describedby=\"sk-tooltip-16230\">&#39;It&#39;s like a game of musical chairs&#39;: A hedge-fund strategist explains how to navigate the oil market as the price flirts with a $140 a barrel &#8212; and identifies a price point to monitor to avoid being left &#39;standing when the chair gets pulled&#39;</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Friar)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/622a0a647eb82f00180e4daf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn42@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-05-623_b7812587883aed8c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2nt6SlDMf_w:BZFnL4RpXts:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn97@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-34-811_f97ac11f43cacd8c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2nt6SlDMf_w:BZFnL4RpXts:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-23-967_3920c9a087d3c677.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=2nt6SlDMf_w:BZFnL4RpXts:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn82@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-27-432_851ce921d180cc7a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704382},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Oil prices climb 5% after UAE appears to backtrack on its earlier call for OPEC+ to boost output faster","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/oil-price-today-uae-opec-should-boost-output-faster-production-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229b5c17eb82f00180e46e0?format=jpeg\" height=\"1750\" width=\"3500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"OPEC OPEC+ oil producers oil price\"/><figcaption>The OPEC+ group of oil producing countries abandoned output talks on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Ramzi Boudina/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Oil climbed more than 5% Thursday after the UAE appeared to tone down its message that OPEC+ should boost output.</li>\n<li>&#34;We favor production increases and will be encouraging OPEC to consider higher production levels,&#34; UAE&#39;s ambassador to Washington said Wednesday.</li>\n<li>The UAE reportedly hadn&#39;t consulted other OPEC+ members before making that statement.</li>\n</ul><p>Oil climbed more than 5% on Thursday after OPEC member UAE seemed to back down from an earlier message that it would call on its fellow alliance members to boost crude output faster.</p><p>Oil prices initially fell <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-60680787\">as much as 17%</a> Wednesday after the UAE&#39;s ambassador to Washington, Yousuf Al Otaiba, said the country was supportive of boosting output.</p><p>&#34;We favor production increases and will be encouraging OPEC to consider higher production levels,&#34; Al Otaiba said in a <a href=\"https://www.uae-embassy.org/news/statement-ambassador-yousef-al-otaiba\">statement</a> posted by the embassy.</p><p>But just hours later, UAE energy minister Suhail Al-Mazrouei appeared to tone down that message on Twitter, saying the country stands with the OPEC+ agreement that&#39;s already in place.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The UAE is committed to the OPEC+ agreement and its existing monthly production adjustment mechanism,&#34; he <a href=\"https://twitter.com/HESuhail/status/1501683226884321283?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">said in a tweet</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price?type=brent\">Brent crude futures</a> were last at $114.58 a barrel, after earlier rising 5.4% at $117.19 a barrel. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price?type=wti\">West Texas Intermediate</a> was last at $110.87, after rising 3.7% to $112.80 a barrel.</p><p>Oil recovered losses from its dramatic dip Wednesday that came after multiple daily upward runs since Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine began, sparking fears of disruption.</p><p>But a calm of sorts descended after UAE said it was minded to encourage other members to pump more oil to relieve the super-high prices, and provide more stability to the global economy, Susannah Streeter, markets analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said.</p><p>US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken <a href=\"https://www.state.gov/secretary-antony-j-blinken-and-uk-foreign-secretary-elizabeth-truss-at-a-joint-press-availability/\">welcomed the move</a>, saying it&#39;s &#34;an important thing to stabilize global energy markets, to make sure that there remains an abundant supply of energy around the world.&#34;</p><p>President Joe Biden has pointed out that oil and gas companies are profiting off soaring energy prices, and has pledged to take <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-russia-war-biden-economy-sanctions-inflation-2022-2\">active steps to bring down the cost</a>. He announced a ban on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-us-ban-russian-oil-natural-gas-coal-imports-report-2022-3\">Russian oil imports</a> Tuesday, but acknowledged that not every European country would join in a blanket ban.</p><h3>Possible tension within OPEC+</h3><p>The UAE hadn&#39;t discussed the matter with other alliance members before making Wednesday&#39;s statement, <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-09/opec-member-the-uae-says-group-should-boost-oil-output-faster\">Bloomberg reported</a>, citing a source.</p><p>It&#39;s more than likely that the UAE ambassador&#39;s proposal would have sparked tensions, because the wider alliance has indicated it doesn&#39;t want to boost output any faster. At its last meeting lasting just 13 minutes earlier this month, OPEC members <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/commodities/oil-price-russia-ukraine-biden-energy-sanctions-opec-output-plan-2022-3\">decided to stick to their plan</a>&#160;to add 400,000 barrels of crude oil production in April.&#160;</p><p>They made no mention of Russia&#39;s war in Ukraine, a key driver behind recent skyrocketing oil prices.&#160;</p><p>Iraq&#39;s energy minister Ihsan Abdul Jabbar told Bloomberg in a Wednesday interview that extra releases could hurt the oil market.</p><p>&#34;We think that the increases that OPEC+ has are enough to meet demand,&#34; he said. &#34;Additional releases could actually harm the market.&#34;</p><p>Any proposal by OPEC to increase production could be seen as a way to help Western countries in their efforts to reduce reliance on Russian oil.</p><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin told Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/ukraine-crisis-russia-saudi-idINR4N2UZ08A\">in a call last week</a> that the politicization of global energy supplies was unacceptable. They agreed both countries would coordinate efforts within the OPEC+ deal framework.</p><p>OPEC meets again on March 31.</p><p><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><strong>Read More:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-markets-oil-commodities-crisis-ukraine-goldman-sachs-economist-2022-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-markets-oil-commodities-crisis-ukraine-goldman-sachs-economist-2022-3\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">Goldman Sachs&#39; renowned chief economist lays out what Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine will mean for global oil prices, the stock market, an &#39;overheating US economy&#39; and Federal Reserve rate rises</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"McDonald's says restaurant closures in Russia will cost the chain $50 million a month","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-say-russia-closures-will-cost-50-million-per-month-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/540067cfeab8ea315166901f?format=jpeg\" height=\"2390\" width=\"3187\" charset=\"\" alt=\"mcdonald&#39;s russia\"/><figcaption>A man walks past a McDonald&#39;s in Moscow.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Maxim Zmeyev</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>McDonald&#39;s estimates that its store closures in Russia will cost the company $50 million per month.</li>\n<li>The fast-food giant is continuing to pay the wages of its 62,000 workers in Russia.&#160;</li>\n<li>It has nearly 850 restaurants in Russia, most of which are owned by the company.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>McDonald&#39;s said its&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-mcdonalds-long-queues-rush-moscow-one-last-meal-2022-3#:~:text=A%20day%20earlier%2C%20McDonald&#39;s%20CEO,following%20Russia&#39;s%20invasion%20of%20Ukraine.\">restaurant closures</a> in Russia will cost the company millions of dollars.</p><p>Speaking at a UBS consumer and retail conference on Wednesday, and reported by <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/09/mcdonalds-russian-shutdown-will-cost-fast-food-chain-50-million-a-month.html\">CNBC</a>, CFO Kevin Ozan said that while McDonald&#39;s is still evaluating the full impact on the business, it estimates that the closure of its nearly 850 restaurants in Russia will cost the chain around $50 million per month.&#160;</p><p>The fast-food giant had come under intense <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-pepsico-face-boycott-halt-business-russia-ukraine-invasion-2022-3\">pressure to act</a> in response to Moscow&#39;s decision to invade Ukraine, and announced <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-closing-russia-locations-during-conflict-2022-3\">Tuesday</a> that it would temporarily close doors in Russia<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-pepsico-face-boycott-halt-business-russia-ukraine-invasion-2022-3\"></a>. Some of its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/list-all-the-companies-pulling-out-of-russia-ukraine-war-2022-3#46-kfc-46\">leading competitors in the food and beverage space</a>, including Yum Brands-owned KFC, followed suit shortly after.</p><p>McDonald&#39;s has promised to continue paying the wages of the 62,000 workers it employs in Russia while its stores remain shuttered. Ozan also said at the UBS conference that the company will continue to pay the leases for its shuttered stores, along with other supply chain costs, per CNBC.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We expect this to be temporary and we certainly don&#39;t take this decision lightly, but for us this is about doing what we think is the right thing to do, both for the global business and for our people locally,&#34; he said.</p><p>McDonald&#39;s did not immediately reply to a request for comment from Insider made outside normal US operating hours.&#160;</p><p>While most of the other US food chains in Russia are run by franchisees, McDonald&#39;s owns and operates the majority of its 847 restaurants there. The company said that its business in Russia and Ukraine accounts for around <a href=\"https://corporate.mcdonalds.com/content/dam/gwscorp/assets/investors/financial-information/Supplemental-Information/Russia%20and%20Ukraine%20Supplemental%20Schedule.pdf\">9%</a> of the company&#39;s worldwide revenue.&#160;</p><p>More global brands are choosing to exit Russia as the conflict in Ukraine intensifies. However, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-invastion-war-sanctions-corporate-response-companies-not-leaving-2022-3#1-uniqlo-1\">several</a> are resisting, despite boycott threats from customers.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/540067cfeab8ea315166901f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7e975b169bdb6a93694da3b38c432eff","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn51@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-05-632_9bc01b3dcdd503cb.webp","destWidth":3187,"destHeight":2390,"sourceBytes":491312,"destBytes":491312,"author":"insider@insider.com (Mary Hanbury)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/540067cfeab8ea315166901f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn51@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-05-632_9bc01b3dcdd503cb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=yt1HOsQmt04:Ngy_q_menw0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn41@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-29-438_34cc4de4a5a24edb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=yt1HOsQmt04:Ngy_q_menw0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn32@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-831_9ac8920c318e2d42.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=yt1HOsQmt04:Ngy_q_menw0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn31@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-35-765_61dc67d635094ce9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704330},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"The world's first Airbus A319neo just took its maiden flight, but the jet has already been losing out to the planemaker's more popular A220","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-worlds-first-a319neo-passenger-flight-china-southern-airbus-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622966516ec7c20019cd6df0?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"China Southern Airlines A319neo delivery.\"/><figcaption>China Southern Airlines A319neo delivery.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The world&#39;s first Airbus A319neo just took its maiden flight with China Southern Airlines on Tuesday.</li>\n<li>The jet has lagged behind the planemaker&#39;s other narrowbodies, particularly due to the success of the similar A220-300.</li>\n<li>Both the A319neo and A220 serve regional and short-haul routes and have comparable range and capacity.</li>\n</ul><div id=\"slideshow\"><div class=\"slide\">Airbus&#39; best-selling A320 narrowbody entered the market in 1984 to compete with Boeing&#39;s popular 737 jets that were dominating the industry.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62291ab19fa32d00184c9c09?format=jpeg\" height=\"735\" width=\"979\" charset=\"\" alt=\"First A320.\"/><figcaption>First A320.<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-a320-history-boeing-737-rival-2018-9\">The amazing story of how the Airbus A320 became the Boeing 737&#39;s greatest rival</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The plane gained popularity quickly, becoming a workhorse for airlines worldwide. The success prompted Airbus to manufacture additional variants, including the stretched A321 and the shorter A319 and A318 models.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6138fbe82534ab0018535db3?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Alitalia Airbus A319\"/><figcaption>Alitalia Airbus A319.<p class=\"copyright\">Wirestock Creators/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-a320-history-boeing-737-rival-2018-9\">Insider</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Over the decades, the industry has worked towards creating more fuel-efficient aircraft to lower costs for airlines and reduce CO2 emissions.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61da3070607df100189c4a1b?format=jpeg\" height=\"745\" width=\"993\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Airplane flying over trees.\"/><figcaption>Airplane flying over trees.<p class=\"copyright\">Gergitek Gergi tavan/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airbus-a320-history-boeing-737-rival-2018-9\">Insider</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">While some manufacturers made complex changes to their narrowbodies to meet demand, like Boeing&#39;s 737 MAX, Airbus&#39; solution was to fit its current models with an upgraded engine.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622918889fa32d00184c9bb4?format=jpeg\" height=\"2670\" width=\"3561\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ryanair Boeing 737 Max\"/><figcaption>A Ryanair Boeing 737 MAX.<p class=\"copyright\">Croatorum / Shutterstock.com</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a320neo\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The program is known as NEO, or &#34;new engine option,&#34; and helped the planemaker maintain its narrowbodies as the world&#39;s &#34;most advanced and fuel-efficient single-aisle aircraft family.&#34;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61e08ff3c5e27c00185b7bb4?format=jpeg\" height=\"695\" width=\"927\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Airbus A320.\"/><figcaption>Airbus A320.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a320neo\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Airbus has three NEO versions in its fleet, including the A319neo, the A320neo, and the A321neo. These aircraft are successors to the company&#39;s original A320 family variants, now known as &#34;CEO,&#34; or current engine option.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62291b937eb82f00180e3b25?format=jpeg\" height=\"2066\" width=\"2755\" charset=\"\" alt=\"VivaAerobus Airbus A320neo\"/><figcaption>A VivaAerobus Airbus A320neo.<p class=\"copyright\">AaronP/Bauer-Griffin/GC Images</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a320neo\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The two engine choices available to customers include Pratt &#38; Whitney&#39;s PurePower PW1100G-JM geared turbofan…<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62291b159fa32d00184c9c1b?format=jpeg\" height=\"396\" width=\"528\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Pratt &#38; Whitney&#39;s PW1100G-JM Engine.\"/><figcaption>Pratt &#38; Whitney&#39;s PW1100G-JM Engine.<p class=\"copyright\">Pratt &#38; Whitney</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a320neo\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">…and CFM International&#39;s LEAP-1A.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62291b4a9fa32d00184c9c27?format=jpeg\" height=\"2827\" width=\"3769\" charset=\"\" alt=\"LEAP-1A engine, developed by CFM\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">REMY GABALDA/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a320neo\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Two of the upgraded planes have done well in the market, with the A320neo and A321neo racking up 3,752 and 4,037 orders as of December 2021, respectively.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6203e7773b86990018b2882e?format=jpeg\" height=\"684\" width=\"912\" charset=\"\" alt=\"JetBlue A321neo.\"/><figcaption>JetBlue A321neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Business Wire</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/products-services/commercial-aircraft/market/orders-and-deliveries\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">However, the A319neo, which is the smallest model, has significantly underperformed, despite the original A319 being a big success with 1,488 orders as of November 2021.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62291dfb7eb82f00180e3bda?format=jpeg\" height=\"483\" width=\"644\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A319neo.\"/><figcaption>A319neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/products-services/commercial-aircraft/market/orders-and-deliveries\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The A319neo took its maiden flight in 2017 and was ready to enter service in the first half of 2019. However, the plane has only accrued 70 orders to date.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62291e939fa32d00184c9d08?format=jpeg\" height=\"624\" width=\"832\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A319neo.\"/><figcaption>A319neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/products-services/commercial-aircraft/market/orders-and-deliveries\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">This is due to the rise in popularity of the planemaker&#39;s A220-300 plane, which first entered commercial service in 2016.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61e09112dbf4c6001931e9e6?format=jpeg\" height=\"2635\" width=\"3513\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Airbus A220\"/><figcaption>Airbus A220<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flying-on-jetblue-airways-brand-new-airbus-a220-photos-review-2021-6\">I flew on JetBlue&#39;s brand-new Airbus A220 and saw why it&#39;s the perfect plane to lead the airline into its next era</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Several airlines worldwide have ordered the massively successful jet that has garnered over 600 orders to date, like Delta Air Lines…<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622923837eb82f00180e3e76?format=jpeg\" height=\"768\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Delta A220.\"/><figcaption>Delta A220.<p class=\"copyright\">Benjamin Zhang/Business Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/products-services/commercial-aircraft/market/orders-and-deliveries\">Airbus</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flying-on-delta-air-lines-new-airbus-a220-300-photos-2021-3\">I flew on Delta&#39;s newest jet, the controversial Airbus A220-300, and it&#39;s my new favorite airliner in the US</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">…Breeze Airways…<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62279ed7913301001822dbd5?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Breeze Airways A220-300 aircraft.\"/><figcaption>Breeze Airways A220-300 aircraft.<p class=\"copyright\">Breeze Airways/Business Wire</p></figcaption></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/breeze-adds-35-new-routes-10-new-cities-transcontinental-a220-2022-3\">Upstart airline Breeze will fly coast-to-coast using its brand-new Airbus A220 jets in a 35-route expansion&#8212; see the full list of new destinations</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">…SWISS...<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622924b86ec7c20019cd67e6?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"SWISS A220.\"/><figcaption>SWISS A220.<p class=\"copyright\">Markus Mainka/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://blog.swiss.com/en/2021/05/a220-swiss-pilot-tina-schwabe-an-aircraft-delivery-is-a-very-special-experience/\">SWISS</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">…and AirBaltic.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622924796ec7c20019cd67c6?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"AirBaltic A220.\"/><figcaption>AirBaltic A220.<p class=\"copyright\">Karolis Kavolelis/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/r-air-baltic-ceo-says-on-track-for-a220-deliveries-as-delays-ease-2018-9\">Air Baltic CEO says on track for A220 deliveries, as delays ease</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The A319neo&#39;s similarity to the A220 is its biggest downfall. Specifically, both jets cater to regional and short-haul markets and have comparable designs.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622925787eb82f00180e3f35?format=jpeg\" height=\"642\" width=\"856\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A319neo.\"/><figcaption>A319neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a220/a220-300\">Airbus</a>, <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a319neo#:~:text=As%20one%20of%20the%20shorter,highest%20levels%20of%20passenger%20comfort.\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">In terms of capacity, both can carry up to 160 passengers in a multi-class configuration.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622925c27eb82f00180e3f81?format=jpeg\" height=\"723\" width=\"964\" charset=\"\" alt=\"AirBaltic A220 cabin.\"/><figcaption>AirBaltic A220 cabin.<p class=\"copyright\">Karlis Dambrans/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a220/a220-300\">Airbus</a>, <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a319neo#:~:text=As%20one%20of%20the%20shorter,highest%20levels%20of%20passenger%20comfort.\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">As far as range, the A319neo can fly up to 6,850&#160;kilometers (4,256 miles), while the A220 is close behind with a maximum range of 6,297&#160;kilometers (3,912 miles).<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229262d6ec7c20019cd68a6?format=jpeg\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\" alt=\"JetBlue Airways Airbus A220-300 Flight\"/><figcaption>Flying on a JetBlue Airways Airbus A220-300.<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a220/a220-300\">Airbus</a>, <a href=\"https://aircraft.airbus.com/en/aircraft/a320/a319neo#:~:text=As%20one%20of%20the%20shorter,highest%20levels%20of%20passenger%20comfort.\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Despite the similarities, the A220 has pulled ahead of the A319neo with its comfortable cabin, impressive efficiency and capacity, and overall lower operating costs.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622926427eb82f00180e3fc7?format=jpeg\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"JetBlue Airways Airbus A220-300 Flight\"/><figcaption>Flying on a JetBlue Airways Airbus A220-300.<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Pallini/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/products-services/commercial-aircraft/market/orders-and-deliveries\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">However, there are still going to be rare glimpses of A319neos flying the skies.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229268c7eb82f00180e3ff9?format=jpeg\" height=\"704\" width=\"939\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Airbus flight crew standing in from of an A319neo.\"/><figcaption>Airbus flight crew standing in from of an A319neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/boeing-787-10-dreamliner-airbus-a319neo-first-flight-2017-3\">Airbus and Boeing debuted new jets on the same day</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">On Tuesday, the world&#39;s first A319neo flew its maiden passenger flight with China Southern Airlines from Guangzhou to Chengdu.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62296b3d6ec7c20019cd6e15?format=jpeg\" height=\"768\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"China Southern&#39;s first A319neo flight.\"/><figcaption>China Southern&#39;s first A319neo flight.<p class=\"copyright\">FATIII Aviation</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/FATIIIAviation/status/1501367121678266370\">FATIII Aviation</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">China Southern received both of its A319neos in a double delivery in February, making it the first operator of the jet.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229277e7eb82f00180e403a?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"China Southern Airlines A319neo.\"/><figcaption>China Southern Airlines A319neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CSAIRGlobal/status/1495277035597537281\">China Southern Airlines</a>, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/FATIIIAviation/status/1501367121678266370\">FATIII Aviation</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">According to FATIII Aviation, a Chinese content creator who was on the first flight, the airline&#39;s plane features a three-cabin layout with 136 seats, including first class, premium economy, and regular economy.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622965ef6ec7c20019cd6de0?format=jpeg\" height=\"577\" width=\"768\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Onboard the first A319neo passenger flight.\"/><figcaption>Onboard the first A319neo passenger flight.<p class=\"copyright\">FATIII Aviation</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://twitter.com/FATIIIAviation/status/1501367121678266370\">FATIII Aviation</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Only two other carriers have ordered the passenger jet, including Spirit Airlines...<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61a8f9e85d47cc0018e902f3?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Spirit Airlines A319 aircraft.\"/><figcaption>Spirit Airlines A319ceo aircraft.<p class=\"copyright\">Marcus Mainka/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airportspotting.com/airbus-delivers-first-a319neo-airline-orders/\">Airport Spotting</a>, <a href=\"https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2019/10/23/1934429/15631/en/Spirit-Airlines-Announces-Upcoming-Order-of-100-Airbus-A320neo-Family-Aircraft.html\">Spirit Airlines</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">...and Air Côte d&#39;Ivoire, the flag carrier of Ivory Coast, a country in West Africa.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622928656ec7c20019cd695a?format=jpeg\" height=\"654\" width=\"873\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Air Côte d&#39;Ivoire A320neo.\"/><figcaption>Air Côte d&#39;Ivoire A320neo.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airportspotting.com/airbus-delivers-first-a319neo-airline-orders/\">Airport Spotting</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The A319neo may have just entered commercial service, but it has also proven useful for Airbus&#39; sustainability programs.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229290d6ec7c20019cd6983?format=jpeg\" height=\"677\" width=\"902\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A319neo SAF flight.\"/><figcaption>A319neo SAF flight.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/newsroom/stories/2021-10-this-a319neo-is-the-latest-to-test-100-saf\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">In October 2021, a CFM LEAP-1A-powered A319neo took off over Toulouse, France, using 100% sustainable aviation fuel. The flight was &#34;the first in-flight study of a single-aisle aircraft running on unblended SAF.&#34;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622929447eb82f00180e40ce?format=jpeg\" height=\"690\" width=\"920\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Fueling the A319neo for its SAF flight.\"/><figcaption>Fueling the A319neo for its SAF flight.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/newsroom/stories/2021-10-this-a319neo-is-the-latest-to-test-100-saf\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The project will help Airbus collect data on how 100% SAF performs on the ground and in-flight. For the specific test flight, only one engine was run with full SAF, though the planemaker expects to fly the jet with both engines using 100% biofuel in 2022.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622929726ec7c20019cd69aa?format=jpeg\" height=\"707\" width=\"943\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Fueling the A319neo for its SAF flight.\"/><figcaption>Fueling the A319neo for its SAF flight.<p class=\"copyright\">Airbus</p></figcaption></figure><p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.airbus.com/en/newsroom/stories/2021-10-this-a319neo-is-the-latest-to-test-100-saf\">Airbus</a></em></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The news came just a month before United Airlines flew the first-ever passenger flight using 100% SAF. The SAF was supplied by World Energy, North America&#39;s only commercial biofuel producer.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61ba325722d30d0018a08451?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"United Airlines is the first airline in the world to use 100% SAF on a passenger flight.\"/><figcaption>United Airlines is the first airline in the world to use 100% SAF on a passenger flight.<p class=\"copyright\">United Airlines</p></figcaption></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-operates-passenger-flight-with-100-sustainable-aviation-fuel-2021-12\">United Airlines just became the first airline in history to operate a passenger flight using 100% sustainable aviation fuel</a></em></p></div></div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a myreaderx3/cdn64@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-31-890_1d37c025b6da3c7f.webp","https://i.insider.com/622929447eb82f00180e40ce?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn47@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-23-930_c8b58495623dc9bd.webp","https://i.insider.com/622929726ec7c20019cd69aa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn16@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-23-507_ab1d3197ae3eb54b.webp","https://i.insider.com/61ba325722d30d0018a08451?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn7@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-29-145_435d89e150a208da.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UGI0D8mtfRQ:ZO_1jHnUOBs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn70@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-35-864_7e5763b89a11877d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UGI0D8mtfRQ:ZO_1jHnUOBs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-31-607_8683e6b3b6eacf11.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UGI0D8mtfRQ:ZO_1jHnUOBs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn58@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-31-477_88d8e8f055ff1d77.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704399},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Zelenskyy calls on West to show 'courage,' a thinly veiled jab at the US for refusing to help send fighter jets","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-calls-courage-western-leaders-us-refuses-fighter-jets-aid-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229c3587eb82f00180e473a?format=jpeg\" height=\"521\" width=\"1043\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Volodymyr Zelenskyy\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy seen on March 10, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Office of the President of Ukraine</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Zelenskyy called on Western leaders to show &#34;courage&#34; in an address Thursday.</li>\n<li>The day before, the US rejected a plan to get Polish fighter jets to Ukraine via a US air base.&#160;</li>\n<li>Zelenskyy called for either jets or a no-fly zone, both of which allies have already been rejected.</li>\n</ul><p>President Volodymyr Zelenskyy called on Western leaders to recover their &#34;courage&#34; after <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pentagon-rejects-poland-offer-send-jets-us-air-base-ukraine-2022-3\">the US rejected a plan</a> to send Polish fighter jets to help Ukraine combat Russian air power.</p><p>On Tuesday, Poland, a NATO member, offered to send Ukraine MiG-29 jets via the US Air Force&#39;s Ramstein Air Base in Germany.</p><p>However, the Pentagon quickly poured cold water on the idea.</p><p>&#34;It is simply not clear to us that there is a substantive rationale for it,&#34; Pentagon spokesman John Kirby <a href=\"https://twitter.com/PentagonPresSec/status/1501336450012528647\">tweeted</a>.</p><p>&#34;The prospect of fighter jets &#39;at the disposal of the Government of the United States of America&#39; departing from a US/NATO base in Germany to fly into airspace that is contested with Russia over Ukraine raises serious concerns for the entire NATO alliance.&#34;</p><p>In <a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/yevropejci-povinni-posilyuvati-sankciyi-proti-rosiyi-tak-sho-73465\">an address early Thursday</a>, Zelenskyy, who has thanked Poland for the offer, called on the West to step up in helping defend Ukraine from Russia&#39;s aerial attacks.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Together we must return courage to some Western leaders. So that they finally do what they had to do on the first day of the invasion,&#34; he said.</p><p>&#34;Either close the Ukrainian sky from Russian missiles and bombs, or give us fighter jets so that we can do everything ourselves. A pause without a decision has become simply deadly.&#34;</p><p>Zelenskyy has long decried the lack of military action by the West over Russia&#39;s invasion, calling on the US and NATO to impose a no-fly zone over Ukraine.</p><p>Agreeing to a no-fly zone would mean the US and NATO committing to shoot down Russian aircraft that enter Ukrainian airspace, a prospect most Western leaders have been unwilling to contemplate.</p><p>Echoing the Pentagon, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz <a href=\"https://www.dw.com/en/scholz-sending-polish-jets-to-ukraine-via-us-base-in-germany-certainly-not-an-option/a-61060929\">said Wednesday</a> he did not support the proposal to send jets as it won&#39;t help &#34;de-escalate the conflict.&#34;</p><p>Marek Magierowski, Poland&#39;s ambassador to the US,&#160;<a href=\"https://t.co/QtEdek3Tzj\">said</a> he understood the US position that the plan was &#34;too escalatory&#34; and that NATO should &#34;move on.&#34;&#160;</p><p>On Monday, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraines-zelensky-says-he-has-cooled-on-joining-nato-2022-3\">Zelenskyy said he had &#34;cooled down&#34; on Ukraine&#39;s plan to join NATO</a> &#34;after we understood that NATO is not prepared to accept Ukraine.&#34;&#160;</p><p>Though the US has refused to send its military forces into Ukraine, it has supplied equipment and military aid, and bolstered its military presence in neighboring countries.</p><p>On Tuesday, <a href=\"https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/us-sending-2-patriot-missile-batteries-to-poland-statement/2528353\">the US sent two Patriot missile batteries</a> to Poland &#34;to confront any potential threats&#34; to NATO as a result of Russia&#39;s invasion.</p><p>In his address Thursday, Zelenskyy highlighted the stream of what he said were war crimes recently committed by Russia during the first two weeks of the invasion.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Destroyed hospitals. Destroyed schools, churches, houses. And all the people killed. All the children killed,&#34; he said.&#160;</p><p>On Wednesday, three people, including one child, were killed after Russia bombed a maternity hospital in the city of Mariupol, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60675599\">Ukrainian officials said.</a></p><p>&#34;The air bomb on the maternity hospital is the final proof. Proof that the genocide of Ukrainians is taking place,&#34; Zelenskyy said.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Today, we must be united in condemning this war crime of Russia, which reflects all the evil that the invaders brought to our land.&#34;</p><p>The foreign ministers of Ukraine and Russia <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/\">met on Thursday</a> in Turkey, the first high level talks between the counties since the invasion began. In remarks made around the time of publication, Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister said the two countries were no closer arranging a ceasefire.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on Bostock)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229c3587eb82f00180e473a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn53@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-27-133_d2179d503c7db009.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=pUF13qg22uQ:NDkp4p7fDtg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn60@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-28-611_e5b118913f40145b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=pUF13qg22uQ:NDkp4p7fDtg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn56@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-32-071_bcc9d5c26c900ef5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=pUF13qg22uQ:NDkp4p7fDtg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn48@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-26-114_47a369658c4bde26.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704370},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Uniqlo closes its stores in Russia, days after its CEO pledged to keep them open because 'clothing is a necessity of life'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/uniqlo-closes-stores-in-russia-reversing-pledge-to-keep-them-open-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6225ed40dcce010019a700e2?format=jpeg\" height=\"1418\" width=\"1890\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Uniqlo\"/><figcaption>Uniqlo is closing its Russia stores.<p class=\"copyright\">Gavriil Grigorov\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Uniqlo said it will close stores in Russia after previously promising to keep them open.&#160;</li>\n<li>The Japanese chain condemned Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine in a statement Thursday.</li>\n<li>It has 50 stores in Russia.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>Uniqlo is closing its stores in Russia after all.</p><p>Just days after its CEO <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uniqlo-keeps-stores-open-in-russia-zara-hm-pull-out-2022-3\">promised</a> to keep stores open because &#34;clothing is a necessity of life&#34; and &#34;the people of Russia have the same right to live as we do,&#34; the company has backtracked and is suspending operations immediately.&#160;</p><p>In a statement on <a href=\"https://www.fastretailing.com/eng/ir/news/2203101800.html\">Thursday</a>, Uniqlo&#39;s parent company, Fast Retailing, condemned Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine and said that it has become more difficult to do business there because of the conflict.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We have recently faced a number of difficulties, including operational challenges and the worsening of the conflict situation. For this reason, we will temporarily suspend our operations,&#34; the company said.&#160;</p><p>It is becoming increasingly difficult for stores to operate in Russia since most <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/maersk-pauses-russia-shipments-except-food-medical-humanitarian-aid-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"7210704516f1ea8bcecc8429ed0c7870\">major logistics companies</a> have halted shipments to the country. Sanctions also threaten to cripple the economy &#8211; crimping consumer spending &#8211; and make it more difficult to process international financial transactions.</p><p>Uniqlo is among a growing number of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/list-all-the-companies-pulling-out-of-russia-ukraine-war-2022-3\">major global brands</a> that are retreating from Russia as the conflict in Ukraine intensifies. Over the past few days, retail giants such as Starbucks, McDonald&#39;s, KFC have pulled out amid <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-pepsico-face-boycott-halt-business-russia-ukraine-invasion-2022-3\">rising pressure</a> from customers and politicians to do so. Others are still <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-invastion-war-sanctions-corporate-response-companies-not-leaving-2022-3\">resisting</a>, however.&#160;</p><p>Uniqlo has 50 stores in Russia, its largest footprint in any European country. It doesn&#39;t split out its sales numbers for Russia, so it&#39;s not immediately clear how important the market is to the brand. However, data analytics firm Global Data estimates it accounted for 1.3% of total worldwide sales in 2020.</p><p>Analysts told Insider that its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-starbucks-kfc-uniqlo-are-keeping-doors-open-in-russia-2022-3\">original decision to stay open in Russia</a> could have been driven by a motivation to keep its most important and fastest-growing market &#8211; China &#8211; on side. While China has not actively supported Russia&#39;s invasion, it hasn&#39;t condemned it either.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uniqlo-closes-stores-in-russia-reversing-pledge-to-keep-them-open-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6225ed40dcce010019a700e2?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"0b14731e2d7fa8c792023d1ab17eec2b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn56@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-05-545_3a9c913c7addec54.webp","destWidth":1890,"destHeight":1418,"sourceBytes":152060,"destBytes":152060,"author":"insider@insider.com (Mary Hanbury)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6225ed40dcce010019a700e2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn56@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-05-545_3a9c913c7addec54.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dDxYpPhOKRc:uRhxhxrQbMA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn96@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-30-752_f4b5471d9f5e8895.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dDxYpPhOKRc:uRhxhxrQbMA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn89@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-31-818_c845acac89145a14.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=dDxYpPhOKRc:uRhxhxrQbMA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-30-462_a96de83df0b40b42.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704319},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Most people who quit their jobs during the Great Resignation say it was worth it","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/quitting-great-resignation-good-for-workers-pew-survey-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622913be7eb82f00180e38ed?format=jpeg\" height=\"1535\" width=\"2047\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Woman texting on phone walks past large red &#34;now hiring&#34; sign\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">OLIVIER DOULIERY/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Most workers who quit during the Great Resignation say it&#39;s boosted their quality of life, per a new survey.</li>\n<li>Most people found new jobs quickly with better pay, more opportunities, and more flexibility.&#160;</li>\n<li>But benefits remain a sticking point: Less than half say their new job has better benefits.</li>\n</ul><p>It looks like the Great Resignation has turned out pretty well for most workers.&#160;</p><p>That&#39;s according to <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2022/03/09/majority-of-workers-who-quit-a-job-in-2021-cite-low-pay-no-opportunities-for-advancement-feeling-disrespected/\">a new Pew Research Center survey,</a> which asked US adults about their reasons for quitting their jobs, as well as how things worked out for them after they quit. The findings showed that those who voluntarily left their jobs in search of something better generally found it.&#160;</p><p>Pew&#39;s survey of 6,627 non-retired adults, conducted between February 7 and February 13, included 965 people who quit in the last year. People cited several primary reasons for leaving their jobs, including low pay, no opportunities for advancement, and feeling disrespected at work.</p><p>Child care issues and lack of flexibility played a role for many people as well, the survey found.&#160;</p><p>Most of the people who quit said they found another job quickly &#8212; more than half said they&#39;re currently employed full time, and 61% said it was at least somewhat easy to find their new job, according to the survey.&#160;</p><p>And those who quit found a better quality of life as well: 56% said they&#39;re making more money, 53% said they have more opportunities to move up the ladder, 53% said it&#39;s easier to balance their work life and family life, and 50% said their work schedules are more flexible.&#160;</p><p>One sticking point appears to be benefits, according to Pew&#39;s research. Only 42% of people who quit said they have better benefits now and 36% said their benefits situation, which includes things like health insurance and paid time off, is pretty much the same. Nearly a quarter of workers say their benefits are now worse than at their last job.</p><h2>The Great Resignation, one year later</h2><p>The idea of a Great Resignation began percolating in the spring of 2021 and continued throughout the year, with a record <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-many-people-quit-jobs-november-record-high-great-resignation-labor-shortage-2022-1\">4.5 million workers quitting in November alone</a>, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data.&#160;</p><p>In fact, the news of so many people quitting may have even influenced people to quit their own jobs, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/workers-rethinking-jobs-careers-due-to-great-resignation-comparably-survey-2022-2\">Insider reported</a>.&#160;</p><p>The unusually high quit rate has led to a shortage of workers across industries and a rush to fill open positions. On the employment website CareerBuilder, for example, the number of monthly job postings jumped from roughly 1 million in February 2021 to over 1.8 million in February 2022.</p><p>Nursing roles and counselor positions have seen triple-digit percentage increases in the last two years, the company said Wednesday. Other sectors &#8212; like hospitality, retail, and foodservice &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/great-resignation-january-quits-jolts-report-labor-shortage-hiring-walkouts-2022-3\">consistently saw high </a>quit rates&#160;throughout 2021.&#160;</p><p>Pew&#39;s findings align with stories from those who left their jobs in the last year.&#160;An ICU nurse told Insider that working through the pandemic <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/icu-nurse-encourages-others-to-quit-after-pandemic-burnout-2022-1\">led him to quit in search of less stress</a>.&#160;One teacher <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/teacher-turned-plumbing-apprentice-career-switch-pandemic-2022-2\">quit her job after more than a decade in the field</a> to become a plumbing apprentice, telling Insider that teaching remotely wasn&#39;t for her. Childcare workers told Insider they quit <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/childcare-workers-quitting-low-pay-childcare-shortage-2021-10\">in search of better pay</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I think a lot of people are looking to better themselves,&#34; Labor Secretary Marty Walsh <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/3-reasons-everyones-quitting-great-resignation-biden-labor-secretary-2022-1\">previously told Insider</a>. &#34;They&#39;re quitting the job that they&#39;re in, and they&#39;re going to be looking for better-paying jobs and more opportunities.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/quitting-great-resignation-good-for-workers-pew-survey-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Mays)","articleImgCdnMap":{"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6_T1AXvX1w:m1i3juHtaS8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn40@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-24-565_7328638efbf31e0a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6_T1AXvX1w:m1i3juHtaS8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn43@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-26-832_820a16fefeb88dc0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=O6_T1AXvX1w:m1i3juHtaS8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn80@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-23-960_a4f55ee07716208e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704397},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Ukrainian woman killed by Russian shelling with her children was a tech exec who spent her last days helping colleagues evacuate, reports say","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-woman-killed-russian-mortar-tech-firm-report-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622a07b67eb82f00180e4d40?format=jpeg\" height=\"1334\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People fleeing Irpin, Ukraine\"/><figcaption>People fleeing advancing Russian forces file across wooden planks crossing Irpin River below a destroyed bridge in Ukraine, March 9, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Peter/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A Ukrainian woman and her two children were killed by a Russian mortar strike while trying to flee.</li>\n<li>Tetiana Perebyinis worked at the Kyiv office of a tech company that had offices in London and Palo Alto.</li>\n<li>In her final days, Perebyinis was trying to help colleagues get out of the country, her colleague told the NYT.</li>\n</ul><p>A Ukrainian woman who was killed by Russian shelling with her children was a tech executive who spent her last days helping colleagues evacuate, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/09/world/europe/ukraine-family-perebyinis-kyiv.html\">The New York Times</a> reported.</p><p>Tetiana Perebyinis, her two children, Mykyta, 18, and Alisa, 9, and a church volunteer <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-strike-kills-ukrainians-escaping-violence-photo-video-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\">were hit by a Russian mortar strike</a> on Sunday as they tried to escape via a damaged bridge in Irpin, a city northwest of the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, The Times reported.</p><p>The mortar strike&#160;was <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/andriy.dubchak/posts/5230090187014561\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ff82bb0c26091e4bbf8516430f64b22b\">filmed by a freelance journalist</a>. A <a href=\"https://twitter.com/cliffordlevy/status/1500681528732495874?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1500681528732495874%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&#38;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Frussia-strike-kills-ukrainians-escaping-violence-photo-video-2022-3\">graphic picture</a> of the family lying dead on the street after the attack was featured on the front page of The Times on Monday.</p><p>Perebyinis was the chief finance officer at the Kyiv office for SE Ranking, a software company headquartered in London, The Times and <a href=\"https://www.siliconvalley.com/2022/03/08/ukrainian-woman-killed-in-shelling-near-kyiv-identified-as-silicon-valley-tech-firm-accountant/\">SiliconValley.com</a>.</p><p>She was hired in 2016 and was one of the first employees in the Kyiv office, SiliconValley.com reported. The company also has offices in Minsk, Belarus, Moscow, and Palo Alto, California, <a href=\"https://seranking.com/about-us.html\">according to its website.</a></p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229f9377eb82f00180e4c0a?format=jpeg\" height=\"882\" width=\"1764\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian shelling hits fleeing civilians in Irpin, Ukraine\"/><figcaption>Screenshot of a video showing Russian shelling hitting fleeing civilians in Irpin, Ukraine, on March 6, 2022. It was this strike that killed Tetiana Perebyinis.<p class=\"copyright\">Andriy Dubchak/Donbas Frontliner</p></figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/serankingcom/posts/1939963706191795\">In a Monday Facebook post</a>, the company confirmed Perebyinis&#39; death, saying: &#34;There are no words to describe our grief or to mend our pain. But for us, it is crucial to not let Tania and her kids Alise and Nikita remain just statistics.&#34;</p><p>The company had encouraged employees to leave Ukraine after Russia launched its invasion on February 24, even renting rooms for them in Poland, Perebyinis&#39; husband, Serhiy, told The Times.</p><p>Anastasia Avetysian, who worked with Perebyinis at SE Ranking, said the company had also provided emergency funds for employees and that Perebyinis had been busy disbursing them in her final days.</p><p>&#34;Even when she was hiding in the basement, she was optimistic and joking in our group chat that the company would now need to do a special operation to get them out, like &#39;Saving Private Ryan,&#39;&#34; Avetysian told The Times.</p><p>Serhiy Perebyinis told The Times that he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-man-learned-of-familys-death-on-twitter-2022-3\">found out about this family&#39;s death on Twitter</a>. He said he was attending to his sick mother in eastern Ukraine at the time.</p><p>Serhiy Perebyinis told The Times that it was important that his family&#39;s deaths were recorded in photographs.</p><p>&#34;The whole world should know what is happening here,&#34; he said.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Ankel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/622a07b67eb82f00180e4d40?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn21@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-25-238_e285a14f44288b58.webp","https://i.insider.com/6229f9377eb82f00180e4c0a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn64@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-25-875_053018fe09959bae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-jt_IeRSums:UiGBT1XU1CM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn70@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-31-485_5da920758eab2ed9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-jt_IeRSums:UiGBT1XU1CM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn52@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-35-922_5f4e20dd7bdf5ab1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-jt_IeRSums:UiGBT1XU1CM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn42@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-171_e451b3a3084f2b9c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704396},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"10 Things in Tech: Googlers' comp frustration","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/10-things-in-tech-googlers-frustrated-compensation-leaked-survey-2022-3","description":"<p>Howdy. A leaked survey shows Google workers are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-internal-survey-compensation-googlegeist-2022-3\">growing dissatisfied with compensation</a>, and Volkswagen has revealed the electric version of its <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vw-id-buzz-electric-volkswagen-bus-camper-rv-2022-3\">iconic bus.</a></p>\n<p>Let's get to it.</p>\n<hr />\n<p>If<em> this was forwarded to you, </em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/subscription/newsletter/10-things-in-tech\"><em>sign up here</em></a><em>. Download Insider's app – click </em><a href=\"https://apps.apple.com/app/apple-store/id554260576\"><em>here for iOS</em></a><em> and </em><a href=\"https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.freerange360.mpp.businessinsider\"><em>here for Android</em></a><em>.</em></p>\n<hr />\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-internal-survey-compensation-googlegeist-2022-3\"><strong></strong></a></p>\n<figure>\n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-internal-survey-compensation-googlegeist-2022-3\"><strong><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61eb2c4b2b43ff00185e20e6?format=jpeg\" height=\"2050\" width=\"2733\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Google CEO Sundar Pichai speaks during Google I/O 2016 at Shoreline Amphitheatre on May 19, 2016 in Mountain View, California. The annual Google I/O conference is runs through May 20.\" />\n   <figcaption>\n    <p class=\"copyright\">Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</p>\n   </figcaption></strong></a>\n</figure>\n<p><strong>1. A leaked survey shows Googlers are increasingly dissatisfied with compensation. </strong>Insider got a look at the company's internal sentiment survey, called \"Googlegeist,\" and found employees are growing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-internal-survey-compensation-googlegeist-2022-3\">dissatisfied with their total compensation</a>:</p>\n<ul>\n <li aria-level=\"1\">53% of workers responded favorably that their total compensation is competitive compared to that of similar jobs at other companies, down from 63% last year. Meanwhile, 27% responded unfavorably, up from 18% last year.&nbsp;</li>\n <li aria-level=\"1\">60% responded favorably that their total compensation is \"fair and equitable,\" down from 66% last year. 19% responded unfavorably, up from 14% last year.&nbsp;</li>\n <li aria-level=\"1\">Other responses reflected positive changes at the company. More Googlers said their well-being had improved, and that they can detach work from non-work time.&nbsp;</li>\n</ul>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-internal-survey-compensation-googlegeist-2022-3\"><strong>What else we learned from the survey.</strong></a></p>\n<p><strong>Plus: </strong>Search our comprehensive <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/salary-database-google-goldman-amazon-how-much-top-jobs-pay-2021-7?r=salary-hp\">salary database here.</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><u><strong>In other news:</strong></u></p>\n<p><u></u><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/biden-crypto-executive-order-digital-dollar-cbdc-bitcoin-congress-2022-3\"></a></p>\n<figure>\n <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/biden-crypto-executive-order-digital-dollar-cbdc-bitcoin-congress-2022-3\"><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6216feee45889c0019d209c4?format=jpeg\" height=\"3996\" width=\"5328\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Joe Biden\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   U.S. President Joe Biden.\n   <p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n  </figcaption></a>\n</figure>\n<p><strong>2. President Joe Biden signed an executive order on cryptocurrencies. </strong>The executive order outlines six priorities, including protecting consumers, reducing crime risks, and exploring the creation of a digital US dollar. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/biden-crypto-executive-order-digital-dollar-cbdc-bitcoin-congress-2022-3\">What we know about Biden's crypto plans.</a></p>\n<p><strong>3. A virtual assistant who makes $6,000 a month shares how she got her start. </strong>The 32-year-old took a 90-day virtual assistant course online — and now travels to places like Myanmar and Northern Europe while doing copywriting for her clients. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-virtual-assistant-makes-6k-travels-world-remote-work-2022-3\">She explains how she built her career.</a></p>\n<p><strong>4. A crew of former Uber execs created an impromptu supply chain network for Ukraine's volunteer fighters. </strong>Uber alum Andrey Liscovich and a team of volunteers have built an operation running trucks of essential supplies like boots, phones, and portable chargers for volunteer fighters to collect. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-former-uber-execs-are-supplying-ukraines-volunteer-fighters-2022-3\">He gave us an inside look at how he did it.</a></p>\n<p><strong>5. Two partners of a \"Shopify Mafia\" offshoot share what they're looking to invest in next.</strong> Since a group of former Shopify employees launched Backbone Angels last year, the angel investment collective has invested $2.3 million in women-led startups. Two members told Insider they're interested in mentorship, growth, and commerce startups. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/shopify-mafia-female-leaders-fund-women-led-startups-through-backbone-2022-3\">Here's what else they told us.</a></p>\n<p><strong>6. Tinder users can now run a background check on their matches.</strong> Through a partnership with startup Garbo, the dating app will give users two free background checks — and will boot users with violent criminal pasts. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tinder-free-background-checks-garbo-partnership-2022-3\">Here's what to know about the new service.</a></p>\n<p><strong>7. Better's layoffs this week led to mass confusion over who lost their jobs. </strong>Thousands of employees were reportedly laid off on Tuesday, but many haven't heard their fate directly from the company —&nbsp;instead, they learned from pay stubs, or when their laptop suddenly shut down. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/better-employees-see-mass-confusion-over-who-lost-their-jobs-2022-3\">Inside Better's bungled layoffs.</a>&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>8. Amazon announced a stock split and $10 billion of buybacks. </strong>The company's shares soared in late trading after announcing its board had approved a 20-for-one stock split. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-stock-split-20-for-one-buyback-shares-surge-2022-3\">Here's what that means.</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><u><strong>Odds and ends:</strong></u></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vw-id-buzz-electric-volkswagen-bus-camper-rv-2022-3\"></a></p>\n<figure>\n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vw-id-buzz-electric-volkswagen-bus-camper-rv-2022-3\"><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622930ed6ec7c20019cd6b74?format=jpeg\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2224\" charset=\"\" alt=\"EMBARGO 3/9 PM DNP: The Volkswagen ID. Buzz\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   The Volkswagen ID. Buzz.\n   <p class=\"copyright\">Volkswagen</p>\n  </figcaption></a>\n</figure>\n<p><strong>9. Volkswagen just revealed the electric version of its iconic bus. </strong>In a revival of its microbus — a staple of 1960s counterculture — Volkswagen gave us a glimpse inside the electric ID. Buzz. The van will come in commercial and passenger versions and hit US streets in 2024. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/vw-id-buzz-electric-volkswagen-bus-camper-rv-2022-3\">Check out the new ID. Buzz here.</a></p>\n<p><strong>10. LimeWire is making a comeback — as an NFT marketplace. </strong>A decade after the popular peer-to-peer file-sharing website shut down, it's relaunching as a site that will allow people to buy and trade music-related digital assets. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/limewire-music-returning-nft-marketplace-file-sharing-lawsuit-riaa-crypto-2022-3\">More on the rebirth of LimeWire.</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><u><strong>What we're watching today:</strong></u></p>\n<ul>\n <li aria-level=\"1\">Oracle is set to report earnings today. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/earnings-calendar\">Keep up with earnings here.</a></li>\n <li aria-level=\"1\">Axios is hosting a discussion on trends <a href=\"https://dealmakersvcinvesting.splashthat.com/\">shaping venture capital in 2022.</a></li>\n</ul>\n<hr />\n<p><em>Curated by Jordan Parker Erb in New York. 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Russia claims without evidence that the maternity hospital it bombed &mdash; which killed a child &mdash; was a Ukrainian militia base","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-says-mariupol-maternity-hospital-militia-base-no-evidence-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229dbcd6ec7c20019cd718e?format=jpeg\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"ANTALYA - TURKIYE - MARCH 10: Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov holds a press conference after Russia-Turkiye-Ukraine tripartite Foreign Ministers meeting at the Antalya Diplomacy Forum in Antalya, Turkiye on March 10, 2022. (Photo by Mustafa Ciftci/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images)\"/><figcaption>Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov holds a press conference in Antalya, Turkey, on March 10, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Mustafa Ciftci/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Ukraine said three civilians died after Russia bombed a maternity hospital in Mariupol on Wednesday.</li>\n<li>Russia&#39;s foreign minister said Thursday,&#160;without giving evidence, that it was occupied by Ukrainian militia.</li>\n<li>Multiple images showed bloodied civilians being rescued from the wreckage.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said without evidence on Thursday that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-condemns-russia-direct-strike-at-mariupol-maternity-hospital-2022-3\">Russia bombed a maternity hospital</a> in Ukraine because it contained Ukrainian militants.</p><p>Three people, including one child, were killed, and 17 people were injured in Wednesday&#39;s attack in Mariupol, the city council said, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-boris-johnson-business-europe-united-nations-bf2bcfb3a499d688e3075f2d4cf54989\">the Associated Press reported.</a></p><p>Images taken at the wrecked hospital <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-women-injured-russian-attack-mariupol-ukraine-maternity-hospital-2022-3\">showed numerous civilian injuries</a>, including a bloodied pregnant woman being carried away on a stretcher.&#160;</p><p>However, during <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60675599\">a press conference</a> following talks with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba, Lavrov said that the hospital was empty of patients and that Russia had told the UN it was being used as a Ukrainian militia base.</p><p>&#34;On March 7 or 6, I don&#39;t remember exactly now, but at a meeting of the UN Security Council, facts were presented by our delegation about that this maternity hospital was seized long ago by the Azov Battalion and other radicals,&#34; Lavrov said, <a href=\"https://ria.ru/20220310/lavrov-1777465005.html\">the state-run RIA Novosti news agency reported</a>.</p><p>&#34;All the women in labor, all the nurses, and all the attendants were expelled.&#34;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229d9db7eb82f00180e48f7?format=jpeg\" height=\"1125\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Cars and building destroyed by an aviation strike in Mariupol, Ukraine\"/><figcaption>A view shows cars and a building of a hospital destroyed by an aviation strike in Mariupol, Ukraine, in this handout picture released March 9, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Press service of the National Police of Ukraine/Handout via Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Azov Battalion is <a href=\"https://theintercept.com/2022/02/24/ukraine-facebook-azov-battalion-russia/\">a volunteer infantry unit</a> of right-wing Ukrainian ultranationalists that became part of the country&#39;s national guard in 2014.</p><p>The UN did not immediately return a request for comment from Insider.&#160;</p><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy <a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/yevropejci-povinni-posilyuvati-sankciyi-proti-rosiyi-tak-sho-73465\">said</a> Thursday morning that the attack was an &#34;atrocity&#34; and showed Russia was committing &#34;genocide.&#34;</p><p>&#34;What kind of country is this, the Russian Federation, which is afraid of hospitals, afraid of maternity hospitals, and destroys them?&#34; he said.</p><p>&#34;The air bomb on the maternity hospital is the final proof,&#34; he later said. &#34;Proof that the genocide of Ukrainians is taking place.&#34;</p><p>However, Lavrov rejected the classification at the press conference, saying: &#34;It is not the first time we see pathetic outcries concerning so-called atrocities.&#34;</p><p>Lavrov also called the Russian invasion of Ukraine a &#34;special military operation&#34; and denied, falsely, that Russia had attacked Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;We&#39;re not planning to attack other countries. We didn&#39;t even attack Ukraine,&#34; he said, repeating the claim that Russia was defending the pro-Kremlin Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk.</p><p>Speaking at his own press conference, Kuleba said he and Lavrov had made <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2?utm_source=copy-link&#38;utm_medium=referral&#38;utm_content=topbar#russia-and-ukraine-say-they-are-no-closer-to-arranging-a-cease-fire-after-top-level-talks\">no progress on arranging a cease-fire</a>.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
