Bostock)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229dbcd6ec7c20019cd718e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn30@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-33-838_5346febf8e8dec70.webp","https://i.insider.com/6229d9db7eb82f00180e48f7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn34@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-27-941_4a8156efafdcc85a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LcUyDCzND3A:1i8gQ3OGRTs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn3@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-30-174_f237483287570ec4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LcUyDCzND3A:1i8gQ3OGRTs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn77@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-31-874_c1152294526604fa.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=LcUyDCzND3A:1i8gQ3OGRTs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn32@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-30-424_26ac3a90552a6396.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704318},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Former Trump-spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham says her gay son was 'ashamed' she worked for Trump","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stephanie-grisham-gay-son-ashamed-she-worked-for-trump-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62293dd36ec7c20019cd6c65?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Stephanie Grisham\"/><figcaption>Former White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham watches as US President Donald Trump speaks to reporters on November 08, 2019.<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Former Trump-spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham said her gay son was &#34;ashamed&#34; she worked for Trump.</li>\n<li>Grisham made the comments while serving as a guest host on &#34;The View&#34; on Tuesday.</li>\n<li>The hosts of the talk show discussed Florida&#39;s controversial &#34;Don&#39;t Say Gay&#34; bill during the episode.</li>\n</ul><p>Former Trump spokeswoman Stephanie Grisham said her 14-year-old son, who recently came out as gay, told her that he was ashamed she once worked for the former Republican president and his party.</p><p>Grisham made the comments during a Tuesday episode of&#160; &#34;The View,&#34; during which she was serving as a guest co-host on the talk show.</p><p>During one segment, first reported on by <a href=\"https://www.thedailybeast.com/stephanie-grisham-says-her-gay-teen-son-was-ashamed-she-worked-for-trump-and-gop?via=twitter_page\">The Daily Beast</a>, the hosts discussed <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fight-over-floridas-dont-say-gay-bill-explained-2022-2\">the controversial Parental Rights in Education bill</a> that the GOP-controlled Florida legislature passed on Tuesday after weeks of intense opposition from <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/nbc-out/out-news/chasten-buttigieg-says-floridas-dont-say-gay-bill-will-push-kids-back-rcna13463\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"31ba747ab5a19d1b467d065a3ea8eb1c\">national Democrats</a>, Florida students,&#160;<a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/protests-continue-florida-dont-gay-bill/story?id=83303075\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"38fd90f9272faf86e8dbf72e3c6df889\">LGBTQ advocates</a>, and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-slams-florida-dont-say-gay-bill-desantis-support-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"7a70933433eb2de7dd3f58388986f7d7\">the White House.</a> The legislation &#8212; which critics have dubbed the &#34;Don&#39;t Say Gay&#34; bill &#8212; bans the discussion of sexual orientation and gender identity in primary classrooms from kindergarten through third grade.</p><p>The bill now heads to the desk of Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis who is expected to sign it into law. If he does, the legislation would take effect in July.</p><p>During Tuesday&#39;s episode of &#34;The View,&#34; the show&#39;s hosts slammed the bill, bemoaning the effects it will have on LGBTQ+ students, as well as their teachers and families.&#160;</p><p>&#34;So is this bill shaming kids from being who they are and punishing teachers who actually want to help them?&#34; moderator Whoopi Goldberg said. &#34;I mean, I&#39;m not sure what the point of this is.&#34;</p><p>Co-host Sara Haines jumped in to discuss her own brother&#39;s experience as a gay student.</p><p>&#34;He started to feel different at about five or six. If he asked a question, he could have been in a situation where he turned to a teacher that had to betray him,&#34; she said. &#34;I think this is going in the wrong direction.&#34;</p><p>The legislation would also allow parents to sue school districts that don&#39;t alert them to &#34;critical decisions affecting a student&#39;s mental, emotional, or physical health or well-being,&#34; including discussions about a child&#39;s sexuality or gender-identity.&#160;</p><p>Another co-host on &#34;The View&#34; suggested the bill was &#34;cruel&#34; on purpose: &#34;It&#39;s to shame family. It&#39;s to shame children, co-host Sunny Hostin said.</p><p>Hostin then turned her attention to Grisham, suggesting that the bill is a result of the culture former President Donald Trump helped promote during his time in office, saying he started &#34;to say the quiet part out loud.&#34;</p><p>Grisham, who has spent months <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stephanie-grisham-says-she-has-no-illusions-shell-be-forgiven-2021-10\">publicly apologizing for her role</a> in the Trump White House while <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stephanie-grisham-trump-rolled-eyes-rules-so-we-did-too-2022-2\">denouncing the former president</a> and his administration, said the subject matter was &#34;personal&#34; to her.</p><p>&#34;I have a 14-year-old son who is gay, recently came out as gay. I have his permission to talk about this, by the way,&#34; she said. &#34;He didn&#39;t want to tell his friends where I worked. He was ashamed of where I worked, rightfully so.&#34;&#160;</p><p>Grisham went on, accusing the legislation of making young students &#34;feel different.&#34;&#160;</p><article><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Justin Baragona  (@justinbaragona) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1501237242815254531?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 8, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>During her appearance on the show, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stephanie-grisham-trump-admired-putin-loved-dictators-2022-3\">Grisham also discussed Trump&#39;s relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin</a>, saying the former president both feared and admired Putin.</p><p>&#34;Honestly, I think he feared him. I think he was afraid of him. I think the man intimidated him,&#34; she said. &#34;I also think he admired him greatly,&#34; Grisham said. &#34;I think he wanted to be able to kill whoever spoke out against him.&#34;&#160;</p></article><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Erin Snodgrass)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/62293dd36ec7c20019cd6c65?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn19@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-31-298_dcf8c8acab4c0944.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xq6xRiX2npw:-mlzydnyz-E:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn23@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-35-252_2bf57716b488913a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xq6xRiX2npw:-mlzydnyz-E:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn17@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-28-082_662f8829aa5d2def.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Xq6xRiX2npw:-mlzydnyz-E:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn3@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-30-785_1b78e6741e7afaec.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704363},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"'Big Short' investor Michael Burry returns to Twitter with a nod to the 1970s, as the world battles with inflation and an energy crunch","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/big-short-michael-burry-twitter-inflation-warning-energy-crunch-1970-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229c9176ec7c20019cd6ff4?format=jpeg\" height=\"668\" width=\"1336\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Dr. Michael Burry\"/><figcaption>&#34;Big Short&#34; investor Michael Burry, founder of hedge fund Scion Capital.<p class=\"copyright\">Astrid Stawiarz/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>&#34;Big Short&#34; investor Michael Burry took to Twitter after months with a cryptic tweet that seemed like a nod to the 1970s.</li>\n<li>The &#39;70s, dubbed as a period of &#34;Great Inflation,&#34; showed high inflation can have a devastating effect on an economy.</li>\n<li>His tweet may have also been a reference to the energy crisis of the &#39;70s, since oil prices are skyrocketing now.</li>\n</ul><p>Michael Burry returned to Twitter after an absence of more than three months, apparently to remind his followers that the current market environment is reminiscent of unexpected inflation in the 1970s.</p><p>&#34;1977 says Hello,&#34; the famed investor said in a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/michaeljburry/status/1501816251890294784\">Thursday tweet</a>, posting a picture of himself at the age of 6.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Cassandra  (@michaeljburry) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1501816251890294784?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 10, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>His tweet was likely a reference to the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stagflation\">period of stagflation</a> that occurred in the 1970s, when the US entered a recession but the inflation rate topped 12%, thanks to an oil embargo, and the effect of monetary and fiscal policies.</p><p>The decade has been dubbed a time of &#34;<a href=\"https://www.stlouisfed.org/dialogue-with-the-fed/reflections-on-the-maverick-reserve-bank/videos/part-3-david-wheelock-the-great-inflation-period\">Great Inflation</a>&#34; that showed stagflation &#8212; a brutal combination of stagnant economic growth and high inflation &#8212; can have damaging economic consequences. Before that, experts believed price rises would cool if an economy slowed, as it would dampen demand.</p><p>The Ukraine war has sent commodities prices soaring, given major supplier Russia is facing tough sanctions. That has raised concerns of a knock-on effect on consumer prices for energy and food.</p><p>Economists have warned that complacency by the Federal Reserve and persistent high inflation could put the US economy back in the grip of stagflation, which <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-stagflation-explained-oil-outlook-low-growth-high-inflation-2021-10\">it was battling</a> even before the conflict.</p><p>Burry flagged inflation <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-elon-musk-michael-burry-jack-dorsey-inflation-warnings-2021-10#michael-burry-2\">as early as April 2020,</a> when the COVID-19 pandemic was still in its early stages, and warned the situation could rival America&#39;s inflationary crisis in the 1970s. His prediction was proved right multiple times, as inflation gauges in the last two years have repeatedly hit decade-highs.</p><p>The US Consumer Price Index &#8212; a popular measure of inflation &#8212; marked a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inflation-cpi-january-price-growth-report-omicron-wave-supply-chains-2022-2\">40-year high of 7.5%</a> in January, and billionaire &#34;Bond King&#34; Jeff Gundlach has warned US inflation <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/jeff-gundlach-inflation-outlook-warning-recession-fed-rates-stock-market-2022-3\">could hit 10%</a> sometime this year.</p><p>Burry might also have been referring to the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/photos-oil-crisis-in-the-1970s-2012-11\">last energy crisis</a> in the 1970s. An <a href=\"https://www.britannica.com/event/Arab-oil-embargo\">Arab oil embargo</a>, in response to the US&#39; support of Israel during the Yom Kippur war, went into effect in October 1973 &#8212; and crude prices immediately jumped 300%, from $3 per barrel to $12.</p><p>Oil prices now are <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/commodities/oil-price-today-uae-opec-should-boost-output-faster-production-2022-3\">soaring</a> in response to Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine, with crude teasing $120 a barrel in recent days.</p><p>Burry is known to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/news/big-short-michael-burry-deletes-twitter-profile-warning-market-bubbles-2021-4-1030275994?utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\">leave Twitter</a> repeatedly, having done so at least twice in 2021. His tweets are closely watched by the finance community, after his iconic billion-dollar bets during the US housing market bubble that developed in the mid-2000s.</p><p>The investor of &#34;The Big Short&#34; fame and head of Scion Asset Management was one of the first to predict and profit from the subprime mortgage crisis.</p><p>His last noteworthy tweet was in November, when he slammed <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/tesla-stock-price-elon-musk-share-sale-twitter-poll-2021-11\">Elon Musk&#39;s stock-selling spree</a>. He suggested <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/big-short-michael-burry-elon-musk-tesla-stock-market-bubble-2021-11\">Musk might want to sell some Tesla stock</a> to cover his personal debts.</p><p>Through his <a href=\"https://twitter.com/michaeljburry/header_photo\">header photo</a>, Burry also subtly compared the then-market environment to the Dutch tulip bubble. That header image hasn&#39;t been replaced since.</p><p><strong>Read More:&#160;</strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/big-shot-china-nickel-trading-derivatives-tycoon-tsingshan-short-squeeze-2022-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/big-shot-china-nickel-trading-derivatives-tycoon-tsingshan-short-squeeze-2022-3\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">A Chinese tycoon reportedly got squeezed in the global nickel market and faced billions in losses. Here&#39;s how the short squeeze happened and 7 things you need to know about &#39;Big Shot.&#39;</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister said after a meeting with his Russian counterpart that they were no closer to arranging a cease-fire.</li>\n<li>Russia&#39;s foreign id=\"slideshow\"><div class=\"slide\">Zelenskyy accuses Russia of lying after foreign minister claims the maternity hospital it bombed was used by Ukrainian militants<p>Shortly after Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov claimed the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-says-mariupol-maternity-hospital-militia-base-no-evidence-2022-3\">Mariupol maternity hospital Russia shelled was a Ukrainian militia base</a>, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy accused Russia of lying.</p><p>Referring to the Russian people, Zelenskyy said: &#34;The Russians were lied to that there had been no patients in the hospital and no women or children in the maternity hospital. The Russians were lied to that &#39;nationalists&#39; had allegedly taken up positions there. They lie confidently, as always.&#34;</p><p>&#34;War crimes are impossible without the propagandists who cover them up. I want to tell them one thing: you will bear responsibility just as all those who give orders to bomb civilians.&#34;</p><p>&#34;You will definitely be prosecuted for complicity in war crimes. And then, it will definitely happen, you will be hated by Russian citizens,&#34; he added, appearing to refer to Russia&#39;s leaders.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kamala Harris says there should &#39;absolutely&#39; be a war-crimes investigation into Russian bombing of maternity hospital<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62128a91462ff20019c5dd65?format=jpeg\" height=\"682\" width=\"910\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Kamala Harris\"/><figcaption>US Vice President Kamala Harris.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Michael Probst</p></figcaption></figure><p>US Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday supported calls for a war-crimes investigation into Russia&#39;s bombing of a maternity hospital in Mariupol, Ukraine, the day before.</p><p>&#34;We have been witnessing, just in the last 24 hours, atrocities of unimaginable proportion,&#34; she <a href=\"https://twitter.com/SkyNews/status/1501896441186463746\">said</a>. &#34;A maternity hospital, a children&#39;s hospital, where we have witnessed pregnant women who were there for care ... Unprovoked. Unjustified.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Absolutely there should be an investigation, and we should all be watching,&#34; she <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-duda-andrzej-duda-kamala-harris-europe-792555553cca39ef9e1b4f1e7f8cebe6?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&#38;utm_medium=AP&#38;utm_source=Twitter\">said, according to the Associated Press</a>.</p><p>Duda said: &#34;It is obvious to us that in Ukraine Russians are committing war crimes.&#34;</p><p>At least three civilians, including a child, was killed in Wednesday&#39;s bombing, Ukraine said.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin-Zelenskyy meeting is possible, Russian foreign minister says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622744e3913301001822c2a9?format=jpeg\" height=\"2249\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Vladimir Putin, Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>A composite image of Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.<p class=\"copyright\">Mikhail Svetlov/Getty Images, Laurent Van der Stockt for Le Monde/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia&#39;s foreign minister said a meeting between President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian Volodymyr Zelenskyy could potentially take place.</p><p>&#34;Everyone is well aware that President Putin never refuses contacts. We only want these contacts to be organized not for their own sake, but in order to fix some specific agreements,&#34; Sergei Lavrov said after meeting his Ukrainian counterpart Dmytro Kuleba, according to the state-run Ria news agency.</p><p>&#34;I reminded him [Kuleba] that we are always in favor of meeting if we can achieve some added value and can solve the problem.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia claims without evidence that the maternity hospital it bombed &#8212; which killed a child &#8212; was a Ukrainian militia base<figure><img service of the National Police of Ukraine/Handout via Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said without evidence on Thursday that&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-condemns-russia-direct-strike-at-mariupol-maternity-hospital-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"4e523fed307aaf66c06573588e80ba33\">Russia bombed a maternity hospital</a>&#160;in Ukraine because it contained Ukrainian militants.</p><p>Three people, including one child, were killed, and 17 people were injured in Wednesday&#39;s attack in Mariupol, the city council said,&#160;<a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-boris-johnson-business-europe-united-nations-bf2bcfb3a499d688e3075f2d4cf54989\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"8929181d4f4ecdd3dc81ddaaadd6efb1\">the Associated Press reported.</a></p><p>However, during&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60675599\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"075bb996b19572b90b6faac80cf3ab0a\">a press conference</a>&#160;following talks with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba, Lavrov said that the hospital was empty of patients and that Russia had told the UN it was being used as a Ukrainian militia base.</p><p>&#34;On March 7 or 6, I don&#39;t remember exactly now, but at a meeting of the UN Security Council, facts were presented by our delegation about that this maternity hospital was seized long ago by the Azov Battalion and other radicals,&#34; Lavrov Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian foreign minister on a nuclear war: &#39;I do not want to believe in it and do not believe it&#39;<figure><img At least three people, including a child, was killed, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60675599\">the BBC reported</a>, citing city officials.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK sanctions 7 Russian oligarchs, including Roman Abramovich<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621fb7c975b649001845b930?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich is seen on the stand during the Barclays Premier League match between Chelsea and Sunderland at Stamford Bridge\"/><figcaption>Roman Abramovich.<p class=\"copyright\">Getty/Clive Mason</p></figcaption></figure><p>The United Kingdom announced on Thursday that it had sanctioned seven more Russian oligarchs.</p><p>These include the Chelsea FC owner Roman Abramovich, aluminum group Rusal founder Oleg Deripaska, and Rosneft CEO Igor Sechin, the UK government said in a <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/abramovich-and-deripaska-among-seven-oligarchs-targeted-in-estimated-15bn-sanction-hit\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"e55405d21fe374ee3fc888280975b918\">press release</a>.&#160;</p><p>The other oligarchs include Alexei Miller, Gazprom CEO; who have a collective net worth of around £15bn &#8212; will have their assets in the UK frozen, they are banned from travelling here and no UK citizen or company may do business with them,&#34; the UK government said.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/roman-abramovich-sanctions-oleg-deripaska-russian-oligarch-billionaires-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelenskyy calls on West to show &#39;courage,&#39; The amount gradually crept up with many lawmakers in both parties eager to provide financial and military help to Ukraine, especially as the Russian military campaign intensified in recent days.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-house-passes-government-funding-bill-ukraine-aid-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian man says he learned of family members&#39; deaths via photos on Twitter<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622990c76ec7c20019cd6ec6?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine troops patrol in Irpin\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian troops patrol in Irpin, Ukraine, on March 1, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Anastasia Vlasova/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>A Ukrainian mother and her two children, along with a church volunteer who was helping them escape Kyiv amid Russia&#39;s ongoing invasion were killed by mortar fire on Sunday as they attempted to flee via a damaged bridge in the town of Irpin.</p><p>Hours later, Serhiy Perebyinis discovered the deaths of his wife and children via graphic photos of their dead bodies on Twitter, the father told&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/09/world/europe/ukraine-family-perebyinis-kyiv.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"53565898fbcdabc6a1cec74ce227b1f5\">The New York Times.</a></p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-man-learned-of-familys-death-on-twitter-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Foreign ministers of Russia and Ukraine to meet in Turkey on Thursday<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622964d06ec7c20019cd6db8?format=jpeg\" height=\"1440\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine&#39;s Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba (left) and Russia&#39;s Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov\"/><figcaption>Ukraine&#39;s Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba (left) is set to meet his Russian counterpart Sergey Lavrov (right) in Turkey on Thursday.<p class=\"copyright\">Carolyn Kaster/Getty Images, Shamil Zumatov/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The foreign ministers of Russia and Ukraine are set to meet in Turkey on Thursday, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/09/world/europe/ukraine-russia-cease-fire-talks.html\">The New York Times reported</a> on Wednesday.&#160;</p><p>The scheduled meeting between Russia&#39;s Sergey V. Lavrov and Ukraine&#39;s Dmytro Kuleba will be the highest-level talks between the two countries since <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-announces-military-assault-against-ukraine-in-surprise-speech-2022-2\">Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine began on February 24,</a> per The Times.</p><p>Turkey&#39;s President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the talks could &#34;crack the door open to a permanent cease-fire,&#34; per the outlet.</p><p>On Wednesday, Russian foreign ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova said her country has <a href=\"https://www.newsweek.com/russia-ukraine-war-invasion-zelensky-occupy-1686260\">no intentions to overthrow Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy&#39;s government or take over Ukraine.</a></p><p>In an <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/US/video/zelenskyy-interview-david-muir-reporting-abc-news-exclusive-83309456\">interview with ABC News on Monday night</a>, Zelenskyy said he had &#34;cooled down&#34; on the idea of his country joining NATO. He also said that he was open to discussions about the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraines-zelensky-says-he-has-cooled-on-joining-nato-2022-3\">control of Russian-backed separatist regions in eastern Ukraine.</a></p><p>During his speech announcing the invasion, Russian President Vladimir Putin framed his country&#39;s actions as an <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-threatens-worst-ever-consequences-if-west-intervenes-in-ukraine-2022-2\">act of self-defense against NATO&#39;s eastward expansion in Europe.</a></p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Poland&#39;s US envoy says his country understands America&#39;s rejection of its plan to provide Polish fighter jets to Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622957606ec7c20019cd6ccd?format=jpeg\" height=\"1221\" width=\"1629\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Polish MiG&#39;s-29 take off for a training mission at the military airport near Minsk Mazowiecki, east of Warsaw, December 6, 2005. As part of a rotational duty shared by members of the military alliance, Poland&#39;s MiGs will begin &#34;air policing&#34; missions over Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania in January. REUTERS/Peter Andrews\"/><figcaption>Two Polish MiG-29 fighter jets seen near Minsk Mazowiecki, east of Warsaw, on December 6, 2005.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Peter Andrews</p></figcaption></figure><p>Marek Magierowski, Poland&#39;s ambassador to the US, said his country understands America&#39;s rejection of a Polish plan to provide Ukraine with fighter jets, the <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-poland-united-states-europe-warsaw-534cd345f7bcb5a08a21fc2244efb04f?utm_medium=AP&#38;utm_source=Twitter&#38;utm_campaign=SocialFlow\">Associated Press reported</a> on Wednesday.</p><p>&#34;Our American partners rejected this proposal because they have come to the conclusion that it was too escalatory,&#34; Magierowski told CNN, per AP.&#160;</p><p>Magierowski said his country understood the US&#39; decision and called for &#34;unity and cohesion&#34; among NATO countries while adding that it&#39;s time to &#34;move on&#34; from the issue, per the wire.</p><p>On Tuesday, the Department of Defense <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pentagon-rejects-poland-offer-send-jets-us-air-base-ukraine-2022-3\">rejected Poland&#39;s proposal to send its Russian-made MiG-29 warplanes to Ukraine via a US airbase.</a>&#160;</p><p>Ukraine&#39;s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has previously <a href=\"https://www.axios.com/zelensky-ukraine-no-fly-zone-planes-7eb2e6f8-d488-4444-bc70-889141b34dcf.html\">called for the US and NATO nations to provide his country with fighter jets</a> amid Russia&#39;s ongoing invasion. However, the US and NATO have held back from doing so over concerns that such a move could <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-invasion-of-ukraine-could-lead-to-open-confrontation-with-nato-experts-2022-1\">spark a larger conflict with Russia.</a></p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine has forced a Jewish orphanage to flee Odesa<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622951af6ec7c20019cd6ca5?format=jpeg\" height=\"768\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People on a bus in Ukraine\"/><figcaption>Children were boarded onto eight buses in Odesa and spent nearly 60 hours fleeing to safety in Romania.<p class=\"copyright\">Tikva Children&#39;s Home</p></figcaption></figure><p>By 1900, more than a third of Odesa&#39;s population was Jewish. But the 20th century was not kind to this population, in Ukraine as elsewhere.</p><p>Today, the city of more than 1 million on the coast of the Black Sea is home to some 45,000 Jews. At least it was.</p><p>The Russian invasion &#8212; sold as a campaign of &#34;de-Nazification&#34; in the only country outside of Israel with a Jewish head of state &#8212; has once again forced this persecuted minority to flee.</p><p>Earlier this month, Odesa&#39;s chief rabbi, Shlomo Baksht, who had come to the city in the 1990s to help rebuild its Jewish community, decided it was time to get out.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/interview-russias-invasion-forces-jewish-orphanage-to-flee-ukraine-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">White House says Russia&#39;s baseless claim of US having chemical weapons in Ukraine suggests Putin&#39;s forces may &#39;possibly use&#39; them<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622940237eb82f00180e43e7?format=jpeg\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2221\" charset=\"\" alt=\"destruction war ukraine kharkiv\"/><figcaption>A burnt-out car is seen on the street after a missile launched by Russian invaders hit near the Kharkiv Regional State Administration building in Svobody (Freedom) Square) at approximately 8 am local time on Tuesday, March 1, Kharkiv, northeastern Ukraine, on March 1, 2022, in Kharkiv, Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Vyacheslav Madiyevskyy/Ukrinform/NurPhoto via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia&#39;s baseless accusation that the US has chemical weapons in Ukraine could mean the Kremlin is planning to use them, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said on Wednesday.</p><p>&#34;We took note of Russia&#39;s false claims about alleged US biological weapons labs and chemical weapons development in Ukraine. We&#39;ve also seen Chinese officials echo these conspiracy theories,&#34; Psaki said in a&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/PressSec/status/1501676240180322311?s=20&#38;t=CS42ilgPSgZNdd8vyAEyxg\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ec4083580025d2489dc09fc1e258a1e9\">Twitter thread</a>. &#34;This is preposterous.&#34;</p><p>She said the claim was &#34;the kind of disinformation operation we&#39;ve seen repeatedly from the Russians over the years&#34; and &#34;an example of the types of false pretexts we have been warning the Russians would invent.&#34;</p><p>Psaki said the US is in full compliance with the Chemical Weapons Convention and does not have such weapons anywhere.</p><p>Russia has repeatedly used chemical weapons to target dissidents. Novichok, a Soviet-era nerve agent, has been the favored weapon that Western nations have accused Russia of deploying against some of its most notable dissidents.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-russia-may-possibly-use-chemical-weapons-in-ukraine-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Polish lawmakers warn Putin could take military action beyond Ukraine: &#39;He won&#39;t stop&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62292b086ec7c20019cd6a16?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A man in camouflage clothing helps refugees from Ukraine to pull their suitcases at the border crossing in Medyka, Poland.\"/><figcaption>A man in camouflage clothing helps refugees from Ukraine to pull their suitcases at the border crossing in Medyka, Poland.<p class=\"copyright\">Sebastian Gollnow</p></figcaption></figure><p>Crushing Russia&#39;s economy is imperative to ensuring that Russian President Vladimir Putin does not take military action beyond Ukraine, a scenario that could potentially spark a much broader war, Polish lawmakers warn.&#160;</p><p>&#34;There is a concern that Russia may go further if we don&#39;t stop the invasion in Ukraine,&#34; Magda Biejat, a member of Poland&#39;s parliament from the Left Together party (Partia Razem), told Insider.</p><p>&#34;There&#39;s a belief among many experts and politicians that Putin is doing what he is doing because of the lack of reaction for what he did in Georgia, for what he did in Crimea. And that he felt he could get away with anything...&#34; Biejat said.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/polish-lawmakers-warn-putin-could-take-military-action-beyond-ukraine-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Experts say there&#39;s clear cut evidence of war crimes in Ukraine, but building a case against Putin will take years and it&#39;s unlikely he&#39;ll ever face justice<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62292a6b7eb82f00180e4129?format=jpeg\" height=\"631\" width=\"841\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin summons meeting of Russia&#39;s Security Council at Kremlin in Moscow, Russia on February 21, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Kremlin Press Office/Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>In the two weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine, there have been reports of&#160;<a href=\"https://khpg.org/en/1608810140\" href=\"https://www.hrw.org/news/2022/03/08/ukraine-russian-assault-kills-fleeing-civilians#\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"d54af598bbfa42b996550a2043267391\">civilians being fired on</a>&#160;as they try to flee to safety.&#160;</p><p>These incidents have led many to question whether Russian President Vladimir Putin could be charged with war crimes.&#160;</p><p>Insider spoke to two experts in the field, who explained how such cases are built, the likelihood of Putin being charged, and how charges would impact Putin&#39;s life.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/experts-how-war-crimes-case-can-be-built-against-putin-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Before and after satellite imagery highlights the devastation from Russia&#39;s attacks on Mariupol, Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228fe617eb82f00180e30b0?format=jpeg\" height=\"2921\" width=\"5000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Satellite images show damaged houses in Mariupol, Ukraine\"/><figcaption>Satellite images show damaged houses in Mariupol, Ukraine<p class=\"copyright\">Satellite image ©2022 Maxar Technologies</p></figcaption></figure><p>Before Russia&#39;s invasion last month, Mariupol was a bustling port city in southern Ukraine. But since the war began, it has been besieged and repeatedly struck by Russian airstrikes and artillery fire, with civilians reportedly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-says-russia-shelling-mariupol-humanitarian-corridor-break-cease-fire-2022-2\">shelled as they try to flee</a>.</p><p>On Wednesday, the situation became even grimmer, with reports that Russian attacks had <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-condemns-russia-direct-strike-at-mariupol-maternity-hospital-2022-3\">leveled a children&#39;s and maternity hospital</a> in the city of roughly 400,000 people.</p><p>Satellite images taken by the US firm Maxar Technologies &#8212; from June 2021 and March 9, 2022 &#8212; show the physical devastation from two weeks of war that have also killed more than 1,000 Ukrainian civilians.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mariupol-ukraine-before-after-satellite-photos-show-destruction-russian-attack-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelenskyy says Putin&#39;s threats of nuclear war are a &#39;bluff&#39; that shows &#39;nothing else is working&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228ef917eb82f00180e2c81?format=jpeg\" height=\"853\" width=\"1280\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.<p class=\"copyright\">UKRINFORM/ Ukrinform/Future Publishing via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy called Russian President Vladimir Putin&#39;s threat to turn to nuclear weapons &#34;a bluff&#34;&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">amid Russia&#39;s war against Ukraine</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I think that the threat of nuclear war is a bluff. It&#39;s one thing to be a murderer. It&#39;s another to commit suicide,&#34; Zelenskyy&#160;<a href=\"https://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2022-03/wolodymyr-selenskyj-ukraine-russia-war-interview-english/komplettansicht?utm_referrer=https%3A%2F%2Ft.co%2F\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"758a053a6a94ea7c63ef80b586a134a1\">told German newspaper Die Zeit</a>&#160;in an interview published on Wednesday.&#160;</p><p>Putin, within days of invading Ukraine,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-puts-russias-nuclear-deterrent-forces-after-sanctions-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"51b836e682577f741746065923b5f279\">ordered Russia&#39;s nuclear weapons on high alert</a>&#160;in a movie he said was triggered by &#34;aggressive statements&#34; from Western powers.&#160;</p><p>NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg quickly called Putin&#39;s order &#34;dangerous rhetoric.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-says-putins-threats-of-nuclear-war-are-a-bluff-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia admits it sent young conscripts into its Ukraine war after Putin denied those troops were involved<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621501a3462ff20019c5fadc?format=jpeg\" height=\"2863\" width=\"4586\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian troops Ukraine tensions\"/><figcaption>Russia ordered troops to cross into rebel-held Ukrainian territory on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Russian Defense Ministry Press Service/Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia&#39;s military admitted on Wednesday that young draftees were sent to fight in&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">its war against Ukraine</a>&#160;after Russian President Vladimir Putin denied that conscripts were involved in the attack.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Unfortunately, some facts have come to light about the presence of conscript servicemen among the Russian armed forces conducting the special military operation on Ukrainian territory,&#34;&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/KevinRothrock/status/1501567647741358082\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"c8193b79c1e40cdbbfb6804b50039eae\">said Russian Defense Ministry spokesman Igor Konashenkov</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Practically all of the conscripts have been returned to the territory of the Russian Federation,&#34; Konashenkov added.</p><p>Konashenkov said, however, that some of the conscripts have been captured.</p><p>Earlier this week, Putin said that only &#34;professional&#34; Russian soldiers were sent in to invade Ukraine and that he would not send conscripts to fight,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/03/09/russia-admits-conscripts-take-part-in-ukraine-operation-a76846\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"0995145074b61c2110143158a903ceab\">according to The Moscow Times</a>.&#160;</p><p>The Kremlin said on Wednesday Putin ordered conscripts to be excluded from Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine, according to Russian state media.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-admits-sending-young-conscripts-into-its-ukraine-war-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian mayors under Russian siege plead for help and say they&#39;re being targeted in a &#39;genocide&#39;<p>Ukrainian mayors of cities&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">under Russian siege</a>&#160;painted a grim picture on Wednesday of the terror and humanitarian crises unfolding in their regions as they put out an urgent plea for Western powers to impose a no-fly zone over Ukraine in order to put a stop to the daily bombing across the country.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Most local casualties were inflicted by bombing and we are helpless against the bombing. Please help us,&#34; pleaded Serhiy Orlov, the deputy mayor of the southeastern Ukrainian city of Mariupol.</p><p>Mariupol is&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-russia-cease-fire-in-besieged-mariupol-fails-again-200000-trapped-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"98a221e9fdbf0e95fee4bc78579edcbd\">being attacked on all sides,</a>&#160;and Orlov said during a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-zoom-guide\" data-site=\"bi\" data-keyword=\"Zoom\" data-analytics-product-module=\"Auto-Linker\" data-analytics-product-area=\"link\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"58d8e5f784e20eaa8076b47b1aef5771\">Zoom</a>&#160;call with reporters that Russian forces have blocked the delivery of food and water supply, destroyed communication infrastructure, and bombed all of the city&#39;s power lines, cutting off electricity.</p><p>&#34;The war waged by Russia isn&#39;t simply treacherous &#8212; it&#39;s a war crime,&#34; he said. &#34;The only aim of which is the genocide and we have seen for ourselves that [Russian President Vladimir] Putin aims to capture Mariupol despite any destruction, despite the human cost.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-mayors-plead-for-help-russian-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelenskyy says &#39;direct strike&#39; in this case IAEA sees no critical impact on safety,&#34; the tweet said, citing IAEA chief Rafael Grossi.</p><p>The agency said on Tuesday that it had unexpectedly stopped receiving remote data transmission from the plant&#39;s safeguards monitoring systems.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelenskyy addresses Russian soldiers, saying only captivity and death are &#39;waiting for you&#39; in Ukraine<p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy reiterated his message to Russian soldiers that they should not believe their commanding officers.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Do not believe your commanders when they tell you that you still have a chance in Ukraine,&#34; he said in a Wednesday&#160;<a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/ukrayinci-vistoyali-j-nadihnuli-ves-svit-svoyeyu-rishuchisty-73457\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"09d48c1b0502b9594c8198a59b29fab3\">address</a>. &#34;Nothing is waiting for you here. Except for captivity, except for death.&#34;</p><p>&#34;You take our lives and give yours,&#34; his address continued. &#34;And we know &#8212; we have communications interception &#8212; that your commanders already understand everything.&#34;</p><p>Zelenskyy&#39;s stern warning comes just days after a scathing New York Times report that said Russian soldiers on the front lines in Ukraine&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-lied-to-russian-soldiers-left-them-unprepared-attack-nyt-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5d1a2696c37f7d516706ca38fb5d974b\">were not told they would be going into war</a>. <br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-tells-russian-soldiers-to-not-believe-your-commanders-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelenskyy thanks Poland for offering to send fighter jets to Ukraine and slams US refusal to be middleman<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622899ed9fa32d00184c7e84?format=jpeg\" height=\"957\" width=\"1277\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy standing in front of the world&#39;s largest airplane, the Antonov An-225 Mriya.\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.<p class=\"copyright\">Efrem Lukatsky/AP</p></figcaption></figure><p>Poland on Tuesday offered to send fighter jets to Ukraine via a US air base in Germany, but the Pentagon rejected the offer, saying it &#34;raises serious concerns&#34; for NATO.</p><p>In <a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/ukrayinci-vistoyali-j-nadihnuli-ves-svit-svoyeyu-rishuchisty-73457\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"09d48c1b0502b9594c8198a59b29fab3\">a speech Wednesday,</a>&#160;Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy thanked Poland for offering the planes, but criticized the US for sending mixed signals.</p><p>&#34;Russia uses missiles, aircraft, helicopters against us, against civilians, against our cities, against our infrastructure. src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228190b7eb82f00180e0d9c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Soldiers sit inside the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian soldiers safeguards monitoring systems in other parts of Ukraine and would &#34;provide further information soon.&#34;</p><p>The regulator noted that eight of Ukraine&#39;s 15 nuclear plants are still operating, including the Zaporizhzhia plant that was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-forces-attacking-zaporizhzhia-nuclear-power-plant-ukraine-ap-2022-3\">taken over by Russia last week.</a></p><p>The global nuclear monitor said it unexpectedly lost remote contact with safeguarding systems at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.&#160;</p><p>The IAEA said staff at the functioning plants were working in shifts and that radiation levels at the facilities were at &#34;normal&#34; levels.</p><p>On Monday, <a including night-shift workers, firefighters, and medical staff&#160; &#8212; were living at the plant in temporary dormitories.</p><p>The outlet added that the Chernobyl workers were getting by one meal a day and slept on the floor, tables, or cots.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/chernobyl-iaea-cut-off-from-radiation-monitors-after-russia-attack-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">US rejects Poland&#39;s offer to send fighter jets to US air base in Germany to pass to Ukraine<p>Poland officials say they will distribute all their MIG-29 jets to the US Ramstein Air Base located in Germany &#34;immediately and free of charge,&#34; according to a <a href=\"https://www.gov.pl/web/diplomacy/statement-of-the-minister-of-foreign-affairs-of-the-republic-of-poland-in-connection-with-the-statement-by-the-us-secretary-of-state-on-providing-airplanes-to-ukraine\">statement from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Republic of Poland</a> on Tuesday.</p><p>The statement says the jets will be placed at the disposal of the US government.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Łukasz Jasina  (@RzecznikMSZ) <a encouraged &#34;other NATO Allies &#8211; owners of MIG-29 jets &#8211; to act in the same vein.&#34;</p><p>Following Poland&#39;s announcement, Pentagon press secretary John Kirby said that the plan, &#34;raises serious concerns for the entire NATO alliance.&#34;</p><p>&#34;It is simply not clear to us that there is a substantive rationale for it,&#34; Kirby <a class=\"slide\">CIA Director says Putin &#39;has no sustainable political end game&#39; in what will continue to be a &#39;fierce resistance from Ukrainians&#39;<p>CIA Director Bill Burns said Russian President Vladimir Putin &#34;has no political end game to the invasion of Ukraine in the face of fierce resistance from Ukrainians.&#34;</p><p>Burns testified on Tuesday before the House Select Intelligence Committee on threats to national security. When asked by Rep. Adam Schiff how he foresaw the conflict in Ukraine ending, Burns said he wasn&#39;t sure.</p><p>&#34;That&#39;s the core question,&#34; Burns responded. &#34;I think Putin&#39;s assumptions have turned out to be profoundly flawed.&#34;&#160;</p><p>&#34;He failed to see how he could sustain a puppet regime or a pro-Russian leadership that he tried to install in the face of what is a massive opposition from Ukrainian people,&#34; Burns said.&#160;</p><p>Burns continued: &#34;I fail to see how he can produce that kind of an end game.&#34;&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-has-no-political-end-game-against-ukrainian-resistance-cia-director-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">UN denies report that staff were warned not to call Russian attack on Ukraine a &#39;war&#39; or &#39;invasion&#39;<p>The United Nations has refuted a report that said the intergovernmental organization warned staffers in an email not to refer to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine</a>&#160;as a &#34;war&#34; or &#34;invasion.&#34;</p><p>&#34;There is a mistaken impression that UN staff were told to avoid using certain words to describe the situation in Ukraine,&#34; Stéphane Dujarric, the spokesman for the UN&#39;s Secretary-General, told Insider in a statement on Tuesday.&#160;</p><p>&#34;It is simply not the case that staff have been instructed not to use words like &#34;war&#34; and &#34;invasion&#34; to describe the situation,&#34; Dujarric said.&#160;</p><p>The Irish Times&#160;<a href=\"https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/united-nations-advises-staff-against-using-war-or-invasion-regarding-ukraine-1.4821438\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"84235e6724af903087ee7fe51b84ed5f\">published a report earlier Tuesday</a>, saying that the UN emailed staff on Monday advising them not to refer to Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine as a &#34;war&#34; or &#34;invasion.&#34;</p><p>The purported email instead instructed UN staff to use the terms &#34;conflict&#34; or &#34;military offensive&#34; to describe Russia&#39;s aggression against Ukraine, according to The Irish Times, which reported that the email was seen by the news outlet.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/un-denies-report-staff-warning-not-call-russian-ukraine-war-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The US announced it will ban Russian energy imports, including Russian oil, liquefied natural gas, and coal.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217dbabd0009b00190499c3?format=jpeg\" height=\"4784\" width=\"7176\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Joe Biden\"/><figcaption>U.S. President Joe Biden answers questions after delivering remarks about Russia&#39;s “unprovoked and unjustified&#34; military invasion of Ukraine on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>President Joe Biden announced on Tuesday the US would ban Russian energy imports, stepping up an economic-sanctions campaign to punish the Kremlin for its invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;We will not be subsidizing Putin&#39;s war,&#34; Biden said, calling the ban a &#34;powerful blow&#34; against Russian President Vladimir Putin&#39;s ability to sustain a military campaign in Ukraine.</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><div itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"https://schema.org/VideoObject\"><meta itemprop=\"uploadDate\" content=\"Tue Mar 08 2022 14:55:32 GMT-0500 (Colombia Standard Time)\"/><meta itemprop=\"name\" content=\"VIDEO: Biden announces ban of Russian energy imports to US\"/><meta itemprop=\"description\" content=\"President Joe Biden banned Russian energy imports amid what he called an &#34;unjustified and unprovoked&#34; war on Ukraine.\"/><meta itemprop=\"duration\" content=\"P0Y0M0DT0H3M41S\"/><meta itemprop=\"thumbnailUrl\" content=\"https://content.jwplatform.com/thumbs/zCLa9qoh-1920.jpg\"/><meta itemprop=\"contentUrl\" content=\"https://content.jwplatform.com/videos/zCLa9qoh-74jV3sbY.mp4\"/><script src=\"https://cdn.jwplayer.com/players/zCLa9qoh-gFnR6QwM.js\"></script></div></div><p>&#160;</p><p>The ban will affect imports of Russian oil, liquefied natural gas, and coal. <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-08/biden-set-to-ban-u-s-imports-of-russian-oil-as-soon-as-today?sref=lAVQtUwz\">Bloomberg first reported</a> the latest sanctions on Russia.</p><p>The president acknowledged that not every European country would join in a blanket ban on Russian energy imports.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-us-ban-russian-oil-natural-gas-coal-imports-report-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelensky says &#39;responsibility&#39; for civilian deaths lies with Western governments who haven&#39;t closed skies over Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62224d959908630019986f91?format=jpeg\" height=\"3664\" width=\"5208\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Supinsky / Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Tuesday that the &#34;responsibility&#34; for the deaths of Ukrainians amid the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">Russian invasion</a>&#160;lies with Western governments as he renewed calls for them to close the skies over the eastern European country.</p><p>Zelensky&#160;<a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/u-providnih-stolicyah-lyudyanist-povinna-peremogti-strah-ta-73429\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9d448e080313db20f87694bfaa584120\">also said in his video message</a>&#160;that a child in the besieged city of Mariupol died of dehydration and that Russian forces had blocked the delivery of food and water supply and cut off electricity.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The blame for every death of every person in Ukraine from air strikes and in blocked cities, of course, lies with the Russian state, the Russian military, those who give and those who carry out criminal orders, who violate all the rules of warfare, who deliberately exterminate the Ukrainian people,&#34; Zelensky said.&#160;</p><p>However, he added, &#34;The responsibility for this lies also with those who have not been able to make an obviously necessary decision somewhere in the West … those who have not yet secured the Ukrainian sky from Russian murderers.&#34;<br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-says-responsibility-ukraine-deaths-lies-west-not-closing-skies-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Gas prices just hit a record high. Here&#39;s what Biden&#39;s ban on Russian oil means for prices at the pump<p>President Joe Biden is&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-us-ban-russian-oil-natural-gas-coal-imports-report-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"72c13599086d8a669a7ff7d1158b6e66\">reportedly poised to ban Russian oil as early as Tuesday,</a>&#160;marking a major step toward crippling the Russian economy in response to Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>Russia&#39;s energy sector is key to its economy, as the country was the third-largest producer of crude oil in 2020, according to the US <a href=\"https://www.eia.gov/international/data/world/petroleum-and-other-liquids/annual-petroleum-and-other-liquids-production?pd=5&#38;p=0000000000000000000000000000000000vg&#38;u=0&#38;f=A&#38;v=mapbubble&#38;a=-&#38;i=none&#38;vo=value&#38;vb=170&#38;t=C&#38;g=00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000001&#38;l=249-ruvvvvvfvtvnvv1vrvvvvfvvvvvvfvvvou20evvvvvvvvvvnvvvs0008&#38;s=94694400000&#38;e=1609459200000&#38;ev=true\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b56c1e0a436eb38e176648364b482cda\">Energy Information Administration</a>. By banning oil imports, the White House is hurting Russia in an area ignored in the US&#39;s initial set of retaliatory sanctions.</p><p>The ban could heighten the risk of even higher gas prices. The average price-per-gallon in the US hit a record $4.173 on Tuesday, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gas-prices-highest-since-great-recession-ukraine-crisis-commodity-market-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"eda49c7ecde64d4d5dd686db9803cd64\">eclipsing the previous high set in 2008</a>, amid fears that the Russia-Ukraine conflict would further strangle the crude market. Gas could <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-high-will-gas-prices-go-5-gallon-peak-2022-3\">hit $5 a gallon</a>.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gas-price-outlook-forecast-biden-russia-crude-oil-ban-sanctions-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The US is set to ban Russian oil, natural gas, and coal imports, reports say<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ed1c196929400196c2d29?format=jpeg\" height=\"558\" width=\"744\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Biden\"/><figcaption>President Joe Biden speaking in Washington, DC, on February 8.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Alex Brandon</p></figcaption></figure><p>The US is set to ban Russian energy imports, multiple news outlets reported on Tuesday,&#160;citing sources familiar with the matter.</p><p>The announcement of the ban is poised announced by the White House as early as today and it will apply to imports of Russian oil, liquefied natural gas, and coal, two sources who requested anonymity told&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-08/biden-set-to-ban-u-s-imports-of-russian-oil-as-soon-as-today?sref=lAVQtUwz\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"8e89158550dfb70b20f1f36220ef1e54\">Bloomberg</a>, which first reported the news.</p><p>The pending move followed discussions with European allies, but these countries would not join at this time, according to the report. President Joe Biden is set to speak at 10:45am ET about ongoing US efforts to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, per a White House statement.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-us-ban-russian-oil-natural-gas-coal-imports-report-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine says Russian forces are shelling a humanitarian corridor out of Mariupol it promised not to attack<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62232de199086300199890e2?format=jpeg\" height=\"5760\" width=\"7680\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A firefighter works amongst debris in the aftermath of Russian shelling, in Mariupol, Ukraine, Thursday, Feb. 24, 2022.\"/><figcaption>A firefighter works amongst debris in the aftermath of Russian shelling in Mariupol, Ukraine, on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Evgeniy Maloletka</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine said Russian forces shelled a&#160;humanitarian corridor it promised not to attack on Tuesday.</p><p>Ukraine and Russia said earlier on Tuesday that a corridor would open from 10 a.m. local time on Tuesday. The rule of a humanitarian corridor is that neither side&#39;s forces can attack during that period.</p><p>But hours later, Ukraine&#39;s foreign ministry <a href=\"https://twitter.com/MFA_Ukraine/status/1501148055260876804\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"fe6c62060fd7a40179a77255318b6c19\">tweeted</a> that &#34;Russian forces are now shelling the humanitarian corridor from Zaporizhzhia to Mariupol.&#34;</p><p>Ukraine&#39;s military&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/100064359595429/posts/326687306153253/?d=n\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"14df967b3bb5fd885ca0b55a0717a3ce\">wrote in a Facebook post</a>&#160;that &#34;the invaders did not let children, women, elderly people out of the city. The enemy started the attack exactly in the direction of the humanitarian corridor.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-says-russia-shelling-mariupol-humanitarian-corridor-break-cease-fire-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin&#39;s disinformation is so effective that Ukrainians can&#39;t convince their own families in Russia they are under attack<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62272de0913301001822bf8f?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A man in black with his back to the camera, facing the wreckage of his home in Ukraine, March 5 2022.\"/><figcaption>Igor Majayev, looks over the rubble of his home that was destroyed by a suspected Russian airstrike in Markhalivka, Ukraine, on March 5, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Marcus Yam/LA Times via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainians are struggling to persuade their relatives in Russia not to believe Putin&#39;s propaganda.</p><p>One woman told Insider her Ukrainian uncle in Russia threatened to join the invasion. Another Ukrainian woman cut ties with her Russian father who said the war &#34;was a lie.&#34;</p><p>They are startling examples of how effectively authorities in Russia have presented its attack on Ukraine as a just and humane war, in which Russian soldiers are liberating grateful Ukrainians from their Nazi oppressors.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainians-struggle-to-persuade-russia-relatives-over-putin-propaganda-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">2 million people have fled Ukraine since Russia&#39;s invasion, UN says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217895ed80ca400192ce745?format=jpeg\" height=\"3840\" width=\"5119\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine station\"/><figcaption>People wait for trains at a train station in Kyiv on February 24, 2022, the day Russia invaded Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Pierre Crom/Getty Images)</p></figcaption></figure><p>Filippo Grandi, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, tweeted Tuesday morning:</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>That&#39;s about 4.5% of Ukraine&#39;s total population of 44 million, per <a href=\"https://datatopics.worldbank.org/world-development-indicators/\">World Bank data</a>.</p><p>Multiple countries in Europe have suspended visa and COVID-19 quarantine requirements for Ukrainian refugees fleeing the conflict.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine and Russia agree to open evacuation corridor out of Sumy<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62274ac5913301001822c309?format=jpeg\" height=\"1133\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Buses wait during evacuations out of Sumy, Ukraine\"/><figcaption>Screenshot from Ukrainian government video showing buses wait during evacuations out of Sumy, Ukraine, on March 8, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Deputy Head for President&#39;s Office, Ukraine via Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine said it agreed with Russia to open an evacuation corridor out of the northeastern city of Sumy on Tuesday for civilians trying to flee the violence.</p><p>Sumy governor Dmitro Zhivitskiy said the corridor would lead to the city of Poltava, in central Ukraine, Reuters reported.</p><p>Ukraine&#39;s foreign ministry posted video of the evacuation, which included foreign students, on Tuesday morning:</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;MFA of Ukraine 🇺🇦 charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Previous efforts to open &#34;humanitarian corridors&#34; in Ukraine had failed, with Ukraine accusing Russian forces of shelling civilians trying to escape.</p><p>Russia on Monday also offered to open several &#34;humanitarian corridors&#34; on the condition that they end in Russia or its ally, Belarus. Ukraine called that proposal &#34;immoral.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Canadian politician pushes for the revival of the Trump-backed Keystone XL oil pipeline to replace Russian imports to the US<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6226d7cfdcce010019a7259b?format=jpeg\" height=\"1346\" width=\"1794\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Deer gather at a depot used to store pipes for the planned Keystone XL oil pipeline in Gascoyne, North Dakota.\"/><figcaption>Deer gather at a depot used to store pipes for the planned Keystone XL oil pipeline in Gascoyne, North Dakota, January 25, 2017.<p class=\"copyright\">Terray Sylvester/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><p>The premier of Alberta, Canada, is pushing for the the revival of the Keystone XL oil pipeline project that President Joe Biden canceled in January 2021. The move would boost US energy security amid the war in Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;If the United States is serious about this, they could come back to the table and help us build Keystone XL,&#34; Jason Kenney told a Monday news conference.</p><p>Kenney added that had Biden not shut down plans for the pipeline, the &#34;democratic energy&#34; it provided could have, by the end of the year, been displacing the &#34;Russian conflict oil that&#39;s filled with the blood of Ukrainians.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/keystone-oil-pipeline-alberta-premier-urges-revival-russia-ukraine-energy-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s ambassador told Russian diplomats to seek mental help when they repeated Putin&#39;s talking points<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62270eb4990863001998db55?format=jpeg\" height=\"2453\" width=\"3271\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Sergiy Kyslytsya, United Nations permanent representative of Ukraine, holds up a printout of a retweet of Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.\"/><figcaption>Sergiy Kyslytsya, Ukraine&#39;s UN permanent representative, holds up a printout of a retweet by Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.<p class=\"copyright\">Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine&#39;s ambassador to the United Nations delivered a cynical quip to Russian diplomats at a Security Council meeting on Monday night, suggesting they seek mental help for continuing to push the Kremlin&#39;s talking points on the invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>At the meeting, Ambassador Sergiy Kyslytsya held a printout of a tweet by the Russian embassy in the UK, which published a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russias-latest-justification-for-invasion-ukraine-stopping-war-in-ukraine-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b1db4ec65e6f5ac0ed84b8c94dee1b71\">claim by Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov</a>&#160;that &#34;the goal of Russia&#39;s special military operation is to stop any war that could take place on Ukrainian territory or that could start from there.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Let me remind the Russian diplomats that in London, in case of need for mental help, you can dial NHS line 111. Thank you,&#34; Kyslytsya said, referring to the UK&#39;s National Health Service.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-russia-ambassador-mental-help-nhs-hotline-putin-war-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Deputy mayor of Mariupol says the city has no water or heating, and is running out of food<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62174ea745889c0019d20cd4?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian soldiers ride in a military vehicle\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian soldiers ride in a military vehicle in Mariupol, Ukraine, on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Sergei Grits</p></figcaption></figure><p>Sergei Orlov, the deputy mayor of Mariupol, told the BBC&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/m0015495\">&#34;Today&#34; program</a> in an interview aired Tuesday that his city had gone seven days &#34;without any utilities, without water, heat, and supply.&#34;</p><p>Mariupol, a strategic port city on the Azov Sea, has been besieged and shelled by Russian forces for almost a week. The city is located between the Donbas and Crimea, which Russia annexed in 2014, and taking control of it would allow pro-Russian forces from those regions to join up.</p><p>Orlov said there was not enough food: &#34;The number of food is not enough for ten days ... We still have some opportunities to provide our citizens with water, supply tanks in some districts of the city and people collect water from there. But we are not able to give them food because there is no food in the city.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia destroyed a hospital in Mariupol and is targeting schools and kindergartens, deputy mayor says<p>Sergei Orlov, deputy mayor of Mariupol, told the BBC&#39;s &#34;Today&#34; program in an interview aired Tuesday that Russian forces had destroyed a hospital and were targeting &#34;schools, kindergartens, and hospitals.&#34;</p><p>&#34;They even tried to destroy blood collection hospitals,&#34; he said.</p><p>Orlov said Hospital No. 9 in Primorsky District was destroyed because of artillery bombing and shelling from Russian aircraft.</p><p>The BBC said it could not verify Orlov&#39;s remarks about the hospital&#39;s destruction and targeting of schools.</p><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin previously said that no civilians would be harmed in his invasion of Ukraine. The UN&#39;s rights body <a href=\"https://news.un.org/en/story/2022/03/1113372\">said</a> on Sunday it had recorded 1,123 civilian deaths since the invasion began on February 24.</p><p>In the &#34;Today&#34; interview, Orlov estimated that &#34;hundreds&#34; of people in Mariupol had died, but said it was &#34;impossible to calculate&#34; the exact number.</p><p>&#34;He wants Ukraine without Ukrainians,&#34; Orlov said of Putin.</p><p>He <a href=\"https://twitter.com/CNN/status/1500896333212831745\">told CNN&#39;s Jim Sciutto</a> on Monday he had information that Russian forces were targeting humanitarian corridors for Ukrainian citizens, and reiterated calls for a cease-fire.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">A Trump-era national security official suggested the US deploy all of its ballistic-missile submarines to see whether Putin is &#39;really bluffing&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62270956dcce010019a725f7?format=jpeg\" height=\"3378\" width=\"4504\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Retired Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg speaks at a White House podium in a briefing\"/><figcaption>Retired Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg.<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Retired US Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg on Monday suggested what he seemed to tout as a &#34;creative&#34; solution to Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine: Activate the entire US fleet of ballistic-missile submarines to see whether Russian President Vladimir Putin is &#34;really bluffing&#34; on nuclear threats.</p><p>&#34;You know, we&#39;ve generally got between five and six ballistic-missile submarines &#8212; the boomers &#8212; at sea at any one time,&#34; Kellogg said on the Fox News show &#34;Jesse Watters Primetime.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Flush the whole fleet, put every boomer we&#39;ve got at sea, and we can crew them and put them out there. And you say: &#39;Look, we&#39;re not going to back off from a nuclear concern that you&#39;ve got,&#39;&#34; the general said.</p><p>&#34;You know, go all in, bluff him &#8212; you know, he&#39;s &#8212; let&#39;s see if he&#39;s really bluffing or not,&#34; Kellogg continued.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-nuclear-trump-national-security-adviser-says-ballistic-missile-submarine-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian intelligence claims that top Russian general Vitaly Gerasimov has been killed outside of Kharkiv<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62272943dcce010019a7272d?format=jpeg\" height=\"751\" width=\"1002\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Vitaly Gerasimov,\"/><figcaption>Major General Vitaly Gerasimov, the first deputy commander of Russia&#39;s 41st army.<p class=\"copyright\">Ukrainian military intelligence</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian military intelligence said it killed a top Russian general on Monday, in what would be the second high-ranking loss since the invasion began.</p><p>Major General Vitaly Gerasimov, the first deputy commander of Russia&#39;s 41st army, was killed in Kharkiv, the intelligence unit of the Ukrainian defense ministry&#160;<a href=\"https://gur.gov.ua/content/pid-kharkovom-likvidovano-heneralmaiora-rosiiskoi-armii.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"a5cf63f36ab3c3c55f0af33f4532caa0\">said in a statement</a>.</p><p>Christo Grozev, the executive director of the open-source investigative outlet Bellingcat,&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/christogrozev/status/1500959074653024259\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9d02f22bb5d67d1855fa8aeaea9a3ec7\">tweeted Monday</a>&#160;that a Russian source had confirmed Gerasimov&#39;s death. There were no specifics on the death, and neither Russian officials nor state-run media have confirmed the death.</p><p>Alongside the statement, the Ukrainian defense ministry released&#160;<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j2Bvc12476k\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"26f2870352c6ed147755cc3e7a7511af\">audio of an intercepted phone call</a>&#160;between what it said were two Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) officers discussing the death and criticizing Russia&#39;s secure military communication platform.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-says-killed-russia-general-vitaly-gerasimov-intercepted-fsb-call-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia warns oil prices could hit $300 a barrel if the US and Europe reject Russian oil, says the move would have &#39;catastrophic consequences&#39;<p>Russia warned of $300-a-barrel oil and threatened to cut off gas supply to Europe amid sweeping Western sanctions over the invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>The message came a day after US Secretary of State Antony Blinken told&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/us-active-talks-allies-banning-russian-oil-imports-blinken-says-rcna18893\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"0f2ddadd2982bb2a853f425b8b57f15e\">NBC</a>&#160;the US was discussing a ban on Russian oil with Europe.</p><p>&#34;It is absolutely clear that a rejection of Russian oil would lead to catastrophic consequences for the global market,&#34; Russian deputy prime minister Alexander Novak &#8212; who also oversees energy affairs &#8212; said on state television on Monday, according to a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/russia-warns-west-300-per-barrel-oil-cuts-eu-gas-supply-2022-03-07/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ddd8e6a31eb34c780c74809120238a19\">Reuters</a>&#160;translation. &#34;The surge in prices would be unpredictable. It would be $300 per barrel if not more.&#34;</p><p>Oil futures are currently about $120 a barrel after surging 60% year-to-date on the back of fears about supply disruption. Russia is the world&#39;s third-largest oil producer. The country also supplies about 40% of Europe&#39;s gas demand and the jitters sent Dutch gas futures &#8212; the European benchmark &#8212; soaring 80% on Monday.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/commodities/russia-warns-300-dollars-barrel-oil-europe-natural-gas-supply-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div in Ukraine and in neighboring countries, including Russia,&#34; Grossi told the Board.</p><p>Last week, a Russian missile struck a building at Ukraine&#39;s Zaporizhzhya nuclear power plant.
