membership into the 27-nation bloc amid the Russian invasion.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Video shows Russian mortar strike that killed Ukrainian family fleeing invasion<p>Photo and video show the deaths of a young Ukrainian family at the hands of a Russian mortar strike as they tried to escape the violence on Sunday.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/mar/07/ukraine-volodymr-zelenskiy-vows-revenge-russia-forces-fleeing-family-civilians-killed-shelling-irpin-town\">The Guardian</a> reported that eight civilians in Irpin northwest of Kyiv died in the attack.</p><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the attack and vowed to punish &#34;everyone who committed atrocities in the war.&#34;</p><p>Warning: Readers may find the video and photos linked to in this story disturbing.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-strike-kills-ukrainians-escaping-violence-photo-video-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read More</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia says it will stop attacking Ukraine if it gives up territory and promises never to join an international alliance<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61645b469c7bd90019158411?format=jpeg\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin.<p class=\"copyright\">Vladimir Smirnov\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia said Ukraine must give up territory and swear never to join international alliances if it wants the invasion to stop.</p><p>The Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on Monday that Russia had told Ukraine those demands, and that &#34;they were told that all this can be stopped in a moment,&#34; <a href=\"https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2022-03-07/kremlin-says-russian-military-action-will-stop-in-a-moment-if-ukraine-meets-conditions\">Reuters reported</a>.</p><p>The demands involve Kyiv acknowledging the Ukrainian regions of Crimea &#8212; which Russia annexed in 2014 &#8212; as Russian territory, and Donetsk and Luhansk as independent states, Peskov said.</p><p>Ukraine must also change its consitution to make it a politically neutral country and promise to &#34;reject any aims to enter any bloc,&#34; Peskov said.</p><p>He did not specify what international bloc he was referring to, but Russia is firmly against Ukraine&#39;s joining NATO and cited it as a reason to invade. Ukraine also applied to join the European Union last week.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia and Ukraine&#39;s foreign ministers to meet on Thursday<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6225f374990863001998a8f2?format=jpeg\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba and Russia foreign minister Sergei Lavrov\"/><figcaption>A composite image of Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.<p class=\"copyright\">Carolyn Kaster/Pool via Reuters; Shamil Zhumatov/Pool/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine and Russia&#39;s foreign ministers, Dmytro Kuleba and Sergei Lavrov, are set to meet this Thursday, March 10, Turkey&#39;s foreign minister announced.</p><p>They are the highest-ranking officials to meet since Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine started on February 24.</p><p>They are set to meet on the sidelines of Turkey&#39;s Antalya Diplomacy Forum, Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu tweeted.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Hope this step will lead to peace and stability,&#34; he said.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Third round of Russia-Ukraine talks to take place later Monday<p>Russia and Ukraine are preparing for a third round of talks in Belarus later on Monday, multiple reports said.</p><p>The Belarusian state-owned BelTA news agency reported that the discussions would take place at 12 p.m. GMT (7 a.m. ET) Monday, Reuters reported. Russia&#39;s state-owned <a href=\"https://sputniknews.com/20220306/live-updates-over-163000-people-evacuated-from-areas-of-russias-spec-op-in-ukraine-1093642323.html\">Sputnik</a> news agency also reported that talks were taking place later Monday.</p><p>Mykhailo Podoliak, an advisor to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Podolyak_M/status/1500792966725742594\">tweeted</a> that he was on his way to the talks, but said they would take place 4 p.m. Kyiv time (1 p.m. GMT, or 8 a.m. ET).</p><p>The first two rounds of talks between Russia and Ukraine, which also took place in Belarus, ended without cease-fire agreements and neither side achieving their aims.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine says Kremlin offer of &#39;humanitarian corridors&#39; to Russia is &#39;completely immoral&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c50bf101faf0019295fba?format=jpeg\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\" alt=\"President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky holds a press conference\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky attending a press conference in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.<p class=\"copyright\">Ukrainian Presidency/Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine slammed Russia&#39;s offer to open &#34;humanitarian corridors&#34; from Ukrainian cities to Russia or Belarus.</p><p>&#34;This is a completely immoral story. People&#39;s suffering is used to create the desired television picture,&#34; a spokesman for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky&#39;s office said, Reuters reported.</p><p>&#34;These are citizens of Ukraine, they should have the right to evacuate to the territory of Ukraine,&#34; they said.</p><p>Deputy Prime Minister Iryna Vereshchuk also called the Russian proposal an &#34;unacceptable option.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian armed forces offers &#39;humanitarian corridors&#39; for people to evacuate &#8212; as long as it&#39;s to Russia or its ally, Belarus<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6225cf68990863001998a56c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1322\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Woman fleeing Ukraine in Poland\"/><figcaption>A woman covers herself with a blanket after fleeing from Ukraine and arriving at the border crossing in Medyka, Poland, on March 7, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Markus Schreiber/AP</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Russian Armed Forces offered to open six &#34;humanitarian corridors&#34; on Monday for people in Ukraine to flee to Russia or its ally, Belarus, the state media outlets <a href=\"https://tass.com/world/1418091\">Tass</a> and <a href=\"https://ria.ru/20220307/ukraina-1777018926.html\">Ria</a> reported.</p><p>The routes start from the Ukrainian cities of Kyiv, Kharkov, Sumy and Mariupol, and either end in Belarus, with which Ukraine shares its northern border, or Russia, with which Ukraine shares its eastern border, the outlets said. People arriving to Belarus could then fly to Russia, the reports said.</p><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin claimed in an <a href=\"http://en.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/66181\">essay</a> last year that Russians and Ukrainians were &#34;one people,&#34; and also threatened this weekend to destroy Ukrainian statehood.</p><p>The Russian defense ministry said the offer to open the corridors was made following a request from French President Emmanuel Macron, BBC Kyiv correspondent James Waterhouse <a href=\"https://twitter.com/JamWaterhouse/status/1500723715235106823\">reported</a>.&#160;</p><p>But a spokesman for France&#39;s Elysée Palace denied the claim, saying Macron had asked that civilians be able to evacuate.</p><p>&#34;The president of the Republic has neither requested nor obtained corridors to Russia after his conversation with Vladimir Putin,&#34; the spokesman told <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BFMTV/status/1500732049396797441\">BFMTV</a>.</p><p>&#34;It&#39;s another way for Putin to push his narrative and say that it is the Ukrainians who are the aggressors and they are the ones who offer asylum to everyone.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK defense ministry warns Russia is likely destroying Ukrainian communications infrastructure<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Ministry of Defence 🇬🇧 (@DefenceHQ) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1500727508014088192\">March 7, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>The UK Ministry of Defence said Monday morning that Russia was &#34;probably&#34; targeting Ukraine&#39;s communications infrastructure to prevent people from accessing the internet or reliable news sources.</p><p>It cited recent internet outages reported in the cities of Mariupol, Kyiv, and Kharkiv.</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Google&#39;s Ukrainian employees are circulating a letter calling to ban RT globally, not just in Europe<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6170445dfee39f0018fa758c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1600\" width=\"2133\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Google CEO Sundar Pichai wearing a suit and a black face mask in a formal room in the White House\"/><figcaption>Google CEO Sundar Pichai listens as U.S. President Joe Biden speaks during a meeting about cybersecurity in the East Room of the White House on August 25, 2021 in Washington, DC.<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian employees at Google, both in Ukraine and abroad, called on the tech giant to ban the Russian state broadcaster RT from YouTube entirely and do more to help workers in the days after Russia invaded Ukraine.</p><p>Google took action against RT and other media outlets affiliated with the Russian state,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/youtube-blocks-rt-state-funded-russian-media-after-ukraine-attacks-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"30d9515321eec4968384ea4d340c655c\">blocking them from generating YouTube ad revenue</a>&#160;on February 25 and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-blocks-russia-rt-sputnik-apps-play-store-europe-ukraine-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"f7600661b96a0f5804f1f32919bf453e\">banning the outlet from its platforms entirely in Europe</a>&#160;on Tuesday. It also&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-blocks-russia-rt-sputnik-apps-play-store-europe-ukraine-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"d43eee209cbb5aab380e8abde616e0f3\">blocked</a>&#160;RT and Sputnik from its app store in Europe.</p><p>But RT remains available to YouTube users in the US, where its channel has almost 5 million subscribers and features a banner saying it&#39;s the &#34;most watched news network&#34; on the platform.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-googlers-call-for-global-rt-ban-more-staff-help-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Nearly 5,000 class=\"slide\">Russia is recruiting Syrians to fight in Ukraine, report says<p>Russia is recruiting fighters from Syria to assist in their invasion of Ukraine, four US officials told <a rel=\"nofollow sponsored noindex\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"d674a64f33f72b6a3fec6c8be8b9bfd7\">The Wall Street Journal</a>.</p><p>Moscow hopes any had already been deployed to Ukraine. One official told The Journal some were already in Russia preparing.</p><p>Russia has been operating in Syria since 2015 when it launched a military intervention to help the Syrian government fight against rebels.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-recruiting-syrians-to-fight-in-ukraine-report-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">IAEA concerned that Ukraine nuclear plant is under Russian control<p>The International Atomic Energy Agency said it is concerned that the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in Enerhodar, Ukraine, is now under Russian command.</p><p>In a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/pressreleases/update-13-iaea-director-general-statement-on-situation-in-ukraine\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ca54161ef45a266b6bd345836febdfa0\">statement</a>&#160;on Sunday, the IAEA said that Ukraine needs to get approval from a Russian commander before they can do any management of the plant, including&#160;technical operations of its six reactor units.</p><p>&#34;The Director General expressed grave concern about this development,&#34; the statement said, adding that it&#39;s going against one of the pillars of nuclear safety.<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/iaea-concerned-that-zaporizhzhia-nuclear-plant-is-under-russian-command-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">TikTok suspends all live-streaming and content sharing in Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61b8debc13226f00198f6e11?format=jpeg\" height=\"400\" width=\"400\" charset=\"\" alt=\"tiktok logo AR\"/><figcaption>TikTok said it had &#34;no choice&#34; but to make the decision to suspend its content in Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">TikTok</p></figcaption></figure><p>TikTok on Sunday announced that it&#39;s suspending all live-<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-streaming\" data-site=\"bi\" data-keyword=\"streaming\" data-analytics-product-module=\"Auto-Linker\" data-analytics-product-area=\"link\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"1b7994c735a3d12452d2ba3892a73b47\">streaming</a> and content sharing in Russia.</p><p>The move comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin introduced a censorship law that restricts the ability to disseminate information to the public.</p><p>The social media platform said it views itself as a &#34;source of relief and human connection during a time of war when people are facing immense tragedy and isolation.&#34; Blinken said in an interview on NBC&#39;s &#34;Meet the Press.&#34;</p><p>The last sanction the US can impose over Russian President Vladimir Putin is a ban on the country&#39;s oil exports. As Insider&#39;s Mattathias Schwartz&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-ukraine-one-big-sanction-left-putin-russia-oil-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"9820e052669cebda165487c9192f9c44\">notes</a>, Russia&#39;s energy resources bring home more than $500 million per day, which makes up about half its government revenue. Poland are in talks to deliver warplanes to Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622444a3dcce010019a6f8fd?format=jpeg\" height=\"2550\" width=\"5100\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian Air Force MiG-29SMT landing in Ryazan, Russia, after a mission during exercise Aviadarts 2016.\"/><figcaption>Russian Air Force MiG-29SMT landing in Ryazan, Russia, after a mission during exercise Aviadarts 2016.<p class=\"copyright\">Daniele Faccioli/Stocktrek Images/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The US and Poland are discussing a deal that would involve Warsaw sending Soviet-era jets to Ukraine to help it defend itself against the ongoing Russian invasion, multiple media outlets reported Saturday.</p><p>In exchange for supplying Ukraine with the aircraft, Poland would receive F-19s from the US to help it backfill its stocks. US officials told Politico and The Wall Street Journal about the discussions with Poland.</p><p>The reports came after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky called on the US and other NATO nations to provide the country with warplanes, especially if they do not declare a no-fly zone over Ukraine.<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-poland-in-talks-to-give-ukraine-soviet-era-planes-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The International Monetary Fund said the war in Ukraine will greatly impact the global economy<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6224171e99086300199897ed?format=jpeg\" height=\"1857\" width=\"2476\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The seal for the International Monetary Fund is seen near the World Bank headquarters in Washington, DC on January 10, 2022.\"/><figcaption>The seal for the International Monetary Fund in Washington, DC on January 10, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">STEFANI REYNOLDS/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The IMF warned on Saturday that the crisis in Ukraine will &#34;have a severe impact on the global economy.&#34;&#160;</p><p>In a <a href=\"https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2022/03/05/pr2261-imf-staff-statement-on-the-economic-impact-of-war-in-ukraine\">statement</a>, the organization said its Executive Board met on Friday and said the economic consequences from the ongoing fighting &#34;are already very serious.&#34;</p><p>&#34;The war in Ukraine is resulting in tragic loss of life and human suffering, as well as causing massive damage to Ukraine&#39;s physical infrastructure,&#34; the statement said.&#160;</p><p>The statement said that prices for necessities including wheat have increased.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Price shocks will have an impact worldwide, especially on poor households for whom food and fuel are a higher proportion of expenses. Should the conflict escalate, the economic damage would be all the more devastating,&#34; the statement said.&#160;</p><p>The IMF also said that the sanctions placed on Russia will impact the global economy and financial markets, &#34;with significant spillovers to other countries.&#34;</p><p>The statement said countries would have to monitor the global economy as the crisis continues to figure out the best ways to respond.&#160;</p><p>&#34;This crisis will create complex policy tradeoffs, further complicating the policy landscape as the world economy recovers from the pandemic crisis,&#34; the IMF said.&#160;</p><p>They warned that countries with close ties to Ukraine and Russia&#39;s economy will be the most impacted.&#160;</p><p>The IMF added that they plan to bring Ukraine&#39;s request for $1.4 billion in emergency financing to the Executive Board for consideration as early as next week.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty becomes latest media group to suspend operations in Russia<p>Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty said on Saturday it was suspending operations in Russia in response to Kremlin attacks on the organization and the press in general.</p><p>RFE/RL, a nonprofit funded by a US government grant, announced the move in a <a href=\"https://pressroom.rferl.org/a/rferl-suspends-operations-in-russia-following-kremlin-attacks/31738011.html\">statement</a>, saying the Russian government initiated bankruptcy proceedings against its Russian entity and increased police pressure on journalists.</p><p>&#34;It is with the deepest regret that I announce the suspension of our physical operations in Moscow today,&#34; RFE/RL President and CEO Jamie Fly said, adding that the decision was &#34;forced upon us by the Putin regime&#39;s assault on the truth.&#34;</p><p>The statement also noted the law signed by Russian President Vladimir Putin on March 4 that <a href=\"https://cpj.org/2022/03/proposed-russian-legislation-threatens-15-years-in-prison-for-fake-information-about-ukraine-invasion/\">could subject journalist reporting on the war with Ukraine to up to 15 years in prison</a>.</p><p>&#34;Following years of threats, intimidation and harassment of our journalists, the Kremlin, desperate to prevent Russian citizens from knowing the truth about its illegal war in Ukraine, is now branding honest journalists as traitors to the Russian state,&#34; Fly said.</p><p>RFE/RL has been operating in Russia since 1991. The announcement comes after major media outlets like the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/news-outlets-cnn-bloomberg-bbc-suspending-operations-russia-putin-law-2022-3\">BBC and CNN</a> also said they were suspending operations in Russia.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/news-outlets-cnn-bloomberg-bbc-suspending-operations-russia-putin-law-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine shares dramatic footage that appears to show a Russian helicopter gunship shot down in flames<p>Footage appears to show the moment a Russian gunship helicopter was shot down by a man-portable air-defense system (MANPADS) in the Kyiv Oblast province of Ukraine.</p><p>In the video, a helicopter immediately bursts into flames and crashes to the ground after being targeted by a weapon.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Defence of Ukraine  (@DefenceU) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1500037338960965634?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 5, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>The footage was&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/DefenceU/status/1500037338960965634?s=20&#38;t=T1uDDBzKBF0KMpgZjwOCPQ\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"737671f9de92ea122e9a9ac2273cd4c1\">shared on Twitter</a>&#160;by the Ministry of Defence of Ukraine on Saturday morning.&#160;&#34;This is how the Russian occupiers are dying,&#34; Saturday marks the tenth day of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">Russia&#39;s war on its neighbor</a>.&#160;</p><p>Israel has condemned Putin&#39;s invasion of Ukraine and has offered to mediate between the two nations.&#160;&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/israeli-prime-minister-traveled-to-moscow-in-secret-to-meet-with-putin-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin warned that Ukraine will be &#39;blamed&#39; and warned that Ukraine could lose its statehood if its leaders &#34;continue doing what they are doing,&#34;&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/03/05/world/russia-ukraine/putin-ukraine-statehood\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"c088715796b53be91609178a441b88bf\">according to The New York Times</a>.</p><p>Putin, increasingly isolated from the West as he continues his military advance throughout Ukraine, rejected the country&#39;s resistance against his escalating invasion.</p><p>&#34;The current leadership needs to understand that if they continue doing what they are doing, they risk the future of Ukrainian statehood,&#34; Putin said during a meeting in Moscow. &#34;If that happens ... they will have to be blamed for that.&#34;</p><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has remained defiant in the face of Russia&#39;s attacks, rejecting offers to leave the country as he guides his citizenry through the conflict.</p><p>&#34;Our military, our national guard, our national police, our territory defense, special service, nationals of Ukraine, please carry on. and &#39;lost&#39; over its rejection of a no-fly zone<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f3bab96929400196c328d?format=jpeg\" height=\"1132\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Volodymyr Zelensky speaks at a podium with Ukraine&#39;s flag behind him\"/><figcaption>Volodymyr Zelensky speaks in a video he shared March 2, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Volodymyr Zelensky</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Ukrainian president criticized NATO after the alliance said it would not intervene in Ukraine by land or air, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/04/world/europe/zelensky-nato-no-fly-zone-ukraine.html\">The New York Times</a> reported.&#160;</p><p>NATO said it made the decision so it would not cause a bigger conflict with Russia.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We have a responsibility as NATO allies to prevent this war from escalating beyond Ukraine,&#34; which he could escalate into &#34;a full-fledged war in Europe, involving many more countries and causing much more human suffering,&#34; the Times reported.&#160;</p><p>Zelensky said the lack of a no-fly zone gave Russia &#34;a green light&#34; blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Lukas Biba  (@bibalukas) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1499804627495264262?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 4, on eye on this,&#34; Zelensky said during the speech, <a href=\"https://www.axios.com/zelensky-europe-speech-ukraine-rally-russia-war-8ca97595-e4e5-4c42-ba18-880ed8b1fd53.html\">according to Axios.</a></p><p>&#34;If we win, and I&#39;m sure we&#39;ll win, this will be the victory for the whole democratic world,&#34; he added.</p><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian officials say Russia is breaking its promise to allow humanitarian aid into a captured city<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61eca4492b43ff00185e2ab4?format=jpeg\" height=\"997\" width=\"1995\" charset=\"\" alt=\"russia ukraine\"/><figcaption>A convoy of Russian armored vehicles moves along a highway in Crimea, Tuesday, Jan. 18, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian officials in the Russian-occupied city of Kherson said that Russia has not allowed humanitarian corridors as agreed upon as food supplies run low, <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/03/04/kherson-ukraine-russia/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"fa6bfcd020c50302bf7485b6ee61650c\">according to The Washington Post.</a></p><p>On Thursday, Russian and Ukrainian leaders announced that temporary cease-fires would be implemented so that humanitarian corridors could be established in Kherson so that civilians could safely leave and so that food and medical supplies could be distributed.</p><p>On Friday, Stanislav, a Kherson local, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-stores-empty-food-running-out-russians-capture-kherson-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"56a2636ea06b044b2448bfb6e97945b2\">told Insider</a> that food supplies are scarce days into Russia&#39;s occupation, and that he was only able to secure food provisions for one day. &#34;There is simply no food in supermarkets,&#34; Stanislav told Insider.&#160;</p><p>On Wednesday, Russian forces <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-captures-first-major-city-kherson-ukraine-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"ecc8b890f83f6fc9807c035f046847dd\">gained full control</a> of Kherson, which is Ukraine&#39;s third-largest city and a strategic southern port city along the Black Sea.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-says-russia-not-allowing-humanitarian-aid-into-captured-city-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">CNN, BBC Russia, Bloomberg, CBS suspend operations in Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6222b8b49908630019988f6f?format=jpeg\" height=\"1798\" width=\"3597\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The CNN center is seen in downtown Atlanta, Georgia, on October 16, 2021.\"/><figcaption>The CNN center is seen in downtown Atlanta, Georgia, on October 16, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Daniel Slim/AFP/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>CNN, BBC Russia, Bloomberg suspended their operations in Russia on Friday after Russia&#39;s parliament passed a draconian media censorship law that punishes independent journalists and those who publish &#34;false information&#34; about Russia&#39;s war in Ukraine with up to 15 years in prison.</p><p>The bill, approved by Russia&#39;s state Duma, is expected to be signed by Putin and go into effect on Saturday. <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/04/world/europe/russia-censorship-media-crackdown.html\">According to The New York Times,</a>&#160;a journalist could face penalties under the new law for describing the war in Ukraine as a &#34;war.&#34;</p><p>Bloomberg&#39;s editor in chief <a href=\"https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/1499874641875283969\">said that</a> the &#34;change to the criminal code, which seems designed to turn any independent reporter into a criminal purely by association, makes it impossible to continue any semblance of normal journalism inside the country.&#34;</p><p>&#34;This legislation appears to criminal ise the process of independent journalism,&#34; the BBC told Insider <a href=\"https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/1499874641875283969\">in a statement.</a> &#34;Our BBC News service in Russian will continue to operate from outside Russia.&#34;</p><p>&#34;CNN will stop broadcasting in Russia while we continue to evaluate the situation and our next steps moving forward,&#34; a CNN spokesperson <a href=\"https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/1499863796692758535?s=20&#38;t=RxkwUdChdO40lt8URPDSwQ\">said</a> in a statement.&#160;</p><p>CBS News also followed suit on Friday. &#34;CBS News is not currently broadcasting from Russia as we monitor the circumstances for our team on the ground given the new media laws passed today,&#34; the network <a href=\"https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/1499901638164819973\">said in a statement.</a></p><p><br/><br/><br/></p></div><div class=\"slide\">UN sets up independent commission to investigate class=\"slide\">Russia starts blocking and throttling Western tech platforms including Facebook and Twitter<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621d5881101faf0019298cd2?format=jpeg\" station on February 28, 2022 in Kyiv, Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Chris McGrath/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia is beginning to block or limit access to Western technology platforms, including Facebook and Twitter, cutting itself and its citizens off from the rest of the world&#39;s internet in drastic fashion as the Ukraine invasion intensifies and criticism increases.</p><p>Roskomnadzor, the country&#39;s tech and communications regulator, said Friday it has fully blocked access to Facebook, owned by the US tech giant Meta Platforms.</p><p>The regulator did not specify if access would also be restricted to Instagram or WhatsApp, which are also part of Meta.</p><p>Twitter has been&#160;<a with up to 15 years in prison<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62222acde97f930019fa907f?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Security forces detain a woman holding a “No war” sign at an anti-war demonstration on February 24, 2022 in St. Petersburg, Russia.\"/><figcaption>Security forces detain a woman holding a “No war” sign at an anti-war demonstration on February 24, 2022 in St. Petersburg, Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Mihailicenko/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia&#39;s legislature approved a draft law on Friday that would punish anyone who shares &#34;false information&#34; about the war in Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>The new law targets &#34;criminal liability&#34; for those who share &#34;false information about the activities of the armed forces (AF) of the Russian Federation, for &#39;discrediting&#39; the Armed Forces, and &#39;calls to prevent their use,&#39;&#34;&#160;<a href=\"https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/5240327\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"1cada8ba11a7b70f474738f39d7d3634\">according to the Russian media outlet Kommersant</a>.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-legislature-pass-law-punish-false-information-ukraine-jail-time-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin says he has &#39;no ill intention&#39; toward Russia&#39;s neighbors as his troops continue their brutal assault on Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;We see no need to exacerbate the situation or worsen our relations,&#34; Putin said on the state-owned Russia-24 news station, according to a translation from Financial Times&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/polinaivanovva/status/1499716111188860928?s=20&#38;t=FV1R0BgDXL530dYA-bjAJA\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7e6ebdbb45ba6d68e1401ea4b2b936f6\">reporter</a>&#160;Polina Ivanova.</p><p>Putin added: &#34;I think everyone should think about normalizing relations and cooperating normally.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-no-ill-intention-toward-russias-neighbors-as-troops-attack-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kremlin staff didn&#39;t expect Putin to invade Ukraine and were shocked by the severity of Western sanctions, report says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6221fa0104579d001893fac3?format=jpeg\" height=\"976\" width=\"1302\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin seen on March 03, 2022 in Moscow, Russia.\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin seen on March 3, 2022 in Moscow, Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Kremlin Press Office/Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Kremlin officials say they didn&#39;t know Russian President Vladimir Putin would invade Ukraine and were shocked by the severity of Western sanctions imposed upon it, <a href=\"https://www.agents.media/rossijskie-vlasti-sanktsii/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"524d2d48f93a7a3d89af486ad920e5a8\">the independent Russian investigative outlet Agency reported</a>.</p><p>One unnamed senior official said people in the Kremlin &#34;did not know&#34; that it would be an all-out invasion and that many were shocked when news of the military assault broke, the outlet said.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kremlin-staff-didnt-expect-ukraine-invasion-sanctions-shock-report-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">NATO chief warns &#39;days to come are likely to be worse&#39; but says he will not send troops to Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/620d26a0b20df700180a21e8?format=jpeg\" height=\"1308\" width=\"1744\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Jens Stoltenberg\"/><figcaption>NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg in Brussels on June 14, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Olivier Hoslet/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>NATO Secretary Jens Stoltenberg <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BBCWorld/status/1499730727541354498\">told reporters in Brussels on Friday</a>:</p><p>&#34;This is the worst military aggression in Europe for decades, with cities under siege, schools, hospitals, and residential buildings shelled, reckless actions around a nuclear plant last night, and many civilians killed or wounded.&#34;</p><p>&#34;The days to come are likely to be worse, with more death, more suffering and more destruction as Russian armed forces bring in heavier weaponry and continue their attacks across the country,&#34; he said.</p><p>He said, however: &#34;Allies agree that we should not have NATO planes operating over Ukrainian airspace or NATO troops on Ukrainian territory.&#34;</p><p>Ukraine is not a NATO member country, and Russia has strongly spoken against the possibility of Ukraine joining the alliance.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">US calls attack on Russian nuclear power plant a war crime<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6221de36d72a250019740e2c?format=jpeg\" height=\"844\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant\"/><figcaption>Surveillance footage shows the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine during a fire following clashes with Russian troops on March 4, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The US Embassy in Kyiv <a href=\"https://twitter.com/USEmbassyKyiv/status/1499708231903547394\">tweeted</a> on Friday in response to the Russian attack on the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant: &#34;It is a war crime to attack a nuclear power plant. Putin&#39;s shelling of Europe&#39;s largest nuclear plant takes his reign of terror one step further.&#34;</p><p>Earlier on Friday, US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm <a href=\"https://twitter.com/SecGranholm/status/1499577621163626496\">described</a>&#160;Russia&#39;s military operations near the plant as &#34;reckless&#34; and said they &#34;must cease.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Experts say Ukraine&#39;s nuclear power plants are built to withstand war, leaving little chance of a Chernobyl-like disaster<p>Despite dire warnings from Ukrainian officials, fighting at any of Ukraine&#39;s nuclear power plants is extremely unlikely to trigger a nuclear disaster, experts said.</p><p>Nuclear power plants can&#39;t &#34;blow up&#34; like an atom bomb, and although the war in Ukraine is a catastrophe for millions of people, an attack on its nuclear facilities has no prospect of wiping out an entire continent.</p><p>Experts say that modern power-plant design, and nuclear physics itself, make that almost impossible.</p><p>&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nuclear-disaster-in-ukraine-unlikely-despite-russia-invasion-experts-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant&#39;s radiation levels are stable, officials say<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6221f25e04579d001893fa0a?format=jpeg\" height=\"1334\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"IAEA Director General Rafael Mariano Grossi speaks into a microphone\"/><figcaption>IAEA Director General Rafael Mariano Grossi speaks about the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Vienna, Austria, on March 4, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Lisa Leutner</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian and international energy officials said radiation levels at the&#160;Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, which Russia seized Friday morning, were stable.</p><p>Oleksandr Starukh, the head of the Zaporizhia regional military administration, said Russian forces had taken the plant but that its &#34;nuclear safety is now guaranteed,&#34; citing the facility&#39;s director.</p><p>He added that nuclear safety levels were &#34;stable, because the appropriate mode of operation of the units was turned on in time.&#34;</p><p>The State Inspectorate for Nuclear Regulation of Ukraine said employees were still working at the plant to keep it safe. It reported no changes in radiation levels, but warned that could change.</p><p>In&#160;<a href=\"https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/pressreleases/update-9-iaea-director-general-statement-on-the-situation-in-ukraine\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"f7ea2a7b3876e49f1288b8e8de4d982f\">a Friday statement</a>, IAEA chief Rafael Mariano Grossi said the plant was hit by a Russian projectile and that there was no change in radiation levels.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-forces-attacking-zaporizhzhia-nuclear-power-plant-ukraine-ap-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s president has survived at least 3 assassination attempts from Russian-backed agents in the past week, report says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62181b32d0009b001904a98f?format=jpeg\" height=\"2001\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky holds a press conference in Kyiv, Ukraine on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Ukrainian Presidency/Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com/?id=35871X943606&#38;isjs=1&#38;jv=15.2.3-stackpath&#38;sref=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Fukraine-zelensky-russia-backed-assassination-attempts-report-2022-3%3Fr%3DUS%26IR%3DT&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thetimes.co.uk%2Farticle%2Fzelensky-survives-three-assassination-attempts-in-days-xnstdfdfc&#38;xs=1&#38;xtz=0&#38;xuuid=68bccff2e69dedade29e41982547bc7d&#38;xcust=xid%3Afr1646392198901bjb&#38;xjsf=other_click__contextmenu%20%5B2%5D\">The Times of London reported</a> that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky survived three assassination attempts over the past week.</p><p>The report said the attacks came from mercenaries with the Wagner Group private army as well as Chechen special forces working under Ramzan Kadyrov, the head of Russia&#39;s Chechen Republic.</p><p>Kadyrov and the head of the Wagner Group, Yevgeny Prigozhin, are both allies of Russian President Vladimir Putin.</p><p>Ukrainian security officials were tipped off by people working for Russia&#39;s Federal Security Service (FSB) who opposed the invasion, The Times reported.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-zelensky-russia-backed-assassination-attempts-report-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">City of Mariupol &#39;subjected to intense Russian strikes,&#39; UK intelligence says<figure><img It is the largest nuclear plant in Europe.</p><p>Oleksandr Starukh, head of the area&#39;s regional military administration, also confirmed reports that a fire had <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-forces-attacking-zaporizhzhia-nuclear-power-plant-ukraine-ap-2022-3\">broken out at the plant amid intense fighting</a> in the area earlier in the day.</p><p>&#34;The fire that broke out was localized by our [State Emergency Service] units. There was a fight. statement</a>.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Safety of Ukraine&#39;s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant has been secured, officials say<p>The safety of Ukraine&#39;s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant has tweet by AFP on Friday.</p><p>&#34;The director of the plant said that the nuclear safety is now guaranteed,&#34; said Oleksandr Starukh, the governor of Zaporizhzhia province, per the spokesperson Andriy Tuz accused Russia of shelling the facility. &#34;We demand that they stop the heavy weapons fire,&#34; he said, <a Press.</a></p><p>Tuz also said there was no threat of radiation spilling out from the plant, per the AP.</p><p>A live-streamed video feed from the plant appeared to show at least one building on fire and sporadic explosions at the facility.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-forces-attacking-zaporizhzhia-nuclear-power-plant-ukraine-ap-2022-3\" They will then be walking until the Berlin Wall.&#34;</p><p>He added that Ukraine does not plan to attack Russia in return &#8212; in part because they are not in NATO and do not have nuclear weapons.</p><p>&#34;How many people have to be exploded?&#34; he asked.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;TIME (@TIME) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1499505743204134923\">March 3, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">US grants Temporary Protected Status to Ukrainians<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62214e34d72a250019740936?format=jpeg\" height=\"4890\" width=\"6520\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Alejandro Mayorkas in front of US flag\"/><figcaption>Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas speaks during a news conference at the National Press Club on September 9, 2021 in Washington, DC. Mayorkas spoke about a range of issues, including domestic extremism, Afghan refugees and the U.S.-Mexico border.<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainians residing in the United States will be protected from the threat of deportation for at least the next 18 months, the Department of Homeland Security announced Thursday evening.</p><p>&#34;Russia&#39;s premeditated and unprovoked attack on Ukraine has resulted in an ongoing war, senseless violence, and Ukrainians forced to seek refuge in other countries,&#34; DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas <a href=\"https://www.dhs.gov/news/2022/03/03/secretary-mayorkas-designates-ukraine-temporary-protected-status-18-months\">said in a statement</a>.</p><p>Temporary Protected Status is awarded to residents of countries who are facing natural or human-made disasters.</p><p>Since the start of the February 24 war, roughly one million Ukrainians have fled the country, the vast majority to neighboring Poland.</p><p>There are as many 96,000 Ukrainians living in the US who are not citizens, <a href=\"https://www.americanprogress.org/article/what-the-european-union-and-united-states-need-to-do-to-address-the-migration-crisis-in-ukraine/\">according to the Center for American Progress</a>, including 27,000 who are undocumented.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian presidential adviser said talks with Russia led to an agreement on humanitarian corridors<figure><img SERGEI SUPINSKY/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The second round of talks between Ukraine and Russia have come to a close, but Adviser to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, humanitarian corridors in order to evacuate citizens and provide aid where needed.&#160;</p><p>There will be a temporary ceasefire to allow citizens to leave, Podolyak told Thursday lashed out at Western leaders and claimed they, not Moscow, are stoking the fears of a nuclear war.</p><p>&#34;I would like to point out that these are statements of the Western politicians, they are repeating nuclear war,&#34; Lavrov said during a news conference with state-run and foreign media.</p><p><br/><a refrain from fighting back.&#160;</p><p>He published a list of rules and advisories for residents to follow, including that civilians &#34;stop at the first request&#34; and &#34;do not fight.&#34;</p><p>The others are:</p><ul><li>To only go out into the city during the day.</li><li>To abide by a 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew.</li><li>Only cars carrying food or medicines can enter the city.</li><li>Public transport will run so that workers in bakeries, shops, and pharmacies can go to work.</li><li>Pedestrians must walk one by one or two by two.</li><li>Cars must drive slowly and DeSantis was there to announce a $20 million grant program for cybersecurity training.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I mean can you imagine if he went into France?&#34; he said of Russian President Vladimir Putin. &#34;Would they do anything to put up a fight? Probably not.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ron-desantis-says-france-would-fold-in-russian-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">US intel says China asked Russia to not invade Ukraine until Winter Olympics were over: reports<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62204d1f04579d001893c320?format=jpeg\" height=\"1042\" width=\"1390\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on February 4.<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Senior Chinese officials are believed to have asked their Russian counterparts to delay invading Ukraine until the Winter Olympics in Beijing were over, multiple news outlets reported, citing Western senior intelligence officials including those from the Biden administration.</p><p>A Western intelligence report detailed the exchange, said to have taken place in early February, between Chinese and Russian officials. The New York Times first <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/02/us/politics/russia-ukraine-china.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"a95811024cfb2c6c0dddc9991d8254e2\">reported</a>&#160;the news.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-asked-russia-not-to-invade-ukraine-olympics-over-report-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Germany has seized the world&#39;s largest megayacht, which belongs to a Russian oligarch<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5fc8c757b7da001ee11825?format=jpeg\" height=\"2912\" width=\"3882\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Alisher Usmanov\"/><figcaption>Alisher Usmanov owns the Dilbar, a 512-foot yacht that weighs 15,917 tons.<p class=\"copyright\">Mikhail Svetlov/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Germany seized the Russian billionaire Alisher Usmanov&#39;s megayacht, <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/giacomotognini/2022/03/02/germans-seize-russian-billionaire-alisher-usmanovs-mega-yacht/?utm_source=ForbesMainTwitter&#38;utm_medium=social&#38;utm_campaign=socialflowForbesMainTwitter&#38;sh=2e2d1c6a52dd\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"44cf4a1e77aa09dfeb9704515110fd70\">according to Forbes, which cited unnamed sources</a>.</p><p>Usmanov&#39;s yacht, which has been docked in Hamburg, Germany, for months for a refitting, would be the first known to be seized since Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine began February 24.</p><p>Dilbar, a 512-foot yacht that weighs 15,917 tons, &#34;is the largest motor yacht in the world by gross tonnage,&#34; according to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.lurssen.com/en/new-build/yachts/dilbar/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"2d06db928b3f0959bbd25fd1bd85afb6\">Lürssen</a>, the German ship&#39;s maker.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/germany-seizes-russian-billionaire-alisher-usmanovs-mega-yacht-forbes-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">One million people have fled Ukraine during Russia&#39;s invasion: UN refugee agency<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62201cedd72a25001973d5a4?format=jpeg\" height=\"4621\" width=\"6161\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People fleeing Ukraine receiving food, clothing, and toiletries at a train station in Berlin.\"/><figcaption>People fleeing Ukraine received food, clothing, and toiletries at a train station in Berlin.<p class=\"copyright\">Hannibal Hanschke / Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>One million people fled Ukraine in the first week of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-announces-military-assault-against-ukraine-in-surprise-speech-2022-2\">Russia&#39;s invasion</a>, according to Filippo Grandi, the UN&#39;s high commissioner for refugees.</p><p>&#34;For many millions more, inside Ukraine, it&#39;s time for guns to fall silent, so that life-saving humanitarian assistance can be provided,&#34; he said in a tweet in the evening of Wednesday.</p><p>Earlier in the week, European Union nations <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/eu-nations-to-accept-ukraine-refugee-for-3-years-report-2022-2\">unanimously agreed to accept Ukrainian refugees for up to three years</a> while also waiving any requirements for asylum applications.</p><p>The move will allow the refugees to live and work in the EU countries they are accepted into, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/mar/02/ukraine-refugees-right-to-live-in-eu-plan\">per The Guardian</a>.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Filippo Grandi  (@FilippoGrandi) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1499156937644118022?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 2, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script></div><div class=\"slide\">International Criminal Court launches investigation of war crimes in Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6220048104579d001893c073?format=jpeg\" height=\"3280\" width=\"4387\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Damaged building in Kharkiv\"/><figcaption>Firefighters working to contain a fire at the Economy Department building of Karazin Kharkiv National University, believed to have been hit by Russian shelling, in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on March 2.<p class=\"copyright\">SERGEY BOBOK/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The International Criminal Court is investigating allegations of war crimes in Ukraine, the prosecutor of the court said in a <a href=\"https://www.icc-cpi.int/Pages/item.aspx?name=2022-prosecutor-statement-referrals-ukraine\">statement Wednesday</a>.</p><p>The prosecutor, Karim A.A. Khan, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/icc-hague-to-investigate-russia-war-crimes-in-ukraine-2022-2\">argued</a> in a <a href=\"https://www.icc-cpi.int/Pages/item.aspx?name=20220228-prosecutor-statement-ukraine\">statement</a> Monday, just four days into Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine, that he had &#34;reasonable basis to believe that both alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity have been committed in Ukraine.&#34;</p><p>Thirty-nine countries that are part of the ICC sent referrals on the matter to Khan&#39;s office, he said in the Wednesday statement.</p><p>The investigation&#39;s purview reaches as far back as November 2013.</p><p><br/><a following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by SERGEY BOBOK/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine&#39;s defense ministry is asking mothers of captured Russian troops to come pick up their sons.</p><p>&#34;Mama! Your [prisoner of war] son is waiting for you!&#34; the defense ministry wrote on a flyer posted to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/100069073844828/posts/267620162217110/?d=n\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b08a30b83d2949aa4edbb3a59771a446\">Facebook</a>&#160;on Wednesday. &#34;Ukraine has made the decision to return POW to their mothers if they come to Ukraine.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-asks-russian-mothers-pick-up-captured-troops-putin-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Jon Stewart commends Ukrainian President Zelensky&#39;s &#39;courage and tenacity and the way that he&#39;s leading his country&#39; amid Russian invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61d589f05a119b00184b1410?format=jpeg\" height=\"982\" width=\"1310\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The Late Show with Stephen Colbert and guest Jon Stewart during Monday&#39;s June 17, 2019 show.
