Wednesday</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;You see this gentleman&#39;s courage and tenacity and the way that he&#39;s leading his country,&#34; he said of&#160;Zelensky. &#34;It&#39;s incredibly moving.&#34;&#160;</p><p>&#34;My fear for Ukraine is that we&#39;re going to get sucked into this idea of a heroic narrative while these folks get surrounded in a long-term siege that&#39;s just going to cause so much more death and destruction,&#34; Stewart added.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/jon-stewart-commends-ukraine-president-zelensky-amid-russian-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian mom helping the war effort says she&#39;s making the two &#39;most important things&#39; for the troops: borscht and Molotov cocktails<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f804575b649001845a60e?format=jpeg\" height=\"3648\" width=\"4864\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Soldiers are seen around piles of sand used for blocking a road in Ukrainian capital, Kyiv amid Russian attacks on March 02, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Soldiers are seen around piles of sand used for blocking a road in Ukrainian capital, Kyiv amid Russian attacks on March 02, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Aytac Unal/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>A Ukrainian mom aiding her country&#39;s resistance efforts against <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">Russia&#39;s invasion</a> says she has been making the two &#34;most important things&#34; for Ukraine&#39;s troops: borscht and Molotov cocktails.&#160;</p><p>Since Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine began last week, Yurko has been cooking up Ukrainian borscht &#8212; a traditional eastern European soup &#8212; to nourish her country&#39;s Territorial Defense units.</p><p>And Yurko is creating Molotov cocktails to support the troops in their fight against Russian forces.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-mom-making-borscht-molotov-cocktails-russian-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Jailed Putin critic Alexei Navalny urges Russians not to be a &#39;nation of frightened silent people&#39; on the Ukraine war<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f7d7696929400196c3988?format=jpeg\" height=\"3452\" width=\"4603\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Participants of an unauthorized protest rally against of jailing of opposituon leader Alexei Navalny shout, on January 23, 2021 in Moscow, Russia.\"/><figcaption>Participants of an unauthorized protest rally against of jailing of opposition leader Alexei Navalny shout, on January 23, 2021 in Moscow, Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Mikhail Svetlov/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Top Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny urged Russians on Wednesday to continue protesting President Vladimir Putin and the increasingly brutal war he&#39;s launched against Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Let&#39;s at least not become a nation of frightened silent people. Of cowards who pretend not to notice the aggressive war against Ukraine unleashed by our obviously insane czar,&#34; Navalny&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/navalny/status/1498948991228293120?s=20&#38;t=BHSglUZMpTROYARsATCnfA\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"49b89a8f77db05cc0b58dd4d2f857709\">tweeted</a>.&#160;</p><p>He urged individuals &#34;in Russia, Belarus or on the other side of the planet&#34; to plan demonstrations and take to their main squares to protest on weekdays, weekends, and holidays.</p><p>&#34;Everything has a price, and now, in the spring of 2022, we must pay this price,&#34; he said. &#34;There&#39;s no one to do it for us. Let&#39;s not &#39;be against the war.&#39; Let&#39;s fight against the war.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-critic-alexei-navalny-urges-russians-not-silent-ukraine-war-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine and its allies are shaming and embarrassing Russian diplomats at the UN and other international bodies<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f5c8196929400196c35f1?format=jpeg\" height=\"1797\" width=\"2396\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The UN Security Council meeting room appears almost empty while a Russian representative is speaking remotely on a monitor.\"/><figcaption>The room of the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva appears almost empty after several diplomats walked out as a pre-recorded message from Russia&#39;s foreign minister Sergei Lavrov started playing on March 1, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">FABRICE COFFRINI/POOL/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Diplomats and other Western representatives are staging dramatic gestures in high-level diplomatic settings to admonish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>More than 140 envoys walked out as Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov addressed UN Human Rights Council and the Conference on Disarmament on Tuesday.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-allies-shaming-russia-diplomats-un-osce-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kremlin advisor says he&#39;s &#39;shocked&#39; by Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine, marking a rare dissent against Putin<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6214c668f0b06900185ed1ae?format=jpeg\" height=\"1968\" width=\"2624\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into eastern Ukraine on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Alexei Nikolsky/Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>An advisor to the Kremlin says he was caught off guard by President Vladimir Putin&#39;s invasion of Ukraine and can&#39;t understand his reasoning.</p><p>&#34;I was shocked because for a long time, I thought that a military operation was not feasible. It was not plausible,&#34; Andrey Kortunov, who sits on a&#160;<a href=\"https://russiancouncil.ru/en/andrey-kortunov/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ecb94b630afd15d9f14ba421fdbf51d9\">Kremlin panel of foreign policy experts</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/ukraine-invasion-kremlin-policy-adviser-reveals-his-shock-over-vladimir-putins-decision-to-invade-12555163\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"c6f512ca89883119b4c37d95e0998a07\">told Sky News.</a></p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kremlin-advisor-shocked-ukraine-invasion-putin-rare-dissent-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Map shows countries that have closed their airspace to Russia over Ukraine invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f88e475b649001845a7c0?format=jpeg\" height=\"1075\" width=\"1436\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A world map showing the US, EU, Canada and other countries that have banned Russian planes from their airspace.\"/><figcaption>A map showing the US, EU, Canada and other countries that have banned Russian planes from their airspace.<p class=\"copyright\">Insider/Mapchart.net</p></figcaption></figure><p>Thirty-three countries as of Wednesday blocked Russian flights from their airspace following President Vladimir Putin&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>All 27 EU countries, as well as Albania, Canada, Norway, Switzerland, the UK, and the US imposed the ban after Russian forces invaded Ukraine. The ban is shared by some of the world&#39;s most powerful nations, including most members of NATO.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/map-shows-countries-that-closed-airspace-russia-over-ukraine-war-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelensky says 6,000 Russian troops are dead<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6218e093d0009b001904b2b0?format=jpeg\" height=\"964\" width=\"1285\" charset=\"\" alt=\"ukraine tank military\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian Military Forces servicemen block a road in Kyiv, Ukraine, on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Supinsky/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>President Volodymyr Zelensky said in a video address on Wednesday morning: &#34;Russian mothers are losing their children in a completely foreign country. Think of this number: almost 6,000 Russians died, Russian military, in six days of war.&#34;</p><p>He said this figure did not include any deaths on Tuesday night.</p><p>Russia has not given its own figures, and current figures for Ukrainian military deaths are unclear.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-says-almost-6000-russians-killed-first-6-days-invasion-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelensky says Russia has managed to unite both Ukraine and the EU<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62184a39d0009b001904abba?format=jpeg\" height=\"3835\" width=\"5628\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A protester holds a sign that says &#34;Stop war.&#34;\"/><figcaption>People attend a pro-Ukraine protest rally in front of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, Germany, Thursday, Feb. 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Michael Sohn</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said in Wednesday morning video address that Russia&#39;s invasion had managed to unite Ukrainians as well as the European Union.</p><p>He said of Ukrainians: &#34;During this time we have had more unity than for over 30 years before.&#34;</p><p>&#34;At first we were equally scared, then we felt equally painful. And now we do not care. Except for victory. Except for the truth. Except for peace. Except for the tranquility we want to achieve. Except for the lives of our people, for whom we are worried. Except for Ukraine. During this time, we have truly become one.&#34;</p><p>&#34;We forgave each other a lot. We started loving each other. We help each other. We are worried for each other.&#34;</p><p>He added: &#34;During this time we have united the European Union already on a new level.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Higher than formal. Higher than interstate. At the level of the ordinary people. Millions and millions of Europeans. From the Atlantic Ocean to the suburbs of Kharkiv, where fierce fighting continues. When the European parliament stood and applauded us, our struggle, it was an assessment of our efforts. Our unity.&#34;</p><p>Zelensky applied for Ukraine to join the EU earlier this week and asked the European Parliament on Tuesday to admit his country. His speech to the parliament was met with a standing ovation.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelensky says Russia has &#39;orders to erase our history, erase our country, erase us all&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f3bab96929400196c328d?format=jpeg\" height=\"1132\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Volodymyr Zelensky speaks at a podium with Ukraine&#39;s flag behind him\"/><figcaption>Volodymyr Zelensky speaks in a video he shared March 2, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Volodymyr Zelensky</p></figcaption></figure><p>In his Wednesday video message, Zelensky also condemned Russia&#39;s Tuesday missile strike on Babyn Yar, a Holocaust memorial in Kyiv.</p><p>&#34;This strike proves that for many people in Russia our Kyiv is absolutely foreign,&#34; he said.</p><p>&#34;They don&#39;t know a thing about Kyiv, about our history. But they all have orders to erase our history, erase our country, erase us all.&#34;</p><p>Speaking to Russians, he said: &#34;You are killing Holocaust victims for a second time.&#34;</p><p>Zelensky, who is Jewish, said he was &#34;addressing all the Jews of the world.</p><p>&#34;Don&#39;t you see what is happening? That is why it is very important that millions of Jews around the world do not remain silent right now. Nazism is born in silence. So shout about the killings of civilians, Shout about the killings of Ukrainians.&#34;</p><p>Russia baselessly claimed that it was invading Ukraine as part of &#34;de-Nazification&#34; efforts.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine denies Russian claim that it captured major port city<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62170b1145889c0019d20a49?format=jpeg\" height=\"2303\" width=\"3454\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Vladimir Putin points his finger.\"/><figcaption>Russia&#39;s President Vladimir Putin.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Alexei Nikolsky\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>An advisor to Zelensky&#39;s office denied Russia&#39;s Wednesday claim that it had seized the major port city of Kherson.</p><p>&#34;The city has not fallen, our side continues to defend,&#34; Oleksiy Arestovych said, per Reuters.</p><p>Russia&#39;s defense ministry <a href=\"https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/russian-military-says-has-control-of-ukraines-kherson\">said</a> earlier Wednesday: &#34;The Russian divisions of the armed forces have taken the regional center of Kherson under full control.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine says airborne Russian troops landed in Kharkiv amid reports of rocket attacks<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f3dcd96929400196c32b1?format=jpeg\" height=\"1125\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Damage in Kharkiv\"/><figcaption>A view shows the area near the regional administration building in Kharkiv, which city officials said was hit by a missile attack, on March 1, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Vyacheslav Madiyevskyy/File Photo</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian officials <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2022/mar/02/ukraine-news-russia-war-kyiv-kharkiv-russian-invasion-vladimir-putin-joe-biden-latest-live-updates\">said</a> Russian airborne troopers landed in Kharkiv, the country&#39;s second-largest city.</p><p>Ukraine&#39;s State Emergency Service <a href=\"https://fb.watch/bu_0MRQ5jK/\">shared video</a> on Wednesday morning of fire on the roof of the National Police Department building in Kharkiv after &#34;enemy shelling.&#34;</p><p>A hospital was also reportedly <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2022/mar/02/ukraine-news-russia-war-kyiv-kharkiv-russian-invasion-vladimir-putin-joe-biden-latest-live-updates\">attacked</a>.</p><p>The city was also hit by missiles on Tuesday, killing multiple people.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK defense minister says Russia does not have the &#39;moral component&#39; needed to win, but warns of greater brutality<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621e8c7d75b649001845902e?format=jpeg\" height=\"2851\" width=\"4469\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A man on crutches walks past the remains of a Russian military vehicles.\"/><figcaption>A man on crutches walks past the remains of a Russian military vehicles in Bucha, close to Ukraine&#39;s capital of Kyiv, on March 1, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Serhii Nuzhnenko/AP</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ben Wallace said Russia does not have the &#34;moral component&#34; to achieve its goals in the Ukraine conflict.</p><p>He told BBC Breakfast that the Russians were &#34;starting to change their tactics as a result of the poor start.&#34;</p><p>&#34;That means we&#39;re seeing much more of those awful artillery bombardments into the city, not just Kyiv, Kharkiv every night has seen horrendous bombardment. Those are happening predominantly at nighttime in an attempt to break the cities. And that is what is their current tactic, to try and surround a city and bombard it into submission then come into the city,&#34; he said.</p><p>He also <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uk-predicts-increasingly-brutal-approach-russias-putin-lbc-2022-03-02/\">told LBC radio</a> on Wednesday that Russia was likely to adopt more brutal tactics: &#34;Anyone who thinks logically would not do what [Putin] is doing, so we are going to see ... his brutality increase.&#34;</p><p>&#34;He doesn&#39;t get his way, he surrounds cities, he ruthlessly bombards them at night ... and he will then eventually try and break them and move into the cities.&#34;</p><p>The UK Ministry of Defence <a href=\"https://twitter.com/DefenceHQ/status/1498920532485582850\">said</a> on Wednesday that Russia has been frustrated by logistical issues and strong resistance from Ukraine.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-lacks-moral-component-to-win-ukraine-conflict-ben-wallace-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin doesn&#39;t want to &#39;own&#39; Ukraine, says former US envoy<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f144596929400196c3145?format=jpeg\" height=\"4192\" width=\"5589\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Former U.S. Ambassador&#160;Marie Yovanovitch speaks during a ceremony awarding her the&#160;Trainor Award for &#34;Excellence in the Conduct of Diplomacy.&#34;\"/><figcaption>Former US Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch said Russian President Vladimir Putin would need to exercise &#34;a modicum of responsibility&#34; if he &#34;owns&#34; Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Former US Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch said in a recent interview that Russian President Vladimir Putin doesn&#39;t intend to &#34;own&#34; Ukraine because it would make him responsible for the country.</p><p>&#34;When I was in the country, from 2016 to 2019, I always felt that he didn&#39;t really want to &#39;own&#39; Ukraine because then there&#39;s at least a modicum of responsibility. He would have to provide services,&#34; she told<a href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/news/q-and-a/the-ambassador-caught-between-ukraine-and-trump\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"45eb47f5deb2f0eef2a8e4126539fb2e\"> The New Yorker&#39;s David Remnick,</a> in an interview published on Tuesday.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-doesnt-want-to-own-ukraine-says-former-us-envoy-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine claims a plot to assassinate President Volodymyr Zelensky was foiled<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f2bc596929400196c3211?format=jpeg\" height=\"526\" width=\"701\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian authorities claimed that they foiled an assassination plot by Chechen special forces against President Volodymyr Zelensky.<p class=\"copyright\">Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky</p></figcaption></figure><p>A Ukrainian security and defense chief said on Tuesday that Ukrainian forces have thwarted an assassination plot against President Volodymyr Zelensky, using a tip-off from members of Russia&#39;s security services.</p><p>An elite group of Chechen special forces &#8212; known as the Kadyrovites &#8212; was dispatched by Russia to &#34;eliminate our president&#34; but was &#34;destroyed directly,&#34; said Oleksiy Danilov, the head of Ukraine&#39;s National Security and Defense Council, according to a&#160;<a href=\"https://t.me/spravdi/1058\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"eb166588f7f8a130b19b8861606093a3\">Telegram post</a>&#160;written on Tuesday by the Center for Strategic Communications.&#160;<a href=\"https://www.axios.com/zelensky-assassination-plot-foiled-7bea049b-2308-4801-b75a-93104c17b82b.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.axios.com/zelensky-assassination-plot-foiled-7bea049b-2308-4801-b75a-93104c17b82b.html\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"6be8907fc2ce5c54e702836b8f659fd8\">Axios first reported</a>&#160;the story.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-russia-double-agent-foil-assassination-zelensky-claim-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian authorities say citizens don&#39;t need to worry about taxes on captured Russian tanks<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f217e96929400196c31c1?format=jpeg\" height=\"683\" width=\"910\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A fragment of a destroyed Russian tank is seen on the roadside on the outskirts of Kharkiv on February 26, 2022.\"/><figcaption>A fragment of a destroyed Russian tank seen in the outskirts of Kharkiv, Ukraine, on February 26.<p class=\"copyright\">SERGEY BOBOK/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian authorities have reassured citizens that they don&#39;t need to declare captured Russian tanks or any equipment they pick up as personal income.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Have you captured a Russian tank or armored personnel carrier and are worried about how to declare it? Keep calm and continue to defend the Motherland!&#34; read a statement from the Ukrainian National Agency on Corruption Prevention (NACP)&#160;<a href=\"https://ua.interfax.com.ua/news/general/804441-amp.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"9c3de1872ced617cc08684d26735ff88\">seen by Interfax Ukraine.</a></p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraines-tax-office-captured-russian-tanks-not-personal-taxable-income-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">How China&#39;s tech giants are reacting to Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f208275b6490018459d42?format=jpeg\" height=\"2399\" width=\"3199\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A young girl uses the TikTok app on a smartphone.\"/><figcaption>A young girl uses the TikTok app on a smartphone.<p class=\"copyright\">Peter Byrne/PA Images via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Chinese tech giants are diverging in their responses to Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>Since Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday, the US, Canada, Europe, and the UK have&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-sanctions-ukraine-invasion-economic-damage-putin-russian-elites-banks-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"de058e97fdc62a5170cbd104189b1f2c\">imposed sanctions</a>&#160;on Russian elites and entities. In contrast, China has&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/china-avoids-calling-russia-attack-on-ukraine-invasion-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"72f57fc93e9001b10b0c51e48e8b127d\">avoided</a>&#160;outwardly condemning Russia&#39;s actions. A spokesperson for China&#39;s foreign ministry said on Monday the country doesn&#39;t believe in using sanctions to resolve diplomatic issues, a Chinese transcript&#160;<a href=\"https://www.fmprc.gov.cn/fyrbt_673021/202202/t20220228_10646369.shtml\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"c11d063fd12b826b25c32d73da397ea3\">published</a>&#160;on the ministry&#39;s website shows.</p><p>That&#39;s put Chinese tech companies in a bind. Unlike their Silicon Valley counterparts &#8212; many of whom don&#39;t rely as heavily on Chinese consumers &#8212; Chinese tech giants find considerable support for their products and services both within China and elsewhere.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-chinas-tech-giants-reacting-to-ukraine-crisis-tiktok-tencent-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian tennis star Elina Svitolina pledges to donate prize money to her country&#39;s army<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f1f9e75b6490018459d35?format=jpeg\" height=\"4256\" width=\"5674\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine&#39;s Elina Svitolina celebrates after winning her first round match against Anasatsia Potapova\"/><figcaption>Ukraine&#39;s Elina Svitolina celebrates after defeating Russia&#39;s Anasatsia Potapova.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Daniel Becerril</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian tennis star Elina Svitolina has pledged to donate her prize money to her country&#39;s army after defeating Russia&#39;s Anastasia Potapova at the Monterrey Open in Mexico on Tuesday.</p><p>&#34;I was on a mission for my country,&#34; Svitolina said in an on-court interview after the opening-round match, which drew a roar from the audience,&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/ElinaSvitolina/status/1497891262980149248\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"a340370979cff49bd0b6bd0c79cd23b4\">per CNN</a>.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/ukrainian-tennis-star-svitolina-pledges-donate-prize-money-army-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian and Belarusian ice skaters banned from international competitions<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f1c9e96929400196c3190?format=jpeg\" height=\"3488\" width=\"4651\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A pair of ice skates\"/><figcaption>The International Skating Union announced the ban on Tuesday.<p class=\"copyright\">A pair of ice skates</p></figcaption></figure><p>The International Skating Union (ISU) has banned Russian and Belarusian skaters from all its events following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>The ISU made the announcement in a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.isu.org/isu-news/news/145-news/14024-isu-statement-on-the-ukrainian-crisis-participation-in-international-competitions-of-skaters-and-officials-from-russia-and-belarus?templateParam=15\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"92f0be02f601110b1cc94f0d07ef8279\">statement</a> on Tuesday. With immediate effect and until further notice, no skaters from Russia or Belarus will be invited to or allowed to compete in international ice skating competitions, the ISU said.</p><p>&#34;The ISU Council reiterates its solidarity with all those affected by the conflict in Ukraine and our thoughts are with the entire Ukrainian people and country,&#34; the statement read.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/russia-banned-from-ice-skating-events-after-ukraine-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">WATCH: Biden&#39;s first State of the Union address focuses on Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f1a6096929400196c316b?format=jpeg\" height=\"4570\" width=\"6094\" charset=\"\" alt=\"President Biden at State of the Union.\"/><figcaption>President Biden delivering his State of the Union address on Tuesday.<p class=\"copyright\">Saul Loeb - Pool/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>President Joe Biden condemned Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine during his first State of the Union address to Congress on Tuesday.</p><p>In his speech, he announced measures to punish Russia for invading Ukraine and said that the US would be shutting down its airspace to all Russian flights.</p><p>Biden also emphasized that American troops will not be going into Ukraine to fight Russian forces.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/biden-promises-to-inflict-pain-on-russia-for-invading-ukraine-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Trump wouldn&#39;t have stood in Putin&#39;s way if a Russian invasion took place during his term: John Bolton<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f193f75b6490018459cf8?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Stephanie Grisham and John Bolton looking at Donald Trump.\"/><figcaption>Former national security advisor John Bolton has slammed his former boss, saying that former President Donald Trump would not have stood in Putin&#39;s way in the event of a Russian invasion during his term.<p class=\"copyright\">Jabin Botsford/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>John Bolton, the US&#39; former national security advisor, said his ex-boss, former President Donald Trump, would not have stood in Putin&#39;s way if a Russian invasion of Ukraine had happened when he was in office.</p><p>&#34;Well, I&#39;m not sure he would have done much of anything, frankly,&#34; Bolton said in an interview with&#160;<a href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/3abjgn/john-bolton-interview-russia-ukraine\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"fdc2a1a3561da4e4083f5a19681f96e4\">Vice</a>&#160;published March 1, responding to a question about what Trump might have done had Russia attacked Ukraine while he was president.</p><p>&#34;But you never know with Trump. It depends on what time of day it is, it depends on what he thought his political benefit would be at any given moment. I don&#39;t think ultimately he would have stood in Putin&#39;s way,&#34; Bolton told Vice.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/john-bolton-trump-wouldnt-have-stood-putins-way-russian-invasion-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Taekwondo&#39;s governing body strips Putin of honorary black belt<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f181e75b6490018459cf1?format=jpeg\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Putin in 2019\"/><figcaption>Vladimir Putin&#39;s honorary black belt has been revoked by World Taekwondo.<p class=\"copyright\">MIKHAIL KLIMENTYEV/SPUTNIK/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin had his honorary Taekwondo black belt revoked on Monday by the sport&#39;s international governing body, which also condemned&#160;<a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=insider.com+russia+ukraine+invasion&#38;oq=insider.com+russia+ukraine+invasion&#38;aqs=chrome..69i57j69i60l3.4651j0j7&#38;sourceid=chrome&#38;ie=UTF-8\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"4ee16f559b9e35e6832a9b836e539aef\">Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine</a>.</p><p><a href=\"http://www.worldtaekwondo.org/wtnews/view.html?nid=138702\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"3234b25239cee50d8376910b396ff172\">In a statement,</a>&#160;World Taekwondo said it &#34;strongly condemns the brutal attacks on innocent lives in Ukraine, which go against the World Taekwondo vision of &#39;Peace is More Precious than Triumph&#39; and the World Taekwondo values of respect and tolerance.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/world-taekwondo-strips-putin-of-black-belt-invasion-of-ukraine-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Tech giants take unprecedented action against Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61dd9f771025b20018bb24da?format=jpeg\" height=\"1999\" width=\"2668\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Sundar Pichai, CEO of Google and Alphabet, speaks on artificial intelligence during a Bruegel think tank conference in Brussels, Belgium January 20, 2020.\"/><figcaption>Sundar Pichai, CEO of Google and Alphabet, speaks on artificial intelligence during a Bruegel think tank conference in Belgium on January 20, 2020.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo</p></figcaption></figure><p>As technology giants face rising pressure to act over the Ukraine crisis, Google and Apple have moved to curb Russian state media on their platforms, including limiting the reach of Russia state-backed media on their app stores.</p><p>Like&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-ukraine-russia-news-state-media-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"1d56e2454b0c0460999ddc61278096f1\">Meta and other tech companies</a>, Google and Apple have acted under pressure from lawmakers and European governments, reflecting the reach of these giants and their exposure to geopolitical events.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/google-apple-ukraine-crisis-russia-invasion-app-play-store-rt-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Hackers changed the call sign of a Putin-linked superyacht<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621f16ec75b6490018459ce3?format=jpeg\" height=\"2956\" width=\"3941\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The yacht &#39;Graceful&#39; We deplore Russia&#39;s military action that violates the territorial integrity of Ukraine and endangers its people,&#34; ExxonMobile said in a statement. &#34;We are deeply saddened by the loss of innocent lives and support the strong international response. We are fully complying with all sanctions.&#34;</p><p>The company said it would not invest in new developments in Russia, due to the current situation.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">State of the Union: Biden says Putin &#39;badly miscalculated&#39; in Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ed7b996929400196c2dd9?format=jpeg\" height=\"1708\" width=\"2277\" charset=\"\" alt=\"President Joe Biden delivers his State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress at the Capitol, Tuesday, March 1, 2022, in Washington.\"/><figcaption>President Joe Biden delivers his State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress at the Capitol on Tuesday.<p class=\"copyright\">Win McNamee, Pool via AP</p></figcaption></figure><p>On Tuesday night, in his first State of the Union address, President Joe Biden said Russian President Vladimir Putin &#34;badly miscalculated&#34; with his invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;Six days ago, Russia&#39;s Vladimir Putin sought to shake the foundations of the free world thinking he could make it bend to his menacing ways. Biden said during his State of the Union Address on Tuesday, adding that Russian President Vladimir Putin &#34;has no idea what&#39;s coming.&#34;</p><p>The move comes after the European Union and Canada closed their respective airspaces to Russian-owned and -operated aircraft.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sotu-biden-announced-us-closing-american-airspace-to-russian-aircraft-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelensky says Ukraine-Russia talks may be a waste of time as attacks continue<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ed46c96929400196c2d6c?format=jpeg\" height=\"719\" width=\"961\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky seen in Kyiv, Ukraine on February 28, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky seen in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Presidency of Ukraine / Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Inside the basement of a building at an undisclosed position in Kyiv, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said &#34;we&#39;ll see,&#34; a sight mainly seen in Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan, and other Middle Eastern and African countries in the past few decades.&#160;</p><p>However, for some watching the latest crisis unfold, reporting on the chaos showed a double standard.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reporters-make-racist-comparisons-between-ukraine-crisis-and-middle-east-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Biden to call out Putin by name in State of the Union address<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ed1c196929400196c2d29?format=jpeg\" height=\"558\" width=\"744\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Biden\"/><figcaption>President Joe Biden speaking in Washington, DC, on February 8.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Alex Brandon</p></figcaption></figure><p>US President Joe Biden will use his first State of the Union address to argue that history shows leaders like Vladimir Putin will only be emboldened if they do not face the consequences for threatening others.</p><p>&#34;Throughout our history, we&#39;ve learned this lesson: when dictators do not pay a price for aggression, they cause more chaos,&#34; And I guess this is another one,&#34; Vyshnevska told Insider by phone from the Kyiv apartment where she&#39;s sheltering with her family.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-russia-film-producer-kyiv-subway-bunker-panic-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainians are &#39;trembling and crying&#39; as they shelter and listen to bombs and planes flying over Kharkiv<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621e842375b6490018458df5?format=jpeg\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Marina Shut sits in a basement with her coat on with her six-year-old son\"/><figcaption>Marina Shut sits in a basement with her coat on with her six-year-old son during Russia&#39;s attacks on Kharkiv.<p class=\"copyright\">Marina Shut</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainians say they&#39;re &#34;trembling&#34; as they listen to bombs go off in Kharkiv, the country&#39;s second-largest city.</p><p>One Ukrainian woman said she&#39;s hiding out in the basement of her apartment building as she hears planes fly over Kharkiv.</p><p>Marina, a 35-year-old mother, told Insider she&#39;s sheltering with her mother, her 6-year-old son, and some neighbors.</p><p>At 10 p.m. local time on Tuesday at least four planes passed by within the hour, she told Insider.</p><p>&#34;I am scared to death,&#34; she said. &#34;I am trembling and crying.&#34;</p><p>&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainians-trembling-crying-bombs-going-off-kharkiv-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">President Zelensky brushed off praise for his wartime response: &#39;I&#39;m not iconic, I think Ukraine is iconic&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ead9975b649001845971c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1125\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"President Volodymyr Zelensky in a video address released February 28, 2022. data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5633edb47edba1f8d0028d74e9071fef\">Russian forces invaded Ukraine</a>, but Ukrainian&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/who-is-volodymyr-zelensky-ukraine-president-central-to-trump-scandal-2019-9\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"4cacee5627f9d7818dc8fb13cf9c0dd7\">President Volodymyr Zelensky</a>&#160;&#8212; a former comedian and actor turned statesman &#8212; has quickly garnered global praise for his stalwart presence and defiant demeanor in the face of increasing danger.</p><p>On Tuesday, Zelensky sat for an exclusive interview with&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2022/03/01/europe/volodymyr-zelensky-ukraine-cnn-interview-intl/index.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"0ff31d9f479390594fe4cdaa0fb63ef7\">CNN</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/ukraines-president-russia-stop-your-bombs-before-ceasefire-talks-can-start-2022-03-01/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ea686af53c3a9fccd864861eec2da108\">Reuters</a>&#160;from the bunker in Kyiv in which he is directing his country&#39;s military response.&#160;</p><p>The Ukrainian president discussed an array of topics, including the status of ceasefire talks with Russia, the possibility of a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-ruled-out-no-fly-zone-over-ukraine-zelensky-russia-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"0ba06303a820b58b6e93f05992892cf5\">NATO-imposed no-fly zone</a>&#160;over Russia, and the broad consequences to all of Europe should Ukraine fall.</p><p>But when asked by CNN about his journey from television performer to a global wartime leader, Zelensky brushed off praise.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-brushes-off-praise-im-not-iconic-ukraine-is-iconic-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia could fall into a recession by summer, an economist says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621e8ae596929400196c2442?format=jpeg\" height=\"4821\" width=\"6428\" charset=\"\" alt=\"russia ruble currency exchange\"/><figcaption>People walk past a currency exchange office screen displaying the exchange rates of U.S. Dollar and Euro to Russian Rubles in Moscow&#39;s downtown, Russia, Monday, Feb. 28, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Pavel Golovkin</p></figcaption></figure><p>A Russian economist says the country could fall into a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-recession\" data-site=\"bi\" data-keyword=\"recession\" data-analytics-product-module=\"Auto-Linker\" data-analytics-product-area=\"link\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"5a7e26df3ef5192fb110816eba1b59da\">recession</a>&#160;as early as next month as sanctions from the US, UK, and EU take their toll.</p><p>Already, some of the country&#39;s banks have been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-eu-announce-some-russian-banks-removed-from-swift-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"d05e660902a780fa321d524d2e1be5dd\">blocked</a>&#160;from key global financial communications system SWIFT. The US and its European allies have&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-putin-sanctions-russia-central-bank-war-chest-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"1c4640a596fb464854f0296dd12c7054\">frozen Russian assets</a>&#160;and imposed&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-will-announce-sanctions-on-putin-ukraine-invasion-cnn-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5128fc0588c0d785cc5e754a7aa41a40\">personal sanctions</a> against figures like President Vladimir Putin.</p><p>The Russian ruble, the country&#39;s currency,&#160;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/russia-rouble-ukraine-putin-attack-market-halt-trading-rout-sanctions-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"170911f9bb680a04245ef17955b36093\">fell to a record low</a>, and interest rates&#160;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/bonds/russia-ukraine-war-central-bank-ruble-dollar-gold-sanctions-economy-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"8b603191667228436b714f957a5323f0\">have already more than doubled</a>. As Insider&#39;s Joseph Zeballos-Roig and Ben Winck&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-sanctions-ukraine-invasion-economic-damage-putin-russian-elites-banks-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"de058e97fdc62a5170cbd104189b1f2c\">reported</a>, some of these sanctions might still take months to have a visible impact, but others are already rippling across the country.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-recession-second-quarter-before-summer-economist-evgeny-nadorshin-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Belarus&#39; Lukashenko may have accidentally revealed a map of Russia&#39;s Ukrainian invasion plans<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621e5d4996929400196c173d?format=jpeg\" height=\"3322\" width=\"4429\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russia&#39;s President Vladimir Putin (R) shakes hands with his Belarus counterpart Alexander Lukashenko (L) following their talks at in Moscow on February 18, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Russia&#39;s President Vladimir Putin (R) shakes hands with his Belarus counterpart Alexander Lukashenko (L) following their talks at in Moscow on February 18, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Guneyev/Sputnik/AFP via Getty Images)</p></figcaption></figure><p>Belarus leader Alexander Lukashenko may have accidentally revealed Russia&#39;s invasion plans of Ukraine on live television.&#160;</p><p>A short video shared by Belarusian journalist Tadeusz Giczan on Twitter showed Lukashenko pointing to a map of Ukraine. src=\"https://i.insider.com/621df74075b6490018457038?format=jpeg\" height=\"1328\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Two Ukrainian soldiers outside Karkhiv in a snowy environment with bare trees, on Photo</p></figcaption></figure><p>Western officials think Russian President Vladimir Putin is so angry with the rate of Russia&#39;s progress in Ukraine that he might start a more aggressive attack, multiple outlets reported.</p><p>One Western official told Insider on Monday evening: &#34;There are ... some risks that come as a consequence of Russia&#39;s lack of progress.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I fear the way in which Russia is frustrated in achieving its aims on the ground is leading to the use of more indiscriminate fires and as a consequence we&#39;re going to see an increase in civilian casualties.&#34;</p><p>And a senior US defense official told reporters on Monday, <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2022/02/28/politics/us-kyiv-fears/index.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"37c2756af93808d08f401a14670a6f1a\">according to CNN: </a>&#34;They have been slowed and they have been frustrated by their lack of progress on Kyiv, and one of the things that could result is a reevaluation of their tactics and the potential for them to be more aggressive and more overt in both the size and the scale of their targeting of Kyiv.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-angry-ukraine-resistance-may-escalate-reports-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia says it is pushing ahead with building natural gas pipeline to China<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621df41175b6490018456fdd?format=jpeg\" height=\"2250\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Xinhua/Ju Peng via Getty Images, Sergei Guneyev/SPUTNIK/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Gazprom, the Kremlin-controlled energy giant,&#160;<a href=\"https://telegra.ph/Gazprom-Mongolia-02-28\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ecd4d102cf69ceffbb325285d5e7fe27\">said</a>&#160;on Monday that it had signed a contract to perform design and survey work as part of the construction of the Soyuz Vostok gas pipeline.</p><p>The proposed pipeline would deliver up to 50 billion cubic meters (1.77 trillion cubic feet) of Russian natural gas each year to China via Mongolia, Gazprom said.</p><p>Sanctions imposed by Western nations have hobbled Russia&#39;s economy after it invaded Ukraine.<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-china-gas-pipeline-sanctions-ukraine-putin-gazprom-soyuz-vostok-2022-3\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kremlin says Western sanctions will never make Russia change its mind on Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6218d793d80ca400192d15ff?format=jpeg\" height=\"1300\" Druzhinin</p></figcaption></figure><p>Sanctions imposed by the West over Russia&#39;s invasion will not make it change its mind, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters on Tuesday.</p><p>&#34;They are counting on forcing us to change our position. This is out of the question,&#34; Peskov said, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/kremlin-russia-wont-budge-under-sanctions-pressure-over-ukraine-2022-03-01/\">according to Reuters</a>.</p><p>Russia has repeatedly brushed off the punitive sanctions and claimed they were unlawful. On Sunday, Russian President Vladimir Putin placed the country&#39;s nuclear weapons on high alert in response to the sanctions, a move that the US and UK said was merely a distraction.</p></div><div I believe that Russia is trying to put pressure on us in such an unsophisticated way,&#34; said Zelensky.</p><p>&#34;Don&#39;t waste your time. We do not accept such tactics,&#34; he added.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s US ambassador says Russia used a vacuum bomb during its invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621d9b7f96929400196c0099?format=jpeg\" height=\"3996\" width=\"5328\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine&#39;s Ambassador to the US Oksana Markarova\"/><figcaption>Oksana Markarova, Ukraine&#39;s ambassador to the US.<p class=\"copyright\">Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia has used a vacuum bomb in its attack on Ukraine, <a href=\"https://www.c-span.org/video/?c5003667/ukrainian-ambassador-russia-vacuum-bomb-breach-geneva-convention\">said Ukrainian Ambassador to the US Oksana Markarova on Monday.</a></p><p>&#34;They used the vacuum bomb today, which is actually prohibited by the Geneva convention,&#34; she said after a meeting with US lawmakers.</p><p>&#34;So, you know, the devastation that Russia is trying to inflict on Ukraine is large, but we Ukrainians will resist,&#34; she added.</p><p>Vacuum, or thermobaric, weapons use<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-deploys-feared-tos-1-heavy-flamethrower-near-ukraine-cnn-2022-2\">&#160;oxygen from the surrounding air to generate a high-temperature explosion</a> and do more damage than conventional explosive weapons.</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin may intensify Ukraine invasion as frustrations over military mount<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621d980875b6490018456d1b?format=jpeg\" height=\"561\" width=\"748\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin seen at a Russian Security Council at the Kremlin in on February 21.<p class=\"copyright\">Kremlin Press Office/Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>US intelligence agencies say Russian President Vladimir Putin may intensify his country&#39;s ongoing invasion of Ukraine,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/investigations/frustrated-putin-may-order-escalation-violence-ukraine-us-officials-sa-rcna18026\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/investigations/frustrated-putin-may-order-escalation-violence-ukraine-us-officials-sa-rcna18026\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">NBC News reported on Tuesday</a>, citing current and former US officials.</p><p>The sources told NBC News that Putin is getting increasingly frustrated with Russia&#39;s struggling military and has lashed out at his underlings.</p><p>&#34;This is somebody that&#39;s clearly been caught off guard by the size of the Ukrainian resistance,&#34; said Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Sen. Mark Warner on MSNBC, per the outlet.&#160;</p><p>Russian forces have faced fierce fighting in Ukraine, with experts saying that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-holding-out-as-russia-makes-a-mess-of-invasion-2022-2\">Moscow may adjust its approach to the invasion and intensify its attacks.</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine waives visa requirements for foreigners who want to come and fight Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621d66ea101faf0019298da0?format=jpeg\" height=\"3458\" width=\"4611\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Men hug at airport on way to fight in Ukraine\"/><figcaption>Georgian civilian volunteers say goodbye to friends and family at Tbilisi international airport before their scheduled flight to Poland, where they plan to cross to Ukraine to join Ukraine&#39;s army to fight against Russia forces, on February 28, 2022 in Tbilisi, Georgia.<p class=\"copyright\">Daro Sulakauri/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Foreigners who come to Ukraine in order to help fight against the Russian military will not have to worry about first obtaining a visa.</p><p>In a decree&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/IAPonomarenko/status/1498411930091986944\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"8c20d16ac5bf4115a4f651e8b06ebfc9\">signed on Monday</a>, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky authorized a &#34;temporary visa-free regime&#34; for foreigners who want to aid the country&#39;s defense, effective immediately.</p><p>The policy does not extend to Russian nationals, referred to as &#34;citizens of the aggressor state.&#34;</p><p>Citizens of the United States and European Union previously required visas for tourist visits of more than 90 days within a six-month period.</p><p>The visa-free policy comes a day after Zelensky&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-international-legion-foreigners-join-fight-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"13fb2e263d6eb0acdabe78c0dfed0934\">announced the creation</a>&#160;of an International Legion for foreigners who want to volunteer for the Armed Forces of Ukraine or the Territorial Defense Forces.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-waives-visa-requirements-for-foreigners-who-fight-russia-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian army deploys its TOS-1 heavy flamethrower, capable of vaporizing human bodies, near Ukrainian border, footage shows<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621d6691bea1240018a90d96?format=jpeg\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russia Military Show\"/><figcaption>Russian heavy flamethrower system TOS-1 fires during the International Military Technical Forum Army-2018 in Alabino, outside Moscow, Tuesday, Aug. 21, 2018. Russia has displayed its latest weapons at a military show aimed at attracting more foreign customers.<p class=\"copyright\">Pavel Golovkin/AP Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Footage from inside of Russia appears to show a thermobaric rocket launcher being deployed towards the Ukrainian border, according to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2022/feb/26/russia-ukraine-latest-news-fighting-kyiv-zelenskiy-assault-putin-capital#block-621a07ab8f08db56730fca74\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5db2ed1e038cdc5859c214560c60624a\">The Guardian.</a></p><p>The video, shared on Twitter by&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/fpleitgenCNN/status/1497519335350452231?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1497519335350452231%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&#38;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fworld%2Flive%2F2022%2Ffeb%2F26%2Frussia-ukraine-latest-news-fighting-kyiv-zelenskiy-assault-putin-capital\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"a759f9ee3df4ecf802a5d288e5a1ff5b\">CNN correspondent Frederik Pleitgen,</a>&#160;displays a TOS-1 heavy flamethrower, which can shoot thermobaric rockets mounted on a T-72 tank chassis.&#160;</p><p>The footage was captured south of Belgorod, Pleitgen said, which is about 45 miles away from Kharkiv, Ukraine.</p><p>This TOS-1 can launch two types of warheads &#8212; incendiary and fuel-air explosives. The latter, also called vacuum or thermobaric rockets, work by using oxygen from the surrounding air to generate a high-temperature explosion.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-deploys-feared-tos-1-heavy-flamethrower-near-ukraine-cnn-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Billboards in Kyiv are flashing messages to Russian soldiers, telling them to &#39;go away without blood on your hands&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621d65d0101faf0019298d84?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"armed police officer stands on a street outside Kyiv with cars going by\"/><figcaption>A police officer stands guard at a road leading to central Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday, Feb. 28, 2022. Go away without blood on your hands.&#34;</li><li>&#34;Russian soldier, stop. Don&#39;t kill your soul for Putin&#39;s oligarchs. Stay human.&#34;</li></ol><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kyiv-billboards-flashing-messages-to-russian-soldiers-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div Therefore, a decision was made &#8212; not easy from a moral point of view, but useful from the point of view of our protection,&#34; he said.</p><p>&#34;Under martial law ... Ukrainians with real combat experience will be released from custody and will be able to compensate for the guilt in the hottest spots of war.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">The Kremlin says Western sanctions have &#39;considerably changed&#39; the &#39;economic reality&#39; for Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c4055bea1240018a8e122?format=jpeg\" height=\"3332\" width=\"5000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People stand in line to withdraw money from an ATM of Alfa Bank in Moscow, Russia, Sunday, Feb. 27, 2022.\"/><figcaption>People stand in line to withdraw money from an ATM of Alfa Bank in Moscow, Russia, on Sunday.<p class=\"copyright\">Victor Berzkin/Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Kremlin said Monday that Russia&#39;s &#34;economic reality&#34; had &#34;considerably changed&#34; in response to of &#34;heavy&#34; and &#34;problematic&#34; Western sanctions.</p><p>Russia&#39;s ruble hit a <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/russia-ukraine-market-impact-bank-stocks-ruble-sanctions-economy-2022-2\">new low</a> on Monday&#160;and the country&#39;s central bank more than doubled its base interest rate, to 20%. Russians were reportedly&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ruble-hits-record-low-russians-rush-withdraw-us-dollars-atms-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"70193d1188db458cda7dce49eb97bd56\">waiting in long lines</a>&#160;to withdraw foreign currencies from ATMs.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-kremlin-western-sanctions-problematic-change-reality-economy-putin-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Key Putin ally calls for Russia to take a more brutal approach, saying &#39;chosen tactics in Ukraine are too slow&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ca76fbea1240018a8e417?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov at a microphone in front of a Russian flag.\"/><figcaption>Chechen Republic Head Ramzan Kadyrov speaks during a review of the Chechen Republic&#39;s troops and military hardware, February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Yelena Afonina/TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ramzan Kadyrov, the head of Russia&#39;s Chechen republic, said Russia&#39;s strategy in the first days of the war weren&#39;t working, and called for more brutal ones.</p><p>&#34;In my understanding, the chosen tactics in Ukraine are too slow. They take a long time and, in my opinion, are not effective,&#34; he wrote on Telegram.</p><p>He said Russian forces had so far only been &#34;fiddling&#34; with the Ukrainian army.</p><p>He also called on Putin to carry out a &#34;full coordination of the actions of the military, competent alignment of forces and a decisive assault. Everything!&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ramzan-kadyrov-russia-too-slow-in-ukraine-calls-brutal-attack-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK defense minister says Putin&#39;s nuclear alert is an attempt at distraction<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621cb7e2bea1240018a8e55e?format=jpeg\" height=\"632\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin summons meeting of Russia&#39;s Security Council at Kremlin in Moscow on February 21, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Kremlin Press Office/Handout/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"https://news.sky.com/video/ukraine-ben-wallace-says-putins-nuclear-alert-is-a-big-attempt-to-distract-12553845\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"6718e4395743f80225b1b0b582f20b01\">Ben Wallace told Sky News on Monday</a> that Putin decided to put Russia&#39;s nuclear weapons on high alert to try and distract from its invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>He said Russia did not seem more ready than it normally is to actually use its nuclear weapons.</p><p>&#34;The language that President Putin has used doesn&#39;t actually link to anything of Russian readiness procedure,&#34; Wallace said.</p><p>&#34;It&#39;s really, we assess, him putting the deterrent into the communications space, reminding people that he has a deterrent.&#34;</p><p>&#34;It&#39;s also about distracting the world and the public from what he&#39;s actually doing in Ukraine. It doesn&#39;t link to anything specific in their readiness structures of their forces.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-nuclear-alert-attempt-distract-ukraine-resistance-ben-wallace-2022-2?utm_medium=social&#38;utm_source=facebook.com&#38;utm_campaign=sf-bi-uk&#38;r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">More than half a million people have fled Ukraine since Russia invaded, UN says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62178951d0009b0019048404?format=jpeg\" height=\"3840\" width=\"5760\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine station\"/><figcaption>People wait for trains at a train station as they attempt to evacuate the city on February 24, 2022 in Kyiv, Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Pierre Crom/Getty Images)</p></figcaption></figure><p>The UN Refugee Agency <a href=\"https://twitter.com/RefugeesMedia/status/1498249979416256512?s=20&#38;t=iecy0QgLvuL09C9Su1NQpA\">said</a> on Monday that there had been &#34;more than half a million Ukrainian refugee arrivals&#34; into the countries neighboring Ukraine since the invasion.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine asks to be fast-tracked for EU membership<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/611e694734808700196815ba?format=jpeg\" height=\"2658\" width=\"3987\" charset=\"\" alt=\"European Union flags\"/><figcaption>Flags of European Union member countries.<p class=\"copyright\">Shutterstock.com</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine&#39;s president on Monday called for the EU to immediately make Ukraine a member: &#34;We call on the European Union to let Ukraine become an EU member immediately under a new special procedure.&#34;</p><p>&#34;We are grateful to our partners for being with us. But our goal is to be with all Europeans and, most importantly, to be equal. I am convinced that this is fair. it said.</p><p>It also said Russian ground forces had been &#34;slowed&#34; by Ukrainians defending an airfield.</p><p>Two senior US officials separately <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2022/02/26/politics/russian-ukraine-resistance/index.html\">told CNN</a> that Russia was facing &#34;stiffer than expected&#34; resistance from Ukraine, and that it was also struggling with unexpected difficulties in getting supplies to its forces.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Belarus is preparing to join Russia&#39;s attack, US official says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6206bacc3b86990018b2fc25?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian tanks in Belarus\"/><figcaption>Russian and Belarusian armed forces take part in military drills in Belarus on February 11, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>A senior US official <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/02/27/russia-ukraine-war-kyiv-news/\">told The Washington Post</a> that Belarus was preparing to add its troops to Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said: &#34;It&#39;s very clear Minsk is now an extension of the Kremlin.&#34;</p><p>They said Belarus could join Russia&#39;s attack as early as Monday.</p><p>Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko is a close ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Stark photos show Ukrainians, and even a local brewery, making Molotov cocktails<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c8fdabea1240018a8e2c2?format=jpeg\" height=\"3100\" width=\"4134\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A small girl sorts empty bottles for &#34;Molotov cocktails&#34; class=\"slide\">A former US ambassador to Russia says Putin is becoming &#39;increasingly unhinged&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c7ab7101faf001929606c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" from COVID-19, Russian President Vladimir Putin is becoming &#34;increasingly unhinged.&#34;</p><p><a href=\"https://politicalscience.stanford.edu/people/michael-mcfaul\" appearance on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/MeetThePress/status/1497948719446212608?s=20&#38;t=_20n54siCl6UL0exGz-dxw\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" class=\"slide\">Russians are scrambling to withdraw US dollars at ATMs as ruble hits record low<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c7a6cbea1240018a8e25d?format=jpeg\" height=\"3332\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"e1324a71220e550d9ad2140ace135953\">Russian ruble</a>&#160;tumbled nearly 30% against the greenback, dropping to as low Bank&#39;s</a>&#160;international reserves worth $630 billion.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/former-us-ambassador-to-russia-says-putin-increasingly-unhinged-2022-2\" Besides misinformation, Weibo said offending posts include &#34;vulgar content&#34; related to jokes about&#160;<a href=\"https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Ukraine-conflict/China-s-netizens-split-on-Ukraine-war-as-crude-joke-sparks-anger\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"c66bc5c32622ec9c3502fcea14f74f10\">Ukrainian women</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The platform continues to investigate and deal with inappropriate and unfriendly remarks related to &#39;Ukrainian beauties&#39;, which promote hatred and sexism,&#34;
