and &#34;almost treasonous&#34; for anyone who loves freedom to also support Russian President Vladimir Putin.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2022/02/27/politics/mitt-romney-russia-putin-ukraine-cnntv/index.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"f6db0d5d32d47eaf92e1f81cca338ba4\">During an interview on CNN&#39;s &#34;State of the Union,&#34;</a>&#160;the Utah senator was asked about the &#34;pro-Putin sentiment&#34; held by some factions of the Republican Party.</p><p>&#34;Well, a lot of those people are changing their stripes as they&#39;re seeing the response of the world and the political response here in the US,&#34; replied Romney. &#34;But how anybody, how anybody in this country, which loves freedom, can side with Vladimir Putin, which is an oppressor, a dictator.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mitt-romney-almost-treasonous-for-gop-figures-to-back-putin-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Belarus votes to remove its non-nuclear status<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c1a18101faf0019295cc1?format=jpeg\" height=\"1425\" width=\"1900\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Belarussian President Alexander Lukashenko speaks during a joint press conference at the Kremlin on September 9, 2021 in Moscow, Russia.\"/><figcaption>Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko speaks during a joint press conference at the Kremlin on September 9, 2021 in Moscow, Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Mikhail Svetlov/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Belarus voted to renounce its non-nuclear status in a constitutional referendum on Sunday, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/launchpad-russias-assault-ukraine-belarus-holds-referendum-renounce-non-nuclear-2022-02-27/\">Reuters</a> reported, citing Russian news agencies.</p><p>The vote was called by the country&#39;s authoritarian leader, President Alexander Lukashenko, as a way to &#34;cement his 27-year old grip on power,&#34; the <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-kyiv-referendums-belarus-alexander-lukashenko-3acd50c10b125bc45515ccc23a0daa4f\">Associated Press</a> reported.</p><p>The referendum means nuclear weapons could be used on Belarus&#39; soil for the first time since the Soviet Union fell in 1991.&#160;</p><p>The vote comes at a time when Russia is using Belarus as a staging ground to invade Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">European leaders imposed tough sanctions on Russia after speaking with Ukrainian president<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c1502101faf0019295ca6?format=jpeg\" height=\"1451\" width=\"1934\" charset=\"\" alt=\"President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy is pictured during his meeting with President of the Republic of Poland Andrzej Duda and President of the Republic of Lithuania Gitanas Nauseda, Kyiv, capital of Ukraine\"/><figcaption>President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky is pictured during his meeting with President of the Republic of Poland Andrzej Duda and President of the Republic of Lithuania Gitanas Nauseda, Kyiv, capital of Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Hennadii Minchenko/ Ukrinform/Future Publishing via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Several prominent European leaders, including German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, were initially hesitant to impose the toughest sanction proposals against Russian President Vladimir Putin, some of his top administration officials, and some Russian banks, but changed their mind after speaking with Ukraine&#39;s President Volodymyr Zelensky, <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2022/02/27/russia-ukraine-sanctions-swift-central-bank/\">The Washington Post</a> reported.&#160;</p><p>Zelensky video-conferenced into a Thursday night meeting with leaders of the European Union and appealed to the leaders.&#160;</p><p>The Post reported that some became &#34;watery-eyed&#34; following Zelensky&#39;s remarks from a Kyiv battlefield.&#160;</p><p data-qa=\"drop-cap-letter\" data-el=\"text\">&#34;It was extremely, extremely emotional,&#34;a European official briefed on the call told the Post. &#34;He was essentially saying: &#39;Look, we are here dying for European ideals.&#39;&#34;</p><p>In the days since the call, countries across Europe and the world have imposed some of the strictest sanctions against Russia.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">More than 300 Ukrainians have died during Russia&#39;s invasion, Ukraine&#39;s Interior Ministry says<p>Citing <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=320650796757243&#38;set=a.291369773018679\">Ukraine&#39;s Interior Ministry</a>, the <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-spacex-kyiv-business-united-nations-c5b7eb2355aff4f7f6c18b4c705dbe08\">Associated Press</a> reported that 352 Ukrainians have died during Russia&#39;s invasion of the country.&#160;</p><p>The death count includes 14 children.</p><p>Additionally, the ministry said an additional 1,684 people &#8211; including 116 children &#8211; were wounded, the AP reported.&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s hospitals could run out of oxygen in the next day as Russia&#39;s invasion prevents transportation of supplies<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621c0aa6bea1240018a8de8e?format=jpeg\" height=\"1498\" width=\"1997\" charset=\"\" alt=\"World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus attends a daily press briefing on COVID-19 at the WHO headquaters on March 11, 2020 in Geneva.\"/><figcaption>World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus attends a daily press briefing on COVID-19 at the WHO headquarters on March 11, 2020 in Geneva.<p class=\"copyright\">FABRICE COFFRINI/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The World Health Organization on Sunday warned that hospitals across Ukraine could run out of oxygen in the next 24 hours as trucks struggle to deliver supplies from plants to facilities during Russia&#39;s invasion.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The oxygen supply situation is nearing a very dangerous point in Ukraine,&#34; WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus and Europe Regional Director Hans Kluge said in a joint <a href=\"https://www.euro.who.int/en/media-centre/sections/statements/2022/statement-dangerously-low-medical-oxygen-supplies-in-ukraine-due-to-crisis,-warn-who-director-general-and-who-regional-director-for-europe\">statement</a>&#160; &#34;The majority of hospitals could exhaust their oxygen reserves within the next 24 hours. Some have already run out. This puts thousands of lives at risk.&#34;</p><p>WHO said the country needed a 25% surge of oxygen supplies compared to what it needed before Russia&#39;s invasion.&#160;</p><p>The organization called for critical medical supplies to reach those in need and said they&#39;re working with &#34;partners to establish safe transit for shipments through Poland.&#34;&#160;</p><p>Beyond the limited supply of oxygen, WHO warned that critical hospital services were being &#34;jeopardized by electricity and power shortages, and ambulances transporting patients are in danger of getting caught in the crossfire.&#34;</p><p>The supplies are needed to treat people dealing with conditions ranging from COVID-19, which could surge as people flee, and other conditions, as well as injuries sustained as a result of the conflict, WHO said.&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said his country will send an additional $53 million in humanitarian aid to Ukraine<p>In a <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/pm-announces-further-humanitarian-aid-to-ukraine\">statement</a> on Sunday, Johnson said the decision to send $53 million (£40m) came after he spoke with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and met with Ukrainian community leaders in London this weekend.&#160;</p><p>The funds will be used to &#34;provide vital medical supplies and other help to Ukraine.&#34;</p><p>&#34;The funding will help aid agencies respond to the deteriorating humanitarian situation, creating a lifeline for Ukrainians with access to basic necessities and medical supplies such as medicines, syringes, dressings, and wound care packs. UK Government humanitarian experts have also deployed to the region to support those fleeing the violence in Ukraine,&#34; the statement said.&#160;</p><p>Additionally, the statement said that &#34;in response to the growing concern of Ukrainians living in the UK about their welfare of their families back home,&#34; Johnson also confirmed that anyone settled in the UK can bring their immediate Ukrainian family members to join them.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The UK will not turn our backs in Ukraine&#39;s hour of need. We are providing all the economic and military support we can to help those Ukrainians risking everything to protect their country,&#34; Johnson said in the statement.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki said Putin&#39;s decision to put nuclear forces in a state of higher readiness is part of a pattern of &#34;manufactured threats&#34;<p>Psaki on Sunday told <a href=\"https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/week-transcript-27-22-white-house-press-secretary/story?id=83130361\">ABC&#39;s George Stephanopoulos on &#34;This Week,&#34;</a> that Putin&#39;s decision was a way for him to further justify his attack on Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>&#34;This is really a pattern that we&#39;ve seen from President Putin through the course of this conflict, which is manufacturing threats that don&#39;t exist in order to justify further aggression. And the global community and the American people should look at it through that prism. We&#39;ve seen him do this time and time again,&#34; Psaki said.</p><p>Earlier on Sunday, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-puts-russias-nuclear-deterrent-forces-after-sanctions-2022-2\">Putin put his nuclear force on high alert,</a> meaning they will be prepared for the increased possibility of launch. Putin claimed that the move was in response&#160;to statements from countries that are a part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and other western nations.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">US embassies in Russia and Ukraine issue messages warning Americans to &#39;depart now&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621caa16101faf001929627c?format=jpeg\" height=\"4028\" width=\"6236\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People gather in a metro station in Kharkiv, Ukraine.\"/><figcaption>People gather in a metro station in Kharkiv, Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Vyacheslav Madiyevskyy.</p></figcaption></figure><p>The US embassies in Russia and in Ukraine issued warnings to Americans on Sunday, directing them to &#34;depart now.&#34;&#160;</p><p>The <a href=\"https://ua.usembassy.gov/event-ukraine-land-border-crossing-options-february-27-2022/\">US Embassy in Ukraine</a> urged people to leave using &#34;privately available transportation options if it is safe,&#34; noting that in many cases, &#34;Ukraine&#39;s roads are in many cases crowded, exposed to combat operations, and infrastructure such as bridges in some locations has been destroyed.&#34;&#160;</p><p>The embassy recommended people traveling on land go to Hungary, Romania, or Slovakia, because those countries had shorter wait times for entry than Poland.</p><p>&#34;We understand that most border crossings into Poland and all main crossing points into Moldova are severely backed up and some are experiencing extremely long wait times (well over 30 hours in some cases),&#34; the embassy said.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://ru.usembassy.gov/security-alert-u-s-mission-russia/\">US Embassy in Russia</a> also urged any Americans there on Sunday to leave &#34;immediately,&#34; citing an &#34;increasing number of airlines&#34; that have canceled flights in and out of Russia and &#34;numerous countries&#34; that have banned Russian airlines.</p><p>Both Ukraine and Russia carry the US State Department&#39;s most serious &#34;Level 4: Do Not Travel&#34; warning.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kyiv mayor says city is at &#39;border of a humanitarian catastrophe&#39;<p>In a Sunday interview with the&#160;<a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-kyiv-europe-e9cd115540b398be26dfcaf472ec1621\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-kyiv-europe-e9cd115540b398be26dfcaf472ec1621\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">Associated Press</a>, Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko said the city was &#34;at the border of a humanitarian catastrophe&#34; and warned that supplies could soon run out.</p><p>&#34;Right now, we have electricity, right now we have water and heating in our houses. But the infrastructure is destroyed to deliver the food and medication,&#34; he said.</p><p>Nine civilians in Kyiv, including a child, had been killed as of Sunday, Klitschko told the AP.</p><p>He told the AP the city was &#34;encircled&#34; by Russian forces, but later walked back the comments. A spokesperson said he had misspoken.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">The EU to send weapons to Ukraine, shut airspace to Russian planes and ban state-owned media<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62176740d80ca400192ce3e5?format=jpeg\" height=\"3598\" width=\"5396\" charset=\"\" alt=\"EC President von der Leyen speaks after Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine in Brussels\"/><figcaption>EC President von der Leyen speaks after Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine in Brussels<p class=\"copyright\">Kenzo Tribouillard/Pool via REUTERS</p></figcaption></figure><p>The European Union on Sunday said it will purchase and deliver weapons to Ukraine, while also strengthening sanctions against Russia including closing its airspace to Russian planes and banning state-owned Russian media.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The European Union steps up once more its support for Ukraine and the sanctions against the aggressor that is Putin&#39;s Russia,&#34; Leyen said. &#34;For the first time ever, the European Union will finance the purchase and delivery of weapons and other equipment to a country that is under attack.&#34;</p><p>The bans and strengthened sanctions come as global support for Ukraine intensifies in response to ongoing attacks following Russia&#39;s invasion of the country on Thursday.<br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/eu-sends-weapons-ukraine-bans-russian-planes-from-airspace-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Japan joins the EU, Canada, US, and UK in banning Russian access to SWIFT global banking services<p>Japan is joining the rest of the G7 in blocking&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-economic-measures-swift-golden-passports-economic-measures-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"0cb6062eba04994bd888a284733be5c3\">Russian access</a>&#160;to SWIFT, an international banking system.</p><p>Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced Sunday that the country will band with the European Union, Canada, the UK, and the US in removing Russian banks from its SWIFT, or Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication services.</p><p>Kishida added that said Japan will also place further sanctions on Russian officials and send $100 million in emergency humanitarian aid funding to Ukraine. And with Japan&#39;s participation, the full G7 is now onboard with the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-swift-sanctions-russia-ukraine-invasion-global-banking-system-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"b13a6a10ca70086eeb5deb391186ef92\">SWIFT ban</a>.<br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/japan-joins-g7-banning-russian-access-to-swift-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">World&#39;s largest cargo aircraft was destroyed during a Russian attack on an airfield, Ukrainian minister says<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621b9dd8101faf00192958c6?format=jpeg\" height=\"2794\" width=\"4191\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy standing in front of the world&#39;s largest airplane, the Antonov An-225 Mriya.\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky standing in front of the world&#39;s largest airplane, the Antonov An-225 Mriya.<p class=\"copyright\">Efrem Lukatsky/AP</p></figcaption></figure><p>The world&#39;s largest cargo aircraft, the An-225 Mriya, has been destroyed during a Russian attack, according to<a href=\"https://twitter.com/DmytroKuleba/status/1497947370008547332\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"20d9e74ce4c2040a14bdde522d21f30b\">&#160;Ukraine&#39;s minister of foreign affairs, Dmytro Kuleba.</a></p><p>Kuleba tweeted on Sunday: &#34;Russia may have destroyed our &#39;Mriya&#39;. But they will never be able to destroy our dream of a strong, free and democratic European state.&#34;</p><p>&#34;We shall prevail!&#34; he added.</p><p>The plane was based at the Antonov Airport &#8211; also known as Hostomel Airport &#8211; according to Scottish publication&#160;<a href=\"https://www.heraldscotland.com/news/19950717.anotov-an-225-mriya-reports-worlds-largest-plane-destroyed-hostomel-airport/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"35462e0b6352723e85964b966f9fca08\">The Herald</a>.&#160;The paper reported Thursday that the airfield was struck by missiles prior to the attack.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/anotov-an-225-mriya-cargo-plane-destroyed-russian-report-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian ambassador says Zelensky is &#39;as safe as our country&#39;<p>Ukrainian Ambassador to the US Oksana Markarova on Sunday said she believed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was &#34;as safe&#34; as the rest of the country during the Russian invasion.</p><p>&#34;He is as safe as our country, and that&#39;s the choice he made to stay in Kyiv, and in Ukraine, and lead the nation in this very difficult moment,&#34; Markarova said during an appearance Sunday on ABC News&#39; &#34;This Week.&#34;&#160;</p><p>In a video posted Saturday morning local time,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2022/02/26/europe/ukraine-zelensky-evacuation-intl/index.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"e998c1bae7dd1034a96c4b8b624f2669\">Zelensky said:</a>&#160;&#34;I am here. We are not putting down arms. We will be defending our country, because our weapon is truth, and our truth is that this is our land, our country, our children, and we will defend all of this.&#34;&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-ambassador-says-zelensky-is-as-safe-as-our-country-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian missiles struck a radioactive waste disposal site near Kyiv, say Ukrainian authorities<p>Russian missiles hit a radioactive waste disposal site near Kyiv, the State Nuclear Regulatory Inspectorate of Ukraine (SNRIU)&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100064837892613\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"6ea30e1f41243a730df8e3c04b855217\">said in a statement</a>&#160;early Sunday morning.</p><p>The attack happened at about 1:20 am local time on Sunday at a disposal site of the Kyiv branch of the State Specialized Enterprise &#34;Radon.&#34; It is unclear where exactly this site is located.</p><p>&#34;The automated radiation monitoring system failed,&#34; SNRIU said in the statement. &#34;But the surveillance cameras recorded the falling missiles.&#34;</p><p>The extent of the radiation cannot be assessed until fighting in the area has ceased, SNRIU added.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/radioactive-waste-disposal-site-near-kyiv-struck-by-russian-missiles-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine and Russia set to hold negotiations at the Belarusian-Ukrainian border, Zelensky&#39;s office announced<p>Ukraine and Russia are set to hold negotiations at the Belarusian-Ukrainian border, the office of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said in a statement on Sunday,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-europe-60542877\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"e9501a667c7177b9a492b37b23961766\">according to the BBC.</a></p><p>During a phone call with Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, Zelensky agreed that a Ukrainian delegation would meet with President Putin&#39;s representatives without preconditions.</p><p>The meeting is set to take place on the Ukrainian-Belarusian border, near the Pripyat River, the statement said.</p><p>&#34;Alexander Lukashenko will ensure all planes, helicopters and missiles stationed on Belarusian territory remain on the ground during the Ukrainian delegation&#39;s travel, talks, and return,&#34; the statement added.</p><p data-reactid=\".ahcoxnq2ym.0.2.0.0.1.0.1.0.$lx-tabs0.0.$lx-commentary.$lx-commentary.2.0.1.1.1:$post-621b82cf980bea49f4b7a4d1.0.6.0.0:$post_4\">Neither Russia nor Belarus have issued any statements about potential talks.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-confirms-talks-plan-with-russia-at-belarusian-border-zelensky-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin orders Russia&#39;s nuclear deterrent forces on high alert in response to &#39;illegitimate Western sanctions&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6214c664f0b06900185ed1aa?format=jpeg\" height=\"1968\" width=\"2768\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into eastern Ukraine on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Alexei Nikolsky/Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin on Sunday ordered Russia&#39;s nuclear deterrent forces to be on alert amid his ongoing attack on Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>Putin blamed the move on statements from member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and on statements from western nations.</p><p>&#34;Dear colleagues, as you see, Western countries are not only taking hostile actions toward our country in the economic sphere&#8212;I am talking about the illegitimate sanctions everybody knows about,&#34; Putin said in a statement translated to English.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-puts-russias-nuclear-deterrent-forces-after-sanctions-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine files a lawsuit against Russia at the International Court of Justice in the Hague<p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said the country has filed a lawsuit against Russia at the International Court of Justice in the Hague.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Russia must be held accountable for manipulating the notion of genocide to justify aggression,&#34; he <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ZelenskyyUa/status/1497885721931268103?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1497885721931268103%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&#38;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2Feurope%2Flive-news%2Fukraine-russia-news-02-27-22%2Findex.html\">tweeted Sunday</a>, adding that the country expects trials to start &#34;next week.&#34;</p><p>The International Court of Justice, located in The Netherlands, is the main judicial organ of the United Nations.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">1.4 million civilians in Ukraine&#39;s second-largest city, have been told to take shelter as Russian troops arrive<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217f326d80ca400192d0458?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Kharkiv\"/><figcaption>Black smoke rises from a military airport in Chuguyev near Kharkiv, Ukraine, on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">ARIS MESSINIS/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The 1.4 million residents in Ukraine&#39;s second-largest city, Kharkiv, have been urged to shelter indoors after government officials said Russian troops had arrived.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/synegubov.oleg/posts/507022630775096\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7c3153c930a8aea5b981a6e4b686db81\">In a statement</a>&#160;on Sunday morning, Kharkiv&#39;s governor Oleg Sinegubov told people not to leave their homes after a &#34;breakthrough of light equipment of the Russian enemy&#34; reached the central part of the city.</p><p>Russian troops blew up a nine-story residential block overnight, killing one elderly woman,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60543087\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"d0650c37c8109c5e06a2f4026f7731a8\">the BBC reported</a>, citing emergency services.</p><p>Russian forces also blew up a major gas pipeline in the city, which the Ukrainian government said could result in an &#34;environmental catastrophe,&#34;&#160;<a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-volodymyr-zelenskyy-kyiv-europe-united-nations-edc6df79755195b29473cfd6d38b1ebb?utm_campaign=SocialFlow&#38;utm_medium=AP&#38;utm_source=Twitter\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"1e3ac65bc979c31338d6c1ee652392e5\">the Associated Press</a>&#160;reported.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kharkiv-under-siege-russians-enter-ukraines-second-largest-city-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kremlin website was down<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621b691bbea1240018a8d8fe?format=jpeg\" height=\"724\" width=\"965\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The Kremlin Palace in Moscow, Russia.\"/><figcaption>The Kremlin Palace in Moscow, Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Jarung H/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><p>The official website of the Kremlin, kremlin.ru, was down on Saturday, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/official-kremlin-website-down-amid-war-ukraine-2022-02-26/\">Reuters reported.</a></p><p data-testid=\"paragraph-1\">The outage came after Ukrainian Vice Prime Minister Mykhailo Fedorov said the country&#160;will create an &#34;IT army&#34; to fight against Russia&#39;s digital intrusions.</p><p data-testid=\"paragraph-1\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/FedorovMykhailo/status/1497642156076511233\">In a tweet</a> that linked to a channel on the Telegram messaging app, which published a list of prominent Russian websites, Fedorov said: &#34;We are creating an IT army. There will be tasks for everyone. We continue to fight on the cyber front. The first task is on the channel for cyber specialists.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">President Zelensky appeals for foreign volunteers to come to Ukraine and enlist in a &#39;International Legion&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621b671cbea1240018a8d8f3?format=jpeg\" height=\"614\" width=\"818\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky<p class=\"copyright\">Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine is establishing an International Legion for foreigners who want to come and fight against Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Sunday.</p><p>&#34;Anyone who wants to join the defense of Ukraine, Europe and the world can come and fight side by side with the Ukrainians against the Russian war criminals,&#34; the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/zvernennya-do-gromadyan-inozemnih-derzhav-yaki-pragnut-dopom-73213?fbclid=IwAR0OmNJ9RnElRHRK2oQUKTpkqwjZ-vFKw02-a9F-s7IdwKl9rPZNnrztgvc\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"cf898dc821e915fb07ab7c6896cbc27b\">statement</a>&#160;on the presidential website said.</p><p>Zelensky called for international solidarity against Russia and said in the statement that Russia&#39;s invasion was &#34;the beginning of a war against Europe.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-international-legion-foreigners-join-fight-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian border guards who told Russian warship &#39;go fuck yourself&#39; may still be alive<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621b6606101faf0019295713?format=jpeg\" height=\"1141\" width=\"1522\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Zmiinyi (Snake) Island Ukraine\"/><figcaption>Zmiinyi (Snake) Island is situated near the Ukrainian and Romanian coasts along the Black Sea.<p class=\"copyright\">Google Maps</p></figcaption></figure><p>A group of 13 Ukrainian border guards who were thought to have been killed while defending an island from a Russian warship may still be alive, the State Border Guard Service of Ukraine (SBGSU)&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/DPSUkraine/posts/285013563737521\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"109e2597446b95a7ecec9c5d8b85c9a3\">said in a statement</a>&#160;on Saturday.</p><p>&#34;We [have a] strong belief that all Ukrainian defenders of Zmiinyi (Snake) Island may be alive,&#34; the border agency said.</p><p>&#34;Preliminary information that border guards may be dead came before the defenders lost contact,&#34; it added.</p><p>The statement comes two days after&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-border-guards-on-zmiinyi-island-died-as-heroes-zelensky-says-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"44d0d4af2178796645adc9aaf8db786b\">reports said that 13 border guards on Zmiinyi Island had died</a>&#160;when they refused to surrender to a Russian warship, telling it &#34;go fuck yourself&#34; per an audio recording.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-border-guards-who-defended-island-russia-could-be-alive-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Elon Musk says Starlink satellite service is activated in Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61a105251ca5280018115fc6?format=jpeg\" height=\"3123\" width=\"3926\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Elon Musk, Tesla CEO, stands at a press event on the grounds of the Tesla Gigafactory.\"/><figcaption>Elon Musk, Tesla CEO<p class=\"copyright\">Patrick Pleul/picture alliance via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>SpaceX founder Elon Musk responded to pleas from a Ukrainian government official on Saturday, agreeing to send Starlink terminals to the country amid the Russian invasion that has disrupted internet services.</p><p>&#34;Starlink service is now active in Ukraine. More terminals en route,&#34; Musk tweeted at Ukrainian Vice Prime Minister Mykhailo Fedorov.</p><p>Internet connectivity throughout Ukraine has been affected by the invasion, though the extent wasn&#39;t immediately clear on Saturday.</p><p>In response to Musk&#39;s announcement, the official Twitter account for Ukraine tweeted at Musk: &#34;thankx, appreciate it.&#34;</p><p><a Press</a> reported.&#160;</p><p>Residents were advised to cover their windows with damp cloth or gauze and the Ukrainian government warned that smoke from the explosion in the country&#39;s second-largest city could result in an &#34;environmental catastrophe,&#34; the AP reported.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">There are at least 240 civilian casualties so far, according to the UN<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ad7ef101faf001929544f?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A Ukrainian soldier walks past debris of a burning military truck, on a street in Kyiv, Ukraine, Saturday, Feb. 26, 2022.\"/><figcaption>A Ukrainian soldier walks past debris of a burning military truck, on a street in Kyiv, Ukraine, Saturday, Feb. 26, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Efrem Lukatsky</p></figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"https://reliefweb.int/report/ukraine/ukraine-humanitarian-impact-situation-report-no-1-500-pm-26-february-2022\">The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights reported</a> that there have been at least 240 civilian casualties, including at least 64 deaths in Ukraine, since the start of Russia&#39;s invasion.&#160;</p><p>Hundreds of homes have also been damaged, and the damage to infrastructure has left thousands without power or water, the OHCHR reported.&#160;</p><p>The <a data-ti=\"overview\" data-ved=\"2ahUKEwiT6a-X4p72AhVGVhoKHavnC0gQnZMFegQIEhAC\">United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees also reported that over 160,000 people are internally displaced and more than 116,000 have fled to neighboring countries.&#160;</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">French President Emmanuel Macron called on Belarus to order Russian troops to leave<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621ac5c3bea1240018a8d650?format=jpeg\" height=\"823\" width=\"1647\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Emmanuel Macron\"/><figcaption>French President Emmanuel Macron meets Russian President Vladimir Putin on February 07, 2022 in Moscow, Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>In a call on Saturday, French President Emmanuel Macron asked Alexander Lukashenko, the president of Belarus, to demand Russian troops be withdrawn from Belarusian soil, a <a points Russia used to invade the country.&#160;</p><p>Macron denounced &#34;the seriousness of a decision that would authorize Russia to deploy nuclear weapons on Belarusian soil&#34; and told Lukashenko that Belarus should &#34;refuse to be Russia&#39;s vassal and de facto accomplice in the war against Ukraine.&#34;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Western nations agree to cut &#39;selected Russian banks&#39; from the SWIFT global banking system<p>The United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom, and Canada struck an agreement Saturday evening to remove certain Russian banks from SWIFT.</p><p>SWIFT is a payment system that is crucial for global financial communication. Removing Russia from the system could be economically devastating for the nation.</p><p>In a joint statement, the US and its counterparts declared that the move would help &#34;collectively ensure that this war is a strategic failure for Putin.&#34;</p><p>&#34;As Russian forces unleash their assault on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities, we are resolved to continue imposing costs on Russia that will further isolate Russia from the international financial system and our economies,&#34; the statement said.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-eu-announce-some-russian-banks-removed-from-swift-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Germany to send anti-tank weapons and missiles to Ukraine in a major policy reversal<p>Germany is planning to send 1,000 anti-tank weapons and 500 Stinger missiles to Ukraine, according to a statement made by German Chancellor Olaf Scholz on Saturday.&#160;</p><p>&#34;The Russian attack marks a turning point,&#34; Scholz wrote in a statement&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/Bundeskanzler/status/1497632817450266632\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"87a793d157d887774af800f97953d323\">shared on Twitter.</a>&#160;&#34;It is our duty to do our best to help Ukraine defend against the invading army of Putin. That&#39;s why we&#39;re supplying 1000 anti-tank weapons and 500 stinger missiles to our friends in Ukraine.&#34;</p><p>The announcement marks a significant shift of Germany&#39;s restrictive arms export policy. The country has previously said it held &#34;historical responsibilities&#34; that prevented it from sending weapons and arms to conflict areas, often citing guilt for crimes committed against the Soviet Union during World War II.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/germany-sends-weapons-to-ukraine-arms-export-policy-reversal-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian forces are &#39;frustrated&#39; with lack of progress, US official says<p>&#160;</p><p>According to a Reuters report, the US official, who was not named by the outlet, said Russian forces had not planned to bring enough fuel or for other basic logistics.&#160;</p><p data-testid=\"paragraph-5\">&#34;We know that they have not made the progress that they have wanted to make, particularly in the north. to &#39;please come over&#39; and help defend against Russian invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6219d321bea1240018a8cfe7?format=jpeg\" height=\"614\" width=\"1068\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky<p class=\"copyright\">Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday remained defiant in the face of Russia&#39;s invasion, confirming that government forces continued to control Kyiv and &#34;key points around the city.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Please stop those who are lying, or trying to lie to you, or lying to us. remaining in Kyiv early Saturday morning.&#160;</p><p>As Russian forces intensify their attacks against the capital city, the embassy warned US citizens to exercise increased caution due to the possibility of active combat, crime, and civil unrest.</p><p>&#34;The security situation throughout Ukraine is highly volatile, and conditions may deteriorate without warning,&#34; the statement said. &#34;US citizens should remain vigilant and take appropriate steps to increase their security awareness.&#34;</p><p>The advisory urged US citizens to know the location of &#34;your closest shelter or protected space,&#34; and seek shelter immediately in &#34;the event of mortar and/or rocket fire.&#34;&#160;</p><p>&#34;If you feel your current location is no longer safe, you should carefully assess the potential risks involved in moving to a different location,&#34; the advisory said.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">US government prepared to evacuate President Zelensky, according to href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/02/25/russia-ukraine-president-zelensky-family-target/\">The Washington Post.</a></p><p>US and Ukrainian officials told the outlet that preparations have been made to help Zelensky avoid being captured or killed as Russian forces descended upon the capital city early Saturday morning.</p><p>Amid increasing Russian attacks on Friday, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-says-that-enemy-sabotage-groups-have-entered-kyiv-2022-2\">Zelensky promised to remain at the head of Ukraine&#39;s government in Kyiv</a>, despite the danger.</p><p>&#34;According to the information we have, the enemy has marked me as target No. 1, my family as target No.2,&#34; he said in an address. &#34;They want to destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state.&#34;</p><p>Insider has reached out to the White House and the State Department for comment.&#160;</p><p>A senior US official told The Post that US officials in recent days have talked to Zelensky about multiple security issues, including the safest place for the president to remain to maintain the Ukrainian government.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We have been making him aware not only of the threat of Russian invasion, now a reality, but also the threat to him personally,&#34; Rep. Adam Schiff, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, told The Post. &#34;We stand ready to assist him in any way.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Satellite image shows 4-mile-long traffic $6.4 billion in additional spending to aid Ukraine amid Russia&#39;s invasion, according to <a funds would go to humanitarian and security needs in Ukraine, the Baltics, and Poland, including food aid, refugee assistance, and energy stabilization.&#160;</p><p>The remaining $3.5 billion would help the US Department of Defense respond to the conflict, a Biden administration official told Bloomberg.</p><p>The funds could be included in a broad government spending package Congress is aiming professor says he spotted Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine on Google Maps hours before Putin announced the attack<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62191263d80ca400192d292d?format=jpeg\" tanks from advancing.</p><p>Vitaliy Skakun Volodymyrovych was positioned at the Henichesk bridge in the Kherson region during a standoff with Russian forces, the General Staff of the Armed Forces of href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GeneralStaff.ua/posts/258798803099872?__cft__[0]=AZVi4yMdCtHcLLtq9uE1UcxTh-6rGNranTpIS8r_myLUtb1b1kEjoF8ci9Kn6hEgSRcBf2GBURpsQInFOKZqIzM_uFz0aC3CtFrdWokl9tiHSXW5Yrye7rhg5RsOEW3I8eHG6iJEvJgtHkkZm22CHblc&#38;__tn__=%2CO%2CP-R\" Ukrainian forces decided to blow up the bridge, the statement said.</p><p>&#34;According to his brothers in arms, Vitaly got in touch [with them] and said he was going to blow up the bridge,&#34; the the country, saying that only an ID was required and adding, &#34;We give weapons to all patriots!&#34;</p><p>&#34;We will give weapons to anyone who wants to defend the country,&#34; Ukrainian media denies its military attacked Kyiv and claims Ukraine shot down its own plane there<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6218ef98d80ca400192d1bda?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" Russia insisted it was not attacking the city.<p class=\"copyright\">Pierre Crom/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>On Thursday and into Friday it was clear to most people around the world that&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-attacks-ukraine-launching-new-war-in-europe-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"1ed888fad4c83227c3707319b1306987\">Russia had invaded Ukraine</a>, and moved quickly to attack its capital, Kyiv.</p><p>But those receiving their news from Russia&#39;s vast array of state media outlets were given no sense of this, according to a review by Insider and other monitors.</p><p>A selection of stories from the front pages of major Russian outlets in the early afternoon of Friday, the second day of hostilities around Kyiv, show the news the Russian state is promoting.&#160;</p><p>They had a common theme: Russia is winning, Ukraine is planning atrocities, and there are no Russian attacks on Kyiv.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-state-media-denies-kyiv-attack-says-ukraine-attacking-self-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full explosions overnight, interspersed with air raid sirens directing people to find safety in bunkers.&#160;</p><p>Alisa Obraztsova, 25, said she was rocked away by explosions at 4:20 a.m.</p><p>&#34;I slept in the guest room in my apartment because I could hear the sirens from that room better,&#34; she said.&#160;</p><p>Oleksii, a Kyiv resident who asked to be identified only by his first name, told Insider he was also startled awake by bombs.</p><p>&#34;I woke up at around 4 a.m. because there was a massive explosion,&#34; he said. &#34;I looked out the window, everything was a bright Russia has not given a death toll.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine says radiation levels around Chernobyl are increasing after Russia captured it<figure><img Ukraine.</p><p>Ukraine&#39;s president is a Jewish man whose native language is Russian. He came into office after a democratic election.</p><p>Russia has previously tried to justify its attack by claiming it wanted to prevent a &#34;genocide&#34; in Ukraine and to achieve the &#34;de-Nazification&#34; of the country.</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kyiv mayor and former heavyweight boxing champion says he&#39;ll fight for Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6218a816d80ca400192d125a?format=jpeg\" height=\"1327\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Wladimir Klitschko (L) and his brother Vitali Klitschko speak after defeat to Anthony Joshua in the IBF, WBA and IBO Heavyweight World Title bout at Wembley Stadium\"/><figcaption>Wladimir and Vitali Klitschko.<p class=\"copyright\">Getty/Richard Heathcote</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian boxing icons Vitali and Wladimir Klitschko said they would take up arms to defend Ukraine against Russia.</p><p>Vitali, who has also been the mayor of Ukraine&#39;s capital, Kyiv, since 2014, said he was ready to fight in a &#34;bloody war.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t have another choice, I have to do that. Honestly &#8212; I do not see such. Who is ready to guarantee Ukraine&#39;s accession to NATO? Honestly, everyone is afraid.&#34;</p><p>Many nations have condemned Russia and sent weapons to Ukraine. But they have not sent troops, and NATO and the US have said they won&#39;t do so.</p><p>Zelensky also praised the people of Ukraine in his <a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/zvernennya-prezidenta-do-ukrayinciv-naprikinci-pershogo-dnya-73149\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"f7596c2cc1b52885bc1a8dc4c93ec952\">speech,</a>&#160;saying: &#34;You are brilliantly defending the country from one of the most powerful countries in the world.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-president-says-country-left-alone-defend-from-russia-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine posts instructions for making Molotov cocktails and asks people who own drones for help<p>The post below, from Ukraine&#39;s national guard, contained instructions on how to make Molotov cocktails to use against Russian troops.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;НГУ  (@ng_ukraine) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1497132635071541251?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">February 25, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Ukraine&#39;s military also posted a Facebook callout on Friday asking for drone owners to help out.</p><p>&#34;Do you know how to drive a drone? of ethnic Russians in the country.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Kay Nietfeld/picture alliance via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian forces attacked Ukraine early Thursday morning, launching a large-scale and unprovoked invasion that was feared for weeks.</p><p>Here are some reasons Russian President Vladimir Putin has given for why Russia invaded Ukraine &#8212; some of which are based on falsehoods &#8212; along with what the US and NATO have said about his motivations.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-russia-is-attacking-ukraine-putin-justification-for-invasion-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The Biden administration is considering training Ukrainian soldiers in an outside country, according to Axios<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61eb2bcf2b43ff00185e20ab?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian soldiers\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian soldiers patrol on the frontline in Zolote, Ukraine on January 20, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Wolfgang Schwan/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>As Russian forces <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-capital-kyiv-attacked-missiles-2022-2\">enclose on Ukraine&#39;s capital Kyiv</a>, the Biden administration is eyeing its next steps in the ongoing conflict.</p><p>Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin told House lawmakers on Thursday that the US government is considering possible ways to train Ukrainian troops outside of Ukraine, should Russia seize control of the country, according to <a href=\"https://www.axios.com/us-ukraine-troop-training-47be92ec-3693-4f60-88b8-19ff0055134e.html?utm_campaign=organic&#38;utm_medium=socialshare&#38;utm_source=twitter\">Axios</a>.</p><p>Austin reportedly told lawmakers that officials are trying to find ways to provide more defense equipment, including ammunition to Ukrainian forces &#8212; a feat made more challenging as Russian forces assault the country.</p><p>The secretary also told House members that the Biden administration will continue to support Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky&#39;s government as long as it is &#34;viable,&#34; the outlet reported.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian president announces general mobilization of all conscripts and reservists to last 90 days<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62184b09d80ca400192d0fff?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Soldiers sit inside the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian soldiers sit on top of a military vehicle parked outside the hotel in Prypiat, Ukraine on February 4.<p class=\"copyright\">Volodymyr Tarasov/Ukrinform/Future Publishing via Getty Image</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/GeneralStaff.ua/posts/258421829804236\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"a3ceb58ae510d97009e2a35d269ccbea\">ordered</a>&#160;a general military mobilization throughout the country as&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-attacks-ukraine-launching-new-war-in-europe-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"1ed888fad4c83227c3707319b1306987\">Russia continues its large-scale military assault in Ukraine.</a>&#160;</p><p>The declaration ordered the conscription of conscripts and reservists for military service, as well as their delivery to military units and institutions of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in order to &#34;ensure the defense of the state.&#34;&#160;</p><p>The mobilization, which included all of Ukraine&#39;s major cities, will be carried out within 90 days, the decree said. It will provide personnel, vehicles, infrastructure, and land use for the Ukrainian government and military amid Russia&#39;s ongoing invasion, according to the decree.&#160;</p><p>Ukraine has also banned all male citizens ages 18-60 from leaving the country, according to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/europe/live-news/ukraine-russia-news-02-24-22-intl/h_4309a4916d57670f85519210a07fb2c9\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"df0600393f4fcbee98586b18c8a7edcf\">CNN</a>, which cited the State Border Guard Service.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-president-announces-general-mobilization-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Zelensky says &#39;enemy sabotage groups have entered Kyiv&#39; and that he is &#39;number one target&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6216483645889c0019d1e1df?format=jpeg\" height=\"3200\" width=\"4266\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky delivers a statement during the 58th Munich Security Conference (MSC) on February 19, 2022 in Munich, Germany.\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky delivers a statement during the 58th Munich Security Conference (MSC) on February 19, 2022 in Munich, Germany.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Ronald Wittek - Pool/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>In&#160;<a href=\"https://www.president.gov.ua/en/news/zvernennya-prezidenta-do-ukrayinciv-naprikinci-pershogo-dnya-73149\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"f7596c2cc1b52885bc1a8dc4c93ec952\">his second video address</a>&#160;on Thursday, Ukraine&#39;s President Volodymyr Zelensky said that &#34;enemy sabotage groups&#34; entered Kyiv, and that he plans to remain, despite being Russia&#39;s &#34;number one target.&#34;</p><p>&#34;According to preliminary data, unfortunately, we have lost 137 of our heroes today &#8212; our citizens. Ten of them are officers,&#34; Zelensky said in his address. &#34;316 are wounded.&#34;</p><p>He also used the opportunity to dispel rumors that he had fled Kyiv, and that his family had left the country.</p><p>&#34;I stay in the capital, I stay with my people. During the day, I held dozens of international talks, directly managed our country. And I will stay in the capital,&#34; he said. &#34;My family is also in Ukraine. My children are also in Ukraine. My family is not traitors. They are the citizens of Ukraine. But I have no right to say where they are now.&#34;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-says-that-enemy-sabotage-groups-have-entered-kyiv-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">White House is &#39;outraged&#39; over reports that staff at Chernobyl have been taken hostage by Russian forces<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62183bced80ca400192d0f10?format=jpeg\" height=\"3780\" width=\"5040\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Servicemen take part in a joint tactical and special exercises of the Ukrainian Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ukrainian National Guard and Ministry Emergency in a ghost city of Pripyat, near Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant on February 4, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Servicemen take part in a joint tactical and special exercises of the Ukrainian Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Ukrainian National Guard and Ministry Emergency in a ghost city of Pripyat, near Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant on February 4, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Supinsky/AFP/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Press secretary Jen Psaki said the White House is outraged over reports from Ukrainian officials that staff at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine have been taken hostage by Russian troops.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-troops-attack-through-chernobyl-exclusion-zone-risks-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"469818cd82e75741617b6936f815ca45\">Russian forces took over the remnants of Chernobyl</a>&#160;earlier on Thursday during the country&#39;s invasion of Ukraine. The move indicated Russia is likely to assault Ukraine&#39;s capital city, Kyiv, which is located just south of Chernobyl, the site of one of the worst nuclear disasters in history.</p><p>&#34;We&#39;re outraged by credible reports that Russian soldiers are currently holding the staff of the Chernobyl facility hostage,&#34; Psaki said during a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uwcTOWJlAyI\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"4f4e30e3f8d821bb0591aea0a62a866a\">press briefing</a>&#160;on Thursday afternoon, adding &#34;we condemn it and we request their release.&#34;</p><p>Psaki said the situation at Chernobyl was not clear but that the hostage taking was &#34;incredibly alarming and greatly concerning,&#34; adding it could hurt efforts to maintain the facility, which is dangerously contaminated with radioactivity as a result of the 1986 nuclear disaster.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-obama-official-invasion-could-be-start-cold-war-2-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">read full STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">US secretary of state is &#39;convinced&#39; Russia will try to overthrow the Ukrainian government<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62182ddcd80ca400192d0e5c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1545\" width=\"2061\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Antony Blinken\"/><figcaption>US Secretary of State Antony Blinken during an appearance on NBC&#39;s &#34;Meet the Press&#34; on April 11, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Meet The Press/NBC</p></figcaption></figure><p>US Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday said he is &#34;convinced&#34; Moscow will try to overthrow Ukraine&#39;s government.</p><p>&#34;You don&#39;t need intelligence to tell you that that&#39;s exactly what President Putin wants. He has made clear he&#39;d like to reconstitute the Soviet Empire, short of that he&#39;d like to reassert a sphere of influence around the neighboring countries that were once part of the Soviet bloc,&#34; Blinken said during a national TV interview.&#160;</p><p>The secretary pledged that NATO would intervene before Putin successfully accomplished his ultimate goal.</p><p>&#34;Now, when it comes to a threat beyond Ukraine&#39;s borders. There&#39;s something very powerful standing in his way. That&#39;s article five of NATO, an attack on one is an attack on all,&#34; the top diplomat said.</p><p>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Expert says Russia&#39;s Ukraine invasion will result in &#39;horrific scenes,&#39; could be launch of &#39;Cold War 2.0&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62180f7ed80ca400192d0cdc?format=jpeg\" height=\"4476\" width=\"5968\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Protester holds sign saying &#34;Stop Putin&#34;\"/><figcaption>Ukrainians gather in front of the White House in Washington, USA to stage a protest against Russia&#39;s attack in Ukraine on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Yasin Öztürk/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>A former aide to President Barack Obama is warning that Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine is a &#34;game changer&#34; in international relations that will result in &#34;horrific scenes&#34; in the coming days, with President Vladimir Putin intent on pursuing regime change at all costs.</p><p>&#34;I think it&#39;s just a matter of time before Kyiv falls,&#34; Charles Kupchan, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations who also served on the National Security Council in both the Obama and Clinton administrations, told Insider.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-obama-official-invasion-could-be-start-cold-war-2-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">READ FULL STORY</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">The White House says it&#39;s ready to accept Ukrainians fleeing the Russian invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6202e710bd504100191947c4?format=jpeg\" height=\"3915\" width=\"5221\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Jen Psaki\"/><figcaption>White House press secretary Jen Psaki.<p class=\"copyright\">Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The US is prepared to accept Ukrainian refugees fleeing Russia&#39;s invasion, White House press secretary Jen Psaki told <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/europe/live-news/ukraine-russia-news-02-24-22-intl/index.html\">CNN</a>.</p><p>&#34;We are,&#34; Psaki said when asked whether the US was ready to assist fleeing Ukrainians. &#34;But we certainly expect that most if not the majority will want to go to Europe and neighboring countries. So, we are also working with European countries on what the needs are, where there is capacity. Poland, for example, where we are seeing an increasing flow of refugees over the last 24 hours.&#34;</p><p>She added that US officials have been engaging with Europeans on the matter &#34;for some time.&#34;&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian and Russian forces have been fighting for hours over a critical airfield just outside Kyiv<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217eb09d80ca400192d0192?format=jpeg\" height=\"3068\" width=\"4091\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian troops stand guard near Gostomel airport\"/><figcaption>Ukraine army says battle under way for airbase near Kyiv on February 24, 2022<p class=\"copyright\">Daniel LEAL / Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukrainian and Russian forces have been fighting for hours over a critical airfield on the outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine&#39;s capital city.</p><p>Russian forces attacked and seized Hostomel (Gostomel) airfield, a cargo airport near Kyiv that is also known as Antonov airport, early Thursday,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220224-battle-underway-for-airbase-on-kyiv-outskirts\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9234e09e60ff446a5538fa02b0ebb94d\">according to AFP</a>. Ukraine&#39;s leadership reportedly vowed to take it back.</p><p>&#34;The enemy paratroopers in Hostomel have been blocked, and troops have received an order to destroy them,&#34; Ukraine&#39;s data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"f1d85269e93360ec571b9960178a8b6c\">fled the country</a>&#160;as Russia&#39;s&#160;<a their own currency&#39;s value will continue to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-24/ruble-extends-slump-in-offshore-trading-as-ukraine-crisis-grows\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"609c354cfa33ebb0fb328e1a21559cae\">tank</a>, according to the&#160;<a data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"f46e79b333ea4b33aa5fd01c70a0f297\">Wall Street Journal</a>. Banks in the capital city of Moscow are running out of money, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fFGKbbXsg4c\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b2f5f4d76df100681e8eba27361212d6\">MSNBC reported</a>.&#160;</p><p>All of this has&#160;<a href=\"https://nypost.com/2022/02/24/ukrainians-flood-atms-to-withdraw-cash-as-russian-war-begins/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9328618b3afb7928537c6ec96848f9a1\">led to fears</a>&#160;of bank runs, which is when people withdraw money en masse because they worry banks will cease to function. That&#39;s what happened in the United States during the Great&#160;<a href=\"https://www.insider.com/what-is-depression\" data-site=\"in\" data-keyword=\"depression\" data-analytics-product-module=\"Auto-Linker\" data-analytics-product-area=\"link\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"5de12b83b74d2c59cdba2cc7914e16d9\">Depression</a>, and it triggered mass unemployment and loan scarcities.&#160;&#160;</p><p><br/><a class=\"slide\">A top Russian business lobbyist pleaded with Putin to &#39;demonstrate as much as possible&#39; that Russia wants to remain &#39;part of the global economy&#39;<figure><img and Entrepreneurs just hours after Russian forces began attacks in Ukraine.</p><p>The threat of new sanctions was enough for Alexander Shokhin, the business group&#39;s president, to raise concerns with Putin about remaining a member of the world economy.</p><p>The lobbyist urged the president to pad against major economic pain and to ensure conflict in Ukraine doesn&#39;t fuel widespread harm including ones for the Kremlin and the legislature &#8212; went dark after cyberattacks target Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217c873d80ca400192cf7de?format=jpeg\" height=\"3508\" width=\"4678\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A night view of Kyiv as the Kyiv mayor declared a curfew from 10pm to 7am on February 24, 2022 in Kyiv, Ukraine.\"/><figcaption>A night view of Kyiv as the Kyiv mayor declared a curfew from 10pm to 7am on February 24, 2022 in Kyiv, Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by Pierre Crom/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Multiple Russian government websites reportedly went down on Thursday after the country&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-invasion-map-where-russian-troops-attacking-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"bcd08180d9f1722856116d8775b3c2ca\">launched an attack on Ukraine.&#160;</a></p><p>NetBlocks, which tracks disruptions and shutdowns, confirmed on&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/netblocks/status/1496904885455007749?s=20&#38;t=NhkiDbIK3ZQkBVu05avaOg\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ad3bf511284915bc11e64fb046431f9d\">Twitter</a>&#160;that multiple sites went offline shortly after 8:45 p.m. local time in Moscow.</p><p>The&#160;<a href=\"http://en.kremlin.ru/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"580665bf0a85128ea1000ee972284654\">Kremlin</a>&#39;s website and that of the Russian Federal Assembly&#39;s lower house &#8212; or&#160;<a href=\"http://duma.gov.ru/en/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"3db6fa253e722ce5211d86682c86494c\">State Duma</a>&#160;&#8212; were both down for at least 15 minutes. As of 9 p.m. local time, the State Duma website was since restored.&#160;</p><p>Shortly after 9:10 p.m. local time, the Kremlin&#39;s website was also back online.&#160;&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-government-websites-go-offline-after-cyberattacks-on-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin had a range of ways to attack Ukraine. He went with the worst-case scenario for the West.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217bedfd0009b0019049235?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian armed forces trucks move along a Ukrainian road under a dim sky, February 23, 2022\"/><figcaption>A convoy of Russian military vehicles is seen as the vehicles move towards border in Donbas region of eastern Ukraine on February 23, 2022 in Russian border city Rostov.<p class=\"copyright\">Stringer/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>In the build-up to Russia&#39;s assault on Ukraine, analysts and leaders envisioned numerous ways the conflict might play out, from a limited incursion to an all-out invasion.</p><p>Putin used precision missile strikes and airstrikes, followed shortly later by ground maneuvers, the officials said.</p><p>Analysts said attacks came from the east, south, and north, a description consistent with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-invades-ukraine-eyewitnesses-to-bombing-of-kyiv-odessa-kharkiv-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"19c571d7d041cb98e7322108bc1cf261\">reports on the ground</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/map-of-explosions-attacks-in-ukraine-as-russia-invades-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"135aa4cfe0af1c7a653b26547253f85a\">Insider&#39;s map of the invasion</a>.</p><p>All three lines of attack &#8212;&#160;<a href=\"https://theconversation.com/ukraine-how-an-armed-conflict-could-play-out-175274\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7a63775cc5a1ccc54b8f6a0b5dfa7f8f\">as per this analysis in The Conversation</a>&#160;&#8212; had previously been floated as individual possibilities for an invasion.</p><p>Defense analysts warned that Russia&#39;s multipronged attack was full-scale but still in an early phase, with a lot more forces to push into Ukraine to seize key areas or capture its leadership.</p><p>Putin&#39;s overall endgame remains an area of pressing debate.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-invasion-of-ukraine-was-extreme-option-worst-case-scenario-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Key Democratic congressman says the US can&#39;t send support to Ukraine quickly enough &#39;to repel&#39; Russia&#39;s invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217be5ad80ca400192cf51e?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Adam Smith\"/><figcaption>Rep. Adam Smith, Chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.<p class=\"copyright\">Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Rep. Adam Smith, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, ruled out surging supplies into Ukraine as a last-ditch effort to stall Russia&#39;s invasion, arguing it&#39;s unlikely such support would arrive quickly enough to make a difference.</p><p>&#34;The odd of us being able to do that in a rapid enough fashion to be able to repel the invasion are remote,&#34; Smith told CNN on Thursday when asked about a Ukrainian official&#39;s request for more equipment. &#34;I don&#39;t think it&#39;s realistic to think that we can reinforce them enough in the short term to be able to repel the invasion.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-support-weapons-ukraine-russia-invasion-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Poland, Czech Republic, and Sweden are refusing to play their 2022 World Cup qualifying matches in Russia after it attacked Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217ba41d80ca400192cf3bf?format=jpeg\" height=\"3354\" width=\"4472\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A protester holds a poster reading &#34;Sanctions against Russia now&#34; during a rally in front of the Russian Embassy in Stockholm on February 24, 2022, after Russia launched military operations in Ukraine.\"/><figcaption>A protester holds a poster reading &#34;Sanctions against Russia now&#34; during a rally in front of the Russian Embassy in Stockholm on February 24, 2022, after Russia launched military operations in Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by CLAUDIO BRESCIANI/TT News Agency/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Poland, Czech Republic, and Sweden said they are refusing to play their upcoming 2022 World Cup qualifying playoff matches in Russia after it attacked Ukraine on Thursday.</p><p>Based on the latest Russian aggression against Ukraine, &#34;the signatories to this appeal do not consider travelling to Russia and playing football matches there,&#34; the three countries said in a&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/pzpn_pl/status/1496872666061754368/photo/1\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"a35496bcf5b2aa502de943b72c101d5b\">joint statement</a>&#160;addressed to FIFA&#39;s General Secretary Fatma Samoura.&#160;</p><p>The statement continued: &#34;The military escalation that we are observing entails serious consequences and considerably lower safety for our national football teams and official delegations.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/countries-refuse-to-play-world-cup-qualifying-matches-russia-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia&#39;s moving on Kyiv and the plan appears to be to take out Ukraine&#39;s leadership, US defense official warns<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217beb6d80ca400192cf538?format=jpeg\" height=\"504\" width=\"672\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A column of army trucks approaches the Perekop checkpoint on the Ukrainian border. Early on February 24, President Putin announced a special military operation to be conducted by the Russian Armed Forces\"/><figcaption>A column of army trucks approaches the Perekop checkpoint on the Ukrainian border. Early on February 24, President Putin announced a special military operation to be conducted by the Russian Armed Forces against Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Malgavko\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian forces invaded Ukraine Thursday morning, and a senior US defense official says they are moving on Kyiv, likely to topple the country&#39;s government and install their own.</p><p>Russia is &#34;making a move on Kyiv&#34; a senior defense official&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/DanLamothe/status/1496881025477226499\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ebed491bd42dc565515a1943be56829c\">who addressed reporters</a>&#160;Thursday said,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/europe/live-news/ukraine-russia-news-02-24-22-intl/h_edc0092cf043265666acd8dbadd31557\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"97c2b0b720b6dd7900e5c013c19116e9\">according to CNN</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We would describe what you are seeing as an initial phase&#34; of a &#34;large-scale invasion,&#34; the official said,&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/DanLamothe/status/1496881025477226499\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"ebed491bd42dc565515a1943be56829c\">according to The Washington Post&#39;s Dan Lamothe</a>.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-invasion-ukraine-kyiv-leadership-us-defense-official-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Maps show Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217ba4bd0009b0019049073?format=jpeg\" height=\"1249\" width=\"1666\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine map composite.\"/><figcaption>Maps of Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Shayanne Gal/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia invaded Ukraine early Thursday, leading to dozens of Ukrainian and Russian casualties.</p><p>These maps show where Russian troops have attacked Ukraine, which is happening from multiple sides.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-invasion-map-where-russian-troops-attacking-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK plots far harsher sanctions on Russia to punish it for invading Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61df0d684ede320018b72ec1?format=jpeg\" height=\"3144\" width=\"4191\" charset=\"\" alt=\"British Prime Minister Boris Johnson\"/><figcaption>British Prime Minister Boris Johnson<p class=\"copyright\">Adrian Dennis/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo</p></figcaption></figure><p>The UK announced a new set of harsher sanctions on Russia after the country invaded Ukraine early Thursday.&#160;</p><p>A spokesman for the UK government told journalists at a briefing that the UK plans to impose a second round of sanctions.&#160;</p><p>The most intense of the new list of sanctions is an asset freeze on all major Russian banks and an asset freeze against VTB &#8212; the second largest bank with assets totaling £154 billion.&#160;</p><p>The UK also plans to sanction another 100 individuals and entities.</p><p>This is a large step up from the sanctions it announced Wednesday, which were limited to five smaller banks, three individuals close to Putin, and politicians in Russia who voted for military action.</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia has begun arresting anti-war protesters as demonstrations break out after Putin invades Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217b795d80ca400192cf2d8?format=jpeg\" height=\"3538\" width=\"4717\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Police officer detain a woman during an action against Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine in Moscow, Russia, Thursday, Feb. 24, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Police officer detain a woman during an action against Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine in Moscow, Russia, Thursday, Feb. 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Dmitry Serebryakov</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Russian government on Thursday threatened anti-war protesters demonstrating against Russia&#39;s&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-attacks-ukraine-launching-new-war-in-europe-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"1ed888fad4c83227c3707319b1306987\">invasion of Ukraine</a>, warning they could face arrest for organizing.</p><p>And according to a protest monitoring group, the detentions have already begun as small protests have broken out in some Russian cities.</p><p>Russia&#39;s Investigative Committee&#160;<a href=\"https://en.sledcom.ru/news/item/1659238/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"f89accbef683cbc4f9121cce34482d23\">warned citizens in a statement</a>&#160;not to take part in the &#34;unauthorized&#34; protests &#34;associated with the tense foreign political situation.&#34;</p><p>The committee said that people should be aware of the &#34;negative legal consequences of these actions,&#34; which it said includes criminal liability.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-arrests-anti-war-protesters-ukraine-invasion-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s official Twitter is using memes to rip into Putin&#39;s bogus comparison between it and Nazi Germany<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6214c668f0b06900185ed1ae?format=jpeg\" height=\"1968\" width=\"2624\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into eastern Ukraine on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Alexei Nikolsky/Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>After Russian President Vladimir Putin gave the marching orders for an attack on Ukraine early Thursday morning, Ukraine&#39;s official Twitter account got busy.&#160;</p><p>One&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/Ukraine/status/1496716168920547331?s=20&#38;t=0fDrbbeWSwJJcMyxnL3Mag\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9165070a66a752798783efb473789325\">photo</a>&#160;showed what appeared to be caricature images of Adolf Hitler tending to a small Putin.&#160;</p><p>&#34;This is not a &#39;meme&#39;, but our and your reality right now,&#34; Ukraine said in a follow-up tweet.&#160;&#160;</p><p>The account also called for a&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/Ukraine/status/1496776124696780802?s=20&#38;t=0fDrbbeWSwJJcMyxnL3Mag\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"1fea3bcca0011b9bcf28709021b215e8\">so-called &#34;Twitter-storm&#34;</a>&#160;at 12 p.m. local time in Kyiv on Thursday, urging people to use various hashtags to &#34;tell the world of the ongoing Russian aggression against Ukraine and the fact that Ukraine is under attack.&#34;</p><p>Ukraine&#39;s latest post said to &#34;Tag&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/Russia\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"48c19798c31709eb70c0d22d34cf1a6f\">@Russia</a>&#160;and tell them what you think about them,&#34; racking up tens of thousands of likes and quote tweets.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-posts-memes-ripping-into-putins-bogus-nazi-germany-comparison-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Map shows reported movement of Russian troops in Ukraine Thursday<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Reported Russian troop movements, February 24\" aria-label=\"Locator maps\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-KzpR8\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/KzpR8/2/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0;
