Russia launched a wide-ranging attack on Ukraine on Thursday, hitting cities and bases with airstrikes or shelling, as civilians piled into trains and cars to flee.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Emilio Morenatti</p></figcaption></figure><p>A photo shows a woman and her baby fleeing Kyiv on a packed bus as Russia invades Ukraine.</p><p>After Russia launched attacks across Ukraine Thursday, residents tried to quickly flee cities across the country.</p><p>Residents shared photos of major traffic jams, packed busses, and subway stations being used as bomb shelters.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/photo-woman-baby-fleeing-kyiv-ukraine-bus-as-russia-invades-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian troops reportedly attack through Chernobyl fallout zone, risking Western efforts to contain one of the world&#39;s most radioactive sites<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217a6f4d80ca400192cee16?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Soldiers sit inside the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian soldiers sit on top of a military vehicle parked outside the hotel in Prypiat, Ukraine on February 4.<p class=\"copyright\">Volodymyr Tarasov/Ukrinform/Future Publishing via Getty Image</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian troops are reportedly rolling through a protective zone surrounding the remnants of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, a move that signals the likelihood of trying to assault Kyiv and that risks decades of united efforts to contain one of history&#39;s worst nuclear disasters.</p><p>&#34;Russian occupation forces are trying to seize the #Chornobyl_NPP,&#34; Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky wrote on Twitter early Thursday. &#34;Our defenders are giving their lives so that the tragedy of 1986 will not be repeated.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-troops-attack-through-chernobyl-exclusion-zone-risks-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Crowds of Ukrainian people are hiding from airstrikes in subway station<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217abd2d80ca400192cefc4?format=jpeg\" height=\"1671\" width=\"2228\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People, some carrying bags and suitcases, walk in a metro station in Kyiv early on February 24, 2022. and resigns in protest over Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/620520783b86990018b2b100?format=jpeg\" height=\"683\" width=\"911\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin looks on during a press conference after meeting with French President in Moscow, on February 7, 2022. - International efforts to defuse the standoff over Ukraine intensified with French President holding talks in Moscow and German Chancellor in Washington to coordinate policies as fears of a Russian invasion mount.\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin looks on during a press conference after meeting with French President in Moscow, on February 7, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">THIBAULT CAMUS/POOL/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The director of a state-run theater in Moscow on Thursday publicly called Russian President Vladimir Putin a &#34;killer&#34; as she announced that she was stepping down from her post in protest over <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-attacks-ukraine-launching-new-war-in-europe-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"1ed888fad4c83227c3707319b1306987\">Russia&#39;s wide-ranging attack on Ukraine</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Friends, in protest against the Russian invasion of Ukraine, I am resigning,&#34; Elena Kovalskaya, the director of the Meyerhold Center theater,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/elena.kovalskaya\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"bf9a41d0a25016542420e0d304638dca\">posted on Facebook</a>.</p><p>Kovalskaya added, &#34;You can&#39;t work for a killer and get paid by him.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/moscow-theater-director-calls-putin-a-killer-resigns-over-ukraine-invasion-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Thousands of Ukrainian refugees have fled to Moldova, where the government has set up tents and vowed to keep its borders open to help<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217a833d80ca400192cee9c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1113\" width=\"1485\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Refugee tents in Moldova.\"/><figcaption>Refugee tents in Moldova.<p class=\"copyright\">Maia Sandu</p></figcaption></figure><p>Thousands of Ukrainian refugees have fled to Moldova, where the government set up tents and vowed to keep its borders open to help.</p><p>&#34;First [Ukrainian] citizens arrive in [Moldova], with over 4000 crossings today,&#34; Moldova&#39;s President Maia Sandu wrote on&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/sandumaiamd/status/1496859315122147337?s=20&#38;t=S6Aqch61tVY18HL2ounC5Q\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5f2ec14a16583eac6f8465262291af73\">Twitter</a>&#160;on Thursday.</p><p>She added: &#34;The [government] has deployed temporary placement centers near Palanca and Ocnița. Our borders are open for [Ukrainian] citizens who need safe transit or stay.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-refugees-flee-moldova-borders-open-after-russia-attack-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Citizens fleeing Kyiv said traffic jams were &#34;something I haven&#39;t seen before&#34;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62178a3bd0009b0019048429?format=jpeg\" height=\"2259\" width=\"3012\" charset=\"\" alt=\"People are seen stuck in a huge traffic jam as they try to leave Kyiv in the direction of the western parts of the country on February 24, 2022.\"/><figcaption>People are seen stuck in a huge traffic jam as they try to leave Kyiv in the direction of the western parts of the country on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">GENYA SAVILOV/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Nikita Gunkewitsch, resident of Kyiv, who is fleeing by car told Insider that fleeing Ukraine&#39;s capital city took a long time because of the traffic jams.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We heard siren sounds in the morning here in Kiev. Right away we packed and left the city with my girlfriend. Took a while since the traffic jams were something I haven&#39;t seen before,&#34; Gunkewitsch said.</p><p>He also posted a video to Twitter showing tanks driving alongside cars on the roads.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I could hear some bombings and smoke in the distance. I saw fighter jets flying super close to building and on the streets are tanks and military vehicles all the time&#34;</p><p>He continued: &#34;All in all we are positive. We are listing to reggae music and driving to the border. We will be alright.&#34;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Nikita Gunkewitsch (@mrmoonshark) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1496811018609217537\">February 24, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Much of Kyiv is closed after Russian invasion of Ukraine Thursday<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6217a44fd80ca400192ced21?format=jpeg\" height=\"2912\" width=\"3882\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Bus station in Kyiv, Ukraine\"/><figcaption>People wait for a bus at Kyiv&#39;s Central Bus Station on February 24, 2022, hours after Russian forces invaded Ukraine.<p class=\"copyright\">Alan Chin, contributing photographer</p></figcaption></figure><p>Contributing photographer Alan Chin told Insider that much of downtown Kyiv is closed as citizens shelter after a Russian invasion on Thursday.</p><p>&#34;There are long lines at ATMs. Downtown, most businesses are closed, but pharmacies remained open,&#34; he said.</p><p>Chin reported that the last bus leaving Kyiv was full and that the station is now closed. As Russian forces attacked overnight, residents flocked to the train station for protection.</p><p>&#34;An announcer urged calm,&#34; Chin said. &#34;There were no trains heading east; according to what was posted on the board, trains to the west were still running.&#34;&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Eyewitnesses in Ukraine describe the moment they awoke in a war zone as Russian forces bombed the cities where they live<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62179254d0009b00190484f3?format=jpeg\" height=\"5461\" width=\"7281\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Airstrikes have damaged structures and buildings in Kyiv.\"/><figcaption>Airstrikes have damaged structures and buildings in Kyiv.<p class=\"copyright\">Chris McGrath/Getty Images.</p></figcaption></figure><p>People across Ukraine were jolted from their sleep by the sounds of&#160;<a href=\"https://news.sky.com/video/ukraine-air-raid-siren-blares-out-across-capital-kyiv-early-this-morning-following-russia-invasion-12550251\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"8d0072f621e52be95d740c8ca654f529\">sirens</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/world-europe-60508121\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"f677f3abd4aeb65a563165714c2be067\">explosions</a>&#160;as Russian airstrikes hit the country&#39;s capital and several other cities.</p><p>Several eyewitnesses told Insider this was their first realization that a full-scale invasion was underway.</p><p>&#34;I woke up at five in the morning to the sounds of the blasts,&#34; said Ivanna Klympush, an MP with the European Solidarity party, speaking to Insider from her home in Kyiv. &#34;We all did.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-invades-ukraine-eyewitnesses-to-bombing-of-kyiv-odessa-kharkiv-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ex-NATO commander thinks Russian forces will try to capture Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62143d69462ff20019c5efef?format=jpeg\" height=\"480\" width=\"641\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy<p class=\"copyright\">Matt Dunham/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>A former NATO commander and retired US Navy admiral said that he believes Russian forces will try to capture Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky amid&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-orders-russia-troops-to-ukraine-major-escalation-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"9437fb3d3704accfb0776b561c2d0923\">Russia&#39;s full-scale attack on Ukraine</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I think he&#39;s gonna go full-bore, get to Kyiv, try and capture Zelensky,&#34; former NATO Supreme Allied Commander Admiral James Stavridis&#160;<a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/live-blog/russia-ukraine-conflict-live-updates-n1289655/ncrd1289744#liveBlogHeader\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"a1e7f25aafa6d7d3192496e876fea4fd\">told NBC&#39;s &#34;Today&#34; show</a>&#160;of Russian President Vladimir Putin.</p><p>He added that the United States must assist in helping Zelensky to&#34;figure out a way for him to have a government in exile, arm a Ukrainian resistance.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/former-nato-commander-says-russia-may-try-capturing-ukrainian-president-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russia attacked Ukraine just one week after its foreign ministry made jokes about the West&#39;s warning of an imminent invasion<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62178eecd80ca400192ce7a8?format=jpeg\" height=\"3574\" width=\"4765\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov looks on as he gives an annual press conference on Russian diplomacy in 2021, in Moscow on January 14, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov looks on as he gives an annual press conference on Russian diplomacy in 2021, in Moscow on January 14, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by DIMITAR DILKOFF/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine early Thursday morning came nearly a week after its foreign ministry cracked jokes at the West for warning of an imminent invasion.</p><p>&#34;Today we mark another day of the &#39;start of war with Ukraine,&#39; which did not happen again, to the Western media outlets&#39; regret, no matter how hard they whip up the hysteria,&#34; Russia&#39;s foreign ministry wrote on&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/mfa_russia/status/1493960598123687942?s=20&#38;t=ZuTUXThRy3EFEpaeDJXjPA\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"a4d181cf6684bc425926debc0d3a3517\">Twitter</a>&#160;on February 16.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-attack-ukraine-foreign-ministry-western-warnings-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukrainian presidential advisor says &#39;the West must act today&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621778bed80ca400192ce5d5?format=jpeg\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Image Cropper - Ukrainian tanks move into the city, after Russian President Vladimir Putin authorized a military operation in eastern Ukraine, in Mariupol, February 24, 2022. REUTERS/Carlos Barria TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian tanks seen in Mariupol, Ukraine, on February 24, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Carlos Barria</p></figcaption></figure><p>A Ukrainian presidential advisor called on the West to swiftly take action to punish Russia on Thursday after&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-attacks-ukraine-launching-new-war-in-europe-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"1ed888fad4c83227c3707319b1306987\">Moscow launched a military attack on Ukraine</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Russia is attacking not just Ukraine, but all the rules of normal life in the modern world,&#34; Mykhailo Podolyak, an advisor to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/europe/live-news/ukraine-russia-news-02-24-22-intl/index.html\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"75388a57a86e7b1e8174627235767972\">told CNN</a>.&#160;</p><p>Podolyak said that a &#34;full-fledged large-scale war has begun in Europe&#34; after Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered an invasion of Ukraine from multiple directions early Thursday.&#160;</p><p>He added, &#34;But Ukraine needs more support from the world and is very specific &#8212; military-technical and financial support, tough sanctions against Russia. The West must act today.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-presidential-advisor-calls-on-west-to-act-russia-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine reports deaths of at least eight civilians, 40 Ukrainian soldiers, and 50 Russian soldiers<figure><img law.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Peace on our continent has been shattered. moment for the security of Europe.&#34;</p><p>He said member countries would meet on Friday to discuss their response.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine cuts diplomatic relations with Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62177acdd0009b00190482c4?format=jpeg\" height=\"2832\" width=\"4240\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian military track burns at an air defence base in the Forces to destroy the Ukrainian state and the seizure by force of Ukrainian territories with the intent of establishing occupation control.&#34;</p><p>It added that it was evacuating its embassy in class=\"slide\">Oil surges to $100 a barrel for the first time since 2014<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60ca1ce023393a00188e382f?format=jpeg\" height=\"4480\" width=\"6720\" charset=\"\" first time since 2014 on Thursday.</p><p>Russia is one of the world&#39;s biggest oil and gas exporters, which means Russia&#39;s attack on Ukraine and the ensuing global response could disrupt the world&#39;s supply.</p><p>Russia currently supplies around 40% of the EU&#39;s natural gas supply, and threats to the supply could cause prices to rise.</p><p><br/><a Thursday.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Don&#39;t panic. We are strong. We are ready for everything. We will defeat everyone. Because we are Ukraine,&#34; he added.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraines-president-stay-calm-the-army-is-doing-its-work-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s UN ambassador was consoled by other representatives after Russia&#39;s assault was announced<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62172f40081b26001840a5d0?format=jpeg\" height=\"2666\" width=\"3555\" charset=\"\" alt=\"US ambassador to the United Nations (UN) Linda Thomas-Greenfield (C partially hidden) comforts Ukraine Permanent Representative to the United Nations Sergiy Kyslytsya (R) after an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council on Ukraine in New York on February 23, 2022. - The United States and Albania will soon submit their draft resolution to the United Nations Security Council, seeking to condemn Russia for its recent Ukraine actions, diplomatic sources said Wednesday.\"/><figcaption>US ambassador to the UN Linda Thomas-Greenfield (partially hidden) comforts Ukraine Permanent Representative to the United Nations Sergiy Kyslytsya (R) after an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council on Ukraine in New York.<p class=\"copyright\">TIMOTHY A. had been forced to leave the Titan chemicals plant in Armiansk, Crimea. The purpose, the post said, might be to accuse Ukraine of carrying out an attack on the facility &#8212; providing a justification for war.</p><p>&#34;We officially declare that Ukraine has not planned and does not plan any act of sabotage at this facility,&#34; the post said.</p><p>Russia has more than 150,000 troops stationed along Ukraine&#39;s borders, with Russian-backed separatists in the east of the country on Wednesday formally requesting military intervention. when he tried to call Putin<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6216ccdf081b26001840a15d?format=jpeg\" height=\"512\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky<p class=\"copyright\">Matt Dunham/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>In a somber early-morning speech from Kyiv, Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky appealed directly to the Russian people, pleading for peace amid rising fears of an imminent invasion.&#160;&#160;</p><p>&#34;The people of Ukraine and the government of Ukraine want peace,&#34; Zelensky said in a video address. &#34;But if we come under attack that threaten our freedom and lives of our people we will fight back.&#34;</p><p>Zelensky also said that he tried to call Russian President Vladimir Putin late Wednesday but said he was met with &#34;silence.&#34;&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-appeals-peace-but-our-people-will-fight-if-attacked-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Kremlin-backed rebel leaders in eastern Ukraine formally ask Putin for military forces to fight Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6216c078081b26001840a0d5?format=jpeg\" height=\"959\" width=\"1919\" charset=\"\" alt=\"russia ukraine\"/><figcaption>A convoy of Russian armored vehicles moves along a highway in Crimea, Tuesday, Jan. 18, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Kremlin on Wednesday said Moscow-backed rebel leaders in eastern Ukraine have asked Russia for military assistance to fight off Ukrainian &#34;aggression,&#34; just hours after <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-declares-state-of-emergency-russia-troop-order-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"21beb193976ae70a0a77410fda95ea2a\">Ukraine declared a nationwide state of </a>emergency amid&#160;rising <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">fears of an imminent Russian invasion.</a></p><p>The move comes after Russian President <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-recognizes-ukrainian-separatist-regions-independent-states-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"47c72a609596641c92771c23fee0c3b9\">Vladimir Putin on Monday recognized the independence of two Kremlin-backed separatist regions in eastern Ukraine</a>, the self-described &#34;people&#39;s republics&#34; of Donetsk and Luhansk, reversing Russia&#39;s years-long stance on the region and marking a possible lead-up to a major offensive.&#160;</p><p>On Tuesday, Russian lawmakers granted Putin powers to use military force outside of the country.&#160;</p><p>In <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ChristopherJM/status/1496589115369959424\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b45f52d719fd1d90a40324ea605d255d\">letters reportedly sent to Putin</a> and published by the <a href=\"https://tass.com/politics/1409091\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b4684c27b5ee52240728413ed868e1cc\">Russian-state TASS news agency</a>, the Russia-backed rebel leaders requested Russian intervention in an effort to &#34;avoid civilian casualties and prevent a humanitarian catastrophe.&#34;</p><p>The White House responded to the letters, saying the request exemplified <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-planning-false-flag-operation-in-ukraine-us-intel-suggests-2022-1\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"4b078464aac1e9a705f7fe1521e85cab\">the type of &#34;false flag&#34; operations</a> the West has been warning of for weeks, according to <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-business-new-zealand-australia-europe-08ae29f98152817b1b503b4b957c63f1\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"0cb0a515d5d173509c09c0c80ad3cb46\">The Associated Press.</a></p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kremlin-backed-leader-asks-putin-for-help-fighting-ukrainian-forces-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister told the UN a full-blown war with Russia would be &#39;end of the world order&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6216988245889c0019d1fd4c?format=jpeg\" height=\"3021\" width=\"4029\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba speaks at the General Assembly 58th plenary meeting in New York on February 23, 2022, on the Russia-Ukraine conflict.\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba speaks at the General Assembly 58th plenary meeting in New York on February 23, 2022, on the Russia-Ukraine conflict.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by TIMOTHY A. CLARY/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister told the United Nations on Wednesday that a full-blown war with Russia would spell the &#34;end of the world order.&#34;</p><p>&#34;The beginning of a large-scale war in Ukraine will be the end of the world order as we know it,&#34; Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told the UN General Assembly in New York and&#160;<a data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"2d823c76fd2b6fefe3cd78eb183c4a99\">later shared on Ukraine&#39;s government website.</a></p><p>Kuleba urged the UN and international community to impose &#34;swift, concrete, and resolute actions&#34; as a response to the latest Russian aggression.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-dmytro-kuleba-united-nations-russia-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine declares a state of data-reactid=\".1qd9tyj4u76.0.2.0.0.1.0.1.0.$lx-tabs0.0.$lx-commentary.$lx-commentary.2.0.1.1.1:$post-6216227f000e9e34d25a77b3.0.6.0.0:$post_1\">Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday <a for national security and defense within three months.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Верховна Рада України parliamentary body voted.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">The EU reportedly plans to sanction Putin&#39;s right-hand man and a notorious Russian troll farm<figure><img the bloc plans to sanction Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and the Internet Research Agency, a notorious Russian troll farm.</p><p>Shoigu is understood to be one of the few people with influence over Putin, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/30/world/europe/putin-top-advisers-ukraine.html\">The New York Times previously reported</a>. helped to spread online misinformation about the 2016 US presidential election, and it was <a Mueller&#39;s office with conspiring to interfere in the election.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">China says sanctions over Ukraine are ineffective as Russia brushes them off<figure><img &#34;The position of the Chinese government is that we believe that sanctions have never been a fundamental and effective way to solve problems, and China always opposes any illegal unilateral sanctions.&#34;</p><p>Russia also downplayed sanctions from Western countries.</p><p data-reactid=\".1wer5j75t8c.0.2.0.0.1.0.1.0.$lx-tabs0.0.$lx-commentary.$lx-commentary.2.0.1.1.1:$post-6215e15e571bfc64f8e64f0c.0.6.0.0:$post_1\">Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova <a restrain our country.&#34;</p><p data-reactid=\".1wer5j75t8c.0.2.0.0.1.0.1.0.$lx-tabs0.0.$lx-commentary.$lx-commentary.2.0.1.1.1:$post-6215e15e571bfc64f8e64f0c.0.6.0.0:$post_1\">Russia&#39;s embassy in London also <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/europe/live-news/ukraine-russia-news-02-23-22/index.html\">claimed</a> the UK&#39;s sanctions were &#34;illegal in terms of international law&#34; and blamed &#34;anti-Russian hysteria in the British media.&#34;&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine orders conscription of reserve troops<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/620d1524b20df700180a1c04?format=jpeg\" height=\"1460\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine Tochka-U missile\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian OTR-21 Tochka-U missile systems in Ukraine&#39;s Independence Day military parade in Kyiv, August 24, 2016.<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Gleb Garanich</p></figcaption></figure><p>Ukraine&#39;s armed forces <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/UkrainianLandForces/posts/289638233268175\">said on Wednesday</a>&#160;President Volodymyr Zelensky had signed a decree ordering the country&#39;s military reserves.</p><p>It called up reservists aged 18 to 60, and said they would serve up to a year.</p><p>Zelensky said on Tuesday that he was calling up the country&#39;s military reserves, but stopped short of a general mobilization, <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukrainian-president-calls-up-reservists-launches-programme-economic-patriotism-2022-02-22/\">Reuters reported</a>.</p><p>Zelensky <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/22/world/europe/ukraines-president-calls-up-reserves-urging-ukrainians-to-fight-for-their-country.html\">said</a> the government would work to &#34;raise the preparedness of the Ukrainian army to all possible changes in the operational situation.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister calls for more sanctions against Russia<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62162eb245889c0019d1dd34?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba at the State Department in Washington, DC, on February 22, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Carolyn Kaster/Pool via Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><p>The US and UK announced harsh economic sanctions against Russia on Tuesday, and EU countries agreed on imposing a first round of sanctions.</p><p>Dmytro Kuleba, Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister, tweeted Wednesday: &#34;To stop Putin from further aggression, we call on partners to impose more sanctions on Russia now. First decisive steps were taken yesterday, and we are grateful for them.</p><p>&#34;Now the pressure needs to step up to stop Putin. Hit his economy and cronies. Hit more. Hit hard. Hit now.&#34;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-foreign-minister-calls-more-sanctions-against-russia-putin-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine told its 3 million citizens to leave Russia &#39;immediately&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61e4a5b404ce6e0018d77288?format=jpeg\" height=\"1499\" width=\"1998\" charset=\"\" alt=\"This combination of file pictures created on January 11, 2022 shows Russian President Vladimir Putin land Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.<p class=\"copyright\">Valery Sharifulin, Bertrand Guay/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"https://mfa.gov.ua/en/news/rekomendaciyi-gromadyanam-ukrayini-u-zvyazku-iz-ostannimi-rishennyami-rosijskoyi-federaciyi-shcho-grubo-porushuyut-suverenitet-i-teritorialnu-cilisnist-ukrayini\">In a Wednesday statement</a>, Ukraine&#39;s foreign minister told all Ukrainian citizens not to travel to Russia, and told all those who were already in the country to leave &#34;immediately.&#34;</p><p>An estimated 3 million Ukrainians currently live in Russia.</p><p>It also said the foreign minister met US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin on Tuesday to discuss &#34;further practical strengthening of the defense capabilities&#34; of Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;The parties discussed practical steps to protect Ukraine, in particular the development of cooperation in the fields of air and missile defense,&#34; the ministry said.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-urges-millions-citizens-leave-russia-immediately-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">A bipartisan group of 43 lawmakers urges President Biden to get congressional approval before sending troops into Ukraine<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61c0d2d5b6649200197e700f?format=jpeg\" height=\"1869\" width=\"2492\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Congress at sunset\"/><figcaption>Signees of the letter include progressive Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Cori Bush, as well as GOP Reps. Matt Gaetz and Paul Gosar.<p class=\"copyright\">Stock photo via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Forty-three lawmakers from both sides of the aisle have signed a letter urging President Joe Biden to obtain approval from Congress before sending US troops to intervene in the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict</a>.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/RepPeterDeFazio/status/1496252334388785154\">The&#160;letter</a>, dated Tuesday, was signed by both progressive Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Cori Bush and Trump-allied GOP representatives, including Matt Gaetz and Paul Gosar. The letter calls for Biden to abide by the Constitution and seek congressional authorization before having US troops &#34;engage in hostilities.&#34;</p><p>&#34;We strongly urge your administration to respect the separation of powers, US law, and Congress&#39;s constitutional war powers authority,&#34; the letter read.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lawmakers-want-biden-seek-congress-approval-ukraine-troop-deployment-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Ukraine is the frontline of the &#39;battle between authoritarianism and values of the free world&#39; says a Kyiv human rights activist<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62159986081b260018406fe3?format=jpeg\" height=\"1331\" width=\"1774\" charset=\"\" alt=\"russia ukraine\"/><figcaption>A convoy of Russian armored vehicles moves along a highway in Crimea, Tuesday, Jan. 18, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>Oleksandra Matviychuk is the chair of the Center for Civil Liberties, a Ukrainian humanitarian NGO founded in 2007, that is largely focused on implementing and pushing for democratic reforms in the country.&#160;</p><p>Since at least 2014, Matviychuk told Insider that the organization has stood directly in Putin&#39;s path and faced consequences. As Russia formalized its occupation of Crimea that year, the organization&#39;s staff was kicked out of areas of Ukraine that increasingly fell under Russian separatist control.</p><p>Today, Matviychuk describes&#160;<a href=\"https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2022/2/20/for-the-kremlin-war-crimes-are-not-mistakes-but-tactics\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"e8367da9308db5fd4299fd4e5bef332d\">life in Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, as surreal</a>&#160;with people going about their daily lives, but feeling the Kremlin&#39;s stranglehold even more.</p><p>Insider spoke to Matviychuk about the realities facing Ukrainians on the ground.</p><p><a planning for a surge of incoming Ukrainians as the&#160;<a volatile.&#34; Some estimates suggest as many as five million people could be displaced in a worst-case scenario, the outlet reported.&#160;</p><p><a Biden said. Underneath is four photos of a forest with &#34;Moscow&#34; written underneath, and marked with the same timeline.&#160;</p><p>The meme is a reference to a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-denies-reviving-russian-empire-says-ukraine-not-real-country-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"5eaa73a47dbf91566001ca1f7de4597f\">speech Putin gave on Monday</a>&#160;where he claimed that Ukraine was a creation of the Soviet Union and part of Russia&#39;s historic territory.&#160;&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-embassy-trolls-russia-meme-after-putin-ukraine-history-rant-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin backs all of rebels&#39; claims in eastern Ukraine, a possible lead-up to a major assault on Ukrainian defenders<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/615ace00542a580019a8958a?format=jpeg\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin during a meeting with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan at the Bocharov Ruchei residence on September 29.<p class=\"copyright\">Vladimir Smirnov\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Tuesday that he recognized Moscow-backed separatists&#39; full territorial claims to eastern Ukraine, marking a possible lead-up to a major assault on Ukrainian defenders.</p><p>Putin backed the separatists&#39; claims to the territory in the eastern province of Donbas where the separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk are located,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2022/02/22/russia-backs-ukraine-separatists-full-territorial-claims-a76526\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"5a22c64afbd23f33471b022033870432\">according to The Moscow Times</a>.</p><p>&#34;We recognized them. He was referring to Russia moving so-called &#34;peacekeepers&#34; into separatist territories in eastern Ukraine that the Kremlin recognized as independent on Monday.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I think &#39;latest&#39; is important here,&#34; Finer said. &#34;An invasion is an invasion, and that is what is underway. But Russia has been invading Ukraine since 2014.&#34;</p><p>&#34;I don&#39;t know how much more clear I can be,&#34; he added. &#34;This is the beginning of an invasion.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-russia-launched-beginning-of-invasion-in-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin says Minsk accords, which were meant to end war in eastern Ukraine, no longer exist<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61dc5f591025b20018bb0061?format=jpeg\" height=\"1334\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin<p class=\"copyright\">Alexey Nikolsky/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin announced Tuesday that the Minsk peace agreements no longer &#34;exist,&#34; according to Russian state media.&#160;</p><p>The agreements sought to end the war in Eastern Ukraine.&#160;&#160;</p><p>&#34;The Minsk agreements do not exist now,&#34; he said,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.barrons.com/news/putin-says-ukraine-peace-agreement-does-not-exist-anymore-01645548907\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"e70acb8abc3dd0db1450c0c4d0b3708d\">according to a translation from AFP,</a>&#160;one day after he formally recognized the independence of two Moscow-backed separatist regions in eastern Ukraine and ordered troops there.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-says-minsk-agreements-eastern-ukraine-no-longer-exist-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Putin calls for recognition of Crimea as part of Russia, among other demands<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6214c668f0b06900185ed1ae?format=jpeg\" height=\"1968\" width=\"2624\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into eastern Ukraine on Monday.<p class=\"copyright\">Alexei Nikolsky/Associated Press</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin called for a number of demands on Tuesday, including the recognition of Crimea to be a part of Russia.&#160;</p><p>Putin also called for a halt to weapons shipments to Ukraine and an end to talks of Ukraine joining NATO, both long-standing Russian grievances.</p><p>Putin also baselessly claimed on Tuesday that Ukraine had the capacity to create nuclear weapons. The false claim comes as US officials have warned that Russia is seeking a pretext to invade Ukraine.</p><p>Ukraine was briefly the third-largest nuclear power in the world after the fall of the Soviet Union due to a large number of Soviet nukes left behind, <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2022/02/21/1082124528/ukraine-russia-putin-invasion\">NPR reported</a>. However, in 1994, the country agreed to give up the nukes in exchange for the US, UK, and Russia guaranteeing its safety.</p><p>Ukraine has never produced its own nuclear weapons.</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">NATO chief says this is the &#39;most dangerous&#39; moment in European security in a &#39;generation&#39;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/615de1341725d20018b816cf?format=jpeg\" height=\"1308\" width=\"1744\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Jens Stoltenberg\"/><figcaption>NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg gives a press conference during a NATO summit in Brussels on June 14, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Olivier Hoslet/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>NATO&#39;s secretary general gave a warning Tuesday as the possibility for a Russian invasion of Ukraine looms over Europe.&#160;</p><p>&#34;This is the most dangerous moment in European security for a generation,&#34; Jens Stoltenberg said at a&#160;<a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/ukraine-live-updates-russia-recognises-donetsk-and-luhansk-sanctions-invasion-12541713\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"83269dc98c6e8279c1fdfa83f5ab723f\">press conference</a>&#160;after President Vladimir Putin&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/videos-russian-military-tanks-move-donbas-seen-donetsk-putin-invade-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"8a2296fdc718491de5946e42be99b612\">ordered Russian troops</a>&#160;into eastern Ukraine on Monday.&#160;</p><p>&#34;We urge Russia in the strongest possible terms to choose the path of diplomacy,&#34; Stoltenberg added.&#160;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nato-most-dangerous-time-european-security-for-generation-russia-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Russian lawmakers said Putin can use military force abroad<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62150ca3f0b06900185edbbd?format=jpeg\" height=\"1905\" width=\"2541\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian President Vladimir Putin chairs a meeting with members of the Security Council in Moscow on February 21, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Russian President Vladimir Putin chairs a meeting with members of the Security Council in Moscow on February 21, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by ALEXEY NIKOLSKY/Sputnik/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian lawmakers have given President Vladimir Putin the go-ahead to use military force abroad, the Associated Press&#160;<a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-business-europe-russia-vladimir-putin-46cef648807d0e3c2bac9793ad9022a6\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"bae57bee5b7dcf756b11c60bfbb980fb\">reported</a>&#160;on Tuesday.</p><p>The vote passed unanimously and formalizes a military deployment.&#160;</p><p>This move comes a day after Putin ordered troops into Eastern Ukraine as a &#34;peacekeeping&#34; operation and could be the precursor to an invasion.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-lawmakers-approve-putin-request-military-force-abroad-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Jen Psaki praises Germany for shutting down Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline over Russian invasion threat<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6202e710bd504100191947c4?format=jpeg\" height=\"3915\" width=\"5221\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Jen Psaki\"/><figcaption>White House press secretary Jen Psaki.<p class=\"copyright\">Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki commended Germany for shutting down the Nord Stream 2 pipeline after Russia sent troops to Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>&#34;[Joe Biden]&nbsp;made clear that if Russia invaded Ukraine, we would act with Germany to ensure Nord Stream 2 does not move forward,&#34; Psaki&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/PressSec/status/1496115739799040008?s=20&#38;t=B6XnF6IzPvWyy_l9B5U4cg\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"26650d02915031c506491c1f46f44966\">tweeted</a>. &#34;We have been in close consultations with Germany overnight and welcome their announcement.&#34;</p><p>She added: &#34;We will be following up with our own measures today.&#34;</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/psaki-praises-germany-halt-nord-stream-2-pipeline-russia-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">UK sanctions Russian banks, individuals<p>The UK announced sanctions against five major banks and three individuals on Tuesday in its first move to punish Russia for sending troops to Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>Prime Minister Boris Johnson called it the &#34;first tranche, the first barrage&#34; of sanctions over its aggression towards Ukraine.</p><p>The five banks are Rossiya, IS Bank, General Bank, Promsvyazbank, and the Black Sea Bank. Three individuals &#8211; Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg, and Igor Rotenberg &#8211; were also named.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uk-sanctions-5-russia-banks-3-people-over-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Germany axes pivotal Nord Stream 2 pipeline bringing Russian gas to Europe<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6214c7bcf0b06900185ed1ce?format=jpeg\" height=\"990\" width=\"1320\" charset=\"\" alt=\"German Chancellor Olaf Scholz addresses a joint press conference with Ireland&#39;s Prime Minister following talks at the Chancellery in Berlin on February 22, 2022. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / POOL / AFP) (Photo by JOHN MACDOUGALL/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)\"/><figcaption>German Chancellor Olaf Scholz on February 22, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">JOHN MACDOUGALL/POOL/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Germany scrapped plans for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline Tuesday after Russian President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said in&#160;<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M336Nqyw8JM\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"3056150f20426311a6a30996059b52e4\">an address on the Ukraine crisis Tuesday</a> that he is going to &#34;reassess&#34; the certification, a necessary approval for the pipeline to start moving gas from Russia to Europe.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/germany-axes-controversial-nord-stream-pipeline-putin-sent-troops-ukraine-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Map shows potential paths of Russian attack into Ukraine<div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Potential paths of Russian attack into Ukraine\" aria-label=\"Locator maps\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-y01lO\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/y01lO/25/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; operation, a major escalation towards a war<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62140e01f0b06900185ecbbd?format=jpeg\" height=\"1337\" width=\"1782\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Vladimir Putin Ukraine speech February 21 2022 Donetsk Luhansk recongition\"/><figcaption>Vladimir Putin of Russia gives a televised address on Ukraine on February 21, 2022. Shortly after, he recognized the separatist regions of Luhansk and Donetsk as independent and ordered troops there.<p class=\"copyright\">Alexei Nikolsky\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into Eastern Ukraine on Monday as a &#34;peacekeeping operation,&#34; escalating the conflict between the two countries.&#160;</p><p>Putin signed a presidential decree allowing the &#34;peacekeeping&#34; after he decided to recognize Donetsk and Luhansk, two separatist territories that are loyal to Moscow, as independent states rather than a part of Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>Russia has been building up forces around Ukraine for months, while the US and its allies have warned Russia not to invade the country or face severe sanctions.</p><p><br/><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-orders-russia-troops-to-ukraine-major-escalation-2022-2\" class=\"live-blog-button\">Read Full Story</a></p></div><div class=\"slide\">Background reading<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62166704081b2600184087b0?format=jpeg\" height=\"888\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Biden Putin\"/><figcaption>President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin in Geneva, Switzerland.<p class=\"copyright\">Mikhail Metzel/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>Before the invasion, experts told Insider senior reporters&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/john-haltiwanger\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/john-haltiwanger\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">John Haltiwanger</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/ryan-pickrell\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/ryan-pickrell\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">Ryan Pickrell</a>&#160;what they expected&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/here-is-what-could-come-next-in-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/here-is-what-could-come-next-in-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-1\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">Putin&#39;s next moves</a>&#160;would be, how Russia could use failed NATO talks as&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-could-use-failed-talks-as-pretext-for-invasion-experts-2022-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-could-use-failed-talks-as-pretext-for-invasion-experts-2022-1\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">&#34;pretext&#34; for invading</a>, and&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-invasion-of-ukraine-could-lead-to-open-confrontation-with-nato-experts-2022-1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-invasion-of-ukraine-could-lead-to-open-confrontation-with-nato-experts-2022-1\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">how the US could get pulled into a conflict</a>&#160;with Russia.</p><p>In the 1990s,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-helped-nato-expand-in-the-90s-which-putin-now-threatening-war-over-2022-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-helped-nato-expand-in-the-90s-which-putin-now-threatening-war-over-2022-2\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\">Biden played a key role in NATO&#39;s expansion east</a>, which Putin blames for the contentious dynamic between Moscow and the West.</p></div><div 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"US stocks fall as inflation soars in February and Russia-Ukraine talks stall","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-today-dow-oil-february-inflation-russia-ukraine-talks-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61e00194c5e27c00185b5c53?format=jpeg\" height=\"3120\" width=\"6240\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Wall Street 2021\"/><figcaption>Omicron has brought volatility to Wall Street.<p class=\"copyright\">John Moore/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>All three major US indexes opened lower Thursday after a massive rally in the prior session.</li>\n<li>Inflation accelerated, with the February consumer price index up 7.9% from a year ago, a fresh 40-year high.</li>\n<li>Ceasefire talks between Russia and Ukraine did not make progress, and oil resumed its upward march.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>The three major US indexes opened lower Thursday, giving back some gains from the prior session&#39;s massive rally, as ceasefire negotiations between Russia and Ukraine <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\">showed little progress</a>.&#160;</p><p>Meanwhile, new data showed inflation accelerated, with the February consumer price index up 7.9% from a year ago, a fresh 40-year high, topping forecasts for a 7.8% gain. The Ukraine war has boosted prices for key commodities that will continue to stoke inflation. And oil climbed 5% Thursday after the UAE appeared to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/commodities/oil-price-today-uae-opec-should-boost-output-faster-production-2022-3\">backtrack on its earlier call</a> for OPEC+ to boost output faster amid sanctions on Russian crude exports.&#160;</p><p>Additionally, US weekly jobless claims came in at 227,000, higher than the expected 217,000. And the European Central Bank surprised markets by announcing a quicker wind-down of its asset purchase program. The Federal Reserve meets next week and is widely expected to begin raising benchmark rates to rein in high inflation.</p><p><strong>Here&#39;s where US indexes stood as the market opened at 9:30 a.m. on Thursday:&#160;</strong></p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&#38;p_500?utm_source=markets&#38;utm_medium=ingest%3Futm_source%3Dmarkets&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\"><strong>S&#38;P 500</strong></a>: 4,230.58, down 1.11%</li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/dow_jones?utm_source=markets&#38;utm_medium=ingest%3Futm_source%3Dmarkets&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\"><strong>Dow Jones Industrial Average</strong></a>: 32,916.11, down 1.11% (370.14 points)</li><li aria-level=\"1\"><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/nasdaq_composite?utm_source=markets&#38;utm_medium=ingest%3Futm_source%3Dmarkets&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\"><strong>Nasdaq Composite</strong></a><strong>: </strong>13,050.77, down 1.54%</li></ul><p>Russia was shut out further from global finance over its invasion of Ukraine, with the BBC reporting Thursday that the country has been suspended from the Bank for International Settlements.</p><p>As Moscow&#39;s isolation from financial markets deepens, its risk of default risk has grown. And investment giant <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/pimco-russia-26-billion-losses-default-debt-CDS-bonds-ukraine-2022-3\">Pimco is at risk of losing up to $2.6 billion</a>, as it bet big against the country falling into default.</p><p>Famed &#34;Big Short&#34; investor Michael Burry made his return to Twitter after months away with <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/big-short-michael-burry-twitter-inflation-warning-energy-crunch-1970-2022-3\">a callback to the 1970s.</a></p><p>In other news, a portfolio of global stocks, bonds, and real estate could lose up to 13% in a stagflationary scenario, according to an MSCI researcher. He shared <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stagflation-warning-inflation-economy-bear-market-safe-haven-assets-msci-2022-3\">two asset classes to target</a> amid potential stagflation.&#160;</p><p>Oil prices rebounded after tumbling yesterday by more than 12%. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price?type=wti\">West Texas Intermediate</a> crude is up 3.8% to $112.85 a barrel. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price?utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\">Brent crude</a>, the international benchmark, is up about 4.7% to $116.41 a barrel.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/gold-price?utm_source=markets&#38;utm_medium=ingest%3Futm_source%3Dmarkets&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\">Gold</a> traded up 0.9% at $2,007 per ounce. The <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/rates/u-s--rates-10-years?utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\">10-year yield</a> climbed 3 basis points to 1.978.</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/btc-usd?utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\">Bitcoin</a> slipped 6.27% to $39,302.46.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Fidelity's Johnson family is now worth $48 billion after the investing firm bet on retail traders flooding the market last year","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fidelity-johnson-family-worth-48-billion-after-retail-trader-bet-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229fa336ec7c20019cd745c?format=jpeg\" height=\"2295\" width=\"4591\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Abigail Johnson, CEO of Fidelity Investments, wearing white-and-black blouse and red beaded necklace against black-and-white maze-patterned background.\"/><figcaption>Abigail Johnson, CEO of Fidelity Investments.<p class=\"copyright\">Brian Snyder/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The wealth of Fidelity&#39;s Johnson family jumped by $6.2 billion in 2021, Bloomberg said.&#160;</li>\n<li>Meanwhile, Fidelity CEO Abigail Johnson is now worth $21.5 billion, the report found.</li>\n<li>The jump in wealth came amid the firm&#39;s bet on retail traders flooding the market.</li>\n</ul><p>The head of Fidelity and her family increased their wealth by billions of dollars last year amid the investment firm&#39;s bet on retail-trader flow.</p><p>A new report from <a href=\"https://news.yahoo.com/fidelity-trading-boom-lifts-johnson-203531630.html\">Bloomberg</a> found that Fidelity CEO Abigail Johnson is now worth $21.5 billion, and the Johnson family, which owns nearly half of the company, is now worth $48 billion &#8212; a $6.2 billion bump. A representative from Fidelity did not immediately respond to Insider&#39;s request for comment and declined to comment to Bloomberg.</p><p>The surge in wealth came as the Boston-based firm saw a flood of retail traders. In its <a href=\"https://www.fidelity.com/bin-public/060_www_fidelity_com/documents/about-fidelity/2021AnnualReportInfographic.pdf\">annual report</a>, the firm said it had a 15% revenue jump in 2021. Retail-investing accounts climbed 22% to 32.4 million, which includes 2.3 million new individual investors aged 18 to 35, the report said.&#160;</p><p>Fidelity, as Bloomberg pointed out, wooed retail investors to its platform amid last year&#39;s <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/retail-investors-influence-over-stock-market-declining-meme-stock-mania-2022-2\">meme-stock mania</a>. For example, Insider reported last year that the firm began offering investing accounts <a href=\"https://www.msn.com/en-in/money/markets/fidelity-plans-to-offer-no-fee-investment-services-for-teenagers-who-want-to-trade-stocks-and-etfs/ar-BB1gRWaW\">for teenagers</a> as young as 13. Fidelity also said it would hire 9,000 US employees to aid in the retail-trading boom, Bloomberg noted.</p><p>Individual investors joined the market in droves last year with the help of government stimulus money amid continued COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns. They made their presence known early on in 2021 when they mobilized on social media sites like Reddit and drove massive gains in ailing stocks like GameStop and AMC.</p><div Dailey)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229fa336ec7c20019cd745c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn81@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-34-180_c5d3953efc704edf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UumetAoOhQE:FCTwPLBYnCc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-29-578_815a428727af4ac5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UumetAoOhQE:FCTwPLBYnCc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-27-849_129d15308acf2ba7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=UumetAoOhQE:FCTwPLBYnCc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn50@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-29-473_d084cd2e4d66b894.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704384},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"A Ukrainian man whose wife and children were killed by Russian mortar fire said he learned of their deaths on Twitter","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukrainian-man-learned-of-familys-death-on-twitter-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6226363cdcce010019a70c53?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukraine troops patrol in Irpin\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian troops patrol in Irpin, Ukraine, March 1, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Anastasia Vlasova/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A Ukrainian man said he learned of his family&#39;s death from photos on Twitter.</li>\n<li>Serhiy Perebyinis told <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/09/world/europe/ukraine-family-perebyinis-kyiv.html\">The New York Times</a> that his family was killed while trying to flee Kyiv.</li>\n<li>&#34;The whole world should know what is happening here,&#34; he said.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>A Ukrainian mother and her two children, along with a church volunteer who was helping them escape Kyiv amid Russia&#39;s ongoing invasion were killed by mortar fire on Sunday as they attempted to flee via a damaged bridge in the town of Irpin.</p><p>Hours later, Serhiy Perebyinis discovered the deaths of his wife and children via graphic photos of their dead bodies on Twitter, the father told <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/09/world/europe/ukraine-family-perebyinis-kyiv.html\">The New York Times.</a></p><p><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/06/world/europe/ukraine-irpin-civilian-death.html\">A photograph</a> of the family and volunteer covered in blood and lying lifeless in the street taken by New York Times photographer, Lynsey Addario, spread quickly over the weekend, capturing the heartbreaking human toll of Russia&#39;s war, which has included ramped up attacks against populous civilian areas in recent days.</p><p>In an interview with the newspaper, Perebyinis confirmed that his wife, Tetiana Perebyinis, 43, and their two children, Mykyta, 18, and Alisa, 9, as well as Anatoly Berezhnyi, 26, were the victims in the photograph.</p><p>Serhiy Perebyinis said he was away in eastern Ukraine helping his sick mother when his wife decided it was time to take her children and escape the city after a shell hit their apartment building in Irpin, a city about 30 miles northwest of the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv, one night last week.</p><p>But the family never made it out.&#160;</p><p>In order to escape the city, the travelers had to cross a hundred yards of exposed street on the side of a ruined concrete bridge with no cover, according to The Times.&#160;</p><p>Berezhnyi, a church volunteer who had already evacuated his own family but returned to Kyiv to assist others, was with Tetiana Perebyinis and her children when they made their run to safety, the outlet reported. But the group was a mere 12 yards away from where a Russian mortar shell hit and the explosion of shrapnel shards killed them all.&#160;</p><p>The Times&#39; photograph showed Ukrainian soldiers standing over the bodies with the family&#39;s luggage strewn about the street.&#160;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622966367eb82f00180e4533?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Irpin Ukraine dead bodies\"/><figcaption>Dead bodies lie in the street next to a suitcase in Irpin, Ukraine, on March 6, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Murat Saka/ dia images via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>It was their luggage &#8212; some suitcases and backpacks &#8212; that ultimately led to their identification.</p><p>&#34;I recognized the luggage and that is how I knew,&#34; Serhiy Perebyinis told The Times.&#160;</p><p>He said he began seeing posts on Twitter reporting that a family had been killed in a mortar strike while trying to escape out of Irpin. Finally, a post with a photograph came across his feed and he knew.&#160;</p><p>Serhiy Perebyinis told The Times that it was important that his family&#39;s deaths were recorded in photographs.</p><p>&#34;The whole world should know what is happening here,&#34; he said.&#160;</p><p>Addario, the Pulitzer-Prize-winning photojournalist who took the photo, said she <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/photojournalist-who-took-new-york-times-front-page-war-crime-2022-3\">witnessed a war crime</a> after she saw the family killed.</p><p>&#34;I went forward and found a place sort of behind a wall and started photographing,&#34; Addario said in an&#160;<a href=\"https://twitter.com/CBSEveningNews/status/1500980742234509315\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"b01c7d2183f467ff77cac30468081d82\">interview</a> with &#34;CBS Evening News&#34; host Norah O&#39;Donnell on Monday. &#34;And in fact, within minutes, a series of mortars fell increasingly closer and closer to our position until one landed about 30 feet from where I was standing and it killed a mother and her two children.&#34;</p><p>The photographer said she acknowledged that it could be disrespectful to take a photo of the family but she felt had to document the moment that painted the reality of the Russian attack on Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;I think it&#39;s really important that people around the world see these images,&#34; Addario said at the time. &#34;It&#39;s really brave of The New York Times to put that image on the front page. It&#39;s a difficult image, but it is a historically important image.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"French minister says the EU will 'probably' let Ukraine join the pact 'in a few years'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/french-minister-says-eu-probably-let-ukraine-join-few-years-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622a085b7eb82f00180e4d64?format=jpeg\" height=\"3369\" width=\"4492\" charset=\"\" alt=\"France&#39;s European Affairs Minister Clement Beaune.\"/><figcaption>France&#39;s European Affairs Minister Clement Beaune.<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Jean-Francois Badias</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The EU will &#34;probably&#34; let Ukraine join &#34;in a few years,&#34; a French minister reportedly said.&#160;</li>\n<li>That dashes Ukrainian President Zelenskyy&#39;s hopes of his country&#39;s swift entry into the pact.&#160;</li>\n<li>Zelenskyy officially applied to have Ukraine join the EU last month after Russia invaded Ukraine.</li>\n</ul><p>The European Union will &#34;probably&#34; let Ukraine join the 27-nation bloc &#34;in a few years,&#34; France&#39;s European affairs minister said on Thursday, dashing Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy&#39;s hopes of his country&#39;s swift entry into the pact.&#160;</p><p>&#34;It is my deep conviction that there will be a European Union which will be in a few years, I don&#39;t know when, in a few years, probably extended to Ukraine, to Moldova, to Georgia, perhaps to other countries,&#34; French Minister for European Affairs Clement Beaune told radio channel France Inter, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/europe/live-news/ukraine-russia-putin-news-03-10-22/h_a660a41ef2587709d45547afdb61c1cb\">according to CNN</a>.&#160;</p><p>Beaune added that the EU granting Ukraine membership into the bloc is &#34;is not for tomorrow.&#34;</p><p>The European affairs minister made the comments ahead of a meeting of EU leaders taking place Thursday and Friday in Versailles, France, CNN reported.&#160;</p><p>Zelenskyy <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-officially-applied-for-ukraine-to-join-european-union-2022-2\">officially applied</a> to have Ukraine join the EU last month just days after <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\">Russian President Vladimir Putin launched Russia&#39;s war</a> with the eastern European country.&#160;</p><p>The Ukrainian president has urged the EU to give his country &#34;immediate&#34; membership into the pact amid the Russian invasion that has already left hundreds of Ukrainian civilians, including children, dead.&#160;</p><p>&#34;These days, the EU leaders will convene to discuss Russia&#39;s war against Ukraine. To discuss our application for EU membership,&#34; Zelenskyy said in a video message on Thursday. &#34;We are waiting for a concrete signal. We look forward to strong support. Because it will be fair, real, human, European.&#34;</p><p>Last month, Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president,&#160; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/european-commission-president-says-eu-wants-ukraine-to-join-2022-2\">said the EU wants Ukraine as a member</a>.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Indeed over time, they belong to us,&#34; von der Leyen <a href=\"https://www.euronews.com/2022/02/27/ukraine-is-one-of-us-and-we-want-them-in-eu-ursula-von-der-leyen-tells-euronews\">told Euronews</a>. &#34;They are one of us and we want them in.&#34;</p><p>The outlet reported that von der Leyen did not specify whether the process for Ukraine to join would be as quick as Zelenskyy has hoped.</p><p>The process of joining the EU typically takes years, and accession requires unanimous support from current member states.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Y","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-grimes-2nd-baby-girl-y-vanity-fair-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622a063e6ec7c20019cd7547?format=jpeg\" Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Elon Musk and Grimes have welcomed a second child, a girl named Y, Vanity Fair reports.</li>\n<li>The baby was conceived via surrogate &#8212; the couple never announced they were expecting.&#160;</li>\n<li>Musk and Grimes share a nearly 2-year-old son named X. It&#39;s Musk&#39;s seventh child and first daughter.</li>\n</ul><p>Elon Musk and Grimes are parents &#8212; again.&#160;</p><p>The Tesla and SpaceX CEO has secretly welcomed another baby with his on-again, off-again partner, the musician Grimes, she revealed in <a href=\"https://www.vanityfair.com/style/2022/03/grimes-cover-story-on-music-and-mars\">a Vanity Fair cover story by Devin Gordon</a> published Thursday.</p><p>It&#39;s the second child for Musk and Grimes, but Musk&#39;s seventh and his first daughter. The couple&#39;s son, X Æ A-Xii &#8212; which is pronounced &#34;X A.I. Archangel,&#34; Grimes told Vanity Fair &#8212; was born in May 2020.</p><p>Their daughter was conceived via surrogate after Grimes had serious discomfort and complications during her pregnancy with X. The new baby&#39;s name is Y, but the couple hasn&#39;t yet revealed her full name, Vanity Fair reports.&#160;</p><p>Musk and Grimes have never announced that they were expecting again, and it seems they had planned to keep baby Y a secret &#8212; Gordon, the Vanity Fair writer, discovered her existence after arriving at Grimes&#39; house in Austin for an interview and hearing her crying upstairs.&#160;</p><p>&#34;I&#39;m not at liberty to speak on these things,&#34; Grimes said at first, visibly uncomfortable, according to Gordon.&#160;&#34;Whatever is going on with family stuff, I just feel like kids need to stay out of it.&#34;&#160;</p><p>She added that &#34;X is just out there&#34; and that Musk seems to view the 2-year-old as a protégé, bringing him to public events.&#160;</p><p>After the baby began crying louder, Grimes laughed and told Vanity Fair that the baby is &#34;a little colicky&#34; right now. &#34;I don&#39;t know. I don&#39;t know what I was thinking,&#34; she said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229ca0a7eb82f00180e47a9?format=jpeg\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich looks on from the stands during the Barclays Premier League match between Chelsea and Manchester City at Stamford Bridge\"/><figcaption>Roman Abramovich.<p class=\"copyright\">Paul Gilham/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Chelsea FC owner Roman Abramovich was among seven Russian oligarchs sanctioned by the UK on Thursday.</li>\n<li>Rosneft CEO Igor Sechin and Gazprom CEO Alexei Miller were also included in the list.</li>\n<li>The UK will freeze the oligarchs&#39; assets and ban them from doing business with the country.</li>\n</ul><p>The United Kingdom announced on Thursday that it had sanctioned seven more Russian oligarchs.</p><p>These include Chelsea Football Club owner Roman Abramovich, founder of Russian aluminum group Rusal Oleg Deripaska, and Rosneft CEO Igor Sechin, the UK government said in a <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/news/abramovich-and-deripaska-among-seven-oligarchs-targeted-in-estimated-15bn-sanction-hit\">press release</a>.&#160;</p><p>The other oligarchs include Alexei Miller, Gazprom CEO; Andrey Kostin, chairman of VTB bank; Nikolai Tokarev president of the Russia state-owned pipeline company Transneft; and Dmitri Lebedev, who is chairman of the board of directors of Bank Rossiya, per the UK government.</p><p>&#34;These oligarchs &#8212; who have a collective net worth of around £15bn &#8212; will have their assets in the UK frozen, they are banned from travelling here and no UK citizen or company may do business with them,&#34; the UK government said in the release.</p><p>Prime Minister Boris Johnson said in the release: &#34;There can be no safe havens for those who have supported Putin&#39;s vicious assault on Ukraine.&#34;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61fc09a3646a16001823f88f?format=jpeg\" height=\"3446\" width=\"5179\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Boris Johnson at Uxbridge police station grimacing with an officer behind him\"/><figcaption>UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson.<p class=\"copyright\">Leon Neal/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>The seven men are among the Russian oligarchs and billionaires hit by sanctions because of their ties to President Vladimir Putin since his troops invaded Ukraine two weeks ago.</p><p>Abramovich, who has a net worth of&#160;<a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/profiles/roman-abramovich/?sref=lAVQtUwz\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"4197c8e97c1f25ac2f759795e1d61dbc\">$13.6 billion</a>, according to Bloomberg&#39;s Billionaire Index, hasn&#39;t been sanctioned by any other country yet. He <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-oligarch-roman-abramovich-will-sell-english-club-chelsea-fc-2022-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"9d5f5e1c3a6ef0ef562f3ffb68c06dc2\">announced</a> last week that he was selling Chelsea FC, with an asking price of $2.5 billion, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/02/sports/soccer/chelsea-roman-abramovich.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"e78a193a4a90d302742a890241505468\">The New York Times</a>&#160;reported.&#160;</p><p>Deripaska, who has spoken out against Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine, was already sanctioned in the US.</p><p>The UK previously&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uk-sanctions-5-russia-banks-3-people-over-ukraine-2022-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uk-sanctions-5-russia-banks-3-people-over-ukraine-2022-2\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">sanctioned</a>&#160;three Russian oligarchs, including Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg, and Igor Rotenberg, in its first move to punish Russia for attacking Ukraine.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Fans of McDonald&#39;s in Russia have scrambled to get one last meal at the fast-food chain.</li>\n<li>Videos shared online show a long line of cars outside one outlet, while photos show crowds inside another.</li>\n<li>McDonald&#39;s is temporarily closing its restaurants in Russia in response to the invasion of Ukraine.</li>\n</ul><p>Long queues formed at McDonald&#39;s restaurants in Moscow on Wednesday ahead of the iconic fast-food chain&#39;s temporary closure of its outlets across Russia.</p><p>Footage shared on social media appeared to show cars lined up outside McDonald&#39;s outlets in Moscow and Russians wrapped in winter clothing queueing inside the restaurants.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229a74b6ec7c20019cd6eec?format=jpeg\" height=\"3848\" width=\"5713\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Crowded McDonald&#39;s in Moscow\"/><figcaption>A crowd seen inside a McDonald&#39;s outlet in Moscow on Wednesday night.<p class=\"copyright\">Konstantin Zavrazhin/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><p>A day earlier, McDonald&#39;s CEO Chris Kempczinski announced in a <a href=\"https://corporate.mcdonalds.com/corpmcd/en-us/our-stories/article/ourstories.Russia-update.html\">memo</a> that the company would be <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-closing-russia-locations-during-conflict-2022-3\">closing its nearly 850 restaurants in the country indefinitely</a>, following Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Jason Corcoran  (@jason_corcoran) <a predict&#34; at this stage when McDonald&#39;s would reopen its restaurants, but said the company would &#34;closely monitor the situation.&#34; The chain will continue to pay its 62,000 staff in Russia during the closure.</p><p>Several other global food brands such as <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2022/03/08/business/mcdonalds-pepsi-coke-russia/index.html\">Starbucks and Coca-Cola</a> also announced on Tuesday that they would suspend their operations in Russia, aligning themselves with heavy sanctions imposed by Western governments in response to the war in Ukraine.</p><div
