Loh)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229ac1a7eb82f00180e4666?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn68@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-33-031_81d4d567cbb2a79e.webp","https://i.insider.com/6229a74b6ec7c20019cd6eec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-31-528_df18c402dced48fb.webp","https://i.insider.com/6229bab87eb82f00180e46f9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn94@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-31-525_e44871c89b52934b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Vd86dC-tBwE:Q_Zd7r3-AZY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn74@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-073_a6e47afe745955eb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Vd86dC-tBwE:Q_Zd7r3-AZY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn50@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-29-168_4001e160e3eb8782.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Vd86dC-tBwE:Q_Zd7r3-AZY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn38@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-33-359_1dad05b9dc11442e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704370},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Russians are flocking to VPNs as Putin closes off the Russian internet in a crackdown against dissent","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-ukraine-russia-vpn-demand-surge-amid-crackdown-online-dissent-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622975bb6ec7c20019cd6e6b?format=jpeg\" height=\"3840\" width=\"5544\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A woman walks past huge placards bearing images of Russian President Vladimir Putin and reading &#34;Russia does not start wars, it ends them,&#34; in annexed Crimea\"/><figcaption>Moscow launched a crackdown against dissent after Russian President Vladimir Putin announced a &#34;special military operation&#34; into Ukraine on February 24. In this photo in annexed Crimea, a placard reads: &#34;Russia does not start wars, it ends them.&#34;<p class=\"copyright\">STRINGER/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Russian demand for VPNs is soaring as the Kremlin cracks down on dissent amid its invasion of Ukraine.</li>\n<li>Russia is blocking Facebook and Twitter, while other tech firms are withdrawing voluntarily.</li>\n<li>One analysis estimates that downloads for the top 10 VPNs in Russia increased by 4,375%.</li>\n</ul><p>Russians are thronging this week to online tools that help them skirt internet restrictions as the Kremlin began blocking or limiting access to foreign platforms and social media sites, according to multiple media reports and analyses.</p><p>Demand for virtual private networks, or VPNs, has surged in Russia in the weeks after President Vladimir Putin announced a &#34;special military operation&#34; into Ukraine, according to data from <a href=\"https://www.top10vpn.com/research/vpn-demand-statistics/\">Top10VPN</a> released Tuesday. Top10VPN reported that search traffic around the term &#34;VPN&#34; jumped by 1,092% over the previous 30 days.&#160;</p><p>The VPN analysis site also reported that Russian authorities have now <a href=\"https://www.top10vpn.com/research/websites-blocked-in-russia/\">banned 200 websites</a>, including the Russian-language versions of BBC News, German outlet Deutsche Welle, and a plethora of Ukrainian news sites.</p><p>As the war in Ukraine rages on, the Kremlin has launched a widespread crackdown on dissent.</p><p>On Saturday, Russia blocked both <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-blocks-tech-platforms-including-facebook-twitter-amid-ukraine-invasion-2022-3\">Facebook and Twitter</a>. And just a day before, the Russian government signed <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-legislature-pass-law-punish-false-information-ukraine-jail-time-2022-3\">a new law</a> that punishes anyone spreading &#34;false information&#34; about its assault on Ukraine with up to 15 years in prison.</p><p>As Russia cuts its access to these sites, other platforms such as TikTok, Amazon, and Netflix, have <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-suspends-all-live-streaming-and-content-sharing-in-russia-2022-3\">voluntarily withdrawn their services</a> from the country in line with heavy sanctions imposed by the West, further intensifying demand for VPNs.</p><p><a href=\"https://appfigures.com/resources/insights/censorship-leads-to-vpn-russia\">Analysis website AppFigures</a> reported on Monday that downloads for the top 10 VPNs in Russia surged by 4,375%, from an average of 16,000 per day to more than 700,000 daily since February 24.</p><p>&#34;In the 10 days between February 24 and March 5, the top 10 VPN apps on the App Store and on Google Play saw more than 4,600,000 new downloads. And our estimates are very conservative here,&#34; the website wrote.</p><p>Similarly, UK-registered ExpressVPN has seen a 330% increase in traffic from Russia on its website, company Vice President Harold Li <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-09/russians-are-finding-ways-around-putin-s-internet-blockade\">told Bloomberg</a> on Wednesday.</p><p>A spokesperson for another VPN, Surfshark, told the outlet its average weekly sales increased by 35 times since the invasion began.</p><p>&#34;The last time we saw a similar increase in sales was when China passed the Hong Kong Security Law in May 2020,&#34; they told Bloomberg.</p><p>On the other hand, Twitter has started including the Tor onion network on its <a href=\"https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/twitter-supported-browsers\">list of supported browsers</a> as of Wednesday evening, two days after the social media platform told <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2022/03/07/twitter-russia-access/\">TechCrunch</a> that it was working to &#34;fully restore&#34; access to its services in Russia.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/anonymous-web-browser-tor-update-2017-11\">Tor</a> works by routing a user&#39;s connection through other users&#39; computers across the globe, effectively making them anonymous and capable of breaking through a country&#39;s internet restrictions. The browser is also well-known as a&#160; software that allows access to the &#34;Dark Web,&#34; or hidden sites that are often used for illegal purposes and the black market.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-ukraine-russia-vpn-demand-surge-amid-crackdown-online-dissent-2022-3\">Business 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Sony blocks PlayStation sales in Russia","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/sony-blocks-playstation-console-store-sales-russia-ukraine-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61859349326b260018351904?format=jpeg\" height=\"1933\" width=\"2578\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Two people holding PlayStation 5 controllers and playing games.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Rokas Tenys/Shutterstock</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>PlayStation announced it suspended hardware and software sales in Russia.</li>\n<li>That means Russians will be unable to buy both PlayStation consoles and games.</li>\n<li>Microsoft announced last week it would stop all sales in Russia, including Xbox.</li>\n</ul><p>Russians have been cut off from buying new PlayStation consoles or games.</p><p>Sony announced Wednesday it was suspending all sales in Russia in response to the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-close-circle-russian-officials-complaining-about-ukraine-invasion-rustamova-2022-3\">invasion of Ukraine</a>.</p><p>&#34;Sony Interactive Entertainment (SIE) joins the global community in calling for peace in Ukraine,&#34; the company said in a <a href=\"https://twitter.com/PlayStation/status/1501689329730478081\">statement</a>. &#34;We have suspended all software and hardware shipments, the launch of Gran Turismo 7, and operations of the PlayStation store in Russia.&#34;</p><p>Sony joins a <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/story/gaming-industry-unites-russia/\">growing number of gaming companies</a> who have suspended sales in Russia in protest of the invasion.</p><p>Microsoft announced last week it was <a href=\"https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2022/03/04/microsoft-suspends-russia-sales-ukraine-conflict/\">suspending all sales and services in Russia</a>, meaning Russians are now unable to purchase both major consoles PlayStation and Xbox.</p><p>The suspensions from both companies came after Ukraine&#39;s digital minister <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-xbox-playstation-block-russian-gamers-2022-3\">Mykhailo Fedorov appealed directly to Xbox and PlayStation</a> to block Russian gamers&#39; accounts.</p><p>&#34;We are sure that such actions will motivate the citizens of Russia to proactively stop the disgraceful military aggression,&#34; Fedorov wrote.</p><p>It is not clear from Sony&#39;s announcement whether Russian PlayStation account holders will lose access to their games.&#160;</p><p>Sony also announced a donation of $2 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the NGO Save the Children.</p><p>Nintendo has not blocked sales of its console the Nintendo Switch, although it <a href=\"https://www.engadget.com/nintendo-russia-locked-out-digital-purchases-151105934.html\">stopped selling games on its online shop</a> saying the payment service it uses had stopped processing rubles.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/sony-blocks-playstation-console-store-sales-russia-ukraine-2022-3\">Business Hamilton)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/61859349326b260018351904?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn64@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-05-771_26000e427bbd0ee9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tqssqAKLyP0:TnpQPYUCDH8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tqssqAKLyP0:TnpQPYUCDH8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn8@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-23-972_36f472c85647dea3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tqssqAKLyP0:TnpQPYUCDH8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn11@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-32-756_d6d3e81987e266a1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704345},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Pro-Trump Colorado election clerk Tina Peters and her aide indicted by grand jury related to election data breach","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/colorado-clerk-tina-peters-indicted-on-election-data-breach-counts-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229539d6ec7c20019cd6cab?format=jpeg\" height=\"750\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Mike Lindell, Tina Peters\"/><figcaption>yPillow CEO Mike Lindell told Vice News that Peters is now &#34;holed up&#34; in a safe house.<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images, Mesa County</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Pro-Trump Colorado Clerk Tina Peters was indicted on 10 counts related to a May 2021 election data breach.</li>\n<li>The grand jury also indicted Belinda Knisley on 6 counts related to the breach.</li>\n<li>The Colorado sec. of state accused the pair of sharing confidential voting machine info online.</li>\n</ul><p>Tina Peters, the pro-Trump elections official in Mesa County, Colorado, who has been accused of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tina-peters-stripped-of-authority-to-oversee-elections-mesa-county-2021-10\">leaking sensitive voting machine data</a>, was indicted on 10 counts by a Mesa County grand jury related to her alleged role in the election data breach, according to the county&#39;s district attorney. Her aide, Belinda Knisley was indicted on six counts related to the breach.</p><p>Peters was indicted on counts of attempting to influence a public servant, criminal impersonation, conspiracy to commit criminal impersonation, identity theft, first-degree official misconduct, violation of duty, and failing to comply with the secretary of state.&#160;</p><p>Her aide, Knisley, was charged with attempting to influence a public servant, conspiracy to commit criminal impersonation, violation of duty, and failing to comply with the secretary of state. Peters and Knisley turned themselves in, according to authorities.</p><p>In the indictment, District Attorney Dan Rubinstein said that Peters and Kinsley attempted to convince at least four other public servants to follow a plan to disseminate confidential information from Dominion Voting Systems voting machines &#8212; which are not connected to the internet &#8212; online, following a &#34;trusted build,&#34; which is a high-security software update for the machines.</p><p>The indictment added that they convinced staff that an unauthorized man was a county worker.</p><p>&#34;Beginning in April 2021 and in advance of the May 25-26, 2021, trusted build, Tina Peters and Belinda Knisley, either as principal actors and/or acting as complicators, devised and executed a deceptive scheme which was designed to influence public servants, breach security protocols, exceed permissible access to voting equipment, and set in motion the eventual distribution of confidential information to unauthorized people,&#34; Rubinstein wrote in the indictment.</p><p>Colorado Secretary of State Jena Griswold has sued Peters three times, but it was her August 2021 lawsuit accusing Peters of orchestrating the breach that spawned local and national investigations.&#160;</p><p>A grand jury was called after Griswold&#39;s lawsuit, and the case will now go to trial. District Attorney Dan Rubinstein said that others could be charged in connection with the breach.</p><p>In early February of this year, Peters <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pro-trump-colorado-clerk-appears-kick-police-officer-during-arrest-2022-2\">was arrested</a> for resisting a search warrant for her iPad &#8212; unrelated to her alleged election data breach. Peters also announced a run for Colorado secretary of state against Griswold during the same month.</p><p>&#34;The grand jury, randomly selected from the same pool of citizens that elected Clerk Tina Peters and chosen months before any of these alleged offenses occurred, concluded there is probable cause that Clerk Peters and Deputy Clerk&#160; Knisley committed crimes,&#34; Rubinstein and Attorney General Phil Weiser said in a statement.</p><p>Peters accused Griswold of &#34;using a grand jury to formalize politically-motivated accusations against candidates,&#34; <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/tina-peters-colorado-mesa-county-indicted-voting-system-breach/\">according to CBS.</a></p><p>&#34;Using legal muscle to indict political opponents during an election isn&#39;t new strategy, but it&#39;s easier to execute when you have a district attorney who despises President Trump and any constitutional conservative like myself who continues to demand all election evidence be made available to the public,&#34; Peters said in response to the indictment.</p><p>Tina Peters&#39; office did not immediately return Insider&#39;s request for comment.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/colorado-clerk-tina-peters-indicted-on-election-data-breach-counts-2022-3\">Business (Azmi Haroun)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229539d6ec7c20019cd6cab?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn19@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-24-989_df6937e15def8585.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tKt2zyewZAU:KO7NcoAUB8o:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn26@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-33-263_e5e238ad1dbf818c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tKt2zyewZAU:KO7NcoAUB8o:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn73@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-29-577_fa08634544a8e702.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=tKt2zyewZAU:KO7NcoAUB8o:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn66@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-26-272_f343091d76839cd4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704354},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"How to make your iPhone alarm louder, and 5 other tips for making sure your alarm goes off properly","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-make-iphone-alarm-louder","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62295d796ec7c20019cd6d2d?format=jpeg\" height=\"1060\" width=\"2121\" charset=\"\" alt=\"woman on phone in bed\"/><figcaption>There are several ways to optimize your iPhone alarm to make sure it wakes you up.<p class=\"copyright\">Adam Hester/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>You can make your iPhone alarm louder by dragging the Ringer and Alerts slider in the Settings app.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">You should also be sure to choose a louder alarm sound that has a more aggressive noise, which can more easily wake you.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">Consider playing the alarm through external speakers or using an Apple Watch, which can also help wake you with haptics.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tech-reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit Insider&#39;s Tech Reference library for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Is your iPhone&#39;s alarm not loud enough to do its job in the morning? Sure, you might bear some of the blame if you&#39;re an especially sound sleeper, but your iPhone needs to be able to step up to the challenge as well. The good news is that you can raise the volume with just a few taps and not miss your wake-up alarm.&#160;</p><h2><strong>How to make your iPhone alarm louder</strong></h2><p>Your iPhone relies on one accessible slider in Settings to control the overall volume of your alarm. Just beware that this is also your phone&#39;s ringer volume, so you should choose a level that&#39;s appropriate for both.&#160;</p><p><strong>1.</strong> On your iPhone, start the <strong>Settings </strong>app.</p><p><strong>2.</strong> Tap <strong>Sound &#38; Haptics</strong>.</p><p><strong>3.</strong> In the <strong>Ringer and Alerts</strong> section, drag the slider to the right to increase the volume.&#160;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622967046ec7c20019cd6dff?format=jpeg\" height=\"1919\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Changing the ringer and alerts volume on iPhone.\"/><figcaption>In the Sound &#38; Haptics section of Settings, you can adjust the volume of your ringer and alerts.<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson</p></figcaption></figure><p>By default, the volume buttons on the side of your iPhone do not control the ringer and alerts volume (which is also the alarm volume). But you can enable this, which makes it easier to quickly adjust the volume at bedtime. In the Settings app, tap <strong>Sound &#38; Haptics</strong>, then in the <strong>Ringer and Alerts</strong> section, turn on <strong>Change with Buttons</strong> by swiping the button to the right. Just be sure you don&#39;t accidentally lower the volume using the buttons.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Other tips for making sure your iPhone alarm goes off properly</strong></h2><p>There are a few other tips you can check or apply to your alarm&#39;s volume and vibration to help wake you up.</p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong>Make sure you haven&#39;t accidentally set the alarm sound to None.</strong> Start the <strong>Clock </strong>app, tap the <strong>Alarm </strong>tab and tap the alarm you want to use. Make sure <strong>Sound </strong>is not set to <strong>None</strong>.</li></ul><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622967396ec7c20019cd6e03?format=jpeg\" height=\"1734\" width=\"1242\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Setting the iPhone alarm sound\"/><figcaption>If your alarm is silent, it might be because the alarm sound is set to None.<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Johnson</p></figcaption></figure><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong>Choose a louder alarm sound.</strong> Not all alarm sounds are normalized to the same level, and some have a more aggressive noise, which can make them sound louder. That&#39;s especially true if you use your own song or sound effect. Start the <strong>Clock </strong>app, tap the <strong>Alarm </strong>tab and tap the alarm you want to use. Tap <strong>Sound</strong>, then explore the various sounds to see which one works best for you.&#160;</li><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong>Change or customize the alarm vibration. </strong>Through the Clock app, you can also <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-change-alarm-sound-on-iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">change your alarm vibration or even create a custom vibration pattern</a> to accompany the alarm&#39;s sound.&#160;</li><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong>Play the alarm through external speakers.</strong> If you can&#39;t make your iPhone loud enough to suit you, that probably means there&#39;s something wrong with the phone&#39;s built-in speaker, and you might want to get it serviced. In the meantime, you might consider connecting the phone to a dock with integrated speakers or some other external speaker that you can set as loud as you like.&#160;</li><li><strong>Use the iPhone with an Apple Watch.</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-pair-apple-watch-with-iphone\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">An Apple Watch can be configured to work with your iPhone&#39;s Alarm app</a> and will wake you with vibrations and sound.</li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-make-iphone-alarm-louder\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a &#34;powerful men&#34; who might &#34;blow up deals over ego.&#34;</li>\n<li>&#34;He knew exactly how to play these guys, and he played it like a fiddle,&#34; said Trump Jr.</li>\n</ul><p>Donald Trump Jr. said on Wednesday that the praise his father, former President Donald Trump, showered on world leaders like China&#39;s Xi Jinping, North Korea&#39;s Kim Jong Un, and Russia&#39;s Vladimir Putin was all part of a strategy to &#34;play&#34; them.</p><p>In a <a href=\"https://rumble.com/vwycmv-the-truth-trump-proved-everyone-wrong-about-russia.html?mref=i2svv&#38;mc=36we8\">video</a> posted on his Rumble account, Trump Jr. said his father is someone who knows how to deal with &#34;powerful men&#34; and that he &#34;had it right all along&#34; when it came to dealing with foreign leaders.</p><p>&#34;So my father understands that, you know, men will blow up deals over ego. I&#39;ve seen it my whole life, and my father&#39;s certainly seen it. Because he&#39;s dealt with powerful, egotistical people his entire life. He&#39;s built a brand around dealing with those people. World leaders aren&#39;t any different,&#34; Trump Jr. said.</p><p>&#34;He knew exactly how to play these guys, and he played it like a fiddle,&#34; he added, while also noting that his father&#39;s flattery of foreign leaders was not an act of &#34;capitulation.&#34;</p><p>Appearing to mock Trump&#39;s dissenters, Trump Jr. described a typical critic as &#34;some nerd in his mom&#39;s basement who&#39;s never dealt with anything, never actually had any power, never understood those people.&#34;</p><p>Trump has praised authoritarian world leaders like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-praises-kim-jong-un-north-korea-tough-2018-6\">Kim,</a> Putin, and <a href=\"https://www.dw.com/en/us-president-donald-trump-praises-chinas-xi-jinping-for-consolidating-grip-on-power/a-42817441\">Xi </a>during his presidency and even <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-praised-foreign-leaders-ranted-about-windmills-at-gop-retreat-2021-10\">after leaving office.</a></p><p>During a Florida fundraiser in 2018, then-President Trump <a href=\"https://www.dw.com/en/us-president-donald-trump-praises-chinas-xi-jinping-for-consolidating-grip-on-power/a-42817441\">called Xi a &#34;great gentleman&#34; and &#34;the most powerful [Chinese] president in a hundred years&#34;</a> after China scrapped its two-term limit for the country&#39;s presidency.</p><p>That same year, he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-praises-kim-jong-un-north-korea-tough-2018-6\">expressed his admiration for Kim</a>, describing the latter as a &#34;tough guy&#34; who was able to &#34;take over a country&#34; at the age of 27.</p><p>More recently, Trump has been slammed by numerous parties &#8212; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/veteran-diplomats-slam-former-president-trump-for-praising-putin-2022-2\">including veteran diplomats</a> &#8212; for calling<a data-uri=\"99812cbcdcd2eae3212d28764501fe44\"> Putin&#39;s justification for invading Ukraine &#34;savvy&#34; and &#34;genius.&#34; </a></p><p>On February 24, the day Russia&#39;s attack began, he also <a href=\"https://twitter.com/reallizusa/status/1496476919684030468?s=21\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\">released a statement on Twitter</a>&#160;&#8212; via his spokeswoman Liz Harrington &#8212; claiming that Putin was &#34;playing [President Joe] Biden like a drum.&#34;<a (Cheryl Teh)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229653b7eb82f00180e4514?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn59@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-24-724_b24ab71a7b937902.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S1lEwKP9iYg:3QaDIVmB7IE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn41@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-33-020_fa72f5a1d0db81e1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S1lEwKP9iYg:3QaDIVmB7IE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn35@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-23-676_61224fbc5e4afda8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=S1lEwKP9iYg:3QaDIVmB7IE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn69@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-26-274_fd2926430a712b6e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704367},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Johns Hopkins, Yale, and NYU are teaming up to tackle a key bottleneck that will arise as psychedelics come to market","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/psychedelics-psychiatrist-training-program-johns-hopkins-nyu-yale-university-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/603eacb4b46d720018b04765?format=jpeg\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"prestigious US universities psychedelic studies 2x1\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">iStock; Samantha Lee/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li aria-level=\"1\">Universities have become more open about their research into psychedelics in recent years.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">As psychedelic treatments inch toward regulatory approval, schools want to tackle a coming issue.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">Johns Hopkins, NYU, and Yale are collaborating to create a psychedelics-psychiatrist program.</li>\n</ul><p>As psychedelics treatments <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/atai-ceo-interview-on-challenges-facing-the-psychedelics-industry-2021-7?r=psych-lp\">move closer to regulatory approval</a>, there&#39;s an issue looming in the industry: the lack of trained professionals who can handle such powerful compounds.</p><p>Psychedelics are mind-altering substances, and it can take <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/compass-pathways-psychedelics-psilocybin-phase-2-data-depression-2021-11\">hours for professionals to guide patients through the experience</a> of taking them as treatments for conditions like post-traumatic stress disorder and severe depression. Experts like Dr. Stephen Ross, an associate director at the New York University Langone Health&#39;s Center for Psychedelic Medicine, estimate we could need tens of thousands of trained professionals when psychedelic medications come to market.</p><p>In recent years, top universities have begun to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/universities-set-up-psychedelics-research-centers-depression-anxiety-imperial-hopkins-2021-3\">establish centers to study compounds</a> like psilocybin and MDMA. Now, they&#39;re turning to address the lack of trained therapists, which they see as the next bottleneck that could hamper these compounds.</p><p>Johns Hopkins University, Yale University, and New York University announced on Thursday they were collaborating to create a psychedelics curriculum for psychiatrists. A $1 million grant will fund researchers at the three schools over the next two years to develop a curriculum for psychiatrists and create educational materials for other medical professionals.</p><p>The collaboration is the latest sign that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/universities-set-up-psychedelics-research-centers-depression-anxiety-imperial-hopkins-2021-3\">top academic institutions</a> and the medical establishment are warming up to these compounds.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/603e67d013b221001876b17c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1674\" width=\"1256\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Carey Turnbull, president of the Heffter Research Institute and board member of the Usona Institute\"/><figcaption>Carey Turnbull, the president of the Heffter Research Institute and a board member of the Usona Institute.<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Carey Turnbull</p></figcaption></figure><p>&#34;A few short years ago, this would have been an absurd dream,&#34; Carey Turnbull, the president of the psychedelics nonprofit Heffter Research Institute, told Insider.</p><h2>Philanthropists are funding the various parts of the psychedelics movement that need to come together</h2><p>Turnbull and his wife, Claudia Turnbull, who are longtime players in the psychedelics space, spearheaded the fundraising effort. With philanthropists like Tim Ferriss, Bill Linton, Michael and Lisa Cotton, and the Evolve Foundation, they raised $1 million for the program.&#160;</p><p>Lisa and Michael Cotton told Insider they donated $75,000 to the program and had, over the past two years, donated more than $1 million into the psychedelics space.</p><p>&#34;People who have gone through traumatic events should be able to have tools at their disposal that can help them live better lives,&#34; Michael Cotton said.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60f982a2fc253600181fcd5d?format=jpeg\" height=\"2644\" width=\"3992\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Psilocybin mushrooms on a mossy log\"/><figcaption>Psilocybin mushrooms.<p class=\"copyright\">jackfoto/iStock/Getty Images Plus</p></figcaption></figure><h2>Psychedelics are like &#39;nuclear power&#39; and need significant oversight</h2><p>Roland Griffiths, the director of Johns Hopkins&#39; Center for Psychedelic and Consciousness Research, told Insider that he sometimes thought of his work with psychedelics as akin to working with &#34;nuclear power&#34; <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/psychedelic-industry-top-warning-danger-influential-women-psilocybin-mdma-2022-3\">because of how powerful the compounds are</a>.</p><p>Because of this, he said, there needs to be significant medical oversight <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/psychedelics-investors-vcs-predictions-new-compounds-failures-2021-7\">built into the psychedelic model</a>.</p><p>The goal is to have the curriculum certified by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education, which would create a pathway to make the program available to medical schools as an accredited specialty all across the country.&#160;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228e2937eb82f00180e280f?format=jpeg\" height=\"3004\" width=\"4500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Stephen Ross is the associate director at the NYU Langone Health Center for Psychedelic Medicine\"/><figcaption>Stephen Ross is an associate director at the NYU Langone Health Center for Psychedelic Medicine.<p class=\"copyright\">NYU</p></figcaption></figure><h2>The program aims to train psychiatrists and the broader medical community</h2><p>If it receives ACGME certification, psychiatrists will be able to specialize in psychedelic psychiatry, just as they would child psychiatry or forensic psychiatry. But that process could take up to a decade.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228e2e87eb82f00180e2824?format=jpeg\" height=\"1200\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Benjamin Kelmendi is an assistant professor of psychiatry at Yale University and co-director of the Yale Program for Psychedelic Science\"/><figcaption>Benjamin Kelmendi is an assistant professor of psychiatry at Yale University and a codirector of the Yale Program for Psychedelic Science.<p class=\"copyright\">Yale</p></figcaption></figure><p>NYU&#39;s Ross told Insider it was &#34;daunting&#34; to think about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/exclusive-pitch-deck-psychedelic-startup-fluence-3-million-2022-2\">the sheer number of therapists that needed to be trained</a> to expand access for patients. He added that even though this program was geared toward psychiatry, its ambitions were broader.</p><p>The idea is that the program will be designed in a way so that parts of the curriculum can help train other healthcare professionals &#8212; like therapists, nurses, and physician assistants &#8212; and even be provided as material in medical schools.</p><h2>Researchers are working to fill the gap that exists between psychedelics and the medical system</h2><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228e3239fa32d00184c8cce?format=jpeg\" height=\"3472\" width=\"2480\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Christopher Pittenger is co-director at the Yale Program for Psychedelic Science\"/><figcaption>Christopher Pittenger is a codirector at the Yale Program for Psychedelic Science.<p class=\"copyright\">Yale</p></figcaption></figure><p>Dr. Benjamin Kelmendi, a codirector of the Yale Program for Psychedelic Science, told Insider that he saw psychedelics as having broad applications that will attract other branches of medicine.</p><p>&#34;The gap that we&#39;re trying to fill with this program is to bring together the psychedelic expertise that&#39;s been developed at a number of places and bring it into the mainstream of the medical establishment,&#34; Dr. Christopher Pittenger, the program&#39;s other codirector, said.</p><p>&#34;If all the psychedelic expertise grows up <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/top-psychedelics-vcs-predict-a-tech-boom-and-more-clinics-2021-7\">outside of mainstream medicine</a>, then that creates a schism in the field, which I don&#39;t think is good for anyone,&#34; he added.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/psychedelics-psychiatrist-training-program-johns-hopkins-nyu-yale-university-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Russia repeats claim it didn't attack Ukraine, saying it was forced to defend to pro-Kremlin regions","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-repeats-claim-did-not-attack-ukraine-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229e4747eb82f00180e4a30?format=jpeg\" height=\"750\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Sergei Lavrov attends a news conference in Antalya, Turkey, on March 10, 2022.\"/><figcaption>Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov attends a news conference in Antalya, Turkey, on March 10, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Stringer/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said Thursday that Russia was in Ukraine to defend two pro-Kremlin regions.</li>\n<li>&#34;We are not planning to attack other countries, and we did not attack Ukraine,&#34; he said.</li>\n<li>Putin said last month he was aiming for the &#34;demilitarization and de-Nazification of Ukraine.&#34;</li>\n</ul><p>Russia&#39;s foreign minister repeated his country&#39;s false claim that it did not attack Ukraine, saying instead that it had launched the &#34;special military operation&#34; to defend two pro-Kremlin regions.</p><p>After meeting Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba in Antalya, Turkey, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said Russia was being threatened and had to defend the regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, <a href=\"https://news.sky.com/story/ukraine-russia-war-latest-news-putin-zelenskyy-ceasefire-nato-visa-live-updates-12541713\">Sky News reported.</a></p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-recognizes-ukrainian-separatist-regions-independent-states-2022-2\">Russia recognized</a> the pro-Kremlin, Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent states on February 21, three days before Russian troops entered Ukraine. The designation gave Russia a justification to invade Ukraine.</p><p>&#34;We are not planning to attack other countries, and we did not attack Ukraine,&#34; <a href=\"https://twitter.com/TadeuszGiczan/status/1501870356541452290\">Lavrov said</a>.</p><p>The meeting was the first time top diplomats from the two countries met since Russia&#39;s invasion.</p><p>The talks were aimed at &#34;Russia ceasing its hostilities and ending its war against Ukraine,&#34; a Ukrainian Foreign Ministry spokesperson <a href=\"https://twitter.com/OlegNikolenko_/status/1501651229268709379?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1501651229268709379%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&#38;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dw.com%2Fen%2Fukraines-kuleba-no-cease-fire-agreement-reached-at-turkey-meeting%2Fa-61075621\">tweeted Wednesday</a>. But both Kuleba and Lavrov said they were no closer to arranging a cease-fire, with Kuleba saying that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2?utm_source=copy-link&#38;utm_medium=referral&#38;utm_content=topbar#russia-and-ukraine-say-they-are-no-closer-to-arranging-a-cease-fire-after-top-level-talks\">Russia wanted Ukraine to surrender, which Ukraine was unwilling to do</a>.</p><p>Russia has repeatedly denied attacking or invading Ukraine, instead referring to its actions as a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-russia-is-attacking-ukraine-putin-justification-for-invasion-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\">&#34;special military operation.&#34;</a></p><p>Russian President Vladimir Putin said last month that he was trying to prevent a genocide against ethnic Russians and aiming for the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/auschwitz-museum-says-russias-war-in-ukraine-is-an-act-of-barbarity-2022-2?r=US&#38;IR=T\">&#34;demilitarization and de-Nazification of Ukraine.&#34;</a>&#160;</p><p>There is no evidence of genocide in Ukraine, and the country&#39;s democratically-elected president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, is Jewish.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"7ff94d706c030bef4cb81854c0413fac\">Insider&#39;s live blog of the Russian invasion</a>&#160;is covering developments as they happen.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"An '1883' producer explains how the 'Yellowstone' prequel's story will continue without a season 2","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/yellowstone-prequel-1883-story-will-continue-but-without-season-2-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61dc8a1a4ede320018b6debb?format=jpeg\" height=\"1342\" width=\"1936\" charset=\"\" alt=\"1883 yellowstone\"/><figcaption>Sam Elliot in &#34;1883.&#34;<p class=\"copyright\">Paramount+</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Paramount recently announced additional episodes for its &#34;Yellowstone&#34; prequel &#34;1883.&#34;</li>\n<li>Executive producer David Glasser said not to expect a season two, but that the story would continue.</li>\n<li>He said that the &#34;Yellowstone&#34; prequels could be viewed collectively as an &#34;anthology series.&#34;</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/you-dont-need-to-see-yellowstone-to-watch-1883-2022-1\">&#34;1883,&#34;</a> Paramount+&#39;s prequel series to Paramount Network&#39;s &#34;Yellowstone,&#34; aired its finale on February 27, and the episode seemed to complete the main characters&#39; story arcs. After a long journey across the American West, they had reached their destinations and some main characters had died.</p><p>But two weeks earlier, the company Paramount (formerly ViacomCBS) announced during an investor presentation that it had ordered more episodes of the series, stopping short of saying it had been renewed for season two.</p><p>&#34;1883&#34; and &#34;Yellowstone&#34; executive producer David Glasser told Insider during an interview this week that fans shouldn&#39;t expect a second season, but that the story would continue.</p><p>He declined to specify what form the new episodes would take. But Paramount also announced another prequel series, &#34;1932,&#34; and Glasser said it&#39;s safe to think of the prequels together as an &#34;anthology series,&#34; implying that more could be on the way.</p><p>&#34;If you&#39;re a fan of the Dutton family and the saga bringing you to the current day [portrayed in &#39;Yellowstone&#39;], what will come is that continued saga,&#34; he said.</p><p>Glasser said that Sheridan knows how &#34;Yellowstone&#34; will end, no matter how many seasons it continues for. And he had conceived of the 1800s history of the Dutton family when he first started writing &#34;Yellowstone,&#34; long before &#34;1883&#34; was a reality.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/619bbb6b1ca92500180c3a36?format=jpeg\" height=\"1230\" width=\"1748\" charset=\"\" alt=\"yellowstone\"/><figcaption>Kevin Costner in &#34;Yellowstone.&#34;<p class=\"copyright\">Paramount Network</p></figcaption></figure><p>&#34;He knows every character and backstory,&#34; Glasser said. &#34;He told me the &#39;Yellowstone&#39; ending the day we started. When that happens, I don&#39;t know. But he knows where every character ends up.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Yellowstone,&#34; which stars Kevin Costner as the powerful rancher John Dutton, concluded its fourth season in January and Paramount Network quickly <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/yellowstone-renewed-for-season-5-on-paramount-network-2022-2\">renewed the series for season five</a>. The season-four finale was viewed by 9.3 million viewers the day it aired, making it the biggest cable telecast since 2017.</p><p>The streaming rights to &#34;Yellowstone&#34; belong to NBCUniversal&#39;s Peacock, which nabbed them in 2020 before Paramount+ launched in March of 2021. But Paramount is still taking advantage of the show&#39;s popularity. Creator Taylor Sheridan recently renewed a lucrative deal with the company <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/more-tv-shows-from-yellowstone-creator-1883-mayor-of-kingstown-2022-1\">to make original series</a>, including the &#34;Yellowstone&#34; spinoffs and &#34;Mayor of Kingstown.&#34;</p><p>The strategy has paid off. Paramount+ said that &#34;1883&#34; was its biggest original-series debut yet when it premiered in December. The Paramount company added 9.4 million subscribers in Q4 2021 across its streaming platforms (which also includes Showtime), 80% of which came from Paramount+.</p><p>On the franchise&#39;s success, Glasser said that Sheridan, who grew up on a ranch in Texas, was able to tap into an audience he knows well.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Taylor&#39;s a cowboy,&#34; he said. &#34;His writing comes in the evenings. His days are spent being a rancher and farmer. He knows his audience well and he served up something that was for that audience.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/yellowstone-prequel-1883-story-will-continue-but-without-season-2-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6229057b7eb82f00180e330c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d95ea8569264f7e1ca995081f0b466de","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn69@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-23-069_3b9b59cff6b0779f.webp","destWidth":1673,"destHeight":1254,"sourceBytes":43824,"destBytes":43824,"author":"tclark@insider.com (Travis Clark)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/61dc8a1a4ede320018b6debb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn76@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-24-642_0a4a55c198e189a0.webp","https://i.insider.com/619bbb6b1ca92500180c3a36?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn35@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-24-917_ff186588ed1e9e43.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=g8ubPt9VNVw:zFagtu1YzHQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn71@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-30-131_7db9bba5cf16d859.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=g8ubPt9VNVw:zFagtu1YzHQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn64@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-29-075_002fc98d8a342cee.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=g8ubPt9VNVw:zFagtu1YzHQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn26@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-29-251_642488d45771f8aa.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704380},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"The US Navy's only operational sub named after a president has been doing top-secret missions for 17 years","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/navy-seawolf-class-sub-jimmy-carter-secret-missions-17-years-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622961cf6ec7c20019cd6d7d?format=jpeg\" height=\"647\" width=\"1295\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Navy Seawolf-class submarine USS Jimmy Carter\"/><figcaption>US Navy Seawolf-class fast-attack submarine USS Jimmy Carter, September 11, 2017.<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/Lt. Cmdr. Michael Smith</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>US Navy nuclear-powered attack submarine USS Jimmy Carter was commissioned in February 2005.</li>\n<li>USS Jimmy Carter is one of only three Seawolf-class subs, but even among that small group it&#39;s unique.</li>\n<li>The sub has been modified for special missions, and its operations are still closely guarded secrets.</li>\n</ul><p>The US Navy nuclear-powered attack submarine USS Jimmy Carter celebrated the 17th anniversary of its commissioning in February.</p><p>Laid down in 1998, launched in 2004, and commissioned in 2005, Carter is one of only three <a href=\"https://www.navy.mil/Resources/Fact-Files/Display-FactFiles/Article/2169558/attack-submarines-ssn/\" target=\"_top\">Seawolf-class</a> submarines and the only active sub in the US fleet named after a president.</p><p>Though Seawolf-class subs are <a href=\"https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/silent-and-deadly-navys-seawolf-submarine-naval-monster-158526\" target=\"_top\">known</a> as some of the most sophisticated attack subs ever, Carter stands out among the three subs of the class.</p><p>Larger and more advanced than the other two Seawolf boats, Carter has been tasked with some of the US Navy&#39;s most secretive missions.</p><h2>Seawolf-class</h2><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6184196a326b26001834d380?format=jpeg\" height=\"1328\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Seawolf-class fast-attack submarine USS Jimmy Carter\"/><figcaption>USS Jimmy Carter in the Hood Canal as it returns to Naval Base Kitsap-Bangor, September 10, 2017.<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/Lt. Cmdr. Michael Smith</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Navy began designing Seawolf-class subs in 1983 in direct response to the Soviet Navy&#39;s newest <a href=\"https://nationalinterest.org/blog/reboot/how-japan-helped-make-russia%E2%80%99s-akula-class-submarine-stealth-killer-192621\" target=\"_top\">Akula-class</a> attack submarines, which were believed to be stealthier than the US&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.military.com/equipment/los-angeles-class-fast-attack-submarine\" target=\"_top\">Los Angeles-class</a> attack subs.</p><p>At 353 feet long and 40 feet wide, Seawolf-class subs displace 9,138 tons when fully submerged and can sailing over 25 knots. The first boat, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-russia-arctic-activity-amid-us-changes-europe-military-presence-2020-8\" target=\"_top\">USS Seawolf</a>, was commissioned in 1997, while the second boat, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uss-connecticut-accident-hints-at-history-of-submarine-spying-2021-11\" target=\"_top\">USS Connecticut</a>, was commissioned a year later.</p><p>They are designed to be the ultimate stealthy hunter-killer submarines. Their <a href=\"https://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/31708/veteran-sonarman-explains-why-pump-jets-are-superior-to-props-on-modern-submarines\" target=\"_top\">pump-jet propulsion</a> helps keep the noise they make at 95 decibels, just above the level of general ocean background noise, while their high-strength HY-100 steel hulls enable them to dive about 2,000 feet.</p><p>Equipped with eight torpedo tubes &#8212; four more than Los Angeles-class subs &#8212; the Seawolfs can carry up to 50 torpedo-sized weapons, including Mk 48 torpedoes, Tomahawk cruise missiles, and Harpoon anti-ship missiles.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60f85a8d0729770012b91add?format=jpeg\" height=\"1468\" width=\"1958\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Navy submarine USS Jimmy Carter\"/><figcaption>USS Jimmy Carter in the Magnetic Silencing Facility at Naval Base Kitsap-Bangor, August 16, 2006.<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/Master Chief MCS Jerry McLain</p></figcaption></figure><p>The Seawolfs also have an advanced suite of electronics, including a 24-foot diameter spherical sonar array mounted in the bow, a wide-aperture flank array sonar mounted on the sides, and the recently added ability to carry a towed-array sonar.</p><p>The subs&#39; sails are reinforced, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-navy-submarines-carefully-smash-surface-through-arctic-ice-2020-6\" target=\"_top\">allowing them to punch through ice floes in the Arctic</a>, where Soviet and Russian attack and missile submarines have long operated.</p><p>The US Navy originally planned to build 29 Seawolf-class subs over 10 years. By the time Seawolf and Connecticut hit the water, however, the Soviet Union had collapsed. By the <a href=\"https://www.gao.gov/assets/nsiad-93-171.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">early 1990s</a>, the plan had been cut to 12 subs.</p><p>The Russian navy that emerged from the Cold War wasn&#39;t seen as a big enough threat to justify the astronomical $33 billion price of those 12 Seawolf-class subs, and the program was eventually reduced to just three boats.</p><h2>USS Jimmy Carter</h2><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5db6ec06dee01931032c5762?format=jpeg\" height=\"950\" width=\"1400\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Jimmy Carter navy submarine\"/><figcaption>First lady Rosalynn Carter, President Jimmy Carter, and Adm. Hyman Rickover, far right, aboard USS Los Angeles after its commissioning in 1977.<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy</p></figcaption></figure><p>Carter spent more time in the shipyard than Seawolf or Connecticut because the Navy decided to modify it for special intelligence-gathering missions.</p><p>The modification included adding special thrusters fore and aft that allow the sub to remain stationary underwater, as well as a 100-foot hull extension known as the Multi-Mission Platform, which increased its length to 435 feet and its fully submerged displacement to 12,158 tons.</p><p>The MMP is essentially an underwater hangar with a sort of <a href=\"http://www.hisutton.com/SSN-23.html\" target=\"_top\">hourglass passage running its length</a>. It allows Carter to carry remotely operated vehicles, cable spools, special-operations craft, and other advanced technologies needed to carry out classified operations and &#34;enhanced warfighting capabilities,&#34; the Navy says.</p><p>The space can also be used <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/navy-seals-explain-why-submarine-launched-commando-raids-are-tough-2021-9\" target=\"_top\">to deploy Navy SEALs and other special-operations forces</a>.</p><p>Carter is also the only active-duty submarine named after a president; a naming convention typically reserved for aircraft carriers.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5b217e6d1ae6621e008b4f79?format=jpeg\" height=\"930\" width=\"1400\" charset=\"\" alt=\"US Navy submarine USS Jimmy Carter mast conning tower crew\"/><figcaption>Sailors aboard USS Jimmy Carter as it transits the Hood Canal on its way to Naval Base Kitsap-Bangor, September 11, 2017.<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/Lt. Cmdr. Michael Smith</p></figcaption></figure><p>President Jimmy Carter himself served on submarines when he was in the Navy and was part of the Navy&#39;s nuclear-powered submarine program, working under <a href=\"https://www.atomicheritage.org/profile/hyman-g-rickover\" target=\"_top\">Adm. Hyman G. Rickover</a>, who is known as the &#34;Father of the Nuclear Navy.&#34;</p><p>What exactly USS Jimmy Carter does is a closely guarded secret, but it is believed to be able to tap undersea fiber-optic communications lines and conduct intelligence-gathering missions.</p><p>In 2017, the sub returned to its homeport flying the skull and crossbones &#8212; a <a href=\"https://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/14309/why-the-navys-top-spy-submarine-flew-a-pirate-flag-while-pulling-into-port\" target=\"_top\">tradition among submariners</a> usually associated with a successful mission. The sub has received Battle Efficiency awards and a Presidential Unit Citation, though nobody but the crew knows what they did to earn them.</p><p>Carter&#39;s official history <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/uss-connecticut-accident-hints-at-history-of-submarine-spying-2021-11\" target=\"_top\">says</a> it &#34;performed under a wide range of adverse and extremely stressful conditions without external support ... in pursuit of vital national security goals,&#34; during the operation for which it received its Presidential Unit Citation, which is cryptically named &#34;Mission 7.&#34;</p><p>Despite its role as an intelligence-gatherer, Carter remains one of the best attack subs in service, and its deployment, especially <a href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidaxe/2021/08/04/all-three-of-the-us-navys-most-powerful-submarines-were-underway-at-the-same-time-in-the-same-place/?sh=28dbcbc04546\" target=\"_top\">when done alongside its siblings</a>, is often an intimidating sign.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/navy-seawolf-class-sub-jimmy-carter-secret-missions-17-years-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a (Benjamin Brimelow)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/622961cf6ec7c20019cd6d7d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn12@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-24-828_7e187b92efe3074c.webp","https://i.insider.com/6184196a326b26001834d380?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn32@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-25-786_087c2a065d96e9a1.webp","https://i.insider.com/60f85a8d0729770012b91add?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn20@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-23-505_8f3839af975f106d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5db6ec06dee01931032c5762?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn38@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-27-225_fc1ee4bdc945d0cc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5b217e6d1ae6621e008b4f79?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn82@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-26-822_f397a3ef71fb2019.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Rwj7IJq-2b0:7-cv7dzeE3U:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn38@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-32-327_29b8302400c72a9a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Rwj7IJq-2b0:7-cv7dzeE3U:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn10@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-34-804_dec1cfab1ff59dbe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Rwj7IJq-2b0:7-cv7dzeE3U:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn99@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-28-246_389c05440ed9f145.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704378},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Lawmakers accuse Amazon of lying and stonewalling a Congressional antitrust investigation, asks DOJ to step in","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/lawmakers-accuse-amazon-lying-antitrust-investigation-request-doj-intervention-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/611bf432c040ad0018ceb65b?format=jpeg\" height=\"1332\" width=\"1776\" charset=\"\" alt=\"amazon box boxes delivery deliveries\"/><figcaption>Lawmakers accused Amazon of lying during an antitrust investigation.<p class=\"copyright\">Brendan McDermid TPX Images of the Day/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A congressional subcommittee responsible for investigating Amazon accused the tech giant of lying.</li>\n<li>The committee is investigating whether Amazon used third-party seller data to develop its products.</li>\n<li>It said Amazon stonewalled requests for evidence and provided &#34;ever-shifting explanations.&#34;</li>\n</ul><p>The Congressional Subcommittee on Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law sent a <a href=\"https://judiciary.house.gov/uploadedfiles/hjc_referral_--_amazon.pdf\">letter</a> to the Department of Justice on Wednesday requesting that it investigate &#34;potentially criminal conduct by Amazon.&#34;</p><p>The committee has been conducting a long-running antitrust investigation into whether Amazon <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-uses-seller-data-copy-products-alleges-house-antitrust-report-2020-10\">exploited third-party seller data to give itself an unfair competitive edge</a>. Referring Amazon to the DOJ, and particularly accusing it of lying and obstructing Congress, marks an escalation in tensions between lawmakers and the tech giant.</p><p>Amazon employees told <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wsj.com%2Farticles%2Famazon-scooped-up-data-from-its-own-sellers-to-launch-competing-products-11587650015\">The Wall Street Journal</a> in 2020 that the company used third-party data to develop its own first-party products. The committee said in its letter that it uncovered similar evidence from former Amazon employees.&#160;</p><p>The letter said although Amazon told the committee it never used third-party seller data, it didn&#39;t produce any evidence to contradict the committee and The Journal&#39;s findings.</p><p>&#34;Throughout the course of the Committee&#39;s investigation, Amazon attempted to cover up its lie by offering ever-shifting explanations of what it called its &#39;Seller Data Protection Policy,&#39;&#34; the letter said.</p><p>The letter also pointed to a 2021 report by <a href=\"https://themarkup.org/amazons-advantage/2021/10/14/amazon-puts-its-own-brands-first-above-better-rated-products\">The Markup, </a>which&#160;said Amazon gave its own-brand products preferential placement above third-party products on its marketplace.</p><p>&#34;After Amazon was caught in a lie and repeated misrepresentations, it stonewalled the Committee&#39;s efforts to uncover the truth,&#34; the letter said.</p><p>Finally, the letter said the committee wrote to Amazon CEO <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/andy-jassy-amazon-web-services-ceo-2021-1\">Andy Jassy</a> in October 2021 offering the chance to provide evidence exonerating itself.</p><p>According to the letter, Amazon brought in a law firm who said the company had conducted multiple internal investigations. None of them found evidence that employees regularly exploited third-party seller data or that the company gave its own products a boost on its marketplace, it said.</p><p>&#34;When the Committee asked for the business records that proved these claims, however, Amazon refused to provide them,&#34; the letter said.</p><p>In response to the letter, an Amazon spokesperson told Insider: &#34;There&#39;s no factual basis for this, as demonstrated in the huge volume of information we&#39;ve provided over several years of good-faith cooperation with this investigation.&#34;</p><p>The DOJ did not immediately respond when contacted by Insider outside of usual US working hours.</p><p>At a congressional antitrust hearing in 2020 then-Amazon CEO <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-ceo-jeff-bezos-richest-man-world-career-life-story-2017-7\">Jeff Bezos</a> said although Amazon has a policy against using &#34;seller-specific data&#34; to help its own-brand businesses, he <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-amazon-may-have-violated-own-seller-data-policies-2020-7\">could not guarantee that policy had not been violated</a>.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lawmakers-accuse-amazon-lying-antitrust-investigation-request-doj-intervention-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Hamilton)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/611bf432c040ad0018ceb65b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn10@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-33-310_d3ebea1fe6de1e22.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QLFuQ305zvc:qz4lSjBDSKw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn30@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-28-564_24f2eca031095ac9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QLFuQ305zvc:qz4lSjBDSKw:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QLFuQ305zvc:qz4lSjBDSKw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn62@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-41-477_e2a79cd1e5fc6a99.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704334},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"South Korea's incoming president once criticized the country's 52-hour workweek and said people should be allowed to work 120 hours a week","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/koreas-new-president-people-work-120-hours-a-week-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622971297eb82f00180e458c?format=jpeg\" height=\"2022\" width=\"2696\" charset=\"\" alt=\"South Korean next president Yoon Suk-yeol\"/><figcaption>Conservative Yoon Suk-yeol of the People Power Party won South Korea&#39;s presidential election on Wednesday.<p class=\"copyright\">Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Conservative <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/business-elections-voting-campaigns-seoul-f29dd8982b18c1f7318d579b9afc83f1\">Yoon Suk-yeol of the People Power Party</a> won South Korea&#39;s presidential election on Wednesday.</li>\n<li>He had previously criticized a 52-hour workweek policy and said workers should be able to work 120 hours.</li>\n<li>Yoon made a series of controversial comments on his campaign trail.</li>\n</ul><p>South Korea has been trying to put an end to chronic overwork &#8212; but the country&#39;s incoming president has in the past appeared to push for even longer work hours.</p><p>Conservative <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/business-elections-voting-campaigns-seoul-f29dd8982b18c1f7318d579b9afc83f1\">Yoon Suk-yeol of the People Power Party</a> won South Korea&#39;s presidential election on Wednesday. In July, Yoon criticized outgoing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/south-korea-has-dropped-its-inhumane-workweek-to-52-hours-a-week-2018-7\">President Moon Jae-in&#39;s policy</a> to promote better work-life balance. Moon&#39;s policy limits the hours people can work to 52 hours a week &#8212; that&#39;s 40 hours a week, plus another 12 hours of overtime.&#160;</p><p>Yoon said the system should allow for more flexibility, as some workers &#8212; such as game developers &#8212; may need to work longer hours during peak periods before going on an extended break.</p><p>&#34;Workers should be allowed to work 120 hours a week and then take a good rest,&#34; he said, according to the <a href=\"https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2021/11/356_313675.html\">Korea Times.</a> His suggestion of 120 hours a week is the equivalent of five 24-hour days.</p><p>The average South Korean worker worked 1,908 hours in 2020 (36.69 hours a week), according to data from the <a href=\"https://data.oecd.org/emp/hours-worked.htm\">Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD.)</a> That&#39;s one of highest hours-worked totals across the 38-country economic organization, behind only Costa Rica, Mexico, and Colombia. In the US, for comparison, the average worker put in 1,767 hours of work in 2020 (33.98 hours a week).</p><p>Although South Korea&#39;s working hours in 2020 looked punishing, they were down from 1,967 hours in 2019 and 2,106 hours in 2013, per <a href=\"https://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/employment/data/hours-worked/average-annual-hours-actually-worked_data-00303-en\">OECD data</a>.</p><p>South Korea is known for its hard-driving work culture. Workplace traditions such as long hours and weekend work are rife &#8212; even at <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/south-korea-startups-still-caught-in-abusive-gapjil-workplace-cultures-2021-7\">startups</a>. There have also been reports of <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/south-korean-parcel-deliveryman-dies-from-overwork\">delivery workers</a> who have died from overwork.</p><p>Insider was not immediately able to reach Yoon or his representative for comment.</p><h2>A series of controversial statements</h2><p>Yoon&#39;s comments on the length of the workweek didn&#39;t sit well with many.</p><p>&#34;If a person works 120 hours a week, he will die,&#34; said a <a href=\"http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20210721000824\">spokesperson</a> of Yoon&#39;s presidential rival, Lee Jae-myung from the Democratic Party, the <a href=\"http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20210721000824\">Korea Herald</a> reported in July.</p><p>Yoon later said his comments were misinterpreted.</p><p>&#34;What kind of a dictator would make people work 120 hours a week? That&#39;s nonsense,&#34; he said, per the Korea Herald. &#34;I heard that people on the political opposite side from me distorted what I said as if I said we should work 120 hours. It&#39;s not worth any attention.&#34;</p><p>Yoon has made other controversial comments on his campaign trail, including one in which he appeared to disparage Africa.</p><p>&#34;Companies depend on internationally competitive technology. There is no such thing as hands and feet labor like people used to do anymore. India doesn&#39;t even do that anymore. It&#39;s something only a place like Africa still does,&#34; said <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/yoon-seok-youl-faces-racism-controversy-with-comment-belittling-africa-10544723\">Yoon during a meeting</a> with university students in September, the <a href=\"https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2021/09/356_315689.html\">Korea Times</a> reported.</p><p>He has also suggested that feminism is responsible for the country&#39;s abysmal birth rate. South Korea has one of the lowest fertility rates in the world at 0.81 births per woman in 2021, according to the <a href=\"http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20220309000107\">Korea Herald,</a> citing official data. The <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2021/05/24/will-births-in-the-us-rebound-probably-not/\">US total fertility rate</a> was 1.64 in 2020, according to the <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/vsrr/vsrr012-508.pdf\">National Center for Health Statistics.</a></p><p>&#34;Some say feminism is too politically exploited [to the point] it prevents healthy relationships between men and women,&#34; Yoon said, according to the <a href=\"https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2021/08/02/skorea-South-Korean-Yoon-Seokyoul-feminism-comments/6541627927142/\">UPI.</a> &#34;From a social standpoint, the conditions are ill-suited for having and raising children. This is not a problem that can be solved by giving out government subsidies.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/koreas-new-president-people-work-120-hours-a-week-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Tan)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/622971297eb82f00180e458c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-245_1ca515ec5d6e1fbe.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5W6sPLJ0B10:y0eFb8lQS3g:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn21@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-34-997_70ebe7812e253d31.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5W6sPLJ0B10:y0eFb8lQS3g:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn74@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-25-137_dfcd13a558556af3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5W6sPLJ0B10:y0eFb8lQS3g:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn4@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-24-870_48e5edac85a5d737.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704401},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Russia's foreign minister said he does 'not want to believe' that fighting in Ukraine could escalate into nuclear war","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/lavrov-i-do-not-believe-there-will-nuclear-war-over-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229ec587eb82f00180e4ad2?format=jpeg\" height=\"2250\" width=\"4500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov looks on, next to Russian President Vladimir Putin, as they wait for the US-Russia summit at the Villa La Grange, in Geneva on June 16, 2021.\"/><figcaption>Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov next to Russian President Vladimir Putin in Geneva on June 16, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov he doesn&#39;t think there will be nuclear war over Ukraine.&#160;</li>\n<li>The remark on Thursday came amid high tensions over the West giving Ukraine military support.</li>\n<li>Putin has made allusions to nuclear attacks, and put his country&#39;s nuclear forces on high alert.</li>\n</ul><p>Russia&#39;s Foreign Minister, Sergei Lavrov, said that he does not think nuclear war is a likelihood in connection with the country&#39;s invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>In comments made to press on Thursday in Antalya, Turkey, he said: &#34;I do not want to believe in it and do not believe it,&#34; <a href=\"https://ria.ru/20220310/lavrov-1777465005.html\">as Russian state news agency RIA Novosti reported</a>.</p><p>Lavrov had just concluded a meeting with the Ukraine&#39;s foreign ministry, Dmytro Kuleba, in which <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/live-updates-russia-ukraine-crisis-2022-2?utm_source=copy-link&#38;utm_medium=referral&#38;utm_content=topbar#russia-and-ukraine-say-they-are-no-closer-to-arranging-a-cease-fire-after-top-level-talks\">the sides failed to make any progress towards ending their conflict</a>.</p><p>His comment came at a moment of high tension over the question of whether Russia could resort to nuclear weapons as part of its invasion of Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>He went on to blame countries supporting Ukraine for bringing up such a possibility, saying: &#34;This discourse was thrown exclusively by western representatives, primarily NATO members.&#34;</p><p>This is a stark revision of recent history. On February 24, Russian President <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-threatens-worst-ever-consequences-if-west-intervenes-in-ukraine-2022-2\">Vladimir Putin made comments seen as a thinly-veiled threa</a>t to western and NATO nations during a speech offering his rationale for the invasion.&#160;</p><p>They would face &#34;consequences greater than any you have faced in history,&#34; if they became embroiled in the war, he said, while alluding to Russia&#39;s enormous nuclear arsenal.&#160;</p><p>Putin also announced on March 27 that he put his nuclear armory on &#34;special alert&#34; in reaction to western sanctions on Russia.</p><p>The gesture was <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/putin-nuclear-alert-attempt-distract-ukraine-resistance-ben-wallace-2022-2\">interpreted by the UK&#39;s defense minister Ben Wallace</a> as an attempt to distract from the invasion of Ukraine, which many observers believe is proving far more difficult than Russia expected.</p><p>Nonetheless, moves of this kind appear to have informed the responses of NATO and Western supporters of Ukraine, who have proved wary to make any moves that could be read as an escalation.</p><p>One recent example was the US rejecting a plan from the Polish government to provide fighter jets to Ukraine. Although many countries have sent equipment to aid Ukraine&#39;s war effort, the jets were deemed to be a step too close to active involvement in the war.&#160;</p><p>Russia has one of the world&#39;s largest nuclear armories. An estimate by the Federation of American Scientists puts the number of strategic nuclear weapons held by Russia at around 4,500, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-60564123\">the BBC reported</a>.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lavrov-i-do-not-believe-there-will-nuclear-war-over-2022-3\">Business
