16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"10 things before the opening bell","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/10-things-before-the-opening-bell-march-10-2022-3","description":"<p><strong>Good morning, readers.</strong> Top economist Mohamed El-Erian doesn't recommend buying the dip right now, and President Biden gave an important update for the crypto sector. Oil has spiked again after falling on Wednesday.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Here we go.&nbsp;</p>\n<hr />\n<p><em>If this was forwarded to you, </em><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/subscription/newsletter/10-things-opening-bell\"><em>sign up here</em></a><em>. Download Insider's app </em><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/app\"><em>here.</em></a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-russia-ukraine-mohamed-elerian-war-investors-oil-2022-3\"></a></p>\n<figure>\n <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-russia-ukraine-mohamed-elerian-war-investors-oil-2022-3\"><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62290c4c9fa32d00184c9786?format=jpeg\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Mohamed El-Erian, Chief Economic Adviser of Allianz appears on a segment of &quot;Mornings With Maria&quot; with Maria Bartiromo on the FOX Business Network at FOX Studios on April 29, 2016 in New York City. (\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Mohamed El-Erian.\n   <p class=\"copyright\">Rob Kim/Getty Images</p>\n  </figcaption></a>\n</figure>\n<p><strong>1. </strong><strong>Don't buy the dip while there's a war going on in Ukraine. </strong>That's according to leading economist Mohamed El-Erian. After \"buy the dip\" became a mantra during the pandemic, investors now need to be <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-russia-ukraine-mohamed-elerian-war-investors-oil-2022-3\">cautious about rushing back in as the stock market</a> whipsaws. As long as Russia continues to escalate its attack on Ukraine, markets will remain highly unpredictable.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>&nbsp;</strong>\"Unless investors can identify the so-far elusive Putin offramp, their heavily exposed equity positions would be better served by rationalizing them during the bounces rather than buying the current dip outright and hoping for the immediate initiation of a long rally,\" El-Erian said.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>We talked yesterday</strong> <strong>about</strong> how <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-outlook-retail-buying-hedge-funds-sell-gains-ahead-2022-3\">retail traders have been consistently buying the dip</a> amid the Ukraine conflict and how Bank of America sees this as a good sign, but El-Erian's advice is to be cautious and sit tight while uncertainty reigns.&nbsp;</p>\n<p><strong>&nbsp;</strong>If investors are following the famed economist's advice, they'll reshuffle their&nbsp; portfolios during a war-time market bounceback, and be more selective with stock picking as successful investing is far less certain in the current landscape.</p>\n<hr />\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/big-shot-china-nickel-trading-derivatives-tycoon-tsingshan-short-squeeze-2022-3\"></a></p>\n<figure>\n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/big-shot-china-nickel-trading-derivatives-tycoon-tsingshan-short-squeeze-2022-3\"><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62290c737eb82f00180e3600?format=jpeg\" height=\"2880\" width=\"5760\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Lviv, Ukraine.\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Lviv, Ukraine.\n   <p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images</p>\n  </figcaption></a>\n</figure>\n<p><u><strong>In other news:</strong></u></p>\n<p><strong>2. US futures are in the red ahead of key inflation data later.&nbsp;</strong>Oil is up sharply after the UAE appeared to back-track on a pledge to raise output, although the rally is far less spectacular than it was earlier the week. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stocks-markets-futures-oil-gold-russia-ukraine-asia-nikkei-crypto-2022-3\">Here's the latest on the markets.</a></p>\n<p><strong>3. On the docket:</strong> IBI Group, Inscape Corp, and Jones Soda, <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/earnings-calendar\">all reporting</a>.</p>\n<p><strong>4. A Chinese tycoon known as \"Big Shot\" reportedly got squeezed in the global nickel market and faced billions in losses. </strong>Here's how the short squeeze happened after prices hit $100,000 a ton —<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/big-shot-china-nickel-trading-derivatives-tycoon-tsingshan-short-squeeze-2022-3\"> and seven things to know about the company.</a></p>\n<p><strong>5. The SEC and DOJ are investigating billionaire Barry Diller, among others, for possible insider trading with Activision. </strong>\"None of us had any knowledge from any person or any source or any anything about a potential acquisition of Activision by Microsoft,\" Diller said, per the WSJ. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/sec-doj-probe-barry-diller-activision-stock-insider-trading-wsj-2022-3\">Here's what to know.</a></p>\n<p><strong>6. The White House outlined Biden's executive order on cryptocurrencies. </strong>There are six key priorities for developing national policy for digital currencies, and Biden wants the Federal Reserve to keep exploring a Central Bank Digital Currency. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/biden-crypto-executive-order-digital-dollar-cbdc-bitcoin-congress-2022-3\">Here's a list of the president's priorities for crypto.&nbsp;</a></p>\n<p><strong>7. NFT sales have been on the decline. </strong>Sales in January topped $1 billion in a single week. However, over the past week, sales dropped to $168 million —<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/bored-ape-yacht-club-nft-sales-plunge-crypto-non-fungible-2022-3\"> these were the five top-selling collections.&nbsp;</a></p>\n<p><strong>8. A full-time metaverse architect explained how he operates his business. </strong>He said a baseline $5,000 build takes him two or three days to create. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/metaverse-blockchain-cryptos-nfts-virtual-digital-real-estate-architect-architecture-2022-3\">Then, he broke down his prediction that the metaverse will have homeowners associations.&nbsp;</a></p>\n<p><strong>9. Billionaire investor Jeff Gundlach warned oil will top $200 a barrel this year. </strong>The DoubleLine Capital CEO, nicknamed the \"Bond King,\" shared how investors should <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-strategy-stagflation-recession-risk-oil-price-commodities-jeff-gundlach-2022-3\">position their portfolios as the risk of recession has gone up \"substantially.\"</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jolts-january-job-openings-quits-labor-shortage-job-market-hiring-2022-3\"></a></p>\n<figure>\n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jolts-january-job-openings-quits-labor-shortage-job-market-hiring-2022-3\"><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228c4e39fa32d00184c8405?format=jpeg\" height=\"940\" width=\"1240\" charset=\"\" alt=\"JOLTS\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   <p class=\"copyright\">Madison Hoff/Insider</p>\n  </figcaption></a>\n</figure>\n<p><strong>10. Job openings hovered near record highs in January.</strong> According to data from the latest JOLTS report, the US had 11.3 million job openings in the first month of the year. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jolts-january-job-openings-quits-labor-shortage-job-market-hiring-2022-3\">That's down slightly from 11.4 million the month prior.</a></p>\n<hr />\n<p><em>Curated by Phil Rosen in New York. (Feedback or tips? 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"US stock futures dip as investors focus on diplomatic talks between Russia and Ukraine ahead of key inflation data","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stocks-markets-futures-oil-gold-russia-ukraine-asia-nikkei-crypto-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229ce467eb82f00180e47f6?format=jpeg\" height=\"695\" width=\"926\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Volodymyr Zelenskyy\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy seen on March 10, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Office of the President of Ukraine</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>US futures and European shares fell on Thursday ahead of key inflation data and with Russia/Ukraine talks in focus.&#160;</li>\n<li>Asian markets rallied overnight, with Japan&#39;s Nikkei leaping 3.9%, the most in almost 2 years.</li>\n<li>Oil rose 5%, paring some of the previous day&#39;s losses, as the chances of OPEC raising output appeared to wane.</li>\n</ul><p>US stock futures and European shares fell on Thursday, with investors nervous given ongoing diplomatic talks between Russia and Ukraine in Turkey and a reading of consumer inflation coming up.</p><p>Ukraine and Russia held face-to-face meetings between officials since the invasion in Turkey later on. Ukrainian foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba said that his expectations were limited ahead of talks with his Russian counterpart, Sergey Lavrov.&#160;</p><p>The meeting follows <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelenskyy-condemns-russia-direct-strike-at-mariupol-maternity-hospital-2022-3\">claims from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy</a> that Russian troops carried out a direct strike on a Mariupol maternity hospital, with officials calling it a &#34;war crime&#34;, according to the BBC.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/futures/s&#38;p-500-futures\">S&#38;P 500 futures</a> fell 0.6%, while those on the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/futures/nasdaq-100-futures\">NASDAQ 100</a> dropped 0.8% and those on the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/futures/dow-futures\">Dow Jones</a> fell 0.6%.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.msci.com/real-time-index-data-search\">MSCI world equity index</a> was up 0.20%, while the MSCI Asia Pacific returned 3.09%, thanks to a rally in Japanese stocks that boosted the Nikkei by almost 4%, its biggest jump in over 21 months.&#160;</p><p>European markets came under pressure, with the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/stoxx_europe_600\">Stoxx 600</a> dropping 1.2% and Frankfurt&#39;s <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/dax\">DAX</a> down 2.3%, ahead of a European Central Bank meeting to discuss inflation and growth in the eurozone.&#160;&#160;</p><p>While geopolitics would remain the primary focus, Caxton&#39;s head of market intelligence, Michael Brown, said other events could be market catalysts.</p><p>&#34;The ECB&#39;s latest policy decision is one, with policymakers in Frankfurt set to outline their plans to gradually withdraw from providing massive monetary stimulus, while grappling with a sharp upgrade to inflation forecasts, and downgrading growth expectations, as a result of sanctions imposed on Russia, and war in Ukraine,&#34; he wrote.</p><p>US consumer inflation data for February is also due. Economists expect to see a rise of 7.9% in the consumer price index (CPI), following January&#39;s 7.5% increase. Markets have pared back their expectations for a half-point rise next week in US interest rates, given the uncertainty stemming from Russia&#39;s war in Ukraine, but surging price pressures mean the Federal Reserve is about to embark on a series of sustained rate hikes.</p><p>&#34;We expect another hot CPI print this morning, which will likely continue to make Powell anxious. An upside surprise may encourage the market to price a higher probability of a 50bp hike at the March and/or May meeting. However, we would encourage fading such a move as the Fed is currently hiking on eggshells given geopolitical uncertainty,&#34; Bank of America analysts said in a note.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price\">Brent crude oil</a> was up over 4% at $115.60 a barrel, paring some of Wednesday&#39;s steep losses, after the United Arab Emirates <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/commodities/oil-price-today-uae-opec-should-boost-output-faster-production-2022-3\">appeared to climb down</a> from an earlier pledge to raise output. In the two weeks since Russia invaded Ukraine, the price of oil has risen by 18% to around its highest in 14 years.</p><p>Gold was down slightly, as it lost 0.04% to $1,987.50 on Thursday. The metal hit $2,000 an ounce earlier in the week, as investors rushed to buy perceived safe-haven assets.&#160;</p><p>Cryptocurrency markets dropped on Thursday after the EU said crypto would be included in sanctions against Russia. <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/btc-usd\">Bitcoin</a> and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/eth-usd\">ethereum</a> plunged 6.86% and 5.39% respectively. Altcoins like <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/sol-sol\">solana</a> and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/avax-usd\">avalanche</a> also suffered losses over the past day, down 7.21% and 6.87%.</p><p><strong>Read more:&#160;</strong><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6229ce467eb82f00180e47f6?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"ca2527ef74edf865521ee2ad5a192cd4","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn60@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-05-590_5171b11ebb099465.webp","destWidth":926,"destHeight":695,"sourceBytes":24752,"destBytes":24752,"author":"insider@insider.com (Adam Morgan McCarthy)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229ce467eb82f00180e47f6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn60@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-05-590_5171b11ebb099465.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vGHDK1Nnauk:RTAaDzX6z8g:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-27-341_c3c1143c61a024f3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vGHDK1Nnauk:RTAaDzX6z8g:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn20@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-35-254_23b8c34163a8b475.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=vGHDK1Nnauk:RTAaDzX6z8g:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn41@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-27-325_d5b96d3345960bc6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704366},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"The House passes $1.5 trillion government funding bill with emergency aid to Ukraine, sending it to the Senate after Pelosi showdown","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-house-passes-government-funding-bill-ukraine-aid-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6204875b3b86990018b2a9bd?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat from California..\"/><figcaption>House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.<p class=\"copyright\">Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The House approved a military and domestic spending package funding the government through September.</li>\n<li>The massive bill also contained nearly $14 billion in emergency aid for Ukraine.</li>\n<li>Republicans and Democrats each mostly got what they wanted after months of talks.</li>\n</ul><p>The House late Wednesday approved a $1.5 trillion spending package that increased funding for swaths of the federal government, helping the US stave off the threat of a shutdown and sending the bill to the Senate after a Democratic clash.</p><p>The two-part, mostly bipartisan vote topped off a tumultous day on Capitol Hill that saw House Speaker Nancy Pelosi deal with a rebellion from within her ranks over using past stimulus aid to cover additional pandemic spending.&#160;</p><p>Republicans and Democrats struck a long-awaited deal to increase both domestic and military spending in the package, made up of 12 separate bills. <a href=\"https://appropriations.house.gov/sites/democrats.appropriations.house.gov/files/Appropriations%20Division-by-Division%20Summary.pdf\">The legislation contained</a> $730 billion in non-defense funding to boost health, education, and science programs and $782 billion in defense spending. Both represented modest increases from the past fiscal year and the measure would keep the government&#39;s doors open through Sept. 30, the end of the current fiscal year.</p><p><a href=\"https://rules.house.gov/sites/democrats.rules.house.gov/files/BILLS-117HR2471SA-RCP-117-35.pdf\">The 2,741 page bill</a> amounted to one of the largest spending bills in history. It was released in the very early hours of Wednesday morning after months of protracted negotiations and last-minute haggling on a range of spending programs. Lawmakers also approved a four-day funding patch to give the Senate more time to process the bill.</p><p>But many rank-and-file Democrats <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/democrats-states-covid-19-relief-cash-government-funding-bill-2022-3\">squared off with Pelosi</a> after learning the bill clawed back stimulus cash from states to offset around half of $15 billion meant to be spent on new coronavirus aid, mainly vaccines and future pandemic preparedness. The revolt forced her to scrap the funding and push a standalone measure at a later date that&#39;s all but doomed in the Senate given GOP resistance to additional spending.</p><p>Pelosi acknowledged that Democrats ultimately didn&#39;t get everything they wanted, specifically on coronavirus aid. The Biden administration initially sought $22.5 billion in more funding, only to see their request get dropped in Pelosi&#39;s last-ditch efforts to salvage the rest of the package.</p><p>&#34;We have a lively negotiation. It has to be bipartisan,&#34; Pelosi said earlier Wednesday. &#34;We wanted it to be bipartisan. But in the Senate, you need 60 votes.&#34;</p><p>The legislation also <a href=\"https://appropriations.house.gov/sites/democrats.appropriations.house.gov/files/Ukraine%20Supplemental%20Summary.pdf\">set aside $13.6 billion</a> in emergency humanitarian and military aid for Ukraine, a top White House and Congressional priority. The amount gradually crept up with many lawmakers in both parties eager to provide financial and military help to Ukraine, especially as the Russian military campaign intensified in recent days.</p><p>Roughly $6.5 billion of that pot of money was set aside to help Ukraine prop up its defenses, and another $4 billion would go to the State Department so it could channel funds into migrant aid among other uses.</p><p>The bill contained an extra $12 billion for the Internal Revenue Service ahead of a tax season that experts say will further strain the agency. The money was devoted to help the IRS sort through a massive backlog of paper returns and modernize some of its systems. Democrats said it was the largest infusion of federal funding in two decades.</p><p>Republicans and Democrats seemed satisfied with the measures secured in the package. Throughout the process, Democrats pushed to step up domestic spending while Republicans pushed for similar increases in Pentagon spending.</p><p>Both sides broke the impasse by handing each other some political wins, allowing them to avoid another brief spending patch. &#34;During this time of great uncertainty and change, we are tackling some of our nation&#39;s biggest challenges, including making health care more affordable, confronting the climate crisis, and protecting our national security,&#34; Rep. Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut, chair of the House Appropriations Committee, said in a statement.</p><p>Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell <a href=\"https://www.mcconnell.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/pressreleases?ID=A197EEB0-6057-4DC2-9585-2C687830703A\">said in a statement</a> that Republicans locked in more defense spending than the Biden administration wanted, along with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-hyde-amendment-repeal-house-spending-plan-ukraine-2022-3\">securing the renewal of a ban</a> on federal funding for abortion.</p><p>&#34;This compromise is not the bill that Republicans would have written on our own,&#34; the Kentucky Republican said. &#34;But I am proud of the major concessions we have extracted from this all-Democrat government.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-house-passes-government-funding-bill-ukraine-aid-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a them","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-resign-alfa-bank-abh-eu-sanctions-ukraine-fridman-aven-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229d6a26ec7c20019cd70d6?format=jpeg\" height=\"3085\" width=\"4114\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian billionaires and businessmen: Mikhail Fridman (L) and Petr Aven (R) attend resigned from Alfa-Bank&#39;s board the day after the EU sanctioned them.</li>\n<li>Mikhail Fridman and Petr Aven also left the board of the ABH Holdings, per Bloomberg.</li>\n<li>The EU called Aven one of Putin&#39;s &#34;closest oligarchs&#34; and Fridman an &#34;enabler of Putin&#39;s inner circle.&#34;</li>\n</ul><p>Two Russian billionaires resigned from the boards of the Russian banking company Alfa-Bank, along with the holding company that owns it, days after they were sanctioned by the European Union.</p><p>Alfa-Bank&#39;s website <a href=\"https://alfabank.com/corporate-profile/governance/governance-bodies/\">lists</a> Mikhail Fridman and Petr Aven as having left the Moscow-based bank&#39;s board of directors in resignation applications dated March 1, one day after they were sanctioned. <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-09/sanctioned-russian-billionaires-resign-from-alfa-bank-owner?srnd=wealth&#38;sref=lAVQtUwz\">Bloomberg</a> reported that they also resigned as directors of ABH Holdings, the bank&#39;s Luxembourg-based owner, citing a registry filing from March 3.</p><p>Bloomberg reported that Fridman is ABH Holdings&#39; largest shareholder with a 33% stake, while Aven owns 12.4%.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-western-sanctions-declaration-of-war-economy-ukraine-invasion-expert-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\">The West has imposed heavy sanctions on Russia</a> in an attempt to pressure President Vladimir Putin to end the invasion of Ukraine. As well as Russian banks, the West has sanctioned <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/meet-10-russian-oligarchs-sanctioned-by-eu-putin-ukraine-invasion-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\">Russian elites and oligarchs</a>.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2022/02/28/russia-s-military-aggression-against-ukraine-council-imposes-sanctions-on-26-persons-and-one-entity/\">The EU</a> sanctioned Fridman and Aven on February 28 and has also imposed sanctions on <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/russian-banks-out-cold-eu-unveils-swift-sanctions-2022-03-02/\">Alfa-Bank</a>.</p><p>The EU said that Aven, who formerly served as Russia&#39;s minister of foreign economic relations, is one of Putin&#39;s &#34;closest oligarchs&#34; and that he regularly meets the Russian president in the Kremlin. It added that Fridman was known as a &#34;top Russian financier and enabler of Putin&#39;s inner circle.&#34;</p><p>Bloomberg reported that the day after Fridman and Aven resigned from ABH Holdings&#39; board, Mervyn Davies, the new chairman of LetterOne, and Andrea Maffezzoni, an executive at UniCredit SpA, also resigned. Andrei Kosogov, a shareholder in LetterOne shareholder, resigned as an ABH director in a filing Monday, Bloomberg reported.</p><p>Alfa-Bank said on its website that Sergey Masotskiy and Alexander Galitsky resigned from its board in an application dated March 1, the same day as Fridman and Aven&#39;s applications.</p><p>ABH Holdings is owned by Russian conglomerate <a href=\"http://www.alfagroup.org/business/financial-services/alfa-banking-group/\">Alfa Group</a>, which was founded by Fridman, who is a main shareholder alongside Aven, the EU says.</p><p>ABH Holdings has investments in banking groups and owns Alfa-Bank. ABH Holdings&#39; website <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20211222061111/https://www.abhh.lu/about-us/\">said</a> that alongside Russia it operates in the Netherlands, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Cyprus, and Belarus, and that its total assets were valued at $73 billion as of December 2020.</p><p>According to its website, Alfa-Bank has <a href=\"https://alfabank.com/corporate-profile/about-us/geographical-presence/\">491 retail offices</a> and <a href=\"https://alfabank.com/investor-relations/facts-figures/\">around 25,000 employees.</a> It <a href=\"https://alfabank.com/corporate-profile/about-us/about-us/\">describes itself</a> as&#160;Russia&#39;s &#34;largest privately owned bank.&#34; It has a subsidiary in the Netherlands, alongside financial subsidiaries in the UK and Cyprus.</p><p>Alfa-Bank and ABH Holdings didn&#39;t immediately respond to Insider&#39;s request for comment made outside of normal working hours.</p><p>Fridman and Aven were both board members at London-based investment firm LetterOne but it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-banker-mikhail-fridman-sanctioned-locked-out-investment-company-billionaire-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\">froze them out</a> after they were sanctioned. Another member of Alfa-Bank&#39;s board, Andrei Kosogov, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-billionaires-oligarchs-letterone-resign-step-down-board-lock-out-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\">resigned from LetterOne&#39;s board</a> on Monday.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-oligarchs-lawmakers-slam-ukraine-invasion-rare-rebuke-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\">Fridman has spoken out against Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine</a>, calling it a &#34;huge tragedy.&#34; He said that the EU&#39;s sanctions on him were <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russian-oligarchs-eu-sanctions-unfair-putin-ukraine-2022-3?r=US&#38;IR=T\">&#34;groundless and unfair.&#34;</a> Fridman and Aven both told Reuters that they would &#34;contest the spurious and unfounded basis for the imposition of these sanctions.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-resign-alfa-bank-abh-eu-sanctions-ukraine-fridman-aven-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Volodymyr Zelenskyy has survived 'more than a dozen' assassination attempts by Russian agents, says presidential aide","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/volodymyr-zelenskyy-survived-12-assassination-attempts-says-aide-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62224d9cdcce010019a6d90e?format=jpeg\" height=\"3657\" width=\"4877\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky\"/><figcaption>Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has survived a dozen attempts on his life, said a top Ukrainian official and presidential aide.<p class=\"copyright\">Sergei Supinsky / Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A top Ukrainian official says more than a dozen attempts have been made on Volodymyr Zelenskyy&#39;s life.</li>\n<li>Presidential adviser Mikhail Podolyak said counterintelligence groups have been tracking potential attacks by Russian agents.</li>\n<li>Podolyak said the hit squads are &#34;being liquidated&#34; and that Zelenskyy remains the &#34;main target&#34; for Russian forces.</li>\n</ul><p>A top Ukrainian official said on Wednesday that President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has survived more than a dozen assassination attempts since the Russian invasion began.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Our foreign partners are talking about two or three attempts. I believe that there were more than a dozen such attempts,&#34; presidential adviser Mikhail Podolyak told local news outlet <a href=\"https://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/news/2022/03/9/7329735/\">Ukrayinska Pravda</a>. On March 3, <a href=\"https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/zelensky-survives-three-assassination-attempts-in-days-xnstdfdfc\">The Times of London reported</a> that at least three attempts had been made on Zelenskyy&#39;s life since February 24.</p><p>In a video posted on the Ukrayinska Pravda website, Podolyak explained that the Ukrainian government receives a constant stream of operational information concerning Russian agents and sabotage groups attempting to enter government property.&#160;</p><center></center><p>&#34;We have a very powerful network of intelligence and counterintelligence. They track it all, and all these groups are being liquidated. We understand all the plans, and our counterintelligence works on them,&#34; Podolyak said in the video.</p><p>He added that the &#34;risks&#34; to Zelenskyy&#39;s life have not been eliminated and that no other information could be shared at the time for security reasons. Podolyak also noted that Zelenskyy <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/zelensky-says-that-enemy-sabotage-groups-have-entered-kyiv-2022-2\">remains the &#34;main target&#34; for Russian forces</a> because he is Ukraine&#39;s &#34;key manager.&#34;&#160;</p><p>On Monday, Zelenskyy <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/not-hiding-ukrainian-president-zelensky-video-office-russian-invasion-2022-3\">posted a defiant video from his presidential office in Ukraine. </a></p><p>&#34;I stay here. I stay in Kyiv. On Bankova Street,&#34; Zelenskyy he says in the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ChristopherJM/status/1500953180313640961?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1500953180313640961%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_c10&#38;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Fnot-hiding-ukrainian-president-zelensky-video-office-russian-invasion-2022-3\">video</a>. &#34;I&#39;m not hiding. And I&#39;m not afraid of anyone.&#34;</p><p>The Ukrainian president had earlier <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/we-wont-lay-down-our-arms-ukrainian-president-zelensky-kyiv-2022-2\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"58fbe9af91bb8158686c1bfec60daaac\">turned down offers from the US to be evacuated from Kyiv,</a> saying: &#34;I need ammunition, not a ride.&#34; However, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-succession-what-happens-if-zelensky-is-killed-or-captured-2022-3\">a succession plan for the country&#39;s government</a> &#8212; should Zelenskyy be killed or captured &#8212; remains unclear.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Cheryl Teh)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/62224d9cdcce010019a6d90e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn10@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-26-947_978f80ba5a1caced.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qSe3uf48JfA:4evn5N_CFjs:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn41@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-26-163_74a201cb10b823e6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qSe3uf48JfA:4evn5N_CFjs:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn51@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-23-806_a468a9276221bcd6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qSe3uf48JfA:4evn5N_CFjs:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn23@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-28-982_a161dbd467281961.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704366},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Trump said he's started DJing at Mar-a-Lago parties and loves to play 'Y.M.C.A.' and Broadway tunes","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-says-dj-mar-a-lago-broadway-tunes-ymca-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/621358a6462ff20019c5e3a2?format=jpeg\" height=\"864\" width=\"1728\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Former President Donald Trump dancing\"/><figcaption>Then-President Donald Trump dances at the end of a rally in Bern Township, Pennsylvania on October 31, 2020.<p class=\"copyright\">Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Former President Donald Trump has started DJing at parties at Mar-a-Lago.&#160;</li>\n<li>He said his favorite track to play to guests is 1979 disco anthem &#34;Y.M.C.A.&#34;&#160;</li>\n<li>Trump frequently plays the track at rallies, with a meme of him dancing to it going viral in 2020.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>Former President Donald Trump discussed his new sideline as a DJ for guests at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, and revealed his top choice for getting people onto the dance floor.&#160;</p><p>In an interview with YouTubers the NELK Boys for their &#34;Full Send Podcast,&#34; Trump discussed his enthusiasm for music.</p><p>&#34;I&#39;ve always had a high aptitude for music,&#34; he said. &#34;But I love great music.&#34;</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/WRbRoQcO9os\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p>When asked what music he likes to play for guests at his resort, he said &#34;I pick the ones I like.&#34; Trump said he is a big fan of Broadway tunes, namechecking &#34;Phantom of the Opera&#34; and &#34;Les Misérables.&#34;</p><p>His top choice, though, was The Village People&#39;s 1978 hit &#34;Y.M.C.A.&#34;&#160;</p><p>&#34;You know what gets &#39;em rocking? &#39;Y.M.C.A.,&#39;&#34; Trump said. &#34;&#39;Y.M.C.A.,&#39;&#34; the gay national anthem. Did you ever hear that? They call it the gay national anthem. But &#39;Y.M.C.A.&#39; gets people up, and it gets &#39;em moving.&#34;</p><p>&#34;People love it when I do it,&#34; Trump said.&#160;</p><p>The interview confirms <a href=\"https://twitter.com/maggieNYT/status/1489726916991012872?s=20&#38;t=aRqn3GNCp5INtl2lT-eORQ\">a tweet by New York Times reporter Maggie Haberman</a>, who posted and a note she said was sent to guests at Mar-a-Lago in February.</p><p>It said that &#34;great music will be played during dinner of Friday and Saturday evenings, with President Trump playing the role of disc jockey.&#34;</p><p>Trump&#39;s fondness for &#34;Y.M.C.A.&#34; should come as no surprise to those who follow his political rallies, where the disco anthem has got ample play time. A meme of Trump dancing to the track at various rallies went viral in 2020.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Aaron Rupar (@atrupar) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1346300289704316930\">January 5, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Some have remarked on the strangeness of Trump and the ultra-conservative MAGA movement embracing the track, widely interpreted to be about gay cruising in New York City (though one <a href=\"https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/village-people-ymca-gay-sex-facebook-victor-willis-macho-man-anthem-b571402.html\">band member has denied this</a>).</p><p>It was <a href=\"https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/entertainment/music/story/2020-03-25/village-peoples-ymca-added-to-library-of-congress\">admitted to the Library of Congress collection</a> of recordings deemed &#34;culturally, historically or aesthetically significant&#34; in 2020.&#160;</p><p>Trump is a disco veteran and <a href=\"https://www.spin.com/2018/01/studio-54-donald-trump-dance/\">attended legendary New York City nightclub Studio 54</a> as an upcoming business figure and media personality in the late &#39;70s.</p><p>The band themselves have not taken issue with Trump&#39;s use of the track, in <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/rolling-stones-threaten-trump-legal-action-songs-2020-6\">contrast with other artists who have threatened to take legal action over Trump&#39;s use of their work at rallies.&#160;</a></p><p>In a 2020 statement, the band said: &#34;Like millions of Village People fans worldwide, the President and his supporters have shown a genuine like for our music.</p><p>&#34;Our music is all-inclusive and certainly everyone is entitled to do the YMCA dance, regardless of their political affiliation.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-says-dj-mar-a-lago-broadway-tunes-ymca-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=lZemrKYxpiM:g-Kftj8f7dY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6229dbdc7eb82f00180e493b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"670d01dbcf871ffc92fb04829c336cea","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn91@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-23-481_4660313a63e9cd1f.webp","destWidth":1728,"destHeight":1296,"sourceBytes":53596,"destBytes":53596,"author":"tporter@businessinsider.com (Tom Porter)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/621358a6462ff20019c5e3a2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn7@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-30-754_1d443556bf501951.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=lZemrKYxpiM:g-Kftj8f7dY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn91@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-23-919_e90d190db4c6c101.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=lZemrKYxpiM:g-Kftj8f7dY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn91@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-34-608_7ec92bcc8a7a1a64.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=lZemrKYxpiM:g-Kftj8f7dY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn67@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-24-279_0ceeabb14c0cd1a3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704315},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"The House voted to ban the import of Russian oil even though Biden already banned it by executive order","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/house-vote-ban-russian-oil-biden-pelosi-ukraine-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6227a53d913301001822de35?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"House Speaker Nancy&#160;Pelosi&#160;at a press conference on March 3, 2022.\"/><figcaption>House Speaker Nancy&#160;Pelosi&#160;at a press conference on March 3, 2022.<p class=\"copyright\">Kevin Lamarque/Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The House voted to ban on Russian oil a day after the Biden administration enacted its own ban.</li>\n<li>The blowout vote came after the White House tried to squash the bill in order to let Biden claim a win.</li>\n<li>It remains unclear whether the Senate will also pass a Russian oil ban.</li>\n</ul><p>The House approved a sweeping ban on Russian oil and energy imports late Wednesday, a day after President Joe Biden <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-us-ban-russian-oil-natural-gas-coal-imports-report-2022-3\">enacted his own ban via executive order</a>.</p><p>Unlike other bills on the House floor, it was a blowout bipartisan vote. The House approved the measure in a 414-17 vote, reflecting the common desire on both sides of the aisle to punish the Kremlin in the wake of its invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>The <a href=\"https://docs.house.gov/billsthisweek/20220307/BILLS-117HR6968IH.pdf\">17-page House bill</a> would impose a ban on Russian oil and natural gas, a sanction that Biden rolled out on Tuesday. But it goes further in two ways.</p><p>The bill would kickstart a process to suspend Russia from the World Trade Organization and reauthorize the Magnitsky Act, which allows the US government to sanction entities that it deems to be human rights offenders.</p><p>It&#39;s the latest economic penalty that Congress wants to impose on Russia in an escalating campaign to devastate its economy and punish Russian President Vladimir Putin for the onslaught in Ukraine. The US and its European allies had already hammered the Kremlin with other sanctions, cutting off its access to international cash reserves and penalizing political and business elites with close ties to Putin.</p><p>Yet the White House had faced <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nancy-pelosi-calls-for-a-ban-on-russian-oil-imports-2022-3\">rising bipartisan pressure</a> to impose an energy embargo as Moscow intensified its brutal military campaign by targeting Ukrainian civilians. The Biden administration had been reluctant to further rattle global energy markets, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gas-price-outlook-forecast-biden-russia-crude-oil-ban-sanctions-2022-3\">likely leading to even higher gas prices</a>.</p><p>Republicans and Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee had been drafting legislation through the weekend to block the importation of Russian energy supplies. But the White House intervened on Monday to try and squash the bill and prevent them from appearing to corner the administration, two congressional aides told Insider.&#160;</p><p>&#34;They wanted to scoop us,&#34; one of the aides said, adding that the White House had been looped in for days. The aides were granted anonymity to reveal private details about internal discussions.</p><p>House Speaker Nancy Pelosi scheduled the vote despite the early White House objections. But <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-house-passes-government-funding-bill-ukraine-aid-2022-3\">it was ensnared in a separate battle</a> to fund the government, briefly stalling its progress.</p><p>Republicans went along with it. Rep. Kevin Brady of Texas, the top Republican tax-writer in the House, told reporters he was voting for it &#34;principally because Congress forced the president&#39;s hand&#34; on the oil and gas ban.</p><p>Former President Donald Trump has made no secret of his admiration of Russian President Vladimir Putin, calling him <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-vladimir-putin-ukraine-invasion-justification-genius-savvy-2022-2\">a &#34;genius&#34; and &#34;very savvy&#34;</a> recently. But Republican leaders like Kevin McCarthy <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kevin-mccarthy-theres-nothing-savvy-or-genius-about-putin-2022-3\">distanced themselves</a> from the remarks on Wednesday.&#160;</p><p>Where the House bill goes from here remains uncertain. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer held off from committing to voting on the measure at his weekly press conference on Tuesday, telling reporters that he would have to see the final text of the bill and would then work with the White House to &#34;find the best way to make sure that the oil import ban is tight and tough.&#34;</p><p>Senators from both parties said they believed the White House could go further than it already has to further isolate Russia from the global economy, such as by choking off its trade.</p><p>&#34;Russia&#39;s actions do not warrant them continuing to reap the fruits of the international trade system,&#34; Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon told reporters on Tuesday.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/house-vote-ban-russian-oil-biden-pelosi-ukraine-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Mar 2022 04:34:39 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6227a545913301001822de39?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"3e7adbd13f885dfc4a228d8eba33db47","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn47@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-23-141_e269d90202ac2475.webp","destWidth":1761,"destHeight":1317,"sourceBytes":168534,"destBytes":168534,"author":"jzeballos@businessinsider.com (Joseph Zeballos-Roig,Bryan Metzger)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6227a53d913301001822de35?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn2@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-35-916_3027dab5b0785f70.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn41@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-34-666_a8932216300de79f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-29-216_a240c82e9be68133.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=YaZTUghhz0Q:KKCfBa2_daw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn28@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-32-844_1aa60c1d25bf38a9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704351},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"I went to the 85-year-old restaurant that taught Taco Bell's creator how to make its iconic taco &mdash; and it shows just how much the chain has evolved in 5 decades","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/eating-at-mitla-cafe-restaurant-that-inspired-taco-bell-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228c96f9fa32d00184c85a6?format=jpeg\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A taco from Mitla Cafe, the San Bernardino, California restaurant that inspired Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption>The hard shell ground beef taco from Mitla Cafe that launched Taco Bell.<p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>In 1951, Taco Bell founder Glen Bell opened his first taco stand in California.</li>\n<li>Bell went on to create Taco Bell, which popularized hard-shelled ground beef tacos across the US.</li>\n<li>But Bell didn&#39;t create the hard-shelled taco: He was taught by the owners of a popular Mexican restaurant named Mitla Cafe.</li>\n</ul><p>You&#39;d never know it from looking, but an unassuming little restaurant in sleepy San Bernardino, California was the birthplace of an American fast food icon: The hard-shelled ground beef taco.</p><p>Taco Bell, of course, is directly associated with the most American of taco choices: lightly-spiced ground beef, shredded iceberg lettuce, chopped tomatoes, topped with neon-orange cheddar and served in a hard-shelled tortilla.&#160;</p><p>But it was Mitla Cafe, which opened decades before Taco Bell in 1937, that created and popularized it.&#160;</p><p>85 years later, and Mitla Cafe is still standing. Better yet: It&#39;s still churning out incredible hard-shelled tacos that I tried last week.</p><div id=\"slideshow\"><div class=\"slide\">From the outside, Mitla Cafe offers no indication of its historical relevance.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228f3297eb82f00180e2d7b?format=jpeg\" height=\"2496\" width=\"3327\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of Mitla Cafe, the 85-year-old restaurant that inspired the creation of Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption>Every day is beautiful in Southern California, even in early March.<p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>If it weren&#39;t for the steady stream of customers walking from a nearby parking lot, I wouldn&#39;t have known that Mitla Cafe was even open.</p><p>Despite the triple distinction of being located along historic Route 66, being open for 85 years, and being the foundation for the popularization of tacos nationwide, there&#39;s no signage on the outside of Mitla Cafe touting as much.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Upon entering Mitla Cafe, it&#39;s immediately clear that this is a local spot with deep roots.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228f47c7eb82f00180e2dbf?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of the inside bar area of Mitla Cafe, an 85-year-old restaurant that inspired the creation of Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>Growing up in the suburban northeastern US, Mitla Cafe immediately felt familiar &#8212; like so many Italian-American restaurants I frequented as a child.</p><p>Photos of family and friends hang on every wall as a testament to the four generations of the same family that continues to own and operate the decades-old restaurant.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">There&#39;s just one piece of paper detailing the restaurant&#39;s impact on American culture, and you have to look to find it.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228f8927eb82f00180e2ed3?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A cork board at Mitla Cafe in San Bernardino, California, an 85-year-old restaurant that inspired Taco Bell&#39;s creation.\"/><figcaption>A well-used cork board adorned with local happenings, as well as a brief history lesson.<p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>A single 8.5 x 11 piece of paper &#8212; pinned to the community cork board alongside a half dozen business cards and an advertisement for amateur Lucha Libre &#8212; is the only indication in Mitla Cafe that there is any connection to Glen Bell and the Taco Bell fast-food franchise.</p><p>Despite being in the restaurant explicitly because of its history, I didn&#39;t even notice the paper until a family relative who happened to be in the restaurant picking up food saw me snapping photos and asked if I knew of the connection to Taco Bell.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">So the story goes: In the early 1950s, Taco Bell founder Glen Bell began eating at Mitla Cafe. He liked the restaurant&#39;s hard-shelled ground beef tacos so much that he sought to re-create them.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228fd267eb82f00180e3043?format=jpeg\" height=\"4032\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of a piece of paper at Mitla Cafe in San Bernardino, California that explains the restaurant&#39;s connection to Taco Bell founder Glen Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>In Gustavo Arellano&#39;s foundational food history book &#34;<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Taco-USA-Mexican-Conquered-America/dp/1439148627/ref=sr_1_2?keywords=taco+usa&#38;qid=1646852422&#38;sr=8-2&#38;x=0&#38;y=0\">Taco USA: How Mexican Food Conquered America</a>,&#34; the author documents how Bell &#8212; who owned nearby Bell&#39;s Burgers, and later founded Taco Bell &#8212; learned how to make tacos.</p><p>&#34;He used to come over here all the time,&#34; Irma Montaño, a descendent of the original owners Lucia Rodriguez and Vicente Montaño, told Arellano. &#34;My father-in-law would say Mr. Bell kept asking about the tacos, how he made them, and so my father-in-law finally invited him into the kitchen to teach him.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Notably, none of this history is on Taco Bell&#39;s history website.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622901909fa32d00184c9446?format=jpeg\" height=\"761\" width=\"1689\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A screenshot of Taco Bell&#39;s history page, which doesn&#39;t mention Mitla Cafe or the family that showed Glen Bell how to make tacos.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Taco Bell/Yum! Brands</p></figcaption></figure><p>When asked about the history, the current owners of Mitla Cafe demur.&#160;</p><p>&#34;Everyone&#39;s been fairly philosophical,&#34; current co-owner Mike Montaño <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/history-and-tacos-served-at-the-mitla-cafe/\">told CBS last November</a>. &#34;I don&#39;t want people to feel like they weren&#39;t successful or that they were taken advantage of or anything like that.&#34;</p><p>Irma Montaño was similarly positive in Arellano&#39;s book. &#34;Good for him,&#34; she said. &#34;He was a self-starter, and he did push those tacos.&#34;&#160;</p><p>Taco Bell representatives didn&#39;t respond to a request for comment regarding <a href=\"https://www.tacobell.com/history\">the company&#39;s history page</a> excluding Mitla Cafe and the Montaño family.</p><p>&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Don&#39;t worry: On the day I stopped in last week &#8212; a random Wednesday afternoon &#8212; Mitla Cafe was downright thriving. There was even a wait, albeit brief, to get a table.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228ef5c7eb82f00180e2c76?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of the dining room at Mitla Cafe, the 85-year-old restaurant that inspired Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>Regardless of its history, Mitla Cafe wasn&#39;t packed full of tourists roadtripping along Route 66. Instead, both the dining room and the bar area were full of locals. I was certainly the only guy in the dining room furiously snapping photos of my food.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Mitla Cafe&#39;s menu is pulled from another time, and features Cottage Cheese Fruit Salad next to Guacamole &#34;Dip.&#34;<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622903c79fa32d00184c94b4?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of the menu at Mitla Cafe, the 85-year-old restaurant that inspired the creation of Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>There&#39;s a &#34;Mexican Combinations&#34; section and an &#34;American Flavor&#34; section on Mitla Cafe&#39;s menu &#8212; an anachronistic nod to a previous era, when Mexican food like tacos and enchiladas weren&#39;t considered as American as apple pie.&#160;</p><p>You can order an &#34;orange whip&#34; to drink &#8212; a drink that was <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orange_Whip\">last in style</a> decades deep into the previous century.</p><p>There&#39;s not even an obvious way to order the hard-shelled ground beef taco that Mitla is famous for having created. Among the 31 items listed under the &#34;A La Carte&#34; section is one simply labeled &#34;Taco.&#34; It is there that you can specify &#34;hard-shelled&#34; and &#34;ground beef.&#34;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">I ordered a taco, of course, and a beef enchilada. My partner ordered the number one, which included a tostada, a taco, and a cheese enchilada. As we waited, a freshly-fried basket of tortilla chips arrived with salsa.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622906e37eb82f00180e33cd?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Chips and salsa at Mitla Cafe in San Bernardino, Calfornia, the 85-year-old restaurant that inspired the creation of Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure></div><div class=\"slide\">Though visually similar, and made from the same ingredients, it&#39;s hard to overstate how different Mitla Cafe&#39;s hard-shelled taco is from Taco Bell.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622907749fa32d00184c9625?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of the original hard-shelled ground beef taco from Mitla Cafe that inspired Glen Bell to create Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure></div><div class=\"slide\">How different is Mitla Cafe&#39;s hard-shelled ground beef taco from Taco Bell&#39;s hard-shelled ground beef taco?&#160;Let us count the ways! For starters, Mitla Cafe fries each tortilla to order.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622909c29fa32d00184c9694?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"An image of a hard-shelled ground beef taco at Mitla Cafe, the restaurant that inspired Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>You can see the difference both in the tortilla&#39;s lighter color and in the irregularity of its edges. You can also instantly taste the difference, as Mitla&#39;s hard-shelled tortilla doesn&#39;t instantly crack into a trillion pieces after a single bite.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Inside the tortilla, Mitla Cafe uses a heavily-spiced ground beef patty rather than loose ground beef.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62290a769fa32d00184c96e9?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A photo of the hard-shelled ground beef taco at Mitla Cafe, which inspired the creation of Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>The biggest difference in flavor comes from the primary ingredient in Mitla Cafe&#39;s hard-shelled taco: The beef.</p><p>Rather than using loosely sauteed beef which can sog through the tortilla, Mitla creates a kind of burger patty. It&#39;s heavily-spiced, textured, and wildly delicious. The beef, beyond everything else, was the best part of Mitla&#39;s foundational taco.&#160;</p><p>It probably goes without saying, but this is a significantly better taco than the one it inspired at Taco Bell.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">The rest of the ingredients &#8212; shredded lettuce, chopped tomatoes, and grated cheddar cheese &#8212; were improved simply by not coming from a fast-food kitchen.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/62290be17eb82f00180e35c8?format=jpeg\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A hard-shelled ground beef taco at Mitla Cafe, the 85-year-old restaurant that inspired Glen Bell to create Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>More often than not, the lettuce and tomatoes used in fast food items is limp, cold, and flavorless. That&#39;s because it&#39;s often pre-cut and shipped in bags to the franchise for ease of use.</p><p>The experience at Mitla Cafe was what you would expect from a restaurant: the lettuce and tomato were crisp, and the cheddar was room temperature rather than cold. We&#39;re not talking about a revelatory experience here, but it&#39;s clear that the quality was higher solely based on its context. And it makes a difference in the final product when you&#39;re biting through crunchy lettuce rather than wilted greens.</p></div><div class=\"slide\">Beyond the taco, everything we got at Mitla Cafe was tremendous. It&#39;s easy to understand why it&#39;s been a community staple for over 80 years.<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622915c47eb82f00180e3994?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"An enchilada, a tostada, and a hard-shelled ground beef taco at Mitla Cafe, the restaurant that inspired Glen Bell to create Taco Bell.\"/><figcaption>The combination plate my partner got featured a cheese enchilada, a bean tostada, and a hard-shelled ground beef taco. It was glorious.<p class=\"copyright\">Ben Gilbert/Insider</p></figcaption></figure><p>From the fast, friendly service to the delicious food, it&#39;s easy to understand why Mitla Cafe has survived and thrived for nearly 100 years.</p><p>For me, having grown up in the suburbs outside New York City, the experience at Mitla Cafe evoked nostalgia-laced memories of chicken cacciatore and lasagna dinners at my favorite Italian-American restaurant from childhood, <a href=\"https://www.johnthebakerrestaurant.com/\">John the Baker</a>. The flavors are different, of course, but there&#39;s a universality to comforting home cooking that crosses cultures seamlessly.&#160;</p></div><div class=\"slide\">For more on the history of Mitla Cafe and the popularization of tacos across America, check out this CBS Sunday Morning segment:<iframe width=\"800\" height=\"450\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/yI4GLpoTDj0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p>And don&#39;t miss Gustavo Arellano&#39;s critically-important book on the history of tacos in the US, &#34;<a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Taco-USA-Mexican-Conquered-America/dp/1439148627/ref=sr_1_2?keywords=taco+usa&#38;qid=1646860552&#38;sr=8-2&#38;x=0&#38;y=0\">Taco USA: How Mexican Food Conquered America</a>.&#34;</p></div></div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/eating-at-mitla-cafe-restaurant-that-inspired-taco-bell-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 4/08-15-26-071_dfaf350c6d60924d.webp","https://i.insider.com/622915c47eb82f00180e3994?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn68@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-28-190_5b23ce14d0f8c366.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fcg4nlfcmdE:wnA71wmQtSI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn1@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-27-841_a26eed31e3e2c012.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fcg4nlfcmdE:wnA71wmQtSI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn83@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-23-905_7efb2842e49b98f4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=fcg4nlfcmdE:wnA71wmQtSI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn49@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-26-807_13db93e8c6484360.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704414},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"The Dow could be on the verge of a big shakeup following stock splits from Amazon and Alphabet","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-stock-split-dow-jones-industrial-average-index-shakeup-alphabet-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3a825ce89ebf001f04527b?format=jpeg\" height=\"1500\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"NYSE trader\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Spencer Platt/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul><li><strong>Stock splits from Amazon and Alphabet could mean a big change for the Dow Jones Industrial Average.</strong></li><li><strong>Both Amazon and Alphabet are moving forward with a 20-for-1 stock split, which will reduce their stock price from the thousands to about $140.</strong></li><li><strong>Companies with sky-high stock prices are not compatible with the Dow Jones due to its price-weighted methodology.</strong></li></ul><hr/><p>Upcoming <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-stock-split-20-for-one-buyback-shares-surge-2022-3\">20-for-1 stock splits</a> from tech giants <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/googl-stock\">Alphabet</a> and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/amzn-stock\">Amazon</a> could lead to a big shakeup in the 126-year old <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/dow_jones\">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a> later this year.</p><p>That&#39;s because the 30-member index popular with investors is price weighted, which means sky-high stock prices are usually a limiting factor to be included in the index.</p><p>Whereas the <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&#38;p_500\">S&#38;P 500</a> ranks its holdings based on the market value of its constituents, the Dow Jones ranks its holdings based on the absolute level of its constituents&#39; stock price.</p><p>That means <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/unh-stock\">UnitedHealth Group</a> has a higher weighting than Apple in the Dow Jones because its current stock price of about $485 is more than double <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/aapl-stock\">Apple&#39;s</a> current stock price of about $160. That&#39;s despite the fact that Apple is six times the size of UnitedHealth Group based on the traditional market capitalization measure.</p><p>There is little criteria for a company to be included in the Dow Jones, other than that the stock has to already be included in the S&#38;P 500, and is not a utility or transportation company.</p><p>According to guidelines from S&#38;P Dow Jones Indices, a stock &#34;typically is added to the index only if the company has an excellent reputation, demonstrates sustained growth and is of interest to a large number of investors.&#34; It&#39;s safe to say that Alphabet and Amazon both meet those criteria.</p><p>And a post-stock split inclusion in the index wouldn&#39;t be the first time a mega-cap tech company joined the Dow Jones index. Apple was added to the Dow Jones in 2015, about nine months after it enacted a 7-for-1 stock split that brought its stock price down to about $100 from about $700.</p><p>Once the stock splits are enacted, Alphabet and Amazon&#39;s stock price will fall from a current price of $2,668 and $2,885 to about $133 and $144, respectively. As to who the mega-tech giants will replace in the index, potential candidates include the two smallest constituents of the index, Walgreens and Intel.</p><p>Amazon replacing Walgreens would make sense given that both companies are categorized as consumer stocks, while Alphabet replacing Intel could happen given both have a strong tech focus.</p><p>Gene Munster of Loup Ventures believes it&#39;s inevitable that all of the mega-cap tech companies will be added to the Dow Jones index.</p><p>&#34;Eventually, all these big tech companies are going to find their way into the Dow because eventually they will all become essentially consumer staple companies,&#34; Munster told CNBC on Thursday.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Prices of TVs, vacuums, and cars soared by as much as 17% in Russia in the last week, as the Kremlin calls inflation a 'shocking external impact on our economy'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/prices-tvs-vaccums-cars-soar-in-russia-as-inflation-bites-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229f1bf6ec7c20019cd73a3?format=jpeg\" height=\"1328\" width=\"1770\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Russian shopper\"/><figcaption><p class=\"copyright\">Alexander Ryumin\\TASS via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The cost of consumer goods in Russia is soaring as the country&#39;s currency falls.</li>\n<li>The price of TVs, cars, and appliances spiked by as much as 17% in the past week.</li>\n<li>Companies are also pulling out of Russia, leading to shortage concerns.&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>The cost of consumer goods and food is soaring in Russia as Western sanctions severely weaken the value of the Russian ruble and disrupt supply chains.&#160;</p><p>The cost of TV sets, vacuum cleaners, and cars shot up by as much as 17% in the week after Russia invaded Ukraine, according to data from Russia&#39;s governmental statistics agency, <a href=\"https://rosstat.gov.ru/storage/mediabank/38_09-03-2022.htm\">the Federal State Statistics Service</a>. Meanwhile, prices of fruit and vegetables were also up as much as 7%. While prices largely rose across the board, these were the most substantial increases overall as inflation rates spiked.&#160;</p><p>In a <a href=\"https://ria.ru/20220310/ekonomika-1777437042.html\">statement to the press</a>, Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said: &#34;Yes, at the moment there is a pretty shocking external impact on our economy,&#34; which is leading to price increases.&#160;</p><p>Peskov said that while the situation is turbulent at the moment, the Russian government is looking at ways to stabilize it.&#160;</p><p>Russia&#39;s currency, the ruble, has fallen to record lows in recent weeks after Western countries imposed sanctions in a bid to isolate the country from the global economy following its invasion of Ukraine. The ruble has already <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/russian-ruble-us-europe-energy-export-ban-sanctions-ukraine-conflict-2022-3\">lost nearly 40% of its value against the US dollar</a> this year and a move by Russia&#39;s central bank <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/bonds/russia-ukraine-war-central-bank-ruble-dollar-gold-sanctions-economy-2022-2?utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"ee32880823929d074ee2c8a7b99c4c59\">to double interest rates to 20%</a> to avoid further collapse hasn&#39;t so far been effective.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Meanwhile, the country&#39;s elite continues to see their own pool of wealth deplete. According to <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-28/russian-billionaires-count-cost-of-83-billion-wealth-wipeout\">Bloomberg&#39;s Billionaires Index</a>, Russian oligarchs have lost as much as $83 billion collectively this year because of Western sanctions.&#160;</p><p>For the average person on the street in Russia, prices are continuing to soar and worries around shortages are likely to grow as more companies <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/list-all-the-companies-pulling-out-of-russia-ukraine-war-2022-3\">shutter</a> stores in Russia and retreat from this market.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/prices-tvs-vaccums-cars-soar-in-russia-as-inflation-bites-2022-3\">Business 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"How Rivian's fighting to lead the electric vehicle revolution amid investor scrutiny and executive turnover","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rivian-lead-electric-vehicle-ev-revolution-startups-investor-lawsuits-executive-turnover","description":"<figure>\n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622925376ec7c20019cd681e?format=jpeg\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\" alt=\"The Rivian R1T.\" />\n <figcaption>\n  The 2022 Rivian R1T.\n  <p class=\"copyright\">Rivian</p>\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>Rivian's shares have returned to earth after its blockbuster IPO.</li> \n <li>The startup is facing more scrutiny as a public company.</li> \n <li>Rivian is attempting to launch three new vehicles this year.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>In a crowded pack of electric-vehicle startups looking to emulate the success of Tesla, Rivian leaped to the head of the pack with a blockbuster IPO in late 2021. Now facing a number of challenges, from production ramp-up to shareholder lawsuits, investor enthusiasm has cooled and Rivian is looking to prove its mettle as a long-term player in the industry.</p>\n<p>After its first day of trading on the Nasdaq in November, Rivian closed at $100.73 a share, well above its $78 IPO price. That gave the startup a valuation around $86 billion, surpassing the likes of Ford and General Motors.</p>\n<p>Since this white-hot run, Rivian's shares have returned to Earth — trading some $35 lower than its IPO price in the fall — as the company meets some of its biggest challenges yet. Chief among these early obstacles for Rivian is the company's bid to launch production of two electric trucks and a delivery van this year.</p>\n<p>Below, you can read more about Rivian's leadership and the EV startup's early days as a public company.</p>\n<h2>Rocked by executive turnover</h2>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622925846ec7c20019cd6839?format=jpeg\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\" alt=\"RJ Scaringe\" />\n <figcaption>\n  <p class=\"copyright\">Mike Blake/Reuters</p>\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Rivian's C-suite has changed shape in the last few years as the company begins to look more like a techy startup than a traditional car company. The most recent high-profile departure came at the start of the year when Chief Operating Officer Rod Copes retired amid Rivian's initial production ramp-up.</p>\n<p><strong>Read more:</strong></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/turnover-at-rivian-could-complicate-production-launches-2022-2\">Turnover at the top for Rivian could complicate crucial production launches.</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-ace-an-interview-at-tesla-rivian-or-any-ev-startup-2022-1\">Rivian, Tesla, and other EV players are locked in a war for talent. Here's how to land a job by acing the interview, according to top recruiters.</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rivian-electric-vehicle-missed-2021-vehicle-production-target-ev-r1t-2022-1\">Rivian missed its 2021 vehicle production target by 15%</a></p>\n<h2>More shareholder scrutiny</h2>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229263a7eb82f00180e3fbf?format=jpeg\" height=\"2663\" width=\"3551\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Rivian IPO Nasdaq EV electric vehicles cars\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Rivian soared on its debut on the Nasdaq on Wednesday.\n  <p class=\"copyright\">Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images</p>\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>After raising prices on its vehicles last month, Rivian ruffled the feathers of both consumers and investors. A number of class-action shareholder lawsuits have popped up in recent weeks accusing the company of artificially inflating its share price and misleading investors about the price of their vehicles prior to Rivian's IPO.</p>\n<p><strong>Read more:</strong></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rivian-class-action-suit-accuses-rj-scaringe-misleading-investors-preipo-2022-3\">Rivian faces multiple shareholder suits claiming it misled investors pre-IPO</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rivian-price-increase-r1t-r1s-pre-order-customer-backlash-2022-3\">Rivian backtracks on $12,000+ price hikes after outrage from preorder holders</a></p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rivian-amazon-deal-could-backfire-ipo-startup-2021-11\">Rivian's clutch deal with Amazon could come back to bite the startup after its IPO</a></p>\n<p><em>Are you a current or former Rivian employee? src=\"https://i.insider.com/6177113ada7ba4001804d4bb?format=jpeg\" height=\"3996\" width=\"5328\" charset=\"\" alt=\"clerk at amazon prime warehouse\"/><figcaption>Amazon suspends services in Russia.<p class=\"copyright\">Mark Lennihan/AP</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Amazon has stopped shipping products to Russia and has suspended Prime streaming service in the country.</li>\n<li>It&#39;s one of many companies suspending business or exiting the Russian market amid the Ukraine war.</li>\n<li>Amazon doesn&#39;t have facilities in Russia and doesn&#39;t do business with the Russian government.</li>\n</ul><p>Amazon has stopped shipping products to Russia and has suspended the Prime streaming service in the country.</p><p>In <a href=\"https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/community/amazons-assistance-in-ukraine#March8\">March 8 blog post,</a> Amazon said the moves were due to &#34;the ongoing situation in Russia and Ukraine.&#34;&#160;The shipping suspension also applies to Belarus.</p><p>&#34;We&#39;ve suspended shipment of retail products to customers based in Russia and Belarus, and we will no longer be accepting new Russia and Belarus-based AWS customers and Amazon third-party sellers,&#34; the ecommerce giant said in its post.</p><p>Amazon is also no longer accept orders for New World, the only video game it was selling directly in Russia, the company added.</p><p>Russia wasn&#39;t a large market for Amazon. It doesn&#39;t have facilities in Russia and has a &#34;long-standing policy&#34; of not doing business with the Russian government, said the company.</p><p>Amazon joins a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/list-all-the-companies-pulling-out-of-russia-ukraine-war-2022-3\">long list of companies</a> suspending business operations in Russia as Western-led sanctions hit the country following its invasion of Ukraine.</p><p>On Tuesday, <a href=\"https://www.aboutamazon.com/news/community/amazons-assistance-in-ukraine?asc_campaign=commerce-pra&#38;asc_refurl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.businessinsider.com%2Flist-all-the-companies-pulling-out-of-russia-ukraine-war-2022-3&#38;asc_source=browser&#38;tag=thebusiinsi-20\">Amazon</a> said it was halting new customer sign-ups in Russia.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
