16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Investment giant Pimco risks losing up to $2.6 billion if Russia defaults on its debt: report","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/pimco-russia-26-billion-losses-default-debt-cds-bonds-ukraine-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229cd2c6ec7c20019cd7052?format=jpeg\" height=\"667\" width=\"889\" charset=\"\" alt=\"trader russia ruble screen\"/><figcaption>Russian ruble plunges<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Pimco sold $1.1 billion of credit default swaps that compensate holders if Russia fails to make payments on its debt.</li>\n<li>The asset manager also holds $1.5 billion of Russian government bonds, the FT reported Wednesday.</li>\n<li>It stands to lose on both fronts if sanctions-battered Russia defaults, which Fitch says is imminent.</li>\n</ul><p>Pimco is at risk of losing up to $2.6 billion if Russia fails to make its debt payments, after the asset manager bet big against a default, according to a <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/8d5bfe45-ebcb-4f75-8f4f-e0435ca87c1d\">Financial Times report</a>.</p><p>The investing giant holds $1.5 billion in Russian Federation-linked government bonds, the report said, and it had sold $1.1 billion in credit default swaps, or CDS, on Russian sovereign debt at the start of 2022.</p><p>That means Pimco is vulnerable to lose out on two fronts &#8212; the bond holdings and the CDS &#8212; if Russia does default on its sovereign debt, which <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/russia-default-credit-debt-sovereign-markets-oil-restrictions-sanctions-ukraine-2022-3\">Fitch Ratings has warned</a> is imminent.</p><p>At least five Pimco funds sold the CDS to investors wanting insurance against a potential Russian default, the FT reported, with the asset manager betting that Russia would meet its obligations. Pimco did not respond to an Insider request for comment.</p><p>Under the derivatives contracts, customers pay a premium to Pimco periodically and get compensation if Russia fails to pay.</p><p>Russia has been pummeled by Western sanctions that threaten its economy since it invaded Ukraine two weeks ago, and doubts have risen about its ability to pay its debts. Its currency, the ruble, has plunged to below 1 cent, and its financial markets have been thrown into disarray.</p><p>&#34;More generally, the further ratcheting up of sanctions, and proposals that could limit trade in energy, increase the probability of a policy response by Russia that includes at least selective non-payment of its sovereign debt obligations,&#34; Fitch said Wednesday, as it cut Russia&#39;s credit rating deeper into junk territory.</p><p>Agencies <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/bonds/russia-credit-rating-downgrade-junk-sandp-ukraine-war-moodys-fitch-2022-3?utm_medium=ingest&#38;utm_source=markets\">S&#38;P Global</a> and Moody&#39;s have similarly downgraded Russia&#39;s credit rating since its attack on Ukraine.</p><p>Russia&#39;s government said Sunday it would continue to service its debt, but warned that Western sanctions could restrict its ability to meet its obligations, <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-60672085\">the BBC reported</a>.</p><p>Pimco isn&#39;t the only major fund manager struggling with its Russian wagers. A BlackRock hedge fund suffered big losses for its clients last month after the fund increased its bet on Russian stocks just before the country invaded Ukraine, Bloomberg reported.</p><p>The BlackRock Emerging Frontiers Fund lost more than 10% in value in February due to the wager. The bet on Russian stocks accounted for about 9% of the fund&#39;s total gross assets.</p><p><em data-stringify-type=\"italic\"><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-markets-oil-commodities-crisis-ukraine-goldman-sachs-economist-2022-3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-markets-oil-commodities-crisis-ukraine-goldman-sachs-economist-2022-3\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">Goldman Sachs&#39; renowned chief economist lays out what Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine will mean for global oil prices, the stock market, an &#39;overheating US economy&#39; and Federal Reserve rate rises</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6229cd487eb82f00180e47e9?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"a4873fdc6cbe03bb0588ac3e8adcbcd9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn88@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-23-409_a7ff0bcb128075b8.webp","destWidth":888,"destHeight":666,"sourceBytes":36698,"destBytes":36698,"author":"hmalik@insider.com (Hamza Fareed Malik)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229cd2c6ec7c20019cd7052?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn30@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-27-546_70330b7c21c73270.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-Ig1WkjMHnU:9hlRPX4aBEc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn92@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-25-589_8ccd6bc2e3890ac2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-Ig1WkjMHnU:9hlRPX4aBEc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-23-808_00f41be40758a0cc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-Ig1WkjMHnU:9hlRPX4aBEc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn96@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-36-681_3a880b3cbd0917e7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704321},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"I'm a freelancer who works at a cocktail distillery and winery for extra income. It's a fast-paced but fun side gig.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/work-distillery-winery-extra-income-part-time-side-gig-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228bf6c7eb82f00180e1b6c?format=jpeg\" height=\"1126\" width=\"1501\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Zoe Baillargeon\"/><figcaption>Zoe Baillargeon joined the cocktail distillery for extra income but says she also really enjoys working on a team and learning new skills.<p class=\"copyright\">Zoe Baillargeon</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Zoe Baillargeon, 26, is a freelance writer and distillery worker based in Portland, Oregon.&#160;</li>\n<li>She started working part-time at a cocktail distillery last year to supplement her freelance income.</li>\n<li>Baillargeon says the work is fast-paced and laborious but made fun by a great team of coworkers.&#160;&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>When the pandemic stalled my career as a freelance travel and food and drinks writer, I knew I needed to find a part-time job to supplement my writing income.&#160;</p><p>I was eager for something hands-on after digital burnout from five years of working on my computer. My interest had also recently turned to the world of spirits and cocktails, so when a ready-to-drink cocktail distillery called <a href=\"https://straightawaycocktails.com/\">Straightaway</a> in Portland announced they were hiring in production, I applied.</p><p>After a phone call and interview confirming that I could lift heavy boxes and was willing to get my hands dirty, I got the job.</p><h2><strong>I started working part-time at the cocktail distillery in August 2020</strong></h2><p><strong></strong></p><figure><strong><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228be9e7eb82f00180e1acb?format=jpeg\" height=\"2310\" width=\"3072\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Zoe Baillargeon\"/><figcaption>Baillargeon inside a freshly cleaned processing tank.<p class=\"copyright\">Zoe Baillargeon</p></figcaption></strong></figure><p>I primarily worked on the bottling line, cycling between tasks like filling, labeling, shrink wrapping, and palletizing cases of product. The work was fast-paced but easy and made better by a fun crew of coworkers.</p><p>I loved being part of a team again: We played music, chatted, and finished the day with <a href=\"https://www.bonappetit.com/story/shift-drinks\">shifties</a>, the free drink that over-21 workers enjoy at the end of their shift in the beverage industry.&#160;</p><p>Seeing my interest and eagerness to learn, the cellar lead in charge of making the cocktails would also sometimes show me how to clean tanks or measure and batch the cocktails.&#160;</p><h2>After a while, though, I was ready for something more involved</h2><p>Since being introduced to the wine world while living in Chile a few years back, I&#39;d wondered what it&#39;d be like to work a wine harvest.</p><p>I applied to be a harvest intern for fall 2021 at Adelsheim Vineyard, a winery in the nearby Willamette Valley. My boss at Straightaway, who had a winemaking background, was kind enough to give me a leave of absence from the distillery, so in August, I traded spirits for wine.</p><h2><strong>There&#39;s an expression in brewing that brewers are just glorified janitors because of all the cleaning</strong></h2><p><strong></strong></p><figure><strong><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228b5b67eb82f00180e18b8?format=jpeg\" height=\"2268\" width=\"3023\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Kitted out for pressure washing inside the cocktail batch tanks.   Zoe Baillargeon\"/><figcaption>Baillargeon suited for pressure washing inside the cocktail batch tanks.<p class=\"copyright\">Hayley McSwain</p></figcaption></strong></figure><p>That applies to winemaking, too. The glamorous world of winemaking is hours of scrubbing drains, squeegeeing floors, climbing inside giant steel tanks to pressure-wash residue, and cleaning every speck of unwanted grape matter from the equipment.</p><p>Harvest season is one of the busiest times of the year, so working at the winery required near-total devotion from mid-August to the end of October. Workdays could last up to 12 hours and days off were sparse. I returned home tired, sore, smelly, and sticky, and woke up the next morning after not nearly enough sleep to do it all again.&#160;</p><h2><strong>The winery was hard, humbling, and laborious work, but I loved it</strong></h2><p><strong></strong></p><figure><strong><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228bcd17eb82f00180e1a21?format=jpeg\" height=\"2597\" width=\"3463\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Zoe Baillargeon Some of the winery crew. Credit Hayley McSwain.jpg\"/><figcaption>Some of Baillargeon&#39;s coworkers at the winery.<p class=\"copyright\">Hayley McSwain</p></figcaption></strong></figure><p>All the challenges and hardships, from the long hours to feeling like an idiot for not knowing how to handle equipment correctly, was worth it. Every day, I learned something new, like driving a forklift or mastering barrel rolling and stillage working,which involves moving, stacking, and filling wine barrels, in the wine caves.</p><p>The crew made the long shifts fun by singing along to &#34;Red Red Wine&#34; and other songs while working the pinot noir grape-crush line.</p><h2>One of my most memorable moments was powering through six punchdowns in a single morning</h2><p>Punchdowns are where you use a specialized tool to manipulate and punch through the hard, fermented floating cap of grape matter on a several-hundred-gallon tank, releasing color and tannins. It&#39;s a whole body workout. Sometimes, the grape caps are so hard it&#39;s like trying to punch through clay.&#160;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228bd999fa32d00184c81cd?format=jpeg\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Doing aerated pumpovers. Credit Hayley McSwain.jpg Zoe Baillargeon\"/><figcaption>Baillargeon doing aerated pumpovers at the winery by taking juice from the bottom of tank and spraying it over the top to filter back down.<p class=\"copyright\">Hayley McSwain</p></figcaption></figure><p>Every day, I felt more capable, confident, and strong. When harvest ended at the winery in October 2021, I returned to freelance writing and the cocktail distillery with renewed purpose and a zest for discovery that the pandemic had sapped from me.</p><h2><strong>Since first starting work at the distillery, I&#39;ve had to frequently remind myself that there&#39;s no shame in needing a second job</strong></h2><p><strong></strong></p><figure><strong><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6228bd3b7eb82f00180e1a4e?format=jpeg\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Organizing and doing stillage in the wine caves. Credit Hayley McSwain.jpg Zoe Baillargeon\"/><figcaption>Baillargeon organizing and doing stillage in the wine caves.<p class=\"copyright\">Hayley McSwain</p></figcaption></strong></figure><p>I wasn&#39;t a failure or bad at writing &#8212; I even had some of my biggest freelancing wins during the pandemic. I was doing what I needed to do to support myself, and gained new life experiences and became a more well-rounded person because of it.</p><p>With the pandemic&#39;s two-year anniversary on the horizon, my freelancing is finally back on track and better than ever. I still work part-time in the distillery tasting room, partly for financial security and partly because I enjoy the people and atmosphere so much.</p><h2>Working at the cocktail distillery and winery became about more than just a part-time job &#8212; the first-hand experience of working in production has also made me a better wine and drinks writer</h2><p>It&#39;s one thing to read about inoculating cold soaks to start fermentation and quite another to start your mornings with the smell of industrial Fermaid O yeast in your nose and covered with sticky grape juice from doing pumpovers and punchdowns.&#160;</p><p>Ultimately, my forays into winemaking and cocktails reminded me of the joys and rewards of trying new things just because, even if nothing comes of it. My mental health had taken a nosedive during the pandemic, but it rebounded as I stepped outside of my comfort zone again and enjoyed the challenges of a new job.&#160;</p><p>The beverage industry was a safe harbor for me to find my feet again, discover new interests, and learn some cool new things in the process. I hope to stay involved in the spirits world in the future, maybe even by working different harvests around the world.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/work-distillery-winery-extra-income-part-time-side-gig-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a reports","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/taiwan-studies-ukraine-resistance-for-asymmetric-war-plans-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229b0f27eb82f00180e46b5?format=jpeg\" height=\"2064\" width=\"2759\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Taiwan’s defense minister Chiu Kuo-cheng (right) said Thursday that its military is studying the war in Ukraine on how to conduct asymmetric warfare. Here, he stands next to Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen during a ceremony in southern Taiwan on November 18, 2021.\"/><figcaption>Taiwan’s defense minister Chiu Kuo-cheng (right) said Thursday that its military is studying the war in Ukraine on how to conduct asymmetric warfare. Here, he stands next to Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen during a ceremony in southern Taiwan on November 18, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Sam Yeh / AFP via Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Russia-Ukraine war has prompted observers to think if China plans to take Taiwan by force soon.</li>\n<li>Taiwan&#39;s military has been studying the war in Ukraine for &#34;asymmetric warfare&#34; plans.</li>\n<li>However, its defense minister said Taiwan has not seen any unusual deployments from China.</li>\n<li>&#160;</li>\n</ul><p>Taiwan is studying how Ukrainians are holding back Russian aggression in preparation for &#34;asymmetric warfare,&#34; the island&#39;s defense minister told lawmakers Thursday.</p><p>&#34;Taiwan&#39;s military is studying how Ukrainian forces are leveraging on its home battlefield advantage and experience in cognitive warfare, so that we can incorporate those learnings into our plans for asymmetric warfare,&#34; Chiu Kuo-cheng said in comments were captured in a <a href=\"https://tw.news.yahoo.com/%E5%9C%8B%E8%BB%8D%E5%B0%87%E5%8F%83%E8%80%83%E7%83%8F%E4%BB%A5%E5%B0%8F%E6%8A%97%E4%BF%84-%E5%90%B3%E9%87%97%E7%87%AE%E5%97%86%E4%B8%AD%E5%88%A5%E9%8C%AF%E4%BC%B0%E6%83%85%E5%8B%A2-044006938.html\">video</a> from local broadcaster FTV News. He was responding to queries following a discussion on a report to the parliament on the implications of the war in Ukraine.&#160;</p><p>Since Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine, there&#39;s been increased speculation about whether China will take the chance to attack Taiwan. China claims the self-governing island as part of its territory.</p><p>Both <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/china-says-taiwan-ukraine-issues-are-different-2022-03-07/\">China</a> and <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/china/taiwan-says-inappropriate-link-its-situation-ukraines-2022-02-28/\">Taiwan</a> have stressed that the Ukrainian invasion is not parallel to Taiwan, with representatives from both governments saying it was inappropriate to compare the two.&#160;</p><p>Still, Joseph Wu, Taiwan&#39;s foreign minister, called the Ukrainian resistance &#34;an inspiration to the Taiwanese people in facing threats and coercion from authoritarian power.&#34;</p><p>In the meantime, the US has been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-reiterates-taiwan-support-china-avoids-condemning-russia-ukraine-invasion-2022-3\">bolstering</a> support for Taiwan. President Joe Biden sent a delegation of former officials to meet Taiwan&#39;s democratically-elected president Tsai Ing-wen in Taipei last week, with retired Adm. Mike Mullen, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, saying the US &#34;will continue to oppose any unilateral changes to the status quo.&#34;</p><p>At Thursday&#39;s session, Chiu noted that Taiwan hadn&#39;t seen any &#34;unusual&#34; military deployment from mainland China, Radio Taiwan International (RTI) <a href=\"https://www.rti.org.tw/news/view/id/2126806\">reported</a>. He suggested that this could be because Beijing is focused on maintaining stability in mainland China as Xi Jingping pursues a third term in office.</p><p>At the same press conference, Chiu added that a war would be disastrous for all parties. &#34;No one wants to go to war,&#34; he said in a <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R8Kv3OOyKe8\">video</a> from Chung T&#39;ien TV, adding: &#34;But once we&#39;re at war, everyone will be miserable.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (Weilun Soon)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6229b0f27eb82f00180e46b5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn68@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-06-088_5094989f3c800ac5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-33-003_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-Z4jCRcpg9M:tdegpE6--xE:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn94@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-30-964_ba972dbb99a1a13c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-Z4jCRcpg9M:tdegpE6--xE:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn37@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-25-503_aaf856e080e60e75.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-28-705_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-Z4jCRcpg9M:tdegpE6--xE:gIN9vFwOqvQ":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245704342},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:15:04","title":"Inflation sped up in February to the fastest pace since January 1982","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/inflation-cpi-price-growth-gas-prices-february-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/622911cd9fa32d00184c9927?format=jpeg\" height=\"1250\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\" alt=\"Inflation US shopper dollar tree\"/><figcaption>A shopper walks by a sign displaying $1.25 price, posted on the shelves of a Dollar Tree store in Alhambra, California, December 10, 2021.<p class=\"copyright\">Frederic J. Brown/AFP/Getty Images</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Consumer Price Index rose 7.9% year-over-year in February, the government said Thursday.</li>\n<li>That matched the median economist estimate and marked the fastest inflation since January 1982.</li>\n<li>The measure also gained 0.8% through the month, accelerating from January&#39;s 0.6% leap.</li>\n</ul><p>It&#39;s not just gasoline. Prices for a wide range of goods leaped higher in February, further intensifying the inflation problem that&#39;s plagued the US for much of the past year.</p><p>The Consumer Price Index &#8212; a closely monitored measure of US inflation &#8212; gained 7.9% in the year through February, the <a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/news.release/cpi.nr0.htm\">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a> said Thursday morning. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg expected to see a year-over-year pace of 7.9%. The reading marks a healthy acceleration&#160;from January&#39;s 7.5% pace and the fastest one-year inflation since January 1982.</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"Consumer price index inflation\" aria-label=\"Interactive line chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-xAWH3\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/xAWH3/10/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"450\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(e){if(void 0!==e.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.querySelectorAll(\"iframe\");for(var a in e.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var r=0;r<t.length;r++){if(t[r].contentWindow===e.source)t[r].style.height=e.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][a]+\"px\"}}}))}();</script></div><p>&#160;</p><p>The latest data shows prices continuing to surge higher even as the Omicron wave ended and the country reopened again. Inflation was initially expected to cool late last year as supply chains healed, yet lingering pain in the global logistics industry and new pressures on commodity prices have kept the problem around.</p><p>Russia&#39;s invasion of Ukraine has been the biggest factor boosting inflation in the past few weeks. Initial fears of an attack hit crude oil and natural gas prices, as Russia&#39;s energy sector <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gas-price-outlook-forecast-biden-russia-crude-oil-ban-sanctions-2022-3\">plays a major role in feeding the global supply</a>. The conflict has since lifted prices for a range of other commodities <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/russia-ukraine-inflation-lifting-prices-american-shoppers-gas-wheat-nickel-2022-3\">including wheat, nickel, and fertilizer</a>. Though February only includes the first few days of Russia&#39;s invasion, the new release still captures some of the initial market activity as investors began to price in the attack.</p><p>The CPI measure also rose 0.8% through the month, according to the report, similarly&#160;matching the average economist forecast. That marked a pickup from the 0.6% gain seen in January, signaling inflation is still running red hot month-by-month.</p><p>Core CPI, which strips out volatile food and energy prices, rose 0.5% in February, slowing from the 0.6% pace seen a month earlier. That, too, matched economist estimates.</p><p>Soaring prices for gas, rent, and food were the biggest drivers of February&#39;s stronger inflation. The government&#39;s gas-price measure leaped 6.6% through the month, sharply accelerating from the 0.8% decline seen the month prior. Food prices edged 1% higher, and shelter costs notched a 0.5% gain. Demand for those goods and services tends to stay elevated even when the Federal Reserve lifts interest rates. Their large upticks through February hint that, even if price growth cools across other categories, broad inflation is set to remain elevated in the coming months.</p><p>Other goods and services saw encouraging slowdowns in inflation or outright price declines over the month. Electricity prices fell 1.1% after January&#39;s 4.2% gain. Used cars and trucks, which previously fueled much of the US&#39;s pandemic inflation, saw prices drop by 0.2% following the prior month&#39;s 1.5% increase. Apparel inflation also eased to 0.7% growth from 1.1%.</p><p>There could soon be more cooling where that came from. The Federal Reserve is poised to raise interest rates at its March 16 policy meeting, kicking off a cycle of monetary tightening aimed at reining in inflation. Higher rates tend to cool spending and, in turn, leave businesses better equipped to match supply with demand. The February report is all but guaranteed to be the last of the near-zero-rate era.</p><p>There&#39;s a long way to go before inflation returns to its pre-pandemic trend, and fears of persistently strong price growth remain. But as the Fed embarks on its hiking cycle, CPI will offer the first hints at just how quickly inflation will cool.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inflation-cpi-price-growth-gas-prices-february-2022-3\">Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=46y8EkyZ8AA:GXXI5OhjrPc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=46y8EkyZ8AA:GXXI5OhjrPc:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Mar 2022 13:35:01 Kyiv","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/video-ukraine-artillery-blows-up-tanks-kyiv-russia-invasion-2022-3","description":"<figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229d5017eb82f00180e4859?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A screenshot from a video released by the Ukrainian defense ministry, showing a road outside Borodyanka with a burst of smoke where Russian vehicles were reportedly targeted\"/><figcaption>A screenshot from the video released by the Ukraine Ministry of Defense, which says it shows precision strikes on Russian military vehicles outside Borodyanka, on Tuesday.<p class=\"copyright\">Ukraine Ministry of Defense</p></figcaption></figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Ukraine&#39;s Ministry of Defense released a video of artillery strikes on vehicles outside of Kyiv.&#160;</li>\n<li>The aerial footage, dated March 8, shows at least eight strikes outside the town of Borodyanka.&#160;</li>\n<li>Borodyanka is about 45 miles from the center of Kyiv, and has been the scene of fierce fighting.</li>\n</ul><p>A video released Thursday by the Ukrainian military showed artillery strikes on what officials said was a line of Russian military vehicles not far from Kyiv.&#160;</p><p>The aerial footage appears to have been recorded at a distance by a drone. It shows at least eight strikes on vehicles on a rural road identified by the Ukrainian defense ministry as being outside the town of Borodyanka.&#160;</p><p>The video, dated to Tuesday, was posted on <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=334041352009343\">Facebook</a> and Twitter on Thursday to channels run by the Ukrainian armed forces.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Defence of Ukraine (@DefenceU) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1501810489038446593\">March 10, 2022</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>The footage pauses at the moment of a burst of fire on the central vehicle in a line of three &#8212; either tanks or other self-propelled artillery. Then the other two appear to be picked off. Further strikes follow.&#160;</p><p>Insider used geolocation to identify the likely location of the strikes. Satellite imagery showed a distinctive road formation and gas station that matched the aerial footage.</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229d6bc6ec7c20019cd70de?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A satellite view of Kyiv and the surrounding towns with an arrow marking the strike location near Borodyanka.\"/><figcaption>A satellite view of Kyiv and the surrounding towns with an arrow marking the reported strike location near Borodyanka.<p class=\"copyright\">Insider/Google Maps</p></figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229d7137eb82f00180e489e?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A side-by-side of the Borodyanka strike location as it appears in the Ukrainian Defense Ministry video (left) and Google Maps (right)\"/><figcaption>A side-by-side of the Borodyanka strike location as it appears in the Ukrainian Defense Ministry video, left, and its likely location on Google Maps, right.<p class=\"copyright\">Insider/Ukraine Defense Ministry/Google Maps</p></figcaption></figure><p>Lt. Gen. Valerii Zaluzhnyi, commander in chief of Ukraine&#39;s army, described the operation as &#34;delicate,&#34; according to the defense ministry.</p><p>It is a distinction Ukrainian forces might be keen to emphasize in the face of shelling from Russian forces that has hit residential buildings, schools, and hospitals.</p><p>That includes Borodyanka, which is about 45 miles from the center of Kyiv and has been a scene of some of the fiercest fighting around the capital.</p><p>The town of about 13,000 was bombarded in the Russian advance. On March 3, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ukraine-video-shows-aftermath-russian-attack-town-north-of-kyiv-2022-3\">drone footage emerged of the town&#39;s devastation</a>, showing the still-smoking remains of apartment buildings.</p><p>Local media reported that one of the places hit was a veterans&#39; rehabilitation center, <a href=\"https://kyivindependent.com/uncategorized/russian-forces-shell-rehabilitation-center-of-the-ministry-of-veterans-affairs-of-ukraine/\">according to the Kyiv Independent</a>.&#160;</p><figure><img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6229d5077eb82f00180e485d?format=jpeg\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\" alt=\"A screenshot from a video released by the Ukrainian defense ministry, showing a road outside Borodyanka with a burst of fire where Russian vehicles were reportedly targeted\"/><figcaption>A screenshot from the video released by the Ukraine Ministry of Defense.<p class=\"copyright\">Ukraine Ministry of Defense</p></figcaption></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.defense.gov/News/News-Stories/Article/Article/2959856/russian-invaders-crash-into-ukrainian-resistance/\">A Pentagon assessment</a> of Russian advances on Kyiv from Tuesday said that a major column of Russian forces in the region remained.</p><p>&#34;Near Kyiv, we still observe that Russian forces have not moved closer to the city center,&#34; a Defense Department official said. &#34;The closest they&#39;ve been able to get is the airport.&#34;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.defense.gov/News/Transcripts/Transcript/Article/2961733/senior-defense-official-holds-a-background-briefing-march-9-2022/\">In briefings on Tuesday and Wednesday</a>, a Pentagon official said that about 90 to 95% of Russian combat power remains intact, despite fierce resistance from Ukraine and widespread video and photo evidence of destroyed Russian forces.</p><div
